The grant provides funding for the maintenance of the Carlyle Letters office at the Duke University Press and the conversion of existing volumes to an electronic format, The Carlyle Letters Online. We are also grateful to the Arts and Humanities Research Council for its award of funding for three years from October 2006 to September 2009 to support the Edinburgh editorial team and office. Volume 38 of The Collected Letters of Thomas and Jane Welsh Carlyle covers November 1861 to November 1862. Thomas Carlyle’s main preoccupation in these months may have been his continuing work on Frederick the Great, but his and Jane Welsh Carlyle’s letters (whether to each other or to other people) continued to range widely in their discussion of each other, their families, and the illnesses and deaths of several of their friends. Not much attention was paid to current political affairs in London; dramatic events, such as the collapse of a tenement building in Edinburgh’s High Street, were given almost as much attention as Garibaldi’s invasion of Italy or the Civil War in the United States. As always, if either was away from home, there was an assumption, on both their parts, that frequent letters must be sent to each other, as JWC indicated after leaving the Russell home at Thornhill for Edinburgh: “I am not up to a letter today at least to any other letter than the daily one to Mr C, which must be written, dead or alive“ (JWC to MR, [2 Sept.]). However much JWC might have used this demand as justifying a shorter letter or as a way of constructing herself as a martyr to TC’s expectations, it is also clear that these daily letters were expected and, mostly, were written. This can be seen in the number of pages that are filled in any volume of the Carlyle Letters when they are apart, as opposed to those times when they were at home together in Cheyne Row. In this volume, there are twenty-five letters from TC to JWC and twenty-five from JWC to TC; of the letters they wrote to others, eighty-one are from TC and seventy-three from JWC. JWC’s total of letters remains fewer than TC’s, though not by much in this volume. But, increasingly, her letters (written to a few chosen correspondents) tended to length, giving a finely orchestrated picture of her life in London and elsewhere. TC’s letters are often short and businesslike, with only some letters to his family or Lord Ashburton reaching any kind of discursiveness. The reason for this is that TC’s business was the writing of Frederick, with that business the constant excuse for inactivity in any other area of his life. JWC’s business was the writing of letters, as well as the running of the household. The length of JWC’s letters, even though there are fewer of them, means that this volume contains more writing by JWC than by TC.

JWC is known for the carefully crafted portrait of herself to be found in her letters. But it is also apparent from TC’s letters that he too presented constructions of “Thomas Carlyle.“ In this volume he characterizes himself as a suffering martyr in relation to his interminable work on “this unutterable
quagmire“ (TC to CGD, 10 Nov. 1861) or “melancholy slavery“ (TC to JN, 18 June) that was Frederick. The imagery used to describe the process was industrial, vividly describing the process of reducing a mass of research into a concise few pages, but also legitimizing his writing by comparing it to a physical process like any to which a farm or factory worker might be subjected: “Horrors of drossy incoherency … like a mass of mere slag, the size of a waggon; which you have to hammer down (if you can) into metal, the size of a pint“ (TC to JAC, 23 Nov. 1861). The work did, indeed, demand much time and energy, and TC was under some pressure to keep working. Volumes 1 and 2 had been published in 1858. Volume 3 was more or less complete by November 1861, and Chapman clearly wanted another volume to come out rather than wait for TC to complete the fourth volume; by March 1862 TC had agreed to let volume 3 appear. TC was already noting to his brother John A. Carlyle that volume 4 would become volumes 4 and 5 (see TC to JAC, 30 March). Volume 3 appeared early May 1862 to a generally favorable response (see TC to JAC, 3 May; for a more critical response, see JWC to TC, [2 July]). TC continued to complain about his progress with the two next projected volumes. He wrote his drafts, gave them to Robson (Chapman & Hall’s printer, who worked on TC’s writing for many years), and then reworked and added new material when the proof sheets were returned to him. He commented to his brother John: “I got last night a great heap of Vol V Proofsheets. … First half of that Vol. is going to be horridly tough (Seven-Yrs War conclusion); latter half will be I know not what! A tough climb surely; but, once over that hill, there is no other!” (TC to JAC, 3 Oct.). During October, he persisted in this view that volume 5 would be the last volume: “And no other Vol. coming; none, that is it!” (TC to JAC, 23 Oct.). But volume 5 was not to be published until 1864, and there was to be a sixth and final volume published triumphantly in 1865. TC’s complaints about his work on Frederick give some sense of his laborious process. Joseph Neuberg who had done so much to help with research earlier was prevented by ill health from contributing much at this stage, and TC felt overwhelmed by the process:
div1.q:
A good big lump is in type (probably a full 4th of the whole Volume); but that is only half the battle; you never saw such a jumble of horrors as the first proofs are: in my bewildering index-less state, and with such Books and blockheadism,—I cannot, single-handed, deal with the thing, except stage after stage in that tentative way. Often enough, I am doing the very last revise, when (after much screwing and torturing) the really vital point of the matter, rule of all the articulation it must have;—will disclose itself to me; overlooked by the fifty Dryasdusts I have been compulsing!— I have only yet got one sheet of Vol V fairly sent away; 2 or 3 more wd have gone in a week: but I wanted to have one, at the least & lowest, before
Iflying off. Vol IV haggled endlessly in Robson’s hands: but it is done, off forevermore;—Time & the hours wear everything to finis, if you persist! (TC to JAC, 11 Oct.)
div1.p: This picture of TC, struggling with “the very last revise“ and only then finding the “really vital point … overlooked by the fifty Dryasdusts“ from whom he had been drawing his material, expresses difficulties familiar to any historian. But TC also commented in passing on the difficulty he had with the preceding volume and, specifically, with the Seven Years’ War: “Volme Fourth is like to be as dour as any of the others: no end of haggling, fash and impediment; so difficult exceedingly (and never yet tried at all) to make the Seven-Years War march abreast (the many-columned marching Entity), and shew itself for what it was, in any measure!” (TC to JAC, 6 Aug.). The time for questioning why he should write a history of Frederick the Great was long past, but these letters, particularly to John, the brother closest to him intellectually, provide a running commentary on both process and content.

TC was too preoccupied with his own concerns to comment much on the American Civil War, although there are a few passing references. When visiting The Grange, January 1862, he wrote: “Nothing considerable talked of here, but the Yankee War,quite in the indifft tone henceforth, Duke & Duchess [of Argyll], who were enthusiasts for ‘Freedom to the Slave,’ having made exit. No war ever waging in my time was to me more profoundly foolish-looking: neutral I am to a degree, I for one!” (TC to JAC, 30 Jan.). Despite his claim of neutrality, by August he was writing that the “American affairs are getting quite hideous;—but will (after agonies enough) probably deliver the poor Country from a ‘Govt by Blackguards,’ at the long last!” (TC to Lord ALOA, 31 Aug.); this seems to indicate criticism of the government of the North, if not actual support of the Southern states. In February, Charles Butler wrote optimistically about the outcome of the Civil War (from the point of view of a Northerner) to Samuel Adamson, TC’s banker in Dumfries: “Please place the enclosed to credit of Mr. Carlyle to whom I shall shortly write. / I am happy to assure you that the terrible conflict that has been preceding [sic] in this country between the Government and the slave holders of the south is rapidly drawing to a close. The rebellion will be effectually crushed and the government and union will be maintained and preserved intact. No intelligent man who understands the real state of the case can for a moment doubt the result“ (Kimball 293); it is not known whether Butler wrote to TC expressing this view, but TC could certainly have heard similar opinions from the supporters of the North at the Ashburtons. In October, TC reported the views of Vincenzo Botta, “a very honest Turin Italian“ (a naturalized U.S. citizen and professor of literature and languages at the University of the City of New York): “[He] gave us plenty of news abt America: Nothing
but ‘prosperity’ visible in N. York, trade so brisk &c;—going to whip Creation after all, especially to swallow the South out of hand (big fleet ready for bombarding Charlestown &c &c): war, if the South prove positive, ‘may last for thirty years,’ thinks Ba! Did you ever hear of a prettier quarrel abt nothing at all?“ (TC to JAC, 23 Oct.). Botta’s report, suggesting optimistic feelings about the outcome in New York, balanced by the possibility that the South could still separate (which would have lead to a protracted civil war if the North refused to accept a separation), is a reminder for the twenty-first century reader that the outcome of the war was unknowable in 1862, with rumor, news, and opinion all playing their part in the views of onlookers outside the United States. But TC’s closing comment to his brother John here does seem to indicate a lack of appreciation of the seriousness of the divisions over slavery, even if he understood more about the importance of power, control, and business.

TC and JWC had many sources of information about foreign affairs through their friendship circle. Although JWC was no longer as close to Giuseppe Mazzini as she had been in the past (see, for example, his letter to her in July 1846 [20:222JWC to TC, 6 July 1846], when she was angry and upset with TC), Mazzini wrote to her in August 1862; she reported to TC that he had gone to Italy “with his eyes perfectly open to the madness“ of Garibaldi’s plans for an invasion of southern Italy (see JWC to TC, 2 Sept.). By November 1862, she wrote to Lady Airlie that Mazzini had told her in August that Garibaldi’s enterprise was “perfectly ruinous “; he had written, “I go [to Italy] in two days—knowing that I go, merely to involve myself in the ruin which Garibaldi has prepared for us all“ (JWC to Lady ALAI, 10 Nov. 1862). She also reported to Julia Schwabe TC’s low opinion of Garibaldi: “Mr C doesn’t admire Garibaldi at all! Has been bored to death with all the talk of him, declares him to be ‘the great dramatic Mountebank of the Age’“ (JWC to JSJSSC, [ca. 10 Nov. 1862]). Meanwhile, TC gained information about Australia through Charles Gavan Duffy, known first to the Carlyles when he was a radical Young Irelander (see19:64–66TC to MAC, 28 April 1845), but now an eminently respectable commissioner for lands and works for Victoria, Australia, 1858–59, reappointed November 1861. Duffy also sent Australian colleagues to call on the Carlyles, among them Henry Parkes, commissioner for immigration, who was visiting Britain to encourage emigration. TC and Parkes had met in October 1861 and had a long discussion, in which Carlylean opinions were expressed vigorously (see 37:241TC to HP, 2 Oct. 1861). TC commented to Parkes, in a letter of December 1861, “I have no recollection what I said to you about colonisation that evg,“ but continued: “The subject used to be of earnest almost of painful interest to me in old years; it seemed to me there had no Nation ever had such glorious opportunities of changing its nearly intolerable curses and choking nightmares into blessings and winged angels, as Great Britain in our day, by Colonising; or was so scandalously throwing
said opportunity away“ (TC to HP, 31 Dec.). By September 1862, TC wrote to Parkes about Duffy’s “entertaining commentary on the New Land Law [for New South Wales], whh I had not been able to understand before“ (TC to HP, 19 Sept.). It is from brief references such as these in the Carlyles’ letters that we are able to construct a pattern for their sources of information on international affairs. Much of the contact was carried on by letter, but some came out of encounters with new acquaintances in London, sent by friends overseas: for example, Parkes, who was sent by Duffy; Duffy himself, originally introduced in 1845 by the Irish nationalist Frederick Lucas (1812–55; ODNB); and all the American visitors sent by R. W. Emerson or Charles Butler.

While the men among their new acquaintances came mainly to see TC, some of the women became new friends for JWC. Margaret Oliphant, first met during summer 1860 (see 37:62JWC to MO, 12 Dec. 1860) through her work on The Life of Edward Irving, was now a friend. There are only occasional letters between JWC and Oliphant because they lived close enough to visit each other, Oliphant having moved to Ealing from Edinburgh in October 1861; Oliphant wrote, November 1861: “May I call tomorrow somewhere about 2 o clock? Miss Jewsbury brought me your kind message of which you may be sure I was only too glad to take advantage— Indeed I should have gone to see you before, had I not thought it likely you were still out of town. If I do not hear from you tomorrow morning I shall take it for granted that I may come“ (MO to JWC, [11 Nov. 1861]; MS: NLS 1774.214). In early May 1862, JWC postponed a visit to Ealing but suggested a visit the following week (see JWC to MO, [early May]). TC, the first to meet Oliphant, continued to take an interest in her; JWC reported that he thought The Life of Edward Irving was “worth whole cart-loads of Mulochs and Brontes and things of that sort“ (JWC to MO, [early May]). Dinah Mulock, featured in JWC’s letters as an astonishingly young author (see 24:288–89TC to JN, 12 Nov. 1849, 304JWC to HW, 2 Dec. 1849, and 27:387JWC to HW, 30 Dec. 1852), was by now a well-established novelist. TC’s reported comment must have been pleasing to Oliphant, professing admiration for her work above the more commercially successful Mulock and Brontës.

Margaret Oliphant’s function as a new friend for JWC was perhaps to provide reminders of Scotland and of JWC’s youthful friendship with Irving. JWC is compared by Oliphant to her own mother (see 37:32JWC to WDO, 31 Oct. 1860, and Oliphant, ed. Jay, Autobiography 97–98). JWC certainly would have seen Oliphant as her junior, but, because of her professional life ( “one of the best Novelists of the day“ [JWC to MR, [14 April]]) as well as her status as a widow with children, JWC would not have seen Oliphant as an equivalent to young women such as Isabella Barnes, whom JWC also adopted as recipients for enthusiastic friendship. Although there are a few surviving letters to Oliphant, written in JWC’s best style (including her first, December 1860; see
37:62–65JWC to MO, 12 Dec. 1860), their shared Scottishness probably precluded any full-blown swearing of eternal friendship. That was reserved for Charlotte Cushman, the American actress who lived between the United States and Italy, visiting London fairly frequently. JWC and Cushman finally met in August 1861 (see 37:224JWC to CCU, 6 Sept. 1861); this volume includes the development of their correspondence; they hoped to meet when Cushman was passing through London in early October 1862, but may have missed each other as JWC was to be in Dover with another new friend, the “gentle, intelligent, and perfectly well bred“ (JWC to TC, [July]) Caroline Davenport Bromley. Cushman’s and JWC’s surviving letters vie in their expression of exaggerated friendship. JWC wrote: “I want to put my arms round your neck, and give you—oh! such a good kiss! And then,—if you can stand that sort of thing, once in a way,—I should like to lay my head on your shoulder and take a good cry! … But alas Dear! The ‘gods,’ however entreated, will not ‘annihilate Time and Space, to make two Lovers happy’!” (JWC to CC, [31 Jan.]). They met during Cushman’s visit to London in July 1862, although JWC did not refer to these meetings. Cushman signed one of her notes: “God love you, dear, & make you always care for Your loving Charlotte Cushman“ (CC to JWC, 12 July; MS: NLS 1774.233), and the other: “I only am sure of one thing & that is my loving admiration for you. My desire to be with you & my vexation at disappointment / Love me—believe that I am Ever faithfully Your Charlotte Cushman“ (CC to JWC, 15 July; MS: NLS 1774.235). It may be that Cushman enjoyed the frisson of possibility that JWC was open to flirtation if not actually to any lesbian affair. Certainly JWC was probably more capable of flirtation by letter than in person, but it still should be recalled that the swearing of everlasting friendship was a norm in exchanges between many nineteenth-century women in their letters (and possibly in person). JWC recognized this tendency and satirized it, noting in 1846 Geraldine Jewsbury’s “blaze of enthusiasm about Miss Cushman the Actress—with whom she swore everlasting friendship at Manchester“ (see 20:109JWC to JW, 19 Jan. 1846). But now Cushman, at least for the moment, provided JWC with a new and exciting opportunity for the exchange of exaggerated expressions of friendship.

Both Carlyles can undermine preconceptions about “Victorianism“ in what they write, however much TC himself was one of the creators of intellectual Victorianism. This might be explained by their upbringing in a pre-Victorian world, rooted as that was in the more earthy eighteenth century and, in TC’s case, in the realistic world of peasant farmers. TC, often assumed to be detached and protected by everyone from the realities of life, wrote to his brother John, the doctor, about their niece Jenny Carlyle’s irregular menstrual periods: “Jane had heard from questioning Mary that the poor little Jenny was fallen quite ‘irregular in her times’ (for six months past); whh is a
very serious matter for yg women“ (TC to JAC, 13 Sept.). JWC’s letters also showed that conversations between women were frank; after her return from visiting Mary Russell, she wrote, “My breast is quite well“ (JWC to MR, [15 Sept.]), having apparently told Mrs. Russell about some problem during her visit. The vigor of TC’s opinions, whether in conversation or in print, is well known, but a flavor of it can be caught in his letters, particularly those written to family or to JWC. Charles Kingsley, an equally representative Victorian, was already well known to the Carlyles. Kingsley’s wife was the redoubtable Frances Eliza, five years older than Kingsley; TC, meeting her on his visit to the Ashburtons, reported succinctly: “Wife is a strange blubbery, half-squinting, solemnly-contemplative Lady (religious &c)“ (TC to JWC, 29 Jan.). Meanwhile JWC made mischief with the concepts of legitimacy and illegitimacy. Her illegitimate cousin, Jackie Welsh, was fully recognized within the Welsh family; rather than using Jackie’s status to exclude her on grounds of “nonrespectability,“ JWC (in a letter to the wife of an old school friend in Haddington) joked about the illegitimacy: “[I]t is a fact worth notice for both Physiologists and Moralists, that Jackie is admirably Legitimate in her handwriting!” (JWC to JD, 8 March). Her enjoyment of outrageous gossip manifested itself to TC when she wrote about Lord Monboddo’s daughter and the likeness of her son to Francis Jeffrey (one of JWC’s loyalest friends in the early days of the Carlyle marriage): “A woman who commenced with an irregular marriage, you see! quite easy to arrive later at an irregular Baby!—“ (JWC to TC, [15 Aug.]). Lord Monboddo, the famous eighteenth-century Scottish judge and philosopher, was renowned as much for his belief in the close relationship of man to apes and beliefs in the origin of language as for his legal judgments. Jeffrey himself, although not dying until 1850, was equally a representative of the Scottish Enlightenment, one of the founders of the Edinburgh Review in 1801 (the year of JWC’s birth) and a harsh critic of the romantic poets. Meanwhile, the death of Prince Albert (14 Dec.), a defining moment of Victoria’s reign, was referred to not at all by TC, even though he had met Albert in 1854 (see 29:194–95TC to LA, 9 Nov. 1854), and only obliquely by JWC when she thanked Maggie Welsh for the black silk sleeves sent for Christmas and mentioned a black silk waistcoat made at Nichol’s, both in the context of “the present mourning crisis“ (JWC to MW, [28 Dec.]). But this was mentioned in the context of a forthcoming visit to The Grange, where such social niceties as the observation of national mourning for the death of the prince consort would be imposed and JWC would both expect and want to conform.

TC’s religious ambiguities and doubts are well documented, but JWC’s attitudes are perhaps less well known. She clearly was no more convinced of the virtues of religious observance than TC, neither of them undertaking any
conventional observation or church attendance. In this volume JWC also used the idea of religious faith and observation to point up differences between her own upbringing as a Scottish Presbyterian and English religious observations of various kinds. Fond as she was of Isabella Barnes, daughter of JWC’s doctor, JWC’s attendance at her wedding to John Simmonds still led to the comment (reported to the Scottish Mary Russell) on English weddings as “something betwixt a Religious Ceremony and a—Pantomime!“ (JWC to MR, 23 Feb.). JWC also wrote to the equally Scottish Jane Dods about her social life, two dinners (even though she had been ill), and a particularly funny account of Isabella’s Anglican wedding: “And me a Presbyterian too!” (JWC to JD, 8 March). Her skepticism about religion (see, for example, 20:240) extended to her evangelical aunts in Edinburgh (see 33:38TC to JWC, 19 Aug. 1857). She reported to TC while on a visit to them: “[S]till I am like a fish out of water in this element of religiosity; or rather, like a human being in water—and the water hot!” (JWC to TC, [5 Sept.]). To Mary Russell, she made a careful distinction between “religion“ and “religiosity “: “At Craigenvilla … I am always reacting against the self-assumption and the religiosity (not the religion, mind!)“ (JWC to MR, [5 Sept.]). Despite this distinction, her belief in any God was apparently as ambiguous as anything TC wrote privately in his letters or in such works as Sartor Resartus.

The reality of death, on the other hand, was not a matter for satire from either of them. TC was moved by the deaths caused by the collapse of an Edinburgh tenement (see TC to JAC, 1 Dec.) and personally grieved by the death of Lady Sandwich (the mother of the first Lady Ashburton), expressing his sadness to Lord Ashburton and writing about her funeral (which he attended) to his brother John and sister Jean Carlyle Aitken (see TC to Lord ALOA, 21 April; to JCA, 28 [26] April; and to JAC, 29 April). The months of this volume contained a litany of death; beginning with the sudden death next door of Alexander Gilchrist, they continued with the terminal illness and then deaths of Ellen Twisleton (at only forty-four) and of JWC’s old Fife friend Elizabeth Pepoli. Failing all winter, Elizabeth refused to have family with her or to ask for her husband, Count Pepoli, to return from Italy: “[T]here is stoicism in that but not heroism—not lovingness“ (JWC to MR, [13 Feb.]). JWC reported visiting Elizabeth daily, despite her critical view of her “proud stoicism“ (JWC to Lady A, [ca. 25 March]; JWC to MR, [14 April]), and she commented: “[J]ust when the freshness of one sorrow was wearing off there has come another“ (JWC to MR, [5 June]).

Many of TC’s letters were about his perceived slow progress (or lack of it) in Frederick; when he mentioned JWC it was mainly to report on her health or lack of it. But many of JWC’s letters showed her teasing TC, protecting his reputation, organizing, or commenting on him. While on a visit to The Grange, she instructed him: “Look up in your topographical Book for Saltwood
Castle. Lady A asked, when we were [the]re today, if I thought you [w]ould be able to tell us about it and I said ‘of course’ you would“ (JWC to TC, [2 July]). But she also broadened her observations of TC into more general ones on men. After Dr. Russell had an accident, she expanded satirically on men (including TC) and illness:
div1.q: The longer I live, the more I am certified that men, in all that relates to their own health, have not common sense! whether it be their Pride, or their Impatience, or their Obstinacy or their ingrained Spirit of Contradiction that stultifies and misleads them—the result is always a certain amount of idiocy or distraction, in their dealings with their own bodies! I am not generalizing from my own Husband. I know that he is a quite extravagant example of that want of common sense in bodily matters, which I complain of. Few men (even) are so lost to themselves as to dry their soaked trowsers on their legs! (as he does) or swallow five grains of mercury in the middle of the day, and then walk or ride three hours under a plunge of rain! (as he does) &c &c But men generally—all of them I have ever had to do with—even your sensible Husband included you see!—drive the poor women who care for them to despair; either by their wild impatience of bodily suffering, and the exaggerated moan they make over it, or else by their reckless defiance of it, and neglect of every dictate of Prudence! (JWC to MR, [23 Feb.])
div1.p: JWC’s peroration on “men generally,“ health, and common sense, may not be a startlingly radical gender analysis, but it corroborates the consistency of women’s observations of male behavior (whether accurate or not) from one century to another.

The increasing use of photography was something in which both the Carlyles were caught up. The volume begins with references to the photograph of TC on his horse, Fritz, in Hyde Park (see 7TC to CGD, 10 Nov. 1861). But the main excitement came in the following fall. JWC was entertained to be photographed by the Thornhill hairdresser when she was visiting Mary Russell, and circulated copies of the result, TC describing it as a “very successful Photograph“ (TC to JWC, 1 July [Sept.]). JWC told TC that “Mrs Russell and I got taken one day for fun; and if I had dreamt of coming out so well, I would have dressed myself better, and turned the best side of my face!” (JWC to TC, 2 Sept.). TC took a holiday in September, JWC commenting that this “‘sacred week’ of idling and sight-seeing“ would be “an exceptional week in our mutual life“ (JWC to TC, [2 Sept.]), and the luring of TC to a photographer took place in this week. JWC reported:
div1.q:
An immense explosion of photographs has come off in this house! in consequence of Mrs Aitken’s indiscretion in lending the print of Mr C to
a photographist in Dumfries, who tho “bound down to take only six copies, “ … had nevertheless, as I thought at the time, sent these wretched photographs out in shoals for his own gain! My aunt Grace had seen a great heap of them lying on a Booksellers counter in Princes Street! … What all my entreaties had not been able to obtain from Mr C—viz that he would go and be photographed by a right man here, was accomplished by his annoyance at being published over the world under so unlike a form. And having decided that last week was to be a holyday, he actually went with me to the best Photographer in London, who had been for years soliciting him to come and be done—for nothing!— He (the Photographer took a great many different ones, large and small; of which one of the large ones satisfied him, and is to be published and I think it the finest photograph I ever saw. … As of course Mr Jeffrey (the photographer) will make a good thing of supplying the shops with Mr C; he was very obliging in insisting on doing me—who had not laid my account with being done; and so, was at the same loss for a head-dress—as you were at the Hairdressers! (JWC to MR, [21 Sept.])
div1.p: The passage is worth quoting at length as it illustrates the commercial possibilities of the literary celebrity in Victorian times permitted by the improving technologies of photography and reproduction. It also illustrated for Mary Russell, with whom she had just shared the enjoyment of the more “provincial“ photography experience (for example, the edge of another backdrop showing behind the screen; see 179JWC to MCA, [30 Aug.]), her ability to organize TC into doing what she wanted because of his irritation at someone else’s exploiting his image for financial gain. TC made humorous reference to his appearance in this series of photographs when he wrote to Lady Ashburton: “If you be a good child, I do believe you have a chance of one of the ugliest Photographic Pictures of the human countenance you ever saw: an old grim fellow (much older than I thot he was) in wool-white hair; features full of gloom, hard as granite, and looking out quite relentless upon life“ (TC to Lady ALAI, 19 Sept.). JWC then reported TC’s comment: “[W]e are all ugly! some of us very ugly indeed!” (JWC to Lady SLST, 25 Sept.). The final photographic session of the year took place at The Grange with Vernon Heath, the fashionable photographer; JWC reported Lady Ashburton’s description of his picture of TC and Lord Ashburton (see 248JWC to EFO, 30 Oct.): “two Criminals in one dock; the one (Lord A) having received his sentence of death, and sinking away into insensibility; the other (Mr C) in the act of receiving his, and glaring back uneasy defiance!!” (JWC to EFEFO, 30 Oct.). Amusing as this was, the picture itself recorded clearly the increasing frailty of Lord Ashburton, although the death feared in November 1862 did not finally arrive until 1864.

The letters of this volume continue to show the Carlyles in the full detail of their daily lives. Rooted in Chelsea, but with strong links continuing to Scotland, Europe, the United States, and Australia, they developed along with the Victorian age. Their families and friendships, their opinions, their idiosyncrasies, their talents, and their achievements are presented and explored in these letters, providing continuing evidence of the rich trove of material to be found in the Carlyles’ letters.

div1.p: November 1861–November 1862

row.cell: Young, Life of John Welsh (Edin., 1866) xxviii

div1.p: 1862 November. TC promises Lord Ashburton proof sheets of the third vol. of Frederick (10); book 15 not finished until 23 Nov. He writes Duffy with strong opinions about democracy and the press in the British colonies; tells Duffy he and his horse Fritz have ridden about 24,000 miles over the last eight years “in quest ‘of health to go on with’“ and encloses a photograph (10). JWC has caught cold in the winter weather. Ruskin is recovering in Switzerland from a bout of depression; his father sends TC a box of cigars along with an invitation to dine, which TC declines (14). TC recommends Gerald Massey to the Royal Literary Fund for support (23). Frederick, he tells his brother, consists of “[h]orrors of drossy incoherency“ (23). Scarlet fever reaches the Gilchrist home next door, and Alexander Gilchrist dies (29); JWC, “room-fast, sometimes bed-fast,“ remains indoors but writes affectionately offering help to Anne Gilchrist ([30]). TC declines Froude’s request to write on Clough for Fraser’s Magazine, and acknowledges to Ruskin’s father receipt of a book of selections from Ruskin’s published works (30).

December. TC has started book 16 of Frederick but decides after a few days on “a pause absolute“ (1). JWC writes Anne Gilchrist, whose son is recovering from scarlet fever ([6]). Her own health is characterized by “weakness and restlessness,“ which “are most depressing.“ The weather improves. TC tells FitzGerald, “I continue buried; see nobody,“ and thanks his sister Jean for clothes (7). JWC, meantime, describes her imprisonment through bad health to Kate Stanley and the medicine she takes to prevent her brain becoming “dangerously excited.“ She declines the offer of a new, white dog to replace Nero (7). Slowly her health improves; she goes out in a fly for a drive ([19]) and invites Eliza Forster to visit. JWC writes Ann Chamberlayne ([ca. 25]) and Maggie Welsh ([26]) about Christmas gifts, and buys clothes to prepare for her intended visit to The Grange. TC sends New Year’s gifts to his sisters Jean and Mary and niece Jenny (31).

1862 January. TC sends Henry Larkin a New Year’s gift and thanks for “unwearied help “; JWC writes George Cooke to thank him for his gift and for being her “first foot“ (1). She thanks Jane Dods for her good wishes and gift of a photograph. Maria, the maid, is ill for a week with “inflamatory cold and hysteria“ (3). TC starts a new chapter of Frederick. He visits Lady Sandwich “abt weekly“ (17). Isabella Barnes invites both Carlyles to her forthcoming
wedding. JWC, “still weak as water“ reluctantly cancels her visit to The Grange; TC goes by himself (27). A large party are assembled including the duke and duchess of Argyll, Milnes, Ellice, the Kingsleys, Sartoris, Venables, and the bishop of Oxford, with whom TC rides (28). He enjoys the company, though the weather is damp and he sleeps badly (29). JWC writes affectionately to Charlotte Cushman complaining about her “sick room tribulations“ and loneliness as old friends pass away ([31]).

February. Larkin considers moving next door to the Carlyles if Mrs. Gilchrist decides to leave; he does so after his marriage 24 April. TC returns from The Grange (2), “slightly better from these few days of pure air & quiet fields,“ but anxious about Lord Ashburton’s health. John Hill Burton visits (5). JWC “now gets out almost daily“ (6). Two of JWC’s “most intimate friends,“ Ellen Twisleton and Countess Pepoli, are dying; JWC visits both. The Blunts invite JWC to accompany them to Isabella Barnes’s wedding ([13]). TC intends visiting Ruskin (16). JWC’s health is improving, and she goes to the wedding (18) and to two dinner parties, one with Miss Baring and one with Lady Sandwich (23).

March. TC, “still tugging at the galley-oar,“ writes William Allingham to congratulate him on his historical writing (3). JWC writes Jane Dods in Haddington to thank her for Good Words and includes a satirical description of Isabella Barnes’s Church of England wedding service (8). TC writes Arthur Clough’s widow, Blanche, and promises to try to find Clough’s original letters to return to her (9). JWC writes to Forster, offering his wife one of the litter of kittens expected in Cheyne Row ([12]). TC, contrary to his usual practice, accepts a dinner invitation from the duke of Argyll (23). JWC writes Lady Airlie about Lady Dillon’s death, and reports that she is still helping nurse Countess Pepoli “for some hours every day“ ([ca. 25]). JWC invites Woolner (26) to tea to meet Isabella Barnes Simmonds and her new husband (28). TC tells his brother John he has agreed to publish vol. 3 of Frederick by itself to gain “elbow-room“ for later vols. (30). Neuberg’s failing health makes him less useful to TC as an assistant, but Larkin continues to help with maps (30).

April. TC writes to thank James Spedding for his Life of Bacon; he continues to decline dinner invitations; he keeps in touch with family mainly through his brother John (7). JWC has a brief trip to Hastings with Frederic Chapman and his wife (4–7). Countess Pepoli dies (7). TC writes to Froude, editor of Fraser’s, suggesting he invite Ruskin to contribute the papers that eventually became Munera Pulveris (14). JWC complains of the lack of photographs of herself and TC ([14]). TC writes Neuberg, hoping he is better, and requesting help (17). Lady Sandwich dies (19); TC writes Lord Ashburton (21) to
commiserate; he attends Lady Sandwich’s funeral at Barnwell (25). TC and JWC have a brief trip to Addiscombe (26–30), slightly complicated by the sudden illness of Lady Ashburton’s mother in Scotland; TC rides with Lord Ashburton.

May. John A. Carlyle’s stepson William is in trouble, and TC writes with advice (3). Maggie Welsh visits Chelsea, “coming and going all this week.“ TC is reading Margaret Oliphant’s life of Edward Irving; JWC arranges a visit with Oliphant. TC sends Lord Sandwich a memorial gift of a copy of the newly published vol. 3 of Frederick, which he had intended for Lady Sandwich ([ca. 10]). He invites Neuberg to visit, and thanks him for the work he has done (10). Ellen Twisleton dies (17). TC attends a dinner at R. M. Milnes’s (20). F. D. Maurice visits TC.

June. JWC tells Mary Russell she has “been writing to nobody“ because of her poor health. She misses Lady Sandwich, Elizabeth Pepoli, and Ellen Twisleton. Maggie Welsh has left London after a six-week stay ([5]). TC thanks Charles Ward for his favorable comments on vol. 3 of Frederick, telling him he estimates he has a year’s worth of writing left (14). A new Scottish maid arrives in Chelsea. TC writes to his brother John about the Watt stepsons, and also about their nephew James’s prospects in Scotland (18). He dismisses a young man’s drama sent him for approval: “Literature“ is not “the truly noble human carreer“ (25). JWC takes the train to Folkestone for a holiday with Lady Ashburton and a party of friends (28), missing visits to Chelsea by Lady Airlie, Sarah Dilberoglue, Charlotte Cushman, and George Cooke. TC visits John Forster for news of Eliza Forster (29) and writes, very low in spirits, that he has begun vol. 5 of Frederick (30).

July. The Ashburtons invite TC to join them in Folkestone. JWC writes Forster for news of his wife ([2]). TC’s brother John arrives unexpectedly at Chelsea, for the funeral (4) of his stepson Tom, who has unexpectedly died (1). TC is sent a large batch of proofs, which he feels have to be corrected before accepting the Ashburtons’ invitation to join JWC at Folkestone (5–7). JWC writes Mary Russell that she is considering a holiday on her own with her, since TC will not make up his mind about holidays (30).

August. JWC bruises her foot but continues with plans to visit Scotland (2). TC sends Ruskin’s Unto This Last to Thomas Erskine: “I have read nothing that pleased me better for many a year“ (4). TC works under his awning in the garden during the hot weather. Neuberg goes to Bavaria in search of health. JWC, her foot healing, travels to Mary Russell by train via Carlisle and Dumfries, meeting briefly en route TC’s sisters Jean at Dumfries and Mary at Ruthwell (11). Despite wet weather she enjoys the rest and change at Holmhill. JWC writes Thomas Woolner to thank him for a photograph of Mrs.
Twisleton (13). She receives many forwarded letters and encourages TC to accept an invitation to visit The Grange. Bessy Barnet visits TC in Chelsea (18) with news of her forthcoming marriage. JWC visits many old friends with Mary Russell, and many other localities of her youth, “half charming half terrible!” She visits The Gill (26–29), via Dumfries, where she sees old friends. She visits Caerlaverock Castle (27). TC receives visitors such as Karl Wilhelm von Willisen ([24]) and walks with Delane of the Times (25 and 26); he keeps JWC supplied with Chelsea news. He receives a box of grouse and distributes them among friends and neighbors. Jane returns to Holmhill (29) without visiting Scotsbrig, where Jenny Carlyle is ill. William Allingham visits Cheyne Row. JWC sends a photograph taken by a Thornhill hairdresser to Mary Austin (30). TC writes Lord Ashburton for some news of his family (31).

September. JWC goes to Edinburgh to visit her three aunts, en route visiting her mother’s grave in Crawford (1). Lady Ashburton writes to invite TC to The Grange (4). He is keen to accept and suggests 9 Sept. Woolner visits, also Ruskin’s valet with news of Ruskin’s travels and bout of depression. Vol. 4 of Frederick almost finished. JWC visits Betty Braid and her family, but sees no one else in Edinburgh (4). She crosses the Forth to Auchtertool to visit her cousins, pleased to see them “if it werent for that ‘crossing’!” (6–9). TC, with a bowel upset, postpones his visit to The Grange. JWC reminds him to submit his income tax papers or face a heavy fine ([8]). JWC returns to Edinburgh (9), and leaves for London (11). The Ashburtons’ plans change, and the Carlyles cannot go to The Grange, so TC gives himself a week’s holiday in Chelsea. He writes Richard Owen (15), encouraging him in his plan for a natural history museum, and to his brother John that under the guidance of Woolner both TC and JWC are being professionally photographed by William Jeffrey (19)—pirated photographs of TC, made in Dumfries, were being circulated widely and had been seen on sale in Edinburgh. Lady Stanley invites the Carlyles to Alderley but too late; TC has resumed work after his brief holiday (22). Woolner arranges for the Carlyles to have private access to the pictures at the International Exhibition (28). JWC writes Charlotte Cushman (30), regretting that she has committed herself to a visit to Dover at the time Cushman was to be in London. She sends copies of the new photographs to the Carlyles in Dumfriesshire via Jean Aitken, and goes to the tailors to order new clothes for TC (30).

October. JWC arrives in Dover for a holiday with Caroline Davenport Bromley and friends (1–5). TC receives proofs of vol. 4, “sight of them enough to make one shudder!” but finds time to ride with Neuberg (2). JWC sea-bathes daily and feels her health is improved. She declines, on TC’s behalf, an invitation to Freshwater with the Tennysons (4). TC is sunk in proofs, correcting a “jumble of horrors“ (11). They leave for a brief visit to The Grange
(11–18). Vernon Heath, the photographer, is there, recording everything, including TC with Lord Ashburton; JWC is very impressed by the friendliness of both Ashburtons. JWC writes Georgiana Craik to thank her for Winifred’s Wooing (20). TC requests Butler reinvest his U.S. profits in U.S. stocks and send the profits to Dumfries from time to time; this remains a steady source of income for him (30). JWC writes to Eliza Forster to congratulate her on better health (30).

November. TC thanks Lord Ashburton for his offer of one of his horses, but decides to keep his old faithful, Fritz (2); he sends the Ashburtons a list of recommended reading for the winter (5) to take with them when they leave for Nice (10); they have invited the Carlyles to come with them, but TC will not leave Frederick. “Oh what a dreary winter is before me!” JWC tells Lady Airlie (10). TC is gloomily proofreading and thanking his brother John for his help in various tasks; the maid, Maria, leaves Chelsea and the new servant, Florence, arrives. They hear that Lord Ashburton is dangerously ill in Paris (16). JWC thanks Mary Russell for a ham from Scotland ([18]), and reports with joy Lord Ashburton’s rallying health ([20]); she writes Lady Ashburton praising him as “the most unselfish man I ever saw in my life!” ([22]). TC works on, “inch by inch,“ and finishes a chapter (25).

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A[LAI], [early Nov.]. MS: NLS 20767.43. Hitherto unpbd. Dated after Lady Airlie’s letter of 27 Oct. 1861. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 1 November 1861.]
div3.head: JWC TO LADY AIRLIE

docBody.p: The sight of a letter from you,Lady Airlie wrote to JWC 27 Oct. 1861. independently of its contents, always warms my heart and does me good; and this little effervescence of feeling would, on the last occasion, have taken a practical shape by return of Post—but for—what shall I say?Coterie speech; see 17:36JWC to TC, 11 Aug. 1843.—“circumstances over which I had no controul“!See 3:373JBW to MAC, 27 Aug. 1825.—no matter what they were!— Life is too short for particularizing them; Just this; (let me explain)—as being of a certain gravity—to myself! for a week back I have been “off my sleep!“ Do you know what that, means, my Lady? if you don’t know it, by experience; I should despair of moving you to a due pitch of sympathy by any lyrical recognition of the state!—if you have experienced it, I have said enough, to stand excused in your beautiful eyes for my slight dilatoriness in answering.

The rapidly and gracefully sketched picture of your life recalls—Arcadia!There had been a house full of visitors at Cortachy Castle, Forfarshire, and Lady Airlie wrote of her enjoyment, now that they had left: “The … children are all so dear & happy & now that we are alone we are so much together & make long expeditions the three elder ones riding & I following in a poney carriage. Oct is a delightful month here.“ She also commented: “Airlie has been his own Factor all this year“ and had been “sorting papers of 100 years standing—Some very interesting—What a place Scotland must have been at the end of last century & how poor they all were. // Since 1780 rents have risen six fold—expences too“ (MS: NLS 4.208). that is—subsequently to Mr Strachey!Lady Airlie wrote: “Mr Strachey came to see us“; presumably George Strachey, diplomat; his brother Sir Edward Strachey (1812–1901; ODNB), religious and philosophical writer, had succeeded to his uncle’s baronetcy in 1858. the most unarcadian of men I should say!— Of us here, there is nothing to be told that is in the least poetical! “Anything But!” (as my CookMargaret Sullivan. JWC wrote “mange“ below, for “manage.“ says)— Soon after you left London, I was seized with a wild longing for a mouthful of Sea-air! felt as if my very life depended on it! Surely Mr C might mange by himself for one week? At all rates I resolved he should try!— No man knows what he can do till he tries!— So off I went with Geraldine Jewsbury to Ramsgate—for one week.JWC stayed in Ramsgate 3–10 Aug.; see 37:201–208JWC to TC, 6 Aug. 1861. It proved a most untoward choice of a place! swarms of people—and all Jews! The men of them mostly in their shirt sleeves, at open windows, eating shrimps!
The women mostly in the family-way! It was “truly disgusting“ (as Countess PepoliElizabeth, Countess Pepoli. says) and then the noises!—by day and by night! commencing with the Brass Band during breakfast, and with an explosion of cats, on lying down to sleep, and going thro’ every description of natural and artificial noise, short of the crash of Doom! Nevertheless so healthful was the sea air, that we contrived to stay the week out with no sleep “to speak of,“Coterie speech; see 17:63JWC to TC, 18 Aug. 1843. and to return a little stronger; only so sick of one another’s company, (having had no other) that we returned hardly on speaking terms! Then another spell of airless, empty London—till the 12 of September when Mr C and I went to a place called Harewood Lodge, near Windsor on a visit to Lady Sandwich.The Carlyles visited Lady Sandwich 12—23 Sept.; see 37:192TC to LS, 24 July 1861, and 235–36JWC to IEB, 22 Sept. 1861. The horseTC’s horse, Fritz. was invited too; and every possible pains kindly taken to make the visit so easy and pleasant, that we should stay “a month.“ But oh my Dear! Imagine what that man went and did! the very day after our arrival, “Nature“ having just been “refreshed with a shower,“ he went and spread his pocket handkerchief on the wet grass, and sat down on it, to read!—within six yards of a nice dry bench under a tree! The consequence was obvious. Lumbago! In vain then were “the Beauties of Nature,“Coterie speech; see 35:139JWC to JGCO, 9 July 1859. and all Lady S’s unwearied efforts to make him happy! The only possible happiness for a man in Lumbago is that grand one of all— “Perfect freedom to be as ugly and stupid and disagreeable as ever one likes!”Coterie speech; see 13:196JWC to JF, 24 July 1841.— And that happiness you know reserves itself for the domestic hearth! So all his desires strained towards the domestic hearth; and on the tenth day, no entreaties could hold him longer, and home we came! This fatality of being snatched away—like ProserpineProserpine or Persephone, da. of Ceres, was snatched away by Pluto to the underworld.—from every scene, where I am beginning to remember there is such a thing as pleasure in the world; ceases to take me by surprise; but is not on that account the less tantalizing! Since then, life has passed wearily enough, but without any shocks. Except that my medical Brother in law,TC’s brother Dr. John A. Carlyle. who lives in creaking boots, and was, I fancy, born with them,See 25:102TC to JAC, 26 June 1850, and 37:65TC to JA, 14 Dec. 1860. as other some with a silver spoon in their mouths, paid us a week’s visit, and had nearly creaked me into a nervous fever! People who wear creaking Boots, in permanence, never sitting still, as you may have remarked, nor keeping to one purpose any more than to one seat.
Well it is over now! and why “renew grief“?Cf. “renew grief, if you please, not shame“; Edward Bulwer Lytton, The Caxtons (1849) chap. 28.

I am afraid Lord Ashburton is in a most precarious wayLord Ashburton had a heart problem, as well as suffering from gout; see TC to Lord ALOA, 10 Nov., and 37:155TC to LOA, 27 April 1861. They were going to Egypt; but a consultation of Drs was held and and they all (four) forbade it; (Lord A himself said to me) “because they thought it would be so inconvenient I should die at such a distance from home.“ “They did not say that“? I asked— “Not exactly in those words but that is what they implied“! Lady A was looking very sad and anxious; and a letter I had from her two days ago made me cry! I think she is sincerely attached to him—as well as he to her— The saddest part of it to me is, that life should fade away from him so very fast after he had begun for the first time to feel its value— He is so fond of her and of that little child.The Ashburtons’ da., Mary Florence Baring. God bless you
docBody.name: J Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lord A[LOA], 10 Nov. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LORD ASHBURTON

docBody.p: We were gratified, I need not tell you how much, by the good news that came yesterday.Lady Ashburton wrote to JWC, 7 Nov.: “One line to say my dear kind friend, that B [Baring] is much better—indeed quite well for the time being.“ I believe always that The Grange is the best place in the whole world for you, if you will only be quiet there.The Ashburtons had recently returned from Scotland, where they had been since Aug.; see 37:220TC to LOA, 26 Aug. 1861.

Yesterday, being under pressure for time at the finis, I sent you off without any writing, a small Book of Dean Trench’s;Richard Chenevix Trench; the book was the journal of his mother, Melesina Trench (1768–1827; ODNB), Journal Kept During a Visit to Germany in 1799, 1800, [ed. Richard C. Trench] (privately printed, 1861); see 37:190TC to RCT, 24 July 1861. whh will amuse you,—if you have got it, today, for example, amid this pouring rain and the howl of the winds. Perhaps Trench already sent you a copy? If so, pardon. There is no hurry abt returning the thing: only do not lose it; there is a Duchess of Brunswk, a Prince Henry &cPhilippina Charlotte (1716–1801), dowager duchess of Brunswick-Lunëburg, sister of Frederick the Great, and Henry Frederick Louis (1726–1802), prince of Prussia, brother of Frederick the Great and one of his most able generals; see 37:191TC to RCT, 24 July 1861. whom I wish to see again, thro’ those fine clear eyes.

We do indeed (you may tell my Lady) intend to visit The Grange again!The Carlyles had last been at The Grange 15–19 Jan. Nay I individually, in my private moments of enthusiasm, speculate sometimes on “Return-tickets,“ and repeated visits, “from Saty to monday,“ whenever any pretence occurs for a holiday with me! That is to say, provided you are quiet, and have nobody about you, or no disturbed body. A ride on the still sunday (amid multitudinous old thots), and a little quiet talk or silence, the night before and the morning after, wd really be a medicine to me.

At any rate I do intend to send you down the Third volume of Frederick. Am to warn the Printer tomorrow;—in abt a week there may be despatch.Charles Robson of Robson, Levey & Franklyn; TC arranged for proof sheets of vol. 3 of Frederick to be sent to Lord Ashburton. It was pbd. early May 1862. At the rate of two sheets per evg, with my Lady to read, it will serve you a long time.Lord Ashburton reported, 8 Dec., to Mrs. Stewart-Mackenzie, Lady Ashburton’s mother, that he had “been reading Carlyle’s Frederic, with eager relish. Uncouth as is the style, the wisdom of selection, the vigor of expression, the vivid lifelike colouring, & the rigid fidelity of statement, are beyond any other historian“ (MS: NLS Acc. 11388).

All this,—provided you be a good Boy; by whh, I mean, lead the most quiet, dietetic, sanitary life that can be contrived for you, and honestly recognise how many years you now count, and what liberties are not now permissible. What the Doctors say about “disease of the heart“ is no overwhelming matter to me; I have known above half a dozen people, whom the Doctors had solemnly condemned in that manner,—most of them are still living, not one of whom proved to have any “disease of the heart“ at all. To me it is completely problematic whether, in your case, the special organ of the heart is wrong at all. But there can be no doubt you have weak circulatn of the blood, weak nerves, a thin skin,—and must, on every acct, take diligent incesst care of yourself, and try for new strength. Adieu, Both.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-CGD, 10 Nov. MS: NLI. Pbd: Duffy 210–14; Wilson 5:440–41 inc.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES GAVAN DUFFY

docBody.p:
Your friend Parkes, who did not present himself till quite lately, “hearing I was so busy,“—came the other evening;Henry Parkes, a friend of Duffy’s from Australia, had come to Britain for a year as a commissioner of immigration for the Colony of Victoria; he had arrived in Britain in Aug. but did not visit TC until Oct.; see 37:241TC to HP, 2 Oct. 1861. Duffy had given Parkes a letter of introduction to TC. and gave us a few pleasant hours. We
find him a robust, effective, intelligent and sincere kind of man,—extremely loyal to C.G.D.; whh is not one of his smallest merits here. He gave me several more precise notions abt Australian Life; seemed to be thoroughly at home in the anarchic democratic Universal-Palaver element, and to swim about in it, with a candid joy, like a fish in water;—and indeed I could not but own that, in comparison with the old Colonial-Office & Parliamentary-Fogie methods of administration, it might be a real improvement;Parkes later recalled TC saying: “I have been thinking over your praise of your responsible governing machine out there which you have set up in place of the Old Fogies of the Nominee days; on the whole, I think it is better—if you must have one or other—than the Old Fogies“ (Parkes 1:164–65). & that, in short, in the present anarchic condition of England, there was nothing for it but to let her Colonies go, in this wild manner, down the wind, whither they listed; till once it became insupportable to the poor minority of wise men among themselves, and they (probably sword-in-hand) cd resolve to take some course with it, Life to them having grown worse than Death under such conditions. It is my prophecy for Yankee-land, and for England, and for all Countries with National-Palaver & Penny Newspapers in them: if the gods intend that these Nations are to continue above ground, said Nations will have to abolish, or tightly chain-up, all that (so far as I can form the least opinn),—or if the Nation prefers not to abolish, it can at its own good pleasure go down; to very hot quarters indeed; and will find me a resigned man, whichever way!According to Parkes, TC “asked many curious questions about Australia, which showed the original light in which he viewed some well-threshed-out subjects of colonization. … [H]e contended that, if governing men could only free themselves from the trammels of custom and be truly wise, they would remove the Sovereign and the Court and all the machinery of Government to Australia, where the field for national life was so wide, attractive, and unencumbered, and so leave the contracted spaces and the murky atmosphere of England behind them“ (Parkes 1:160–161).— But I waste my paper sadly.

The worst news Parkes gave us was that you did not seem to be in good health; bad health he sometimes defined your situation to be, when we pressed him for details. That you are “out of Office for the last 18 months,“Duffy served as commissioner of lands and works for the Colony of Victoria, 1858–59, and then resigned because of differences over land policy. He was reappointed to the position 14 Nov. is, since you have means of modest livelihood independt, rather a pleasure to hear: but this of health—alas, alas! Could not the Victoria people be persuaded to send you as their “Agent“ hitherward?Colonies in Australia regularly sent agents to Britain to persuade people to emigrate, as Parkes was doing; see 37:253JWC to HP, 22 Oct. 1861. Anything that wd bring you home, how welcome were it to us! Or wd not your means, tho’ modest, enable you to live here, as well as at Melbourne? What a Book you might write on
that wild continent of things; what Books and Instructions;—how much good you might really do. If not loaded with nuggets, if only able to live as a poor man, so much the better, on my word. You promised to come home at any rate, and see us again. If you delay too long, some of us will not be discoverable here when you land expectant.Duffy replied, 20 July 1862: “You speak of my returning to Europe. It is my constant hope to do so—and when I am relieved from office I will probably make a visit of a year at all events, to what we still fondly call Home. I have now however six children, and one does not move so lightly or so rapidly as of old, with a suite like this. When the event will come that makes me free to travel I cannot foretell;—any time may be wondered probable from three months to three years.“ He and his family traveled back to Europe, April 1865, and stayed until Dec. 1866.— I write to beg for a Letter, at the greatest length you can afford, and witht loss of time, elucidating these and the cognate points, whh you need not doubt are at all times interesting to me.Duffy replied, 20 July 1862: “If I delayed answering your last letter it was waiting for the termination of a parliamentary session in which I believed I was accomplishing something; and during which, at all events, I lived like a man in a besieged town. It is now over, and I send you a pamphlet on the new Land Law … as a tangible witness of my preoccupation.“ For the debate on a new land law in New South Wales, see TC to HP, 19 Sept. 1862. Many people, as you may fancy, have criticised you to me; I answer always: “Yes, yes;—and of all the men I saw in Ireland, the two best, so far as I cd judge, were Lord George Hill,Lord George Hill (1801–79), improving landlord in Donegal, known to and admired by TC since 1849; see 24:73TC to JAC, 18 June 1849, 24:176–77TC to JWC, 5 Aug. 1849, and 253TC to ADV, 29 Sept. 1849. See also 34:4JWC to TC, 1 July 1858. and Charles Duffy, even he and that other!”—

By the Lex talionis [Law of retaliation] I have not the least right to a letter: but if you knew the case here, you wd completely drop that plea. It is a literal fact that I have not, for years past, any leisure at all; but have had to withdraw out of all society, and employ every available minute of my day (hardly four good hours to be had out of it, with never such thrift, in these sad circumstances!) for running a race, whh is too literally a flight from the Infernal Hunt, who are at my heels till I get out of that bad Prussian Busss. I ride daily,—have ridden on a Horse, whh I call “Fritz“ (an amiable, swift, loyal creature, now falling old) for 8 years past; I think, abt 24,000 miles or so, in quest “of health to go on with“;—and do not write the smallest Note if it can possibly be helped! This is true: and I will say no more of it; only let it serve you for an explanatn.—

figure.p: Thomas Carlyle, Fritz, and Frederic Chapman in Hyde Park, 2 August 1861

docBody.p:
In the course of next summer or autumn, I do now hope I shall be out of this unutterable quagmireTC did not finish Frederick until 1865. (dark to me as Erebus too often, & so long); and shall then have more leisure. Leisure to the end of the Chapter, as I intend! For I have for once got a complete bellyful of “work,“—curiously enough, reserved for me to finish off with—in my young
time I had no work that was not a mere flea-bite to this whh lay appointed for my old days.

It is only by accidt I have found time and spirit to write you so much. My intentn, unexecuted for weeks and months back, was only to send you the inclosed bad Photograph accompanied by a word or two, whh might stand as apology for a letter. I dare say you recognise the riding figure,tho’ he has little or no face allowed. The standing gentn is Fredc Chapman junr, of the Firm, a prosperous gentn who has dismounted from a horse do.Duffy replied, 20 July 1862: “[T]he photograph, welcome as it was, can only be considered as a striking likeness of your horse, hat and coat, the face having evaded the sun.“ For the photograph of Frederic Chapman, TC, and Fritz, taken in Hyde Park, 2 Aug., see above. For a photograph cropped to show only TC and Fritz (which Duffy reproduced; see Duffy 212), see 37:247TC to JCA, 17 Oct. 1861. There is a strange worth in indisputable certainty, however limited. I wish you wd send me such a sun-pictureA photograph. from Melbourne; it wd be very welcome here.

Will you give my affectionate regards to Mrs Callan:Margaret Callan, b. Hughes (ca. 1817–ca. 1883), Duffy’s wife’s sister; see 24:60TC to GCD, 29 May 1849; she emigrated to Australia with her husband, Dr. John B. Callan, Oct. 1856; see 32:46TC to MACA, 7 Dec. 1856. Parkes told me the Dr had got an honourable & profitable employt in his noble profession; whh I was very glad of. My Wife desires to be remembd; as do I kindly to Mrs D.Susan Duffy. of whom I have still an agreeable shadow left. Yours ever truly, T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A[LLA], [11 Nov.]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:402. Conjecturally dated between the Ashburtons’ return from Scotland, early Nov. (see TC to LOA, 10 Nov.) and JWC’s falling ill by 14 Nov. (see TC to JJR, 14 Nov.).
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Oh thanks—a thousand—for your darling letter!Lady Ashburton wrote a short note to JWC from The Grange, 7 Nov.: “I think we ought to try & meet oftener—life is too short … for us never to meet. … Dear friend I will soon write again.“ Possibly Lady Ashburton wrote another letter a day or two later. Most Dear and Most Good!

I am going now to Bath HouseFor a picture of Bath House, the Ashburtons’ London home, see 30:200JWC’s Journal, 22 Oct. 1855. But I shall not see you; you will not leave your native elementPossibly referring to Lady Ashburton’s family home, Brahan Castle in Ross-shire, where the Ashburtons had spent part of the autumn, but more probably Lady Ashburton was coming from The Grange, leaving her daughter behind, and thus reluctant to leave. Cf. an earlier use by JWC of the phrase “native element“ in “affection is the native element of my soul“ (3:410). till the last possible hour, I know! I am going however to leave a welcome for you; in the shape of a lovely Persian rug—really lovely! and which, I presume to think, may have a place granted it, in your new House (Micham? is it called?)Melchet Court, nr. Romsey, Hampshire, which belonged to Lord Ashburton’s brother Frederick, who had inherited it from their father. Since The Grange would revert to their brother Francis Baring if Lord Ashburton died without a male heir, Lord Ashburton had decided to buy Melchet Court for Lady Ashburton. And remind you sometimes of our existence “here down.“ (as Mazzini expresses it.)Coterie speech; see 17:33JWC to TC, 9 Aug. 1843.

Lord A may recollect a Captain Pelly—an Indian officer whom my Husband once took to Bath House.Lewis Pelly (1825–92; ODNB), officer in the Indian Army; he had met the Carlyles in 1858, when TC took him to dinner with Lord Ashburton; see 33:191–92TC to LP, 19 March 1858. This Capt Pelly was travelling in Persia last year, and made a small collection of carpets, and has sent them, as presents—to some of his Friends in England—and this one falls to our share; And you may see if we could do anything more suitable with it, than lay it at your dear feet!— It would be quite out of place in our own small rooms, and out of
harmony with our plain furniture.In 1860 Pelly served as secretary to the British Legation at Teheran, capital of Persia: “[I] was ordered to ride from [Teheran] to the Indian frontier, in view to reporting on the political condition of the intervening territories. I was at Herat [then in Persia, now in Afghanistan] … when the Persian army, beaten by the Turcomans, was retreating … and one’s head at times felt a little loose on one’s shoulders. … [I]t occurred to me that I was unaccountably calm and happy for an ordinary man who found himself a thousand miles away from any other European, and surrounded by excitable Asiatics. … On reflection, however, I attributed my mental condition to the influence of Carlyle. … The next morning I went into the bazaar and selected a finely woven camel’s-hair robe, and a small Persian prayer-carpet of exquisite colour and texture … for transmission to Cheyne Row“ (Lewis Pelly, “Glimpses of Carlyle,“ Fortnightly Review 51 [May 1892] 725–26). Despite JWC’s offer of the rug to Lady Ashburton, Pelly was later told that the carpet was first placed under TC’s writing-table, and then “taken by Carlyle, in a fit of tenderness, to the dressing-table of his wife.“ The robe was “turned into a sort of dressing-gown, and used by [TC] to the end of his life“ (Pelly 726). So in asking you to take it, one is asking a favour; asking you to give it a fitter place than we can give it, and a place where it will do us the good service of recalling us now and then to the mind of one we both love very dearly and have good cause “to“!
I shall try for a glimpse of you tomorrow.
docBody.name: J W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JJR, 14 Nov. MS: Yale. Pbd: Sanders, “Carlyle’s Letters to Ruskin“ 219; Cate 95.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN JAMES RUSKIN

docBody.p: I really am ashamed under your munificences as to cigars! I was still two Boxes strong; and here has another come today. All I can say is, you are very kind; and I return you many thanks the best I have. The Flowers also are praised as “superlative,“—tho’ my poor wife is not able to put them in their bottles herself today, as she wd otherwise have taken a half-holiday in doing. She has caught cold, in these inclemencies of weather; & keeps her room, and even her bed, all day.

It is a poor return for such kindnesses to say, what has been forcing itself upon me as too probable lately, that I actually must not venture on Sunday.John James Ruskin had invited TC to dinner, Sun., 17 Nov. (see 37:256TC to JJR, 29 Oct. 1861), and noted in his diary, 14 Nov.: “Carlyle was to dine with me. Bayne wanting to bring friends—spoil all“ (Cate 93); Bayne not further identified. This weather is of such a raging character;The Times reported, 15 Nov., “The heavy rain which fell incessantly throughout Wednesday was accompanied towards evening by another fearful gale.“ that bosom-friend (in the windpipe) still keeps such hold;TC had caught cold mid-Oct.; see 37:249TC to JAC, 17 Oct. 1861. the poor wife is so ill &c &c: in short, I will
postpone it till “the Prodigal“John Ruskin, who was in Switzerland. (so let us call him in figurative language) returns from his Swiss wanderings;—and then, I shall be seriously unwell, and things very perverse about me, if I fail! We had a Letter from Lucerne the other day;Ruskin wrote to the Carlyles from Lucerne, 7 Nov., “Two days before hearing from my father of Mr Carlyles kind little visit I had sent an underlined charge of gravest character, to let me know how you both were. I should have written myself, but was for a month after leaving home this last time, in a state of stupid depression which there was no use in giving any account of. I am now settled here, with a bright room, fire—and view of lake. I draw and paint a little every day. … I am gaining strength gradually;—and learning some Latin & Greek.“ Ruskin had suffered a crisis of faith; he wrote to his father, 29 Sept.: “It is a difficult thing to live without hope of another world, when one has been used to it for forty years. But by how much more difficult, by so much it makes one braver and stronger“ (E. T. Cook, The Life of John Ruskin [1911] 2:19). Ruskin had drafted but did not send a letter to the Carlyles, 30 Oct.: “I have been in no heart to write—nothing seemed right and it was useless to tell you things were all wrong“ (V. Surtees, ed., Reflections of a Friendship: John Ruskin’s Letters to Pauline Trevelyan, 1848–1866 [1979] 179). very kind and pleasant, shadowing out a hermit-life among the Mountains yonder,—solitary affectionate, not without a trace of sadness, but wholesome, diligent, and leading towards good that I foresee. So soon as he returns—!—
Believe me always, Dear Sir,
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC: Testimonial for Gerald Massey, 23 Nov. MS: Western Manuscripts Collection, National Lib. of Russia, St. Petersburg. Pbd: Unpublished Letters of Foreign Writers of the 18th and 19th Centuries from Leningrad Manuscript Collections, ed. M. P. Alekseev (Moscow and Leningrad, 1960) 318; Archives of the Royal Literary Fund 1790–1918 (1982–83) file no. 1581. The testimonial was written in support of Gerald Massey’s application for a civil list pension.
div3.head: TC“S TESTIMONIAL FOR GERALD MASSEY

docBody.p:
Judging from all I have credibly heard of Mr Gerald Massey,Gerald Massey (1828–1907; ODNB), impoverished poet, writer, and Christian Socialist. “By November [Massey] had, on the advice of friends, decided to make an application to be placed on the Civil Service Pensions List, despite his disinclination to appeal to Viscount Palmerston, then Prime Minister. … This involved asking persons of influence who knew him, his work and circumstances, to write testimonials on his behalf as being a proper subject for consideration“; testimonials were also supplied by, among others, Ruskin, Thackeray, Browning, and Tennyson; see David Shaw, Gerald Massey: Chartist, Poet, Radical and Freethinker (1995) 105. Massey also applied to the Royal Literary Fund and they awarded him £50, 10 Jan. 1862. He was awarded a civil list pension, June 1863, of £70 a year. as well as from reading some of his Books,Massey sent TC a copy of his poems on the Crimean War, War Waits (1855); see 29:275–76TC to GM, 23 March 1855. Massey’s third book of poems, The Ballad of Babe Christabel and other Poems (1854), was highly acclaimed. His Poetical Works (1861) included a memoir by Samuel Smiles (1812–1904; ODNB). I should consider him as a fit participant in the
Public Fund set apart by the Country for behoof of meritorious Literary Men who are in straightened economic circumstances.

5. Gt Cheyne Row, Chelsea
23 Nov. 1861

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 23 Nov. MS: NLS 525.84. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Here has a Letter come for you,TC probably meant to write “from.“ John A. Carlyle visited Cheyne Row 5–14 Oct. (see 37:249TC to JAC, 7 Nov. 1861) and was now back in Edinburgh. last night; but I still have not the least leisure to answer what you wrote, or send you any news,—except, happily, that there is nothing far wrong with us.

I am just in the act of emerging from Book XV;“The Second Silesian War … 1744–45,“ to be pbd. in vol. 4 of Frederick (1864); see Works 16:1–193. For details of the vol. divisions in the first edn. of Frederick, see Volume Divisions of Frederick. the ugliest puddle, I do think, that has ever yet been. It was written years ago; and NeubergJoseph Neuberg. had it, 3 times over, with commission to copy fair the promising passages; after whh I wd have burnt the rest. Unhappily poor Ng wd never do his bidding; drew up tables of contents &c,—and thrice over, returned me the thing nearly as it was: “Will quite do,“ said he.—“Do!” I had to send it to the PrinterCharles Robson. at last, with altogether hurried, visibly imperfect revisn of my own:—and here it has at last been upon me! Horrors of drossy incoherency;—in fact, the whole story as my chaotic Prussians give it, after never such reading, is intrinsically like a mass of mere slag, the size of a waggon; which you have to hammer down (if you can) into metal, the size of a pint. God be thanked it is now done taliter qualiter [for better or worse] (mostly fit for going into pages); and will not trouble me more, never, thro’ Eternity I hopope!Thus in MS.— — I fancy there is no such bad Piece ahead; but, alas, one always fancies that.

I keep tolerably well, in spite of the weather; we have had deluges of rain; glassy frost too (whh, as a rider, I like worst of all);—today again it is raining so that I cannot ride; and again muddy-warm.

Poor Jane has taken cold; tried to stave it off: but has been persuaded to send for BarnesDr. Alfred Barnes. yesterday. She is by no means what we call very ill; and I
hope will fling the thing off altogether before long. She sleeps ill; is feckless feverish; but keeps up her heart always. Nothing else is in the least wrong with us. I sent you a Watts Booklet,Possibly John Watts (ca. 1824–66), socialist and freethinker, The Origin of Man (1861); more probably Thomas Watts (1811–69; ODNB), librarian at the British Museum, A Sketch of the History of the Welsh Language and Literature (1861). Thomas Watts had been known to TC since the late 1840s (see 32:122TC to TW, 8 April 1857) and was also known to John A. Carlyle.—scarcely more than worth reading;—give it away to somebody.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle
docBody.note: John A. Carlyle sent news about three of his stepsons to James Carlyle Jr., 29 Nov.: “Henry Watt calls every evening. He has got more sense now, & keeps his hands full of occupations manifold from day to day. Arthur too calls once or twice weekly, & is very diligent in preparing for his next examination. Willie, from whom I have a good little letter today, is in hospital at Woolwich with a cold; & he has got out of that row without accident of any sort. ‘Ten corporals’ were rusticated by the decision of the commander in chief last Saturday“ (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). For William Watt’s more serious trouble at Woolwich, see TC to JAC, 3 May 1862.

div3.sourceNote: TC-AG[AGIL], [ca. 24 Nov.]. MS: Univ. of California, Santa Cruz. Hitherto unpbd. Dated during JWC’s illness and by the scarlet fever in the Gilchrist household; see JWC to AGIL, 25 Oct. 1861. Alexander Gilchrist fell ill 24 Nov.; see TC to JAC, 1 Dec.
div3.head: TC TO ANNE GILCHRIST

docBody.p: Dear Mrs. Gilchrist,—It will be a satisfaction, and relief to my own feelings, to come. I surely will.Geraldine Jewsbury wrote to Walter Mantell, 23 Dec.: “a terrible domestic affliction wh altho’ it concerned the people next door [caused] a good deal of bother—fancy them desiring Mr Carlyle to go for the doctor at 12 o’clock at night“ (MS: Mantell). For another report of TC being asked to go for a doctor during the night, see TC to JAC, 1 Dec.

My Wife has been quite weak, ill, and in bed, ever since Saturday;JWC had been ill since before Wed., 14 Nov.; see TC to JJR, 14 Nov. TC probably referred to Sat., 9 or 16 Nov. she bids me tell you so, and what a regret it is to her that she can help you in no respect, tho’ thinking of you every minute of the day.— God be merciful and helpful to us all!—
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JJR, 30 Nov. MS: Yale. Pbd: Sanders, “Carlyle’s Letters to Ruskin” 219; Cate 97–98.
div3.head:
TC
TO JOHN JAMES RUSKIN

figure.p: John Ruskin, engraving by Francis Holl, from a portrait by George Richmond
Selections from the Writings of John Ruskin (1861)

docBody.p:
My Wife continues room-fast, sometimes bed-fast (whh she does not easily consent to be); but is never yet what we can call very ill. There has been a sad tragedy next door to us (a poor Mr Gilchrist, a young literary man; one of hischildren took scarlet-fever, the mother wd not send it away, others of them
took it; and within 5 days illness, the Head of the House is himself lying dead of the disorder);Alexander Gilchrist d. during the night of 29–30 Nov. this of course has been an agitating circumstance on our side of the wall, and has done my own poor Patient a sensible mischief. I believe yr last flask of perfect BrandyJohn James Ruskin was a wine merchant and regularly sent TC gifts of spirits; see 37:138 TC to JJR, 27 March 1861
. (let that be yr thanks for it) went across to poor Gilchrist as medicine, I do not think a nobler use cd have been made of it, tho’ it proved unavailing.— We had another Letter from Switzerld, with nothing but cheery news.Ruskin wrote to JWC, 24 Nov.: “No, I can’t come home yet. There’s a difference I assure you—not small,—between dead leaves in London Fog—and living rocks, and waters, and clouds—I never saw anything as entirely and solemnly divine as the calm winter days are here. … It is like the loveliest summer’s morning at five o’clock—all day long. … I’m better than I was, a good deal. … It would be good for you both to come here to finish Frederick—you would have no influenza—and Mr Carlyle might enjoy his pipe in peace.” Send my best regards when you write.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-AG[AGIL], [30 Nov.]. MS: UCLA. Pbd: Gilchrist 100. Dated by Alexander Gilchrist’s death during the night of 29–30 Nov. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 30 November 1861.]
div3.head: JWC TO ANNE GILCHRIST

docBody.p: Oh God help you, poor afflicted Soul!— What can any human being say to comfort you? Nothing— Nothing!

But is there anything I can do? or Mr C do? Can I write any letters for you?— You would only need to give me the addresses. Can I send any where? Get anything?— Have you money at hand? Oh do use me in some way!—affly yours / J W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAF, [ca. late Nov.]. Pbd: Froude, Carlyle 4:244 inc. Dated after Arthur Clough’s death, 13 Nov., at Florence. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 30 November 1861.]
div3.head: TC TO JAMES ANTHONY FROUDE

docBody.p:
I quite agree in what you say of poor Clough.Blanche Clough wrote, 15 Nov.: “He has been gradually going down hill for two years past, but I never feared anything so rapid as this. It has been very lonely being so far away from home—he has indeed not been home since last July, but from the first he was too ill and too fatigued I think to feel this much.
