And yet he was writing [“composing“ written above] verses perpetually during the first fortnight & struggling afterwards to write themdown It seemed as if all he had been collecting during the past year had suddenly taken a form. … Nothing is finished alas. It is very bitter to me to feel that he has passed away & left almost nothing behind—that so many years of his life have been spent in cutting blocks with a razor—that is making bread for us. … I should very much like some future time to bring to you his little boy—he is very like him externally—as near as 2 can be to 42.“ A man more vivid, ingenious, veracious, mildly radiant, I have seldom met with, and in a character so
honest, modest, kindly. I expected very considerable things of him. As for the ‘two pages’ you propose, there could, had my hands been loose, have been no valid objections, but, as it is, my hands are tied.Froude was appointed editor of Fraser’s Magazine by John William Parker after the death of his son and partner, John William Parker (1820–60; see 31:[2]5631:biographical note). “I knew what Carlyle felt about [Clough], and I tried to induce him to write some few words which might give that memory an enduring form,“ but, Froude noted, “[e]very available moment had been guaranteed to ‘Frederick’“ (Froude, Carlyle 4:244).

div3.sourceNote: JWC-AG[AGIL], [ca. early Dec.]. MS: Pierpont Morgan Lib. Pbd: Gilchrist 103. Conjecturally dated by Alexander Gilchrist’s death and JWC’s illness. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 1 December 1861.]
div3.head: JWC TO ANNE GILCHRIST

docBody.p: My dear friend—Will you be brave and good—and come to me? You might wait till after dark—when you would only have to throw a shawl over your head—and I would send you the latch key, and you could let yourself in, and come straight up to my bedroom without having to see or speak to anybody. I have been on the Drawingroom sofa most part of the last two days— I am much better—and please God shall soon be able to go to you— I mean to ask Mr Barnes if I may go out in a carriage tomorrow—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 1 Dec. MS: NLS 525.85. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: This is Sunday, the one bright dry day we have had since Sunday last,—such a week of mud and pluister as I have seldom seen, and many things going wrong rather than right! I am keeping this day strictly as a holiday; having sat all week futilely trying continually at my new “Book XVI,““Ten Years of Peace“; see Works 16:194–410.—till, last night, I pretty nearly (but not quite) missed my sleep upon it; and so have determined that there shall be a pause absolute. I already think my way is clearer; and that next week will not be so frustrated as this has sorrowfully been. Before going out, I write you one word on matters that have fallen out.

Poor Gilchrist! I have seldom been near such a tragedy. Saturday night gone a week he knocked at our door, but did not come in, somebody being here: one of his children had scarlet-fever tho it seemed nearly well: next day (this day week), Gt himself felt ill, had himself taken the fever; and on Friday, deep in the night, he breathed his last! Such a scene of confusion (servants too falling sick, other children do) as seemed to be in that House filled one with pity and misery. The poor wife had entirely refused the Dr Barnes’s advice to send away that first child;Beatrice; see 37:254JWC to AGIL, 25 Oct. quarrelled with Barnes (in fact, turned him off), and did other unwise things; and is now in such a mood as the cruellest might pity. Poor Jane (mostly on the sofa) did & strove what was possible; her maidsMargaret Sullivan and Maria Chamberlayne. running about continually on errands that came across, or that she herself devised;—and, in fact, I think but for her poor head the Gilchrist House must have gone mad altogether.Sarah Dilberoglue wrote to Charlotte Cushman, 15 Dec.: “[T]he grand old man has had a great deal of unfitting work lately such as being called up in the night to seek a doctor for a dying neighbour—a Mr Gilchrist … who did die and then going to a dreary common-place funeral—to him one of the most horrible things under the sun,—to gratify a poor, distracted widow,—and doing, along with Mrs Carlyle, all sorts of neighbourly kindnesses“ (Charlotte Cushman Papers, LC). Charlotte Cushman wrote to JWC, 16 Nov., sending the letter via Sarah Dilberoglue: “To hear of Cheyne Row through Barnsbury Park is very dear to me—but I want more. … I hear of you & your sayings—for my little friend is clever & knows how to fill her letter acceptably in all ways. I send her this letter to give to you in gratitude, for it will please her.“ Cushman described her response to JWC enthusiastically: “I cannot write to you. I love you but I fear you & my soul blushes as I recognise the fear within the fear that it may be more my self love which fears you than my heart. You are so wonderful to me. I think of you ever—and of all that you said & did on that first & only day I saw you when a new heaven & a new earth was revealed to me. I remember all your looks_all your tones—all your unchecked flow of marvellously fitting words—all your far seeings all your subtle fancies—your facile dissections—your graphic description—your inimitable behaviour—your perfect knowledge of, & yet indifference to, what you were doing—your self possession—your evident indwelling sense of power to have and to hold—even that which was ridiculous to you through its unfitness—& the indomitable frankness with which you held it up to my view—all, all, all are stamped upon my memory—with an electric fire which burns me yet! I find you marvellous! … . There is but one of you, none other in the world like you! I cannot hope to speak or think or write like you. Why should I consider myself. Why should I not minister in my own poor way? Because—I want your consideration I want your respect—I want your care for me—your thoughts of me to be as good as my admiration of you & I fear to lose all through my desire to possess all. But I cannot bear not to hear from you.“ Of course, it has done her no little harm (sleep quite gone for the last 2 nights, &c &c): but what is that to the tragedy itself (other side the wall), of whh all this is but the reflex!— Her cold is never very ill; I hope to send better news next time.

I noticed yr announcet of poor Miss Elliot’s death,Charlotte Elliot (ca. 1785–1861), companion to Elizabeth, Lady Clare (1793–1879), when John A. Carlyle was her physician in the 1830s; see 5:343TC to AC, 1 Aug. 1831, and 12:213TC to MAC, 1 Aug. 1840. “John grew friendly with … Miss Elliot, often horse-riding and walking with her in the moonlight,“ according to Malcolm Ingram; he also notes that she was “one of two young nieces“ with Lady Clare (M. Ingram, “Dr John Aitken Carlyle: Travelling Physician,“ Carlyle Society Papers n.s. 19 Edinburgh, [2006] 25). Recorded by the Times (8 Nov.) as in her “76th year“ when she died in Ryde, Isle of Wight (where Lady Clare also lived), therefore older than Lady Clare, it seems unlikely that she was a niece, and more probable that she was appointed as a respectable lady companion. tho’ I said nothing in answer. The same of your £300 to Ernhirst (Eagle-wood);Ernhirst or Ironhirst, a farm halfway between The Gill and Dumfries, which their niece Margaret Austin and her husband, Thomas Stewart, wanted to rent; they were living there by Aug. 1862; see JWC to TC, [29 Aug.]. John A. Carlyle wrote to Mary Austin, 11 Nov.: “I now enclose a £50 cheque for Mr Stewart. … He can have the remaining £200, which I offered to lend him, whenever he chooses the sooner the better I should say. Of course he will understand that I shall look for strict repayment of the whole whenever he is able to repay it; & I should say about £10 a year for the £250 would be fair interest. I am glad he has got the farm to himself. He seems to me a clear-headed, skilful, diligent young man & is likely to do well. Only I hope he has entirely separated his affairs from those of his brothers & mother, & is his own master in all respects“ (MS: NLS Acc. 9086); for his three brothers and their partnership in Hollybush Farm, see 35:230TC to SGSOUC, 8 Oct. 1859; see also 37:246TC to JCA, 17 Oct. 1861. Rental periods often began at Martinmas, 11 Nov.; see 37:237TC to JAC, 24 Sept. 1861. In Old English “earn“ means eagle, and “hirst“ means copse or wooded hilly ground. whh, whether it be “a good investt“ in the Threadneedle-streetLocation of the Bank of England. sense or not, I perceive to be beyond question verily such in a far truer sense. A thing it gives me pleasure to hear of; and will give you real satisfactn to have done. The CourantEdinburgh Evening Courant, edited 1860–64 by James Hannay (1827–73; ODNB), author and journalist; see 37:94TC to JAHA, 13 Jan. was, as you may have guessed, quite new to us: I remember the locality very well; and pictured to myself what a catastrophe.A tenement building on the High St., Edinburgh, collapsed during the early morning of 24 Nov. Edinburgh Evening Courant reported, 25 Nov.: “An immense, tall and thickly populated tenement … suddenly gave way, fell inwards in a quick series of crashes, floor carrying down floor, and in a few moments buried the unwarned inmates in the ruins. … The building being not less than sixty feet square, and consisting of at least five habitable floors, accommodated probably thirty families and had a population which cannot be estimated at less than a hundred persons. … The terrible event occurred … at an hour when nearly all the inmates were doubtless asleep in bed. … Of their dreadful fall the doomed had evidently no warning, and in many cases they may have been utterly insensible of the descent of death upon them.“ Thirty-five people died. The Illustrated London News, 7 Dec., carried a full-page illustration of the rescue operation; see oppabove. That poor little Boy, “Heave away, men; A’m no dead yet!”One of the last people to be rescued alive was a boy, believed to be 12-year-old Joseph M’Giver or McIver, “who was heard to encourage those toiling in his behalf by calling out ‘Heave away, men; I’m no deed yet’“ (Courant 25 Nov.). Both boy and his saying (slightly anglicized) are commemorated above the entryway to Paisley Close, High St., Edinburgh; see oppabove. sticks fast with us both, & will!—Adieu, dear Brother: I must not wait longer. Yours ever T.C.

figure.p: “The Fall of a House in High-Street, Edinburgh: Searching for the Dead and Wounded by Torchlight“
Commemorative carving, Paisley Close, Edinburgh

div3.sourceNote: JWC-AG[AGIL], [6 Dec.]. MS: Yale. Pbd: Gilchrist 106–7 inc., where dated 7 Dec. Fri. was 6 Dec.
div3.head: JWC TO ANNE GILCHRIST

docBody.p: I was glad and thankful to get your letter this morning. I knew thro’ the nurseUnidentified. that the little BoyHerbert, the Gilchrists’ younger son. was going on favourably; but I needed some token from yourself, that you were not dwelling quite shut up within the black circle of your own great sorrow; without a thought for any thing beyond it, or any of us who care for you, and sympathize with you so sincerely!

It is a strange thing to say; but I was glad when I heard your little Boy had taken the fever, and that you had gone off to him!Herbert had been sent to Anne Gilchrist’s mother, Henrietta Burrows, at Earls Colne in Essex. “No sooner was the funeral over, than scarlet fever attacked the younger son, who, some few days prior to taking it, had been conveyed to Colne“ (Gilchrist 106). I felt sure—perhaps because so much had been taken from you already—that he would be spared; and in the meantime, the anxiety on his account would recall you to a sense of what you had still left—to lose! And the very movement, and change of scene, and of air would rouse you out of that blackness of despair in which your last lines to me were written, poor dear Soul!
Things seem to go on very well in your house. That nurse, from all my girlsJWC’s maids, Margaret and Maria. say of her, seems to be a most anxious painstaking woman.

I have had good accounts of the children every day. Only yesterday PercyPercy Gilchrist, the eldest child and elder son. had a little sickness, the nurse thought “from the heartiness of his appetite“—and a pill in the form of powder would put him all to rights. I sent in this evening to ask if she wished any thing told you as I was going to write and she said she had already mentioned everything to Mrs IrelandIsabella Ireland. who would write.

AnneAnne, the Gilchrists’ maid. has been much better the last two days. it was announced to me quite radiantly by Maria that “Anne had eaten a chop!”— The nurse thinks that “by next week Anne will be quite up to her work.“

For myself, I am quite recovered from my nervous attack, can sleep some and eat some, but the weakness and restlessness it has left behind are most depressing. I have been twice out in a fly the first time I slept most of the way,
and was much worse for it but the last time (yesterday) it procured me a better night than I had had for six weeks.
I do hope you will tell me if there be anything you want done, that I can do, either directly or indirectly
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-EF, 7 Dec. Pbd: John Glyde, The Life of Edward FitzGerald (1900) 232–35.
div3.head: TC TO EDWARD FITZGERALD

docBody.p: Dear Fitz-Gerald,—What a time since we have seen you! And still it is no visit, it is only the arrival of half-yearly noteFitzGerald wrote from Woodbridge in Suffolk, 5 Dec.: “I hope you won’t be bored with another of my half-yearly Enquiries after yourself and Mrs. Carlyle. You can just tell me how you both are: where you have been this Summer: and how you are getting on with your Frederick now you yourself are got, as I suppose, into Winter Quarters.“—better than quite nothing.

We did not quit town at all this year: the wife ran to Ramsgate with a lady
friend, to taste the sea airwas delighted with the sea air, but like to be driven mad by the brass bands, bagpipes, Ethiopians, hawkers, and perpetual ragings of foul …Ellipses by TC or publisher; “foul“ possibly a misreading for “fowl“; for JWC’s description of the noise at Ramsgate, including “hundreds of cocks,“ see 37:201JWC to TC, 6 Aug. 1861. (not to mention the nasty fat Jews and fat-bellied Cockneys), and came home in a week. I sit here under an awning, and the shadow of the back wall, obstinately bungling along at this unblessed task of mine—and might as well have flung it aside, for my rate of “progress“ was frightful. We went in September for about ten days into Windsor Forest; some goodish galloping I had in the noble Park there (though under lumbago, etc.), and that was all the rustication vouchsafed to us this year.

I am now really pretty well in health considering the years I count and the drudgery I have to stick to—if I could get done with the latter, I should really be tolerably off. But alas, the goal is still far away, and sad muddy pilgrimage, and months more than I like to reckon, are loaded with chagrin, disgust, and almost despair, before the deliverance can come. In the mean time I continue buried; see nobody (go to see absolutely nobody), toil and struggle all hours of the day, with whatever strength is left me, towards this as the one good still possible for me. With a kind of indignation for most part (for myself among other people), which, as it is all silent, does the less ill. In truth, “this ten years among the Prussian pots“ has made me very grimy, and humiliated me to the very marrow of the bone. I was computing lately, in one of my rides, that I must have ridden (upon my excellent horse Fritz, who is now waxing old as doth a garment) something like 20,000 miles,—nineteenth-twentieths of it or more in solitude, since I began this hateful adventure!

My poor wife is but weakly, has had a tedious cold, etc., but is now getting better. Are you never to see London again, and us again? You have still that stone to set up on Naseby Moor, remember!FitzGerald had owned land at Naseby; he and TC had discussed setting up a memorial on the battlefield (see 30:40–42TC to EF, 23 Aug. 1855), but the plan was never implemented. It was indeed a miserable oversight not to go on to Edinburgh when so near it.FitzGerald wrote: “I went to Berwick-on-Tweed in a sailing Schooner, just for the sake of the Sail: and was within two hours’ Rail of Edinburgh, which I had never seen, and always wished to see; but, like a great Ass, didn’t go to see when all so near: but ran home again.“ Courage! I will drag you there some day myself. Adieu, dear F.— Yours ever, / T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 7 Dec. MS: NLS 517.30. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
Dear Jean,—Excuse my brevity; never was such hurry! But you ought to be apprised that yr Parcel arrived two nights ago: all safe;—and all right, I do
believe, tho’ truly I have not yet had time to try anything (if it be not one of the 2 excellt Sponges), otherwise than by eyesight! The black waistcoats will suit nicely; the black trowsers too will not be lost,—tho’ they a little disagree with the colours I now have in my coats. I have 7 pairs of woollen trowsers; and can wait!For the sponges and trousers, see 37:248TC to JCA, 17 Oct. 1861. Thanks for the socks, too, and the muffetees.Muffetees were fingerless mittens, or wrist warmers. You have been most industrious and assiduous.— Send me now an acct of the monies, all accurately summed up pat,—that I may at least pay that part of the debt.TC sent a check: “16 decr 1861 / To Jean (Tailor things / £6..19..0“ (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753).

Jane has been very weak and poorly; a great deal of foreign shaking and excitement came thro’ the wall to her from our unfortunate next neighbours (good people, and great adherents of ours), who got Scarlet fever in the House,—and the Head of it, in five days, died of it. Alas, alas!— That is all sadly settled now. And Jane is visibly getting better. Not a word more!— Yours ever affectionate
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-KS[KST], 7 Dec. MS: NLS 1797.52. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO [KATE STANLEY]

docBody.p: I am not up to writing you an answer according to your deserts—that were difficult at any time; but especially out of the question at present! I have been ill—very—for a month; confined to my room all that time and latterly to my bed—prohibited from all use of my brain which had become “dangerously excited“—poor Brain! no wonder! The last three days I have been on the Drawingroom sofa, and am much better. But oh so completely stupified with all the mush and ‘calming’ medicines I have taken into me, that a “Bright young Being,“See 36:214JWC to LST, 30 Aug. 1860; cf. G. M. Sterne, Tales for an English Home (1833) 277. of your seraphic sort, cannot form the least idea of it!
Please god I will write you a letter long enough, at all rates, so soon as I have my wits again!

Meanwhile bless your little heart for the offer of the white dog! all the same as if I accepted it! but that I mustnt do— There are three reasons why I mustn’t (women have never less than three reasons you know) First I place my romantic (if you like) constancy to my dear little dead Nero.JWC’s dog, Nero, was put down 1 Feb. 1860; see 36:56TC to JN, 3 Feb. 1860. I shouldn’t like to see a new dog in his place!—else where I still like dogs, and like to play with them—but a new dog occupying his place on the hearthrug or sofa
would pain me! the little grave at the top of the garden, the little portrait of him in my broochFor an illustration of the brooch, see 36:61TC to JN, 7 Feb. 1860.—would be desecrated for me by a successor.

Second reason; I believe Mr C couldn’t be brought to tolerate a new dog!— He suffered so much thro’ that other in various ways! the worst way of all being grief at his death!See 36:67JWC to LLA, 12 Feb. 1860. and at thoughts of him since!!! Verily we are people of very persistent affections in this house! Third reason is the dogs own happiness! I never would have a dog unless I could keep it in health and bodily comfort—which no dog can be without plenty of exercise — Nero had plenty always I was a capital walker in his time, and took regular long walks for that little creatures sake. But now I am so often confined for months together and seldom walk at all. What would become of a little white dog’s degestion in these circumstances? It would blow out and get puffy, and be a constant wheezing reproach to me for keeping it!—
and now my Darling I am tired to death; with just this much ugly writing. But most faithfully yours Jane Carlyle

I think some game must have come to us from Alderly?The Stanleys’ estate in Cheshire. Kate Stanley replied, [ca. 20 Dec.]: “I was so very sorry to hear of your having been so ill & I hope by this time you have got stronger so as to be able to enjoy your Christmas not that it can be a very merry to anyone with such a mournful prospect as war with America / Mama and Maude are just come back from London where they went just to see Johnny off. We had no time to see him as they started a week after their orders came. … We are very sorry not to have him as we had been looking forward to this Christmas together all the time he was in India.“ She reported that they had been decorating the church, but because of Prince Albert’s death (14 Dec.), there was to be no tenants’ ball; “One person coming here yr enemy W. Oliphant come back alive from Japan. the impostor when he led us to believe he was going for good he is like a bad shilling are you not uneasy at his coming here.“ Laurence Oliphant (1829–88; ODNB), first sec. of the legation in Japan, arrived there late June 1861; on 5 July the embassy was attacked and he was badly wounded and sent home. He had been in England intermittently 1859–61; perhaps JWC met him or he was discussed during her visit to the Stanleys, Aug. 1860. There was nothing to declare whence it came, a basket of game, but I dont know who else would have sent it by that rail way.

div3.sourceNote: TC-UC, 12 Dec. MS Copy: University of Bergen Lib., Norway. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT

docBody.p:
I am sorry to answer, on behalf of my poor wife, that what you so kindly propose is not possible, whh otherwise wd have been so agreeable to both of us! She is evidently on the mending hand,—after a week’s confinement
to bed day and night;—but is so utterly weak the Doctor prohibits all talking and being talked to as quite a specific enemy.Sarah Dilberoglue apparently continued to visit JWC throughout the illness. She reported to Cushman, 15 Dec.: “The note for Mrs Carlyle … came, at a good time; she was confined to her room by illness, and it was quite comforting to her to receive it, indeed. She has been ill for more than a month & during part of the time in her bed so I have felt it right to keep going over to her. She was on the sofa when I saw her on Friday [13 Dec.], but looking a mere shadow. She has trusted me to tell you this that you may understand why she has not written to you—it takes more strength than she has, just to think of what must be daily attended to with her home & her husband[.] She desired her best love to you and promises as soon as her brain feels capable of thinking you a letter, to send you one. I have le[f]t her mine to read. [TC] came to ask his wife when he was going out to ride if he might order her some … jelly. … he was told ‘yes’—but some alterations must be made in it. He took his instructions very carefully, had them repeated over twice—looking all the time with his old wiseman face & figure, so grandly fit for this task he was undertaking—but he was so anxious, and so tender, and so childlike in being taught what he must do, it was something to see. Well, went and in about a quarter of an hour the maid came into the room to say that Master had turned back, not feeling quite sure about his message, would Mrs Carlyle tell it him again? So with a quiet [de]preciating patience, she went through it to the maid, and I heard when I went the other day the jelly had been ordered all right“ (Charlotte Cushman Papers, LC). For Cushman’s previous letter to JWC, 16 Nov., see TC to JAC, 1 Dec.
Believe me
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-EF[EFO], [19 Dec.]. Addr: Montague Square / Hyde Park. PM: London, 19 Dec. 1861. MS: NLS 1797.54. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO ELIZA FORSTER

docBody.p: I am so afraid you wont come again till you are entreated to!

It was too vexatious your being at the door the other day, and my not seeing you; when I had seen nobody for many days that I liked as well! But one never knows what is to happen to one with servants of no long standing about the House!Margaret and Maria had been with the Carlyles since the summer; see 37:163–64JWC to JGCO, 7 May, and 37:189TC to JAC, 20 July. They either doggedly adhere to the general orders given them: and so make the most provoking blunders; or they use their own discretion exactly in the wrong place—and blunder more provokingly still!
Please do come again!
I have been out in a Fly to day, and am every day feeling a little stronger.
I have lots of things to tell you.

And I have one thing to tell your Husband.John Forster. He promised me in the summer a pistol shot portraitA pistolgram was a new kind of instantaneous photograph, using a “pistolgraph“ camera invented by Thomas Skaife (1806–76), so called because it was similar in size and shape to a pistol and manipulated by means of a trigger. of him, like the one you have. and that promise has never been fulfilled! When is he thinking of fulfilling it?—for that he is thinking rather of shirking his promise, I esteem him too highly to believe! Be so kind as suggest to him that the new year is a particularly appropriate season for little “delicate attentions“Coterie speech; see 34:50JWC to TC, 16 July 1858. among friends! and a pistol shot likeness of his well beloved face would be the most acceptable of all delicate attentions to your and his
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-AC[ACH], [ca. 25 Dec.]. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd. Ann Chamberlayne was employed by the Ashburtons at The Grange. Dated by reference to gifts.
div3.head: JWC TO ANN CHAMBERLAYNE

docBody.p: I cannot tell you how it went to my heart when Maria came up to the Drawingroom yesterday, carrying a tray piled with her own boots and little presents, and the cake and the ketchup &c &c for me! her face perfectly radiant with good-child happiness!— With the memory of my own good Mother ever fresh in my mind,Grace Welsh had d. 25 Feb. 1842; see 14:27–28JWC to JOST, 27 Jan. 1842. I could enter so profoundly into her feelings —(happy girl who has still a Mother to care for her, and send her tokens of Motherly love!)—and could see in the contents of your parcel, spread out there so proudly, a more interesting, more beautiful sight, than I should have seen in a trayful of the finest diamonds, unsanctified by Mother-love!
I am often telling Maria how thankful she should be for her good Mother; not that I think she needs any telling—but as a sort of spoken sigh over the loss of my own Mother.

I have nothing but the most gratifying things to tell you of Maria. She does what ever is required of her willingly and well—and her conduct, I needn’t tell you, who know her, is excellent— But she is more than a satisfactory servant to me—she is an intelligent, agreeable companion, and tho’ I am slow in making friendships I already feel towards her as a friend. My Husband also shows more interest in Maria, than I ever saw him take in any servant we have had in England!— For the rest; I think she agrees with the place; she certainly
looks stouter than when she came; and, except a cold for a few days, she has never owned to any illness—

I have been confined to the Drawingroom for nearly three weeks with a bad cold myself—which I am very liable to in winter weather—and last night I missed my sleep entirely—so my head at this moment feels much as it if were full of wool—which is not a good sort of head for writing with—but I wouldn’t let a day pass without thanking you for your kind gifts—

I hope to see you face to face, if we go to the Grange this winter—as is probable—if my health mend enoughLord Ashburton wrote to TC from The Grange, 22 Dec.: “Babe is restored. Lou is well, & I am just recovering without having taken any allopathic drugs from a somewhat tempestuous fit of gout. That means that it had more of the vigor of a strong mans gout than it has of late been in the habit of honoring me with. So I have just to throw off the enemy, without those troublesome accounts with those we have called in to help, generally the worst enemies of the two. // I really am in great spirits about myself, a rather new phase, I can tell you. … // I can not say with what increasing interest I have swept through Frederic. You have preserved the minutest details that could give life & colour, & there is not a word one could omit. We shall receive you & Mrs C whenever it suit you.“ JWC was forced to cancel her intended visit to The Grange because of ill health, and TC went alone late Jan. 1862.—
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MW, [26 Dec.]. Addr: Auchtertool Manse / Kircaldy / N.B. PM: London, 27 Dec. 1861; Kirkcaldy, 28 Dec. 1861. MS: NLS 607.584. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MARGARET WELSH

docBody.p: One line, dearest Maggie, under a pressure of letters to be written that is taking away my breath! One line just to put you and MaryMary Welsh, Margaret’s sister. at ease about your parcels. There have been so many, “felonies by Postmen“ in the Newspapers lately,The Times reported two cases of mail being stolen, one letter including a half-sovereign, the other two half-sovereigns: “Samuel Raw, 20, letter carrier“ and “Edward McLaren, 18, a respectable-looking young man“ (28 Nov., 20 Dec.). They were both sentenced to four years’ penal servitude. that, nobody should be kept a minute longer than is necessary, in doubt whether a felony have been perpetrated on his or her individual parcel!

The two twin looking parcels were the first thing my eyes lighted on this morning, when the shutters were opened preparatory to eating my breakfast. (I still breakfast in bed you see!) Maria had them on her arms like very small Babes of the wood!— You may fancy if my tea was drunk this morning quite at the boiling point (as Mr C recommends)!— There never was such a hit as
those sleeves! The very thing I was most in want of, and not at all seeing any prospect of getting! Just before I fell ill, I had a black silk waistcoat made at Nicol’s the eminent tailors.Isabella and Elizabeth Nicol, dressmakers, 103 New Bond St. But black silk sleeves were indispensable, for making any use of it in winter weather. And as it cost more than I had anticipated I was bound to make use of it! and it was going to come in “neat and appropriate“Cf. 36:214JWC to LST, 30 Aug. 1860. at the present mourning crisis!Prince Albert d. 14 Dec. If only it had sleeves! I knew of no shop where they were to be bought of plain silk to match the waistcoat! so I decided to buy a piece of silk and set Maria to make them. But then the buying of the silk was an enterprise beyond my poor strength. I have been out in a Fly. And drove straight to—of all places in the world—Madame Elise’sMadame Elise, milliner, 170 Regent St., the commercial name of Elizabeth Marie Louise Delepine (d. 1913); see 36:36TC to JN, 4 Jan. 1860.—!!! but a black morning gown was essential—indispensable for the visit I hope to make at the Grange as soon as I am up to the journey. and to order it from Elise, leaving the whole details to her was the least worrying and least fatiguing way I could devise of getting it. So I drove there and said; “Do for Mercy’s sake make me a black morning gown by new year’s day.“ and Elise answered “Oh my God! If this lasts many more days, I shall die!”— “But I am going to the Grange!”— “Well then I suppose you must have it?“ And I drove away—with the waistcoat in my reticule to match! But the idea of entering a haberdasher’s shop was perfectly awful, and indeed impossible for me! So how is that silk to be got I asked myself—and behold the answer by post this morning!! Thank you most cordially. Such pretty sleeves they are too!

Mary’s little headgear was also admired, and rejoiced over! and her little scrap of writing found rather touching! Please tell her I have certainly a good deal of the Father of the Prodigal SonSee Luke 15:20–24. in my nature! For I should have been tempted had she hove in sight, to run and fall on her neck, and kiss her, first, and box her ears after!
But Oh I must not write any more to you! Like Elise I may say “If this goes on many more days I shall die“!
God bless you all
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle
docBody.note: JWC apparently wrote to Emilie Venturi (previously Hawkes), 31 Oct., as Venturi wrote, 26 Dec., acknowledging JWC’s letter; Venturi wrote about a Franciscan friar, a long walk, a ruined roast dinner, a cat who destroyed a dish, and their mutual friend Charlotte Cushman: “I am delighted to know you liked Charlotte Cushman. She is a dear good soul, with far less of the actress in her than most actresses, & worth loving, which to my way of thinking few artists are.“ Charlotte Cushman had mentioned Emilie Venturi to JWC, 16 Nov.: “I want to write to Emilie Hawkes—did she not make you see me—& how much do I not owe her—where is she?—will you make her to know where I am—or me to know where she is?“

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, 27 Dec. MS: NLS Acc. 9086 inc. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.p: I should like to put my arms round your neck and “give you a kiss for it“ (as the children say; in the fond idea, poor things, that their kisses are recompense for everything and anything!— And perhaps their kisses are; when bestowed on—the Fathers and Mothers of them!— Anyhow I should like to give you a good kiss! and would trust, in Providence, and long experience of your goodwill, for your taking it and returning it with the old heartiness!

Yes! My dear! I could give you the warmest of kisses still; but I cannot write you much of a letter! and if it werent that the safe arrival of a present should always be notified by return of post; that the kind sender may not be left with misgivings as to its fate; I should put off writing a little while; till I had gained “more power to my elbow,“ and shaken off the languor and dullness produced by eight weeks confinement to the house, and a good deal of suffering, and the ‘calming’ medecines given me, which have ‘calmed’ me down to something in the nature of a dead fish!

For the rest; except that I was ill, and would much rather have been well; these eight weeks have passed rather peaceably, for myself and others— I was never as well attended to in illness since I lost my Mother; nor did the House ever go on as comfortably in my illness since I knew it—as just on this last occasion. I have got two such good clever Maids— A Welch cook (age 20—and Roman Catholic!) & a Hampshire Housemaid (age 18 and Wesleyan Methodist!)Margaret Sullivan was from Limerick and Maria Chamberlayne’s mother worked at The Grange, Hampshire. I haven’t had a thing to find fault with while I have been laid up— Nor Mr C either which is still more extraordinary! And I have had very much to congratulate myself, and thank God for—in their kind attentions—so seldom to be met with from servants at the present day! My young Methodist especially, with her warm heart, her unobtrusive piety, her clear, open mind and pleasant manners is a comfort to live beside! She brings Mr C any Book he wants from the Library!—in any language! and valets him to perfection! and does all his complicated “little jobs of sewing“—with an intelligence that often strikes me as superhuman! I could tell you many amusing things of these girls— But I so soon get tired with writing—or reading—or doing any
earthly thing. Indeed my Dr forbids me all activity beyond “eating and trying to sleep!”

The Butter is excellent, the best salt butter I ever tasted in my life!! I had some to my tea half an hour after it came I had grown so disgusted with the shop fresh butter whichPart of the letter is missing. The two lines below are written at the beginning of p.1 of the MS.
Do you remember saying that when I was praising their looks
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-HP, 31 Dec. MS: Mitchell Library, Sydney, Australia. Pbd: Parkes 1:162–64.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY PARKES

docBody.p: Mr Howe’sJoseph Howe (1804–73; ODNB), journalist and politician, premier of Nova Scotia 1860–63. Howe was in London as part of a delegation from the British North American colonies asking the British government to give financial aid toward an intercolonial railroad (see J. Murray Beck, Joseph Howe, 2 vols. [Kingston and Montreal, 1983] 2:153–57). Card seems to be irrecoverably lost; and I am sorry therefore to answer that I do not know his address.Parkes later recalled that he and TC “had some fresh conversation about Mr. Howe, which awoke in me a desire to make his acquaintance. Accordingly I wrote to Mr. Carlyle a few days after, asking if he could give me Mr. Howe’s address“ (Parkes 1:162). He merely sent up his Card; was rejected (as many have to be at this door), his name suggesting no notion or suspicion of who he was,—not for two or three days after, when I heard that the Nova-Scotia Mr Howe was in this country. He has not called again; nor did I yet find time to make a counter-attempt on him. The Card, I can remember, had “St James’s“ on it,—“Street,“ “Place,“ “or Square,“ uncertain to me;—and I have a dim persuasion that the No was “3.“ This is all I can say. Of course, you will have no difficulty to make out the actual Address when you return; it is only enquiring of the Postman in that locality,—or at the utmost, investigating a little in the haunts of Colonial people:—I should be well pleased if you found him; and (among other more important matters) were so kind as explain to him the above mistake of mine on that head. In former visits of his,They had met in 1851, when Howe visited Britain promoting emigration to Nova Scotia (see 26:33TC to AH, 2 Feb. 1851, and 35TC to JAC, 20 Feb. 1851), and in 1855 (see 29:340TC to WAN, 26 June 1855). I found him an intelligent, energetic sagacious man; very well worth talking to,—of course, especially if you had business in his department of activity.

I have no recollection what I said to you about colonisation that evg.See 37:241TC to HP, 2 Oct. 1861. The subject used to be of earnest almost of painful interest to me in old years;See, e.g., 16:167–68TC to JSBU, 16 May 1843. it seemed to me there had no Nation ever had such glorious opportunities of changing its nearly intolerable curses and choking nightmares into blessings and winged angels, as Great Britain in our day, by Colonising; or was so scandalously throwing said opportunity away. I have since learned that Gt Britain will go on with her Parliamentary Palaver, her &c &c, were the Day of Judgement close at hand; and turn a totally deaf ear to all considerations of that or the like kind;—and so I have dropped the speculation long ago, and it lies quite dead in me for years and decades past. And to tell you the truth, I am afraid my notions wd be of little or no use to you; and indeed are not executable, except on the hypothesis that we had something of a King among us again, and that the reign of Parliamentary Jargon and Penny-Newspapering had a good deal terminated again,—whh is to say in other words, That the current opinions of English and other men had (with the current practices) immensely changed for the better! Better to “drop“ a subject of that kind, if one have practically any use to turn one’s own poor span of life to! In a word, according to the Anarchic System Colonisatn seems to me to be going on quite as well as one cd expect; and Anarchy (under fine names) being the established faith for the time being, there is nothing more to be said.
I was never in my life so busy; but if you came (abt 8, some lucky evg) wd try to give you an hour again.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 31 Dec. Addr: 25 Oakley Villas, Adelaide Rd. / Haverstock Hill. PM: 31 Dec. 1861. MS: NLS 553.238. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—The Book Klein (with the Hirsch-Voltaire Lawsuit),Ernst Ferdinand Klein, Annalen der Gesetzgebung und Rechtsgelehrsamkeit in den Preussischen Staaten, 26 vols. (Berlin and Stettin, 1788–1809); see Works 16:279–96. whh has stood here for years in a particular corner, is this day wanting when I go to take it down. Enough to overset the temper of Job,—if he had been 12 years swimming for his life in such an element of things & so related to him. (Patience, tho’!)—

A faint possibility that you may have taken it with you to try for an explanatn of that often-discussed passage (unintelligible to me, and by nature so unspeakably interesting!) still stands between me & utter “despair“ so-called. Pray confirm or annihilate the same, without loss of a moment. I wd say
“Happy new year!”—but what “year“ or life at all can there be to (t.o.) any of us, till we are out of this disgusting quagmire, thrice and four times damnable? Ay de mi!See 6:241TC to JSM, 16 Oct. 1832.
docBody.name: T. C. (Chelsea, 31 decr 1861)—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 31 Dec. MS: NLS 517.31. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: This is the last night of the year; and being far away from sight of you, I must beg you to accept this inclosed bit of remembrance from me:TC sent a check: “2 jany 1862 / to Sister Jean / £10..0..0“ (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). He also sent a check for £10 to his sister Mary Austin at The Gill and one for £2..12..6 to his niece Jenny Carlyle at Scotsbrig. a thing suitable, and a real comfort to me in the circumstances. Pray do not say anything about it,—send only, by return of post, an old Newspaper or any such article to signify that the thing has come:The Carlyles put pen strokes on newspapers (sent free of charge) to signify that all was well. I will interpret all the rest; knowing well what your feelings are and always were to me. Precious far beyond CaliforniaThe Californian gold rush (begun 1848) made California synonymous with riches. if one had the whole of it to take or give!— And so enough.

Your Letters about poor old Mary GrierMary Grierson, b. Tait (ca. 1775–1861), ill for some time (see 37:196–97TC to JCA, 3 Aug. 1861, and 246TC to JCA, 17 Oct. 1861), d. 17 Dec. of “Natural Decay“ (death certificate). She was the widow of John Grierson (ca. 1770–1828), whose first wife (m. 1793) was TC’s maternal aunt Jean Aitken (d. 1810; see 4:3TC to MAC, 6 Jan. 1826, and 423TC to JAC, 26 Nov. 1828); see also 36:124JWC to ETW, 29 May 1860. John A. Carlyle wrote to his brother James Carlyle, 19 Dec.: “[Jean] tells me that poor old Mary Tait died. … ‘She had a most peaceful end—raised herself up in bed a few minutes before, & then laid herself back & breathed her last’“ (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). were full of pathos to me: poor old soul, “the two sovereigns“ for funeral, and given by that particular hand, went into one’s heart;—and her sufferings and her strugglings: done, done! A scene that has vanished, melted away like a picture in the clouds, as Life’s scenes all do. I feel very lonely, in late years; and see more than ever what a fearful and wonderful thing this Earthly Existence of ours is. Courage, Hope; and Steady to the last!—

Jane is growing better; gets out a little in late days, after 8 weeks imprisonment. Your JamesJean’s son James, who was working in London. was here, Sunday Evg, to wish us a good New Year. He is
looking well, and doing well. A modest honest young soul; with a good [deal]Word omitted. more of sense than everybody wd guess at the first glimpse. I design to ride over, and see his new LodgingUnidentified. some day; this one is a good deal handier for me than the others were.

My work is beyond measure bothering, slow, slow:—but I shall get it honourably done, I sometimes think; and then. Nobody can make more of this world than do his work in it to an honest pitch. Has the DrTheir brother John A. Carlyle. come to Christmas? He leaves me uncertain since last week. Give my New-Year’s wishes (in the heartiest form) to JamesHer husband, James. & the rest. Adieu dear Sister

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, 1 Jan. Addr: Elm Cottage Old-Brompton Road / Old Brompton. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd. TC wrote the note on the inside of the envelope flap and dated it again, bottom left corner under the address: “T.C.—/ 1 jany 1862.“
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Dear Larkin,—Accept this;A check: “1 jany 1862 / To Larkin (for self) / £50..0..0“ (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). Larkin later recorded that, although he worked for TC voluntarily, “there were several presents of £50, handed or posted to me … in a spirit of … friendliness“ (Larkin, BQR 75); this letter was apparently given personally to Larkin, as the envelope is unstamped. with many wishes for a “good New Year,“ & thanks for yr unwearied help.— T. C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JGC[JGCO], 1 Jan. MS: NLS 607.585A. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:92–93. Quot: Hansons 497.
div3.head: JWC TO J. GEORGE COOKE

docBody.p:
What an adorable little proceeding on your part! I declare I cant remember when I have been as pleased! Not only a “good first foot“; but Salvation from any possibility of a “bad first foot“TC wrote later on MS: “1 jany 1862 / ‘First foot,’ perhaps explained already, is a Scotch superstitn about good or ill luck for the whole year being omened by yr liking or otherwise of the first person that accosts you on Newyears morng. She well knew this to be an idle babble; but nonetheless it had got hold of her fancy in a sort, and was of some real importance to her. As other such old superstitns were. Thus I have seen her, if anybody made or recd a prest of a knife, insist on a penny being given for it, that so it might become ‘purchase,’ and not cut the friendship in two. I used to laugh at these practices but found them beautiful withal; how much more amiable than strong-mindedness (whh have needed only deductn of fine qualities) in regard to such things!” —with which my highly imaginative
scotch mind—(imaginative on the reverse side of things, in my present state of physical weakness) had been worrying itself as new years day drew near!! I could hardly believe my ears when little MargaretMargaret Sullivan had previously been employed at George Cooke’s lodgings; see 37:163–64JWC to JGCO, 7 May 1861. glided to my bedside and said; “Mr Cooke, Mam, with this letter, and beautiful egg-cup (!) for you; but he wouldnt come up as you were in bed!”— That too was most considerate of Mr Cooke!! The “egg-cup“ ravished my senses with its beauty, and perfect adaptation to my main passion. I think you must have had it made on purpose for me! it feels already so much a part of myself!—

And how early you must have risen to be here at that hour! dressed perhaps by candle-light; good God!— All that for me! Well! I am grateful, and won’t forget this!—a talismanic remembrance, to stand between my faith in your kindness for me, and any “babbles“ (my Grandfather’sEither John Welsh (ca. 1760–1823), JWC’s paternal grandfather (see Carlyle, Reminiscences 108–9), or Walter Welsh (1752–1832), her maternal grandfather (see Carlyle, Reminiscences 122–30). word) that may ever attempt, conscously or unconsciouly,Thus in MS. to shake it! And so god bless you, and believe yours affectionately Jane Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [2 Jan.]. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries N. B. PM: London, 2 Jan. 1862. MS: NLS envelope 607.585A. The letter is missing but is referred to in JWC to MR, [13 Feb.].
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: [No text]

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JD[JAD], 3 Jan. MS: NLS 1797.57. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO JANE DODS

docBody.p:
This must be a bare acknowledgement of your newyears-day letter, and inclosure; and thanks for both, from the bottom of my heart! It was a real good thought and good act, of yours, to write me a letter for new years day,
and send me that excellent photograph;Jane Dods wrote to JWC, 31 Dec. 1861, enclosing a photograph of her husband, William, as her “first foot. I have not yet got one of myself fit to send.“so much liker and more agreeable than the large one! On any day of the year the little packet would have been dearly welcome. but on newyears-day—!! My Dear! I am Scotch; I am “far from the Land where—“ I don’t remember what happened in the Song!Cf. Thomas Moore, “She is far from the land where her young hero sleeps,“ l. 1 of “She Is Far From The Land,“ Irish Melodies (London and Dublin, 1808–34), vol. 4. of course then, I cleave to what Lord Jeffrey used to term my “bits of superstitions“Francis Jeffrey (1773–1850; ODNB; see 25:13TC to JWC, 29 Jan. 1850, and earlier vols.), literary critic, judge, and politician; the Carlyles’ friend from 1827. For his similar phrase to JWC, “bits of convictions,“ see 19:137JWC to TC, 10 Aug. 1845. to omens, first-foots, &c &c. and of course such a kind letter from my old home, and such a nice likeness of my BoyfriendWilliam Dods, whom JWC had known at school; see 33:79JWC to GEJ, 11 Sept. 1857, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 43–44. were as omens all that could be wished; to say nothing of their acceptability as facts. And this much said, which I had an inward need to say; I must leave other news and matters, till a quieter hour. For I am in great trouble and anxiety about my Housemaid,Maria Chamberlayne. a dear good girl who is more like a Daughter to me than a Servant! She was taken ill yesterday morning with what my Dr pronounces to be a serious complication of inflamatory cold and hysteria; but which had every appearance at first of tending towards scarlet-fever! that dreadful fever which has been so fatal here of late weeks; and laid the family next door all prostrate, killing the Master of the house.Alexander Gilchrist; see TC to JAC, 1 Dec. 1861. and nearly killing myself, at second hand! But I am now less alarmed about the kind of illness of this poor maid of mine; tho’ still terrified at its severity.

figure.p: Jane Welsh Carlyle to Jane Dods, 3 January 1862 (detail)

p.hi: Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

docBody.p: The other ServantMargaret Sullivan. has a shocking bad common cold. And I myself, only recovering from a long illness, with no strength of either body or mind ‘to speak of’! But it was all a melancholy fiction, that of my having been confined to bed seven weeksJane Dods wrote: “I have just heard that you have been ill—very ill & confined to bed for seven weeks. You must have been ill, ever since we saw you, & we knew nothing about it. … I wish I could be beside you, to be of some use in the way of nursing you; I am afraid Mr Carlyle however anxious & willing, will not be a good nurse.“—translated into truth, it should have stood confined to two rooms for seven weeks, and to bed for some ten days. Thank God in all my illnesses I have never been much in bed! whic[h]Letter omitted. is a mercy, hating it as I do!
Kind love and the best of good wish to you Both affly yrs.
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A[LLA], 17 Jan. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Your Note came to me last night, long after Post-time. You are very kind; and I am very sorry! Alas, I cd have come gladly abt this time last week (tho’ my wife who has relapsed &c since that magnanimous announcement of hers,JWC had presumably written recently to Lady Ashburton, saying that they would visit The Grange. and is still too weak tho better again, could not):—but now I am got into a New Chapter (new sectionProbably a new chapter in bk. 16 of Frederick, “The Ten Years of Peace. 1746–1756,“ which TC had begun by early Dec. 1861; see TC to JAC, 1 Dec. 1861. of this unspeakable Quagmire of mine); and am good for nothing but weltering, or choking, eye-deep in mud; and can think of nothing but of getting out again, alive if I can! Pity me; don’t frown at me; I am very miserable. If I live thro’ summer, I shall be out altogether;—and then!— Weeks on weeks of The Grange, this is one of my earliest hopes!—
Till the night before last, when somebody called, and told Jane of the alarming Pony-Accidt,Unexplained. we knew nothing: but can now well enough understand why there came no answer.
Today is bright here; but so sternly cold and hard, I have renounced riding,—at least till tomorrow.

My kindest regards to his Lordship; and to the little “opening gowan wet wi’ dew,“TC’s phrase for Mary Florence, the Ashburtons’ da.; see Burns, “Song“ to the tune of “My Nanie, O“ (R. Burns, Poems and Songs, ed. James Kinsley [1968] 1:7–8). your treasure & his: Lady Sandwich (weak and a prisoner) whom I see abt weekly, gives me news of you all from time to time.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-IEB, 24 Jan. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:93–94 inc; Bliss 291 inc. Quot: Ireland, JWC 269; Blunt, Forum 541; Blunt, CR 159; Wilson, Carlyle 5:448; Ashton 419.
div3.head: JWC TO ISABELLA E. BARNES

docBody.p:
Oh you agonizing little Girl! How could you?— Come down upon me in that slap dash way,—demand of poor weak shivery me, a positive ‘Yes’ or ‘no,’ as if with a loaded pistol at my head!! How can I tell what I shall be up to on the
18th?Tues., 18 Feb., the date for the marriage of Isabella Barnes and John Simmonds at St. Luke’s, Chelsea. After such a three months of illness and relapses how can I even guess?— If I am alive, and able to stand on my hind legs, and to look like a joyful occasion, I shall be only too happy to attend that solemnity But in my actual state, it would be a tempting of Providence to suppress the if in my acceptance of your ‘amiable invitation’

As for Mr C— My dear! I must confide to you a small domestic passage— I told him what your Father had said weeks ago and he expressed himself as terrified, as was to be expected, at the idea of his being included in anything joyful! and I thought he had forgotten all about it three or four days after, when he came into my room with evidently something on his mind, and said “My Dear—there is a small favour I want from you, I want you to not let me be asked to Miss Barnes’s marriage; for it would be a real vexation to me to refuse that bonnie wee Lassie what she asked; and to her marriage I could not go!—it would be the ruin of me for three weeks“ And that is no exaggeration, I can say who know his ways better than any one else— He added that “the rational thing to be done“ was, that you should “bring your Husband when you had married him, to spend an evening with him (Mr C) in his own house, among quiet things“ (me? and the cat?)
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

ps.p: Oh dont I owe you sixpence? Didnt you go and pay those [illegible word] things

div3.sourceNote: JWC-AG[AGIL], [25 Jan.]. Pbd: Gilchrist 105–6, where dated Dec. 1861. Dated by TC’s forthcoming visit to The Grange, beginning Mon., 27 Jan.
div3.head: JWC TO ANNE GILCHRIST

docBody.p: My Dear Mrs. Gilchrist: Are we still to go on not seeing each other,—you in sorrow, I in sickness; with just a partition between us,—of no comfort to each other at all?

For more than three months now, I have been ill and confined to the house— Three times I have seemed to be recovering, and made an attempt at getting about; but after one drive in a Fly, there was always a relapse; and since New Year’s Day I have had the worst bout of all!

The visit to the Grange which has lain so long a-head of me, and to which I looked for some freshening-up, is finally thrown over altogether as far as I am concerned. Mr. Carlyle will go on Monday by himself for two or three days.

Since the mild weather came, I have been so much better, however, that I
am again projecting a drive; being heartily sick of my two rooms. But for the rain I should have tried it to-day.
Will you come here? or must I wait till I can go to you? that is till it is quite dry; for I should be foolish to expose myself to the damp, after such long shutting up.
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JD[JODO], 26 Jan. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN DOWNES

docBody.p: I have seen Mr Froude and he is ready to see you, in re Fraser’s Magazine. He is going out of Town, on Tuesday next, for ten days; I therefore judged it better to secure you a possibility before that; and said that you wd (in all probability) call at his House, “Monday Evg (tomorrow) between 9 and 11 p.m.“ He lives, “6. Clifton-Terrace,Froude lived at 6 Clifton Pl., Hyde Park. Hyde Park Gardens“;—not far east of Westbourne Terrace. You pronounce his name Frood (in spite of the spelling). He is well disposed to listen to practicable proposals from you; and is a man of clearness punctuality and a great deal of business sense.Downes’s most recent periodical article was “Edmund Burke: His Life and Genius,“ North British Review 35 (Nov. 1861): 445–79. Froude refused his proposal; see TC to JD, 8 May; nor did he publish later in Fraser’s Magazine.— If you like better to wait for 10 days, of course you can.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 26 Jan. MS: NLS 525.86. Hitherto unpbd. TC misdates 1861.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: My dear Brother,— Accept a very brief word from me: I meant to have sent you a longer, on Friday evg still in Post-time;“Receiving offices“ accepted letters for the north until 9 p.m.; TC’s nearest agent was John Gigner, 131 King’s Rd. but was hunted out of that fine intentn, as is too usual.

I am just making ready for a brief bit of an Excursion to The Grange; abt whh there has been a great deal of hithering & thithering, of a tedious nature; and whh is now at the eleventh hour to take effect just before Country-houses
shut themselves for the season.The nobility and upper classes left their country estates to return to London for the “Season“ (early Feb. to early Aug., when Parliament was in session), to take part in fashionable pursuits and amusement. I go tomorrow at 1 p. m; for how long will depend principally on sleep: if I prosper moderately I may stay the greater part of the week, and try whether riding on the downs or sauntering abt, vacant, in the free air, will not perhaps help me. Otherwise I can return, perhaps abt Thursday. You shall have a little Note from the place, even if you send (whh I will not hope, nicht hoffen will) none Poor Jane, alas, is still unable to think of going: a good deal better than when I wrote last; but still weak as water; and only waiting a good day to venture out of doors in a close carriage. We had three days of iron frost, streets all in a tempest with dust the third day; after whh, suddenly, mud-bath extensive almost tepid,—and this morng, again suddenly, all is white rime, and the ground frozen dry (mud become elastic)! I am just going out for a ride;—am to leave my horse in his quarters here.TC kept his horse at John Silvester’s livery stables.

My work goes on perhaps a shade ligh[t]lier,Letter omitted. but still so so. The time it consumes, with fiddling details, is frightful. I sometimes do feel however that I have got it fairly under my shoe, and shall finish it—surely some time in the course of this summer or autumn!

Rae, of Melbourne,Not further identified; he visited TC March 1859, when TC commented on his fortune, made in 10 years; see 35:53–54TC to JAC, 14 March 1859; possibly a relative of either Benjamin Rae, previously schoolmaster at Ecclefechan (see 11:167TC to JAC, 15 Aug. 1839), or of Charles Rae (see 7:96TC to MAC, 11 Feb. 1834). came here one evg; is removing to London now;—looked to me gloomy, wearied, dyspeptically given,—vacant, I guessed, and unhappy, from premature plethora of money! “Gavin C.“Probably Gavin Carlile or Carlyle (1821–1919), nephew of Edward Irving; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 253. He moved to London in June, and became minister of St. John’s Presbyterian Church in Kensington, 1863. is harmless, bothery feckless, ut solet [as usual]. One Downes, whom you know abt, has not found much “Liter[ary“]Word obscured in margin. employt, tho’ he is busy seeking. Adieu dear Brother Your Affecte T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, [27 Jan.]. Addr: 5—Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Alresford, 27 Jan. 1862. MS: NLS 615.549. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.dateline: The Grange, Monday Evg ¼ to 6—[27 January 1862]
docBody.p: Hardly a minute left, my poor little Jeannie, but I will send thee a word,—from the middle of the babble round me.

I got on quite handsomely; had a carriage to myself the greater part of the way (till the theThus in MS. Kingsleys bounced in upon me near Basingstoke);Charles and Fanny Kingsley lived at Eversley, nr. Basingstoke, about 15 mi. (24 km.) N of The Grange.—Duke and Duchess of ArgyleGeorge Douglas Campbell, 8th duke of Argyll, and Lady Elizabeth Georgiana, duch-ess of Argyll. were in the same train; and here they weTC wrote “we“ above “they.“ all are: with tea & babble but no solid basis yet! The Sartoris heEdward John Sartoris; TC writes “he“ above Sartoris, to indicate that only Sartoris was there, not his wife, Adelaide; see TC to JWC, 29 Jan. seems to be here:—no other person that I see.
I have not got sight of my room or trunk:—but have not remembered of anything forgotten; except (n.b.) pills: Oh send me these next Letter.

The Lady did not expect a Letter from you by the lame Messenger; but only that you shd write to her “on the subject at large“ at yr leisure! She also understood herself to have written to you what shd have arrived this morning!— Ld A. is lively; rides sometimes; but goes with two stilts.Crutches. “Opening gowan“ considerably grown has been here—rather leanish, but bright. Nothing said yet of “pistol shot““Pistol-shot“ photograph; see JWC to EF, [19 Dec. 1861].
Go out in fly tomorrow; and take care of yourself, for God’s sake.

closer.salute: Adieu (in & from the middle of confusion).

docBody.name: T. C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-AG[AGIL], [27 Jan.]. MS: Yale. Pbd: Gilchrist 106 inc. Dated by JWC to AGIL, [25 Jan.].
div3.head: JWC TO ANNE GILCHRIST

docBody.p: I am puzzled to understand why you send me back these miserable debts without a word of answer to my Saturday’s note about seeing you. I must take for granted from your silence that you would still rather be left alone—at least so far as I am concerned.

You sent me a sovereign of which I spent only five and ninepence halpenny —so there is owing you out of that 14s 2d;½ —and long ago you paid a bushel of brown flour for meSee 37:254JWC to AGIL, 25 Oct. 1861. For JWC’s calculations at the end of this letter, see 42above.—as the last was ten shillings I suppose that would be the same. Which makes a balance due to you of one pound four shillings and 2d;½—what wretched particulars to write about after so long as a separation
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 29 Jan. Addr: 5—Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Alresford, 29 Jan. 1862. MS: NLS 615.550. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:248; Wilson 5:450.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Thanks, Dearest, for the trouble you took for my sake; whh was well worth while for the satisfaction it gave me,—tho’ the news you send abt your poor little self is far from good. Alas, and you won’t get out today either: a dirty dropping day, as yesterday also proved tho’ it did in the middle part brighten up into an hour of sunshine, as today has refused to do. I will hope for a better sleep, to the poor little soul, at any rate.— I did not write yesterday, partly because I had no time left on getting home; partly too because I had little but croakery and ill omens to send. My sleep has gone but indifferently hitherto; and yesternight I had bad prospects that way at writing time; whh were considerably realised. However, I am better today; and will write in a clearer hand for one thing.TC’s handwriting was very bad and the ink very splotchy in TC to JWC, [27 Jan.]. The first night owing to the flurry &c,—owing very much to the fact that there was nothing of eatable to be had till abt 9 p. m., I made out only 4 or five hours of sleep (continually interrupted by creaking, trampling & slamming of doors, in attempting the matter farther); add to whh, I was formally started at eight; and turned out, after cold water, to wait for breakfast till 10 in a rainy morng:—by all whh methods I was quite thrown wrong, all yesterday; had a furious ride too (not of my own selecting), and sofa and wrappages, but no wink of sleep, possible after): so that it was towards 5, I think, this morning before I cd get to sleep in spite of all industries and precautions: however, I had actually again abt 4 hours; and feel decidedly better than yesterday; and shall now, I doubt not, do well enough. No trouble abt me, therefore; take care of thy poor self, and send me a better bulletin.

We are a brisk party here; full of locomotion, speculatn; and really are in some sort agreeable to one another. Sartoris, who is still here witht the Wife,Adelaide Sartoris. is a quite gentlemanly quiet creature, not without intelligence. Milnes & the BearRichard Monckton Milnes and Edward Ellice (known as the Bear). added themselves yesterday (much lamentatn that my poor Goody was
absent): Kingsley is a thot less noisy than last year; his Wife is a strange blubbery, half-squinting, solemnly-contemplative Lady (religious &c); “do tha’ naither ill na’ guid.“Coterie speech; see 4:369TC to MAC, 20 April 1828. VenablesGeorge Stovin Venables. is here (with a peaked grey beard, otherwise unchanged); the Heir AparentThus in MS. Alexander Hugh Baring (1835–89), eldest son of the current heir, Lord Ashburton’s brother Francis Baring (1800–1868). too, nothing like such a fool as I had thot him. You need not write to Milnes; I have told him abt the poor Gilchrist Book,Alexander Gilchrist had been writing a biography of William Blake before he died. The book was finished by Anne Gilchrist with help from Dante Gabriel Rossetti (1828–82; ODNB) and William Michael Rossetti (1829–1919; ODNB); it was pbd. 1863. & he will give me the title of itMilnes had a large collection of Blake books and manuscripts, to which Anne Gilchrist was given access; see the “Annotated Catalogue of Blake’s Pictures and Drawings,“ drawn up by William Michael Rossetti, in Alexander Gilchrist, Life of William Blake, 2 vols. (1863), and Gilchrist 123 and 125; otherwise unexplained. (not today; for he, the Bear, the Duke,The duke of Argyll. with the woman-kind wholly are off some 20 miles,—mostly in an open carriage, think of it. The Bishop of OxfordSamuel Wilberforce. is here (gone with these women, to see some little Ape called Keble, of the “Christian Year“):John Keble (1792–1866; ODNB), clergyman and poet, associated with the early development of the Oxford movement; author of The Christian Year (Oxford, 1827), one of the most popular books of verse in the 19th cent. he is very perceptibly older in face; but no change in the shifty, cunning thro’going ways of him: it was he that took me riding yesterday, galloping as if for the King’s Hundred,A prize of £100, first given by Charles II (1630–85: ODNB; king of England, Scotland, and Ireland), for a horse race at Newmarket, in Suffolk.—to see something whh he called the Beacon Hill;Beacon Hill, 659 ft. (201 m.) high, nr. Warnford, about 9 mi. (14.5 km.) S of The Grange. whh we never saw (day light failing us), tho we had a gallop of some 16 miles, whh he declares to have made him quite stiff today;Wilberforce wrote in his diary, 28 Jan.: “After luncheon, rode with Carlyle to Cher-i-ton on the way to the Beacon. Carlyle against the essayists on dishonesty ground and atheistic“ (Reginald Wilberforce, Life of Samuel Wilberforce [rev. edn. 1888] 253). For TC and the controversy over Essays and Reviews, ed. H. B. Wilson (1860), see 37:137–38TC to JAC, 27 March 1861. Wilberforce was prominent in the orthodox response to the book.—you may figure whether it suited me in my feverish feeble mood!

The most agreeable man among us is the little Duke; really a good solid Scotch Product; takes, I think, considerably to me; as does his little Duchess (Mamma’s image reduced to miniature),The duchess of Argyll’s mother was Lady Harriet Elizabeth Georgiana Sutherland-Leveson-Gower (1806–68), duchess of Sutherland. tho’ I do not speak much to her,
findg the Nigger question much a topic with her, and by no means a safe one.Froude noted: “The Duke and Duchess were strong for the North [in the Civil War], and there was much arguing, not to Carlyle’s satisfaction“ (Froude, Carlyle 4:247). GamesPossibly charades, a very popular house-party game with the Ashburtons. had to be started last night. Most of these Official figures go on Thursday (tomorrow): I hope to manage better tonight, and hold on for another pair of days. Ld A. keeps the house, with his crutches; but is quite cheery & talky. Nothing yet of “Pistol-shot,“ I am ashamed to say! Never mind Proofsheets till I return: merely lay them on the mantel-piece up stairs till I return.
Luncheon is in; and I suppose they are about done with it,—but am to go for a bit of pudding nevertheless.
God bless thee ever, my poor little Schatz [darling] in this world. Take care of thyself.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: (in plain writing, is it not?)

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 30 Jan. MS: NLS 525.87. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:246.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Yr Letter came this morng; a Piece I was very glad to read. I meant to write a word at any rate; so here goes with the better will.

The journey on Monday proved altogether comfortable for a journey; day fine, carriage nearly all to myself, nothing at all going wrong; and a safe arrival well before dark. In the same train were Duke and Duchess, and in the same Carriage latterly were Kingsley & Missus,—portions of the Party that had been appointed hither; there were some 7 or 8 others; Bishop of Oxford (SoapyWilberforce’s nickname was “Soapy Sam.“ as ever, and ingenious as ever), Richd Milnes, Venables &c: the pink of them have gone today, “to attend Cabinet Council“;The duke of Argyll was a member of the cabinet; the Times reported, 1 Feb.: “Cabinet Council was held yesterday [31 Jan.] at the official residence of the First Lord of the Treasury in Downing-street.“ but Bear Ellice, Milnes &c remain, and more it seems are “expected,“—not at all by my voting. We have been really rather pleasant with one another for these 3 days,—The two Graces of Argyle are really amiable and rational bits of Humanity; very affable in a simple innocent way. Our weather has been damp and dropping; beautiful & temperate when the Sun gets out: I have made out an abundant canter over the downs & dales and hills each day; and that is pretty
much all my conquest here. In sleep I very far from shine; have a constant headache too (owing to the hours & diet); otherwise I feel really well. I shall make out to Saturday,TC wrote on Thurs. as I trust & calculate; and then move home to my affairs again.— I will write to you soon after getting to my loom again; at once if there is anything to report. Jane does not send a very good acct of herself; nothing at all, this day;—and I fear will never yet have got out, owing to the damp weather. Nothing considerable talked of here, but the Yankee War,—quite in the indifft tone henceforth, Duke & Duchess, who were enthusiasts for “Freedom to the Slave,“ having made exit. No war ever waging in my time was to me more profoundly foolish-looking: neutral I am to a degree, I for one!—

I wish Jamie cd get that Farm if it be worth the money.Their nephew James Carlyle Jr. was looking at farms to rent, and had been to see Breckonside Farm, nr. Moffat. John A. Carlyle wrote to James, 15 Jan.: “I am glad to hear that your father & you were pleased with the look of Breckonside. If it could be got at a reasonable rent, your occupation there might be as genial as any thing one has a right to expect for you“ (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). For John’s comment to James Jr. about his letter on the Moffat farm to “Mr Stewart,“ see TC to JCA, 17 Feb. Mauritius wd have been far suitabler; but it cannot be had.John had also been speaking to his friend James Currie, a merchant in Mauritius (then a British colony), about the possibility of work for James there. In his letter, 15 Jan., he also wrote: “Apparently he [Currie] has made money enough there by sore work during nineteen years, but has also injured his health—for which no amount of money can be a compensation. And he is now under the necessity of going out again, & exposing himself to fresh dangers in the hot climate. I do not remember what he said in talking of Mauritius Law & Lawyers; but I noticed nothing in it that could have any relation to you, though I saw you setting all your hair on end with alternate right & left hands at the time it took place“ (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). Adieu dear Br. T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 30 Jan. Addr: 5—Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Micheldever Station, 31 Jan. 1862; London, 31 Jan. 1862. MS: NLS 615.551. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Nothing for Craigenpk today Ma’am!Coterie speech; see 19:209JWC to TC, 23 Sept. 1845. Perhaps you will send me a little word tomorrow; if it wd say you got some fair modicum of sleep again, and had dared to undertake the Brougham witht damage,—how welcome! Any way, I do want to hear.

The illustrious of us are gone today; “Cabinet Council“ calling; Rt Revd Samuel too is gone; Alick Baring, Sartoris &c (Sartoris is really not a bad fellow; took me & Venables a beautiful gallop yesterday):—Milnes & the Bear
still survive with V.bles, Miss Baring,Louisa, Lord Ashburton’s elder sister. Miss Antruther(?),Probably Annie Nairn Anstruther, eldest of Lady Ashburton’s unmarried nieces.—and more, alas, are coming tonight! The diet, hours &c are very stiff upon me; sleep quite so so: but I intend holding out till Saturday;—if I shd even write nothing tomorrow, know that the train will be the 1 o’clock (3¾ p.m arrive); and that I shall want brown-soup & mutton collop or chop,—thank Heaven for them & you!
I have spoken abt the “pistol-shot“; and will try to get it, & send it by this. Meanwhile Lunchn is afoot agn, & I must try for some edible morsel. Adieu, Dearest.

A miserable wet-warm afternoon; no riding, and I had so much need of it! I have lit my fire; rung the bell to request that nobody may come near me; and am going to try for a little sleep.— I have got the Pistol-shot; but it is a huge thing &cannot come except in portmanteau. The tiny copy of the same I am promised; but it will have to come along with the other.— Secure agt intrusion the man says! (n.b. not my man; but one sent by her Ladyship for another purpose!)
Well that is the end of me then; I am dead weary; I hope to sleep till post-time. Adieu, Dearest. Ever Yours such as I am, / T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-CC[CCU], [31] Jan. Addr: 38 via Gregoriana / Rome. PM: London, 1 Feb. 1862. MS: Charlotte Cushman Papers, LC. Pbd: Fielding and Sorensen 268–71. Quot: Julia Markus, Across an Untried Sea (2000) 163. Letters and punctuation in sq. br. are obscured by binding.
div3.head: JWC TO CHARLOTTE CUSHMAN

docBody.p:
My Dear! My Dear! I want to put my arms round your neck, and give you—oh! such a good kiss! And then,—if you can stand that sort of thing, once in a way,—I should like to lay my head on your shoulder and take a good cry! That is how natu[re] prompts me to acknowledge your dear letter, and dear newyear’s tokens,Cushman wrote to JWC, 28 Jan.: “I sent a wee parcel to you … too hurriedly to admit of my sending a word of loving greeting … & now [I] ask you if you had a little Roman scarf on New Years day—just to remind you that the Eternal City held one, who thought of, & wished to be remembered by you.“—with a good kiss and a good cry; rather than with any written sentences that my poor nearly extinct Brain can cobble together in these Hard Times! (I am so worn out and disheartened with long illness and confinement to two rooms!) But alas Dear! The “gods,“ however entreated, will not “annihilate Time and Space, to make two Lovers happy“!Cf. Alexander Pope, “Peri Bathous“ (1728) chap. 11. That has been
clearly ascertained some time since! And so, faute de mieux [for want of better] I must have recourse to writing, “under difficulties[“]Coterie speech; see 27:179JWC to TC, 23 July 1852. and that without further delay, on penalty of passing for both fickle and ungrateful; when—God bless you!—I am as far as possible from being either! and as unwilling as possible that such an idea should be entertained of me—by you!

Mrs Dilberoglue, being the precisest and faithfulest of dear little “Goods,“ would do infallibly what she promised, nay volunteered to do, namely, “explain to Miss Cushman all about it“Sarah Dilberoglue introduced JWC to Charlotte Cushman, Aug. 1861 (see 37:224–25JWC to CCU, 6 Sept. 1861); for her letter to Cushman, 15 Dec., see TC to JAC, 1 Dec., and TC to UC, 12 Dec. 1861. Possibly Dilberoglue wrote to Cushman again after JWC received the new year’s gifts.—“It“ meaning my happiness at having a letter from you,—my true Scotch-woman impatience to make “a suitable return,“Coterie speech; see 19:227JWC to JW, 29 Sept. 1845.—and then my illness—the extreme weakness and nervousness which made any—the least—use of my head intolerably irksome besides being especially prohibited by my Doctor;—all that the little Good was to “explain“! and trusting that she did so with her accustomed accuracy and lucidity, I will not go back upon the causes of my long silence; It is enough to have been four months ill and shut up in two rooms; without “renewing grief“ by details of one’s fit-for-nothingness; so soon as ever one has recovered a certain use of one’s tongue and pen!

But if I shut down the lid and turn the key on my sick room tribulations; what is there left out of these weary four months to tell you? This—first and foremost; that I am not a bit cooled on the sudden affection I took for you; and believe it to be one of those Elective AffinitiesSee Goethe, Die Wahlverwandtschaften [Elective affinities] (Tübingen, 1809), a novel based on the idea of human passions being governed by the laws of chemical affinity; see also 5:26–27TC to G, 3 Nov. 1829. on which one does not cool—ever! I have seen you twice—that’s all! and already you are mixed up with my life like an old friend! Something new and good in my life—not outside it! I look forward with pleasure to seeing you again; but, without seeing you without interchanging words with you, it is a pleasure to know of you in the same world with me. The influence of a strong, brave, loving true woman may be felt at any distance, I firmly believe, without outward visible sign. And then Dear, you are come to me just at the right time!—to be a consolation as well as a possession! For, of late years, it had been all loss, loss with me! Never gain! One Friend after another out of “dear old Long Ago,“Coterie speech; see 36:166JWC to LST, 9 Aug. 1860. that had cared for me and that I had cared for all my Life had gone to their rest,Jess and Jean Donaldson, George Rennie, and Robert McTurk, all old friends from Scotland, d. during 1860. leaving me so lonely on the Earth! Playing at Friendship with the new
