people I was thrown amongst; and so discouraged in my secret heart that I despaired of both my chances and my ability to ever make myself a new real Friend!— My Heavens! when I went to Barnesbury ParkWhere the Dilberoglues lived. that day to see you; how very very little I dreamt of jumping into your arms! and “swearing eternal Friendship,“ like any boarding-school girl! But it was all right! After so many months and after a severe fit of illness (which I take to be the best possible test of realities and shams) I feel no misgivings about that somewhat german-lookingBehavior more usual between close relatives. transaction! rather compliment myself on having so much Life left in me after all! and on having turn[ed] it to such account!

My Life has been making another pronunciamento [declaration] with which I could throw you into fits of laughter, if I had you beside me! My Dear!I have had a fearful row with Geraldine Jewsbury!Geraldine Jewsbury wrote to Walter Mantell, 23 Dec. 1862: “Kee [George Cooke] & Mrs Dilglue will tell you more of Mrs C than I can—for you will be sorry to learn that it is a case of one more broken & vanished friendship—after it had lasted many years. I do not expect from my knowledge of her that it will ever be renewed—she takes things into her head & believes them—& nothing can alter her notions— I cannot blame myself altogether tho’ I wd gladly do so & take the whole of it if that wd work any change but I cannot renew her health & give her clear eyesight & I can only feel that if I were in her position domestic & physical that I shd be less reasonable and more disagreeable a great deal—the final break was so sudden so utterly unlooked for, that I might say of it as the maids say when they break a precious piece of China ‘Ma’am I was holding it quite carefully when it flew out of my hand’ I could not have cared more for any one than I have for her—or have been more true—ah well these are some of the ‘many deaths we suffer before we die’“ (MS: Mantell). According to the Hansons, JWC was upset that Mantell had not replied to one of her letters and became angry when she found out that Jewsbury had been begging him to write to her (Hansons, NE 498). Jewsbury had certainly asked Mantell to write to JWC, but it was a year earlier, in Jan. 1861 (see 37:120JWC to WMAN, 22 Feb. 1861); JWC’s last known letter to Mantell was 19 Oct. 1861 (see 37:250–51JWC to WMAN, 19 Oct. 1861). JWC was often irritated with Jewsbury, but this time the rift lasted longer and relations were apparently not restored until summer 1863. which has made “pigs and whistles“Falling into wrack and ruin; see 35:57JWC to MR, 25 March 1859. of that everlasting friendship! and

lg.l: “Like cliffs that have been rent asunder
A dreary sea now flows between!”Cf. Samuel Taylor Coleridge, “Christabel“ (1798) lines 422–23.

docBody.p: I should be more overpowerd with grief than I am, (in fact I have shown an insensibility unexampled!) had the cliffs been rent by one explosion; but the rent has been the gradual work of many years, and the cliffs were only of sand or some loose material to begin with! I do think that sort of emotional woman, all “finer sensibilities“Coterie speech; see 30:167Jane Carlyle’s Notebook, 13 April 1845. and no feeling, all smoke and no flame is one of the most intolerable inventions of Civilization, should be put down by act of Parliament; and prayed against in all Churches!

You asked for Mrs Hawk’s (Madame Venturi’s) address. After the 7th of January (she wrote to me) I was to address Emilia Venturi nata Ashurst poste restante Milan She had been living up to that date in some rooms of an old Château, near Brescia, dismantled and unfurnished, in the midst of all sorts of inconveniences and discomforts; waited on by a girl of the Country whom she named Bare legs (as Mr Carlyle would say) “significative of much!”Coterie speech; see 16:200JWC to JOST, 16 June 1843. But caring for none of these things—very fond of her new Husband I think and very happy with him!—happy as a young girl!—and with a touching air of consciousness that not being a young girl she has no claim to that sort of happiness and no sure hold of it! She writes to me “I am so glad you like Charlotte Cushman, she is a dear good noble soul!”
Aren’t you glad we are not to be natural enemies? It would have been so absurd that way as well as so vexatious!! When will you come? And how long will you stay?

I cannot put into words how touched I was by your newyears bouquet, and the little scarfs! I took them not only as tokens from you but as omens of a fortunate year; and—next day I had a relapse and was thrown into bed again for a fortnight!!

Does your friendEmma Stebbins. remember me? I do her—and offer her my kind regards and just one word more and the paper is full. Please love me ever so much but dont flatter me for it makes me “think shame“!Coterie speech; see 30:220JWC’s Journal, 21 Nov. 1855. Yours faithfully and affectionately Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 1 Feb. [31 Jan.]. MS: NLS 615.552. Addr: Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Alresford, 31 Jan. 1862. Hitherto unpbd. TC misdated.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: No news at all today or yesterday; I much fear there was only baddish news to send: but you had better have written what it was than have left me the prey of my own imaginatn! The LowesRobert Lowe (1811–92; ODNB), M.P., and Georgiana, b. Orred (ca. 1811–84), part of the Ashburton circle; see 33:275–7633:biographical note. had “sent somebodyUnidentified. down“ yesterday or the day before; and the somebody’s report was not cheering at all on the head of poor Goody. Wae’s me, what can I do?—

TomorrowSat., 1 Feb. I am coming home to see with my own eyes. My train is to be
1.57, that is to say, edge of 2 p.m.;—so that I will be abt 5 before I can arrive. I wish I were there.

Much talk there has been about getting us “both to come for a long while,“ were this hurlyburly over. I really think it might be managed, and wd do good: in spite of the tumultuous bad-sleeping misarranged conditns now prevalent, I really feel as if I were slightly better from these few days of pure air & quiet fields. The Lady is to correspond with you on the above project. Till 3 p.m. the day to be my own &c.— I shd only vote farther that we took some waiterage of our own with us (Maria for example); the quality of valet I now have is among the lowest of my experience; in fact rather worse than none.
Enough for this day, Dearest: may you only get out, and be a little better when I come
docBody.name: T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady S[LS], 1 Feb. [31 Jan.]. MS: NLS 19.3.52.51. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:451; Hansons, NE 499. TC misdated.
div3.head: TC TO LADY SANDWICH

docBody.p: I have been here since Monday: I am afraid my poor Wife has not been able to call at your door on my behoof,—the news from her yesterday, and today there was none at all. She was to return your Polish Book;Unidentified. explain how I cd not call on Sunday last to take leave; and send me some word how you were. Word I have had none; but I hope there has been no falling off since I last saw you;—in two days from this, I hope to call once more, and see with my own eyes. I return tomorrow.

We have been rather a numerous Party here, and still rather are so tho’ with changes. Duke & Duchess of Argyle, Bishop of Oxford, Alick Baring &c are gone. In return for whom are Milnes, Trench,Richard Chenevix Trench the Lowes and so on. Sufficient for the day is the evil thereof.Cf. Matt. 6:34. Lord A. is pretty much confined with gout; drives, but has not ridden since Saturday last; is cheery, but looks weak.

The Place is pretty as ever, or mainly so; I have been round my old walks, a ShadowLady Sandwich’s da. Lady Harriet Ashburton; for her death, see 32:42–43TC to VL, 5 Dec. 1856. very sad and very beautiful escorting me throughout: the “Hall of the Past“Cf. Wilhelm Meister’s Apprenticeship, Works 24:153. it has all grown to me; and will so remain. One of my pilgrimages
was to the Church of Northington; I walked silently round that Building; visited the inside,—and read a little Tablet, “4 May 1857,“Lady Harriet’s d. date; she was buried at Northington Church, Alresford; see 32:145TC to JCA, 11 May 1857. whh will be memorable to me all the days of my life. Weak sorrow does not beseem one, dear Lady, as you well know; but there is no forgetting possible in certain cases;—and if I mention this one to you, it is sacred & silent from all other mortals.
On Sunday I will hope to see you; at any rate on Monday Evg
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-AG[AGIL], [Feb.]. Addr: Mrs Gilchrist. MS: Pierpont Morgan Lib. Quot: Gilchrist 114–15. Dated in the weeks before Anne Gilchrist moved from 6 Cheyne Row. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 3 February 1862.]
div3.head: JWC TO ANNE GILCHRIST

docBody.p: Mr Larkin, whom you have seen here, came to night to ask if you were returned home. He is looking for a house,Henry Larkin wrote later: “In 1862 I married; and, mainly at Mrs. Carlyle’s instigation, took the house, No. 6, next door … which was then falling vacant“ (Larkin, BQR 75). and, seeing a ticket in your window, he thought, if it was somewhere about the same rent as ours, that this house you are leaving (to my infinite regret) would suit him better than any he had yet looked at.
But he felt a delicacy about asking any questions, or asking to see the house if you were in it.

I told him that if you had advertised the house to be let, you had of course made up your mind to its being viewed; and that the business could be transacted with your servant, without your having to trouble yourself with him. But as he still seemed perplexed what to do, I told him I would warn you of his intention to call tomorrow afternoon; that the disagreeable visit might not take you by surprise and that you might give what instructions you liked to Ann before hand.

Since you are to go, I wish to Heaven you were out of all this! I know how dreadful these details must be! how little chance of calm there is for you till you have gathered yourself together in a new scene.Anne Gilchrist and her children moved to Shottermill, Surrey, in March.

Dont write but tell MariaJWC’s maid when delivering this letter by hand. how the little girl is?Probably Grace; Beatrice had been the first to fall ill (see 37:254JWC to AGIL, 26 Oct. 1861) and would presumably have recovered by now. and how your own head is?
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A[LLA], 6 Feb. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Dear Lady Ashburton,— Many thanks for the thrice-welcome Little Note, whh has come at last. I was in great impatience about it, expecting it since Monday. I had gone to Lady Sandwich; but she knew nothing more than myself, “that QuainDr. Richard Quain. had been sent for“:—today I shd have been at Lowe or somebody, had not your good news come.

It is now as good as certain to me that Lord A. will go on well; and visibly acquire strength from week to week and from day to day. I am convinced it was we, and our noisy socialities, that threw him into that fit of sore throat. Of course you will do your best and utmost; be not over-assiduous, over-anxious, nor do too much. For some hours daily, his solitary self with his Books and his thoughts, will be his best society; then a drive together, looked forward to, and looked back upon, as the flower of the day:—if you once had him able to ride on horseback again, the young woods, the spring skies and breezy downs, and the rural interests and businesses he has are wholesome occupation; above all, for the healthy mind that has the misfortune to be lodged in a body not healthy! We will look for you, in clearly improved circumstances, about Easter time, for so much of Town-life as you judge it good to venture on,—not too much. You have never yet fairly tried a Summer of The Grange. Perhaps I exaggerate; but it seems to me there could be no healthier location in all the world. And if it were not for that defunct King of Prussia (worse luck to him!) I would myself come and try.

My Wife I found a great deal better. She now gets out almost daily; takes to her household and other cares again;—speaks of running down to Brighton for 4 days;—and, in spite of her great weakness, looks really promising. Always keeps up her heart, poor soul; and, in the worst extremity, is wonderfully cheerful.

For myself I seem to have done almost nothing but sleep since my return. I suppose it is really my form of improvement in health. Never in my life have I felt wearier, less able for despatch of work;—and yet there is behind that, a sense that I am really somewhat better for my airing & galloping & talk with friends.— Mill’s American Article is a poor shrieky Piece;John Stuart Mill, “The Contest in America,“ Fraser’s Magazine 65 (Feb. 1862): 258–68. It was written in the aftermath of the Trent affair when Capt. Charles Wilkes (1798–1877) of the U.S. navy seized two Confederate commissioners to Britain, James Murray Mason (1798–1871) and John Slidell (1793–1871), from a neutral British ship, the Trent, 8 Nov. 1861. Seen as an insult to the British flag, this aroused widespread fury in Britain. The two men were released after prolonged diplomatic negotiations, late Dec. 1861, and allowed to continue on their journey. Mill praised the U.S. government’s decision: “Mr. Lincoln’s Government have … said, in direct terms, that our demand was right; that they yielded to it because it was just“ (Fraser’s 65:260). He wrote: “[W]e ought to dismiss from our minds as far as possible, those feelings against the North, which have been engendered not merely by the Trent aggression, but by the previous anti-British effusions of [U.S.] newspaper writers and stump orators“ (Fraser’s 65:259). The article also contained a passionate attack on slavery and the opinion that, although the Republican Party was not at the time an abolitionist party, it was likely that if the war went on for long it would become abolitionist: “Those who have read, even cursorily, the most valuable testimony to which the English public have access concerning the real state of affairs in America—the letters of the Times correspondent, Mr. Russell—must have observed how early and rapidly he arrived at the same conclusion, and with what increasing emphasis he now continually reiterates it“ (Fraser’s 65:263). Mill concluded that the longer the war went on, the better. For the earlier reports by William Howard Russell (1820–1907; ODNB) on the American Civil War, see 37:210TC to JAC, 9 Aug. 1861. in case you have it not, here it is; in case you have, it can be burnt. Yours ever truly / T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 7 Feb. MS: NLS 525.88. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Dear Brother,—Here (2 p.m.) has your Note come, the second I have had since my return. A small word is better than none.— I must put off reading the Adjunct Notes till dinner time; nothing can exceed my struggle to get something done this day, not nothing as in most of the past days!

Jane is a good deal better; gets out &c;—but must be very cautious now that the weather has suddenly grown cold again. I too seem to feel intrinsically better for my Hampshire visit (ended, Saturday last). But ever since my getting home, there has been the strangest sleepiness upon me (only going fairly, this day); and to get work done, especially this miserable kind of fiddle-tuning, has been much of an impossibility!

Night before last, BurtonJohn Hill Burton (1809–81; ODNB), Scottish historian, journalist, and political economist; he sent TC a copy of his edn. of Alexander Carlyle, Autobiography of the Rev. Dr Alexander Carlyle, Minister of Inveresk Edinburgh, (1860), Dec. 1860; see 37:52TC to JHB, 4 Dec. 1860. from Edinr (a very curious apparition, totally difft from what one had figured him!) came bustling in; talked a good while, pleasantly enough, in his limited but honest dialect;Burton was from Aberdeen, NE Scotland.—had seen you “three times in Edinr the day before.“ I walked him to Hyde-Park Corner (roads being all mysterious to him), after whh he insisted on accompanying me back near a mile; at the Horns Tavern (west of yr old Lodging),The Bell and Horns, 18th-cent. inn, at the junction of Thurloe Pl. and Brompton Rd.; John A. Carlyle had often lodged at 48 Brompton Rd.; see 31:150TC to AJS, 5 Aug. 1856. as the road forked there, and he might loose himself, I compelled a return. If he come agn, he shall be welcomed, poor little soul.

If you can get anything out of Currie or another source of the kind, for Scotsbrig James, it will be an evidt & great benefit! Nothing more salutary I shd say; try whatever you can!— Yours ever T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-IEB, [13 Feb.]. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Pbd: Blunt, Forum 66 (1921): 541–42; Blunt, CR 159–60 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO ISABELLA E. BARNES

docBody.p: Dear little girl! that is going to be spirited away from me, into “the house of bondage,“ (vide Captain Cuttle—“and when found make a mark of it!”)Captain Cuttle in Dickens, Dombey and Son (1848), describes marriage as a “house of bondage“ and uses “when found, make a note of it“ as a catchphrase. aren’t you coming to see me first? I have been expecting you today, every minute; and expected you all yesterday. Maria said you promised to come yesterday morning; having first asked at what hour I went out; and she having answered that I “generally went out at one oclock“—“one oclock?“—“Generally“? What did you mean by saying that? Don’t I generally not go out at all?— Haven’t I been out just once in the last fortnight?“— “Yes“!—“and didn’t I go out then at half after two?“— “Yes“!—“then, what did you mean by saying I “generally went out, at one“?— “Well!—I meant!—! I don’t know“!
My dear prospective young Housewife! beware of Servants who write poetry! they haven’t common sense ever!
But are you coming tomorrow morning? or when? I must see you again before—

Unless the weather mends materially, it would be madness for me to go to the Church in my wedding garments; not having the excitement of going to be married myself to nerve me against catching cold. Whether even that will save yourself from the natural consequences of a low dress and bare head in winter remains to be seen! Mrs BluntFrances Blunt, wife of Gerald Blunt, rector of St. Luke’s, Chelsea. asked me to go with them; and I should like that—and should like to see you made away with! If only it come warm enough to be out so long in fine clothes! but at all rates I hope to live to present myself at the house at one oclock— I wish you would come and see my new bonnet for the occasion—it will be lost on you when the occasion is there— It is lovely! Your ever affectionate / JWC

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [13 Feb.]. MS: NLS 607.606. Quot: Fielding and Sorensen 272–73. Dated by the start of TC’s visit to The Grange.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: My motive in this present writing is purely selfish. I have nothing to tell that feels to need to be told. But I want to hear about you; and to obtain that gratification I must write and ask for it. I have no pleasant visit to tell of. nor pleasant anything I have never left home! and only some half dozen times have been out of doors since you last heard from me!Presumably the missing letter JWC to MR, 1 Jan. In the first week of the new year (which began I must say with the most fortunate omens!— So much for omens!) I had a relapse of my illness, more severe than what had gone before, and more aggravating; because a little care, and composure, and common sense might have prevented it!

On newyearsday I let my House maid go for a Holyday— Mistake the first! for the girl had been coughing furiously for a week or two. But I had refused to let her attend “a midnight Religious Meeting“ the previous night. and I had not strength of mind to say another ‘no’; tho I knew it would be best for herself. She came home much excited and pleased but complained that her “legs had never warmed all day“— Next day she dragged about with “a headache,“ and the next again when she brought me my breakfast in bed She said she was “so giddy she thought she must fall.“ I ordered her to bed at once and when I had got my clothes on went to see her. She was sleeping heavily—again and again I found her sleeping—and grew frightened at such heavy sleep. At last she awoke as I was standing looking at her, sat up in bed with wild, gleaming eyes, and for the rest; was—as mad my Dear, as a March Hare! chattering incoherent nonsense amidst laughter and sobbs! She must have got a fever I thought, and the same fatal fever that had raged at next door and been fatal to the Master!Alexander Gilchrist. Mistake the second! without knowing the symptoms of scarletfever I was a fool to settle upon that.

I sent for my Doctor: but he was out and did not come for four hours!—and these four hours I devoted to picturing out the other girl and Mr Carlyle laid down thro’ infection—and Mr C of course killed like Mr Gilchrist!! Meanwhile I kept running backwards & forwards after Maria, keeping my terrors locked in my own breast, and neglecting the necessary precautions to be taken against Mr C’s draughts in the stair-case, viz wearing a shawl and bonnet!! Mistake the third!—and so by the time Mr Barnes came and told me
it was a case of “Severe inflamatory cold complicated with Hysteria“ and that the Girl would probably be all right in a aRepeated at turn of page. few days; I had realized for myself thro’ the unusal fatigue and exposure; and above all the fright, such a new Influenza as confined me to bed in perfect wretchedness for ten days, and to the house for weeks!— I am only now beginning to drive out on favourable days. The Girl was confined to her bed for a week. And the poor little Roman Catholic Welsh womanMargaret was Irish; JWC often referred to her as Welsh. Jewsbury wrote to Mantell, 25 Feb., that she could not give his servant, Ellen Sullivan, Margaret’s sister, any news: “Margaret (tell Ellen) I have not seen as of course I cannot go to Mrs Carlyle when she shews so unmistakenly that she does not want me“ (Mantell). with a horrid cold of her own had us both to wait upon, besides Mr C, who, like most men, has no notion that any discription of household crisis should interfere in any one particular with the details of service he is accustomed to. Now if I had just kept myself quiet and rational, what a difference it would have made!

I persuaded Mr C some three weeks ago to go and get done with that long talked of visitTo The Grange, 27 Jan.–1 Feb. by himself—and relieve me of the fret of being required to get well, sooner than I could! So he went and actually staid a week, and I think was much the better for it.

Maria (the Housemaid) has quite recovered—except that to my imagination perhaps—there is a certain weak-mindedness about her—a sort of numbness of her natural intelligence, and clipping affectation in the tones of her voice! If I could give over watching her! But when one has so little communication with the outer-world above all with the outer air it is difficult to avoid occupying oneself morbidly with the affairs within doors.

The last day I was out, I went to see two of my most intimate friends here who are both, I fear, dying the one a beautiful bright little Mrs Twisleton,Ellen Twisleton. who, after having been treated for two years by all the first Doctors for Neuralgia, is discovered to have a far advanced tumour in her left side! LocockCharles Locock (1799–1875; ODNB), physician, of whom the Carlyles strongly dis-approved; see 32:87–88TC to LOA, 12 Feb. 1857, and 106TC to JAC, 21 March 1857. says it “is not absolutely incurable“ which means, I suppose, that he has no hope of her. She has next to none of herself! but is lying there as calm (when out of agony) and heroic, and loving as an angel! The other is Countess Pepoli, who has been shut up in her room for six months with a cough and difficult breathing. Alone, having left her husband and own family in Italy,Carlo Pepoli had returned to Italy, 1859; her brother, John Fergus, and sister Jessie Fergus were visiting Italy; see JWC to MR, [14 April]. and refusing to let any of them come to her, “because, she says, when one can be no pleasure to ones friends it is much best to be without them!! and
anyone in the house with her would only give her the fret and trouble of thinking about their dinners &c!!!Elizabeth Pepoli wrote to JWC, 31 Dec. 1861: “A good new year to you my dear Jane I like the old words—/ Think how vexed I was to lose that rare satisfaction a little talk with you—/ People forget my complaint is on my chest and stay talking thinking they are doing the proudest thing in this world— Yesterday I was quite exhausted and today I forbid any one to be allowed to come upstairs. … / My accounts from Pisa continue as usual / This needs no answer.“ there is stoicism in that but not heroism—not lovingness She has a dreadfully sharp haggard look that freezes one’s sympathy. When I saw her after so many months of mutual illness, she asked me after two minutes if I “had read Mrs Delany’s memoirsThe Autobiography and Correspondence of Mary Granville, Mrs. Delany, ed. Lady Llanover, 6 vols. (1861–62); Mary Delany, b. Granville (1700–1788; ODNB), artist, letter writer; favorite at the court of George III. and what I thought of the Book“!!! She has two Servants—sistersUnidentified further.—who have been with her ever since her marriage,In 1839. and who are kind attached creatures and even them she repells, and they told me with tears that when they wished to stay in her room in nights when she looked too ill to be left alone she ordered them away “quite angrily.“ Oh the difference between these two women! and yet they are both brave in their several ways! Count Pepoli is made something important in his native Bolognia, “Governor“ or something,The Times reported, 25 Dec. 1861, that the Italian government was “to appoint Count Carlo Pepoli to the honourable, but somewhat dangerous, office of Sindaco, or Mayor, of the city of Bologna.“ They reported, 8 Feb.: “Order reigns at Bologna, under the wise and firm rule of the new Prefect, Magenta, and the new Syndic, Carlo Pepoli.“ and one of her servants told me “the Countess was fretting dreadfully, she thought, that she wasnt well enough to be with him now, when she would have been of use at the head of his house“! Her vanity about “Carlo“s greatness was the only human trait I found in her the other day.
What a melancholy letter! Well! it is a melancholy world!
Write soon—give my love to the best of DoctorsMary Russell’s husband, James.—and believe me ever your affectionate / Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 14 Feb. MS: NLS 517.32. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Pardon again for unavoidable brevity (it is near 4 p. m.,—no riding today); one little word in time is better than two after delays.

I am very glad you continue yr exertions for our Junior of Scotsbrig:Their nephew James Carlyle; see TC to JAC, 30 Jan.; “you do“: thus in MS. it is very kind and beneficent of you do so, and I hope you will continue. For except thro’ you he has little chance of getting delivered from ‘his present state of futile pluistering,’—seeking farms to no purpose, in whh he might easily succeed ill if he got them;—a condition of life not at all good for him. Do yr best to help the poor fellow out of that,—thro’ Currie or some other.

That of getting into some Govt Office in the Isle of FranceMauritius was called Île de France while under French control, 1715–1810. or elsewhere I clearly perceive to be moonshine altogether; first because “£1,000 a-year,“ or anything approaching, wd be entirely unsuitable to him & he to it (perhaps worse, very much, than his present posture); and, secondly, because he has not the slightest chance to be able to get it. I have hardly spoken above once, in my life, to the Duke of Newcastle;Henry Pelham Fiennes Pelham-Clinton (1811–64; ODNB), 5th duke of Newcastle under Lyme, politician; colonial secretary, 1859–64, therefore in a position to help. TC’s meeting with him is untraced. John A. Carlyle wrote to James Carlyle Jr., 20 Feb.: “I agree with you in regard to the Govt situation of £400 a year, but there seems to be no prospect of getting it any more than the other of £1000. … I shall try to see [Currie] … & have a talk about the whole of our project.“ He wrote again, 28 Feb.: “I am much impressed with what [Currie] again says of the Clerkship, & I mean to try whether any application, direct or indirect, can be made to the Duke for it. … Mr Currie did well in not speaking to your uncle on the subject“; and 8 March: “I don’t think anything could come of your writing to the Duke of N. & it would not be easy to do in your present position.“ He then wrote, 13 March: “What you say about situations, & writing to the Duke of Newcastle … is quite right. I don’t think there is any likelihood of getting occupation in a mercantile way so long as times continue so bad“ (MSS: NLS Acc. 9086). a thin commonplace man, who cares not a doit for me, or the like of me; and will feel bound, by a kind of “principle,“ to give away any place that falls vacant to some dependent’s dependt (for smoothness, & to strengthen his own poor hands): an application from me, especially for one whom I cannot pretend to recommend for fitness, wd produce nothing but an arching of the scraggy Ducal brows, & a “No“ elaborately sealed in red wax!

If Currie in Maurits, or another in any climate Jamie cd live in, cd procure him some honest Clerkship like what he had, that wd be the thing! Keep trying for that, where you can.— Nothing wrong here.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: There is a go: I have had two sheets lying together!

div3.sourceNote: TC-JR[JRU], 14 Feb. MS: NLS 23167. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN RUSKIN

docBody.p: Dear Ruskin,—I am regretting very much to see so little of you while you are near.Ruskin had been abroad during the last half of 1861, returning 31 Dec. The day before yesterday I was under way to you; just putting foot in stirrup,—when a man came to ride with me, and we had to take a difft direction. Sunday next, I again propose riding over (subject to casualties); may arrive between 3 and 4; but cannot stay dinner, this time;—nor are you to tie yourself, with any tightness, to waiting at that hour upon so loose a tryste. Let me take my chance;—and be sure of a wholesome ride plus hope, whh will be reward enough for so unprofitable a creature. You cannot now write to forbid,TC wrote on Fri., so presumably could not expect a reply in time to prevent his visiting Ruskin on Sun. (16 Feb.). at any rate.— The Wife is a great deal better.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle
docBody.note: Ruskin wrote to Lady Trevelyan, ca. 13 Jan.: “Frederick is very fine, but too full of names; my mother likes to hear bits read, but I’ve to put the names out of my mouth like fishbones, first, before I can get through a sentence—and skip not a little“ (Reflections of a Friendship, ed. Virginia Surtees [1979] 184).

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MML, [ca. mid-Feb.]. MS: EUL. Quot: Fielding and Sorensen 272. Martha Macdonald Lamont (ca. 1803–78; see JWC to MML, 29 Dec. 1843), author; known to JWC since 1843, their last recorded contact was in 1849; see JWC to MML, 1 Aug. 1849. Conjecturally dated by JWC’s confinement to the house since Nov. 1861. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 15 February 1862.]
div3.head: JWC TO MARTHA M. LAMONT

docBody.p: Just two lines to keep you from speculating; I am not up to a letter; being only half recovered from a long and fatiguing illness.
No—I am sure you were not to blame for the failure of last June.Presumably Lamont had suggested meeting.
Neither was I to blame; at least not much.

I was prevented from paying that visit at WokingWoking, Surrey, 26 mi. (42 km.) SW of London. by the sudden discovery that my Cook had an abcess which made her life “unsafe for twelve hours“Matilda, cook with the Carlyles for only a few weeks before falling ill, July 1861; see 37:180–81JWC to MR, 3 July 1861, and 27037:biographical note.— After a day or two of terrible anxiety she had to be removed to St Georges
Hospital for surgical treatment, and I, too weak at the time for such shocks had to take to bed so soon as I could be moved I was ordered to the seasideand went for a fortnight to RamsgateJWC went to Ramsgate with Geraldine Jewsbury 3–10 Aug. 1861; see 37:197JWC to TC, 4 Aug. 1861, and 217JWC to JAO, 23 Aug. 1861.—
And that was how you heard no more of me— And I am sure you can’t be angry! at least if you are a Xian!

Neither must you be angry that I say only the absolutely needful; for I am so worn out with suffering and confinement to the house—three months of it; that I have as great a horror of pen and ink as a mad dog has of water.
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JN, [15 Feb.]. MS: NLS 554.61. Pbd: Scudder, JWCN 32–33. Quot: Wilson 5:475. Dated by the reference to St. Valentine’s day.
div3.head: JWC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Mr C in rushing out to his horse has just called to me to send you a line, to say “how he is situated.“

His situation is this! Lord Ashburton is come to town for two days—very ill—and “will want Mr C to sit with him tomorrow evening.“ And you were to have come here tomorrow evening! You are requested then to understand the situation and “to come some day of the week—or at all events next Sunday evening instead.“
For the other matter of which you wrote to myself; I was letting it lie over till I should see you tomorrow—but I must now go into it on paper—

Since poor Mr Gilchrist’s death there seems to have been a prevailing idea that i am the natural person thro’ whom all applications for lent ‘books’ and ‘papers’ is to [be]Word omitted on MS. made to Mrs Gilchrist!! Now it is anything but an agreeable mission this, to put on me, and I have complied several times, with reluctance, but I protest against going on with this sort of thing, which must be making me perfectly odious to the poor woma[n] and with which I have no business!

Tell Mr Robinson, whom I was believing peacefully laid at rest years and years ago, to write a note himself to the Widow, stating precisely what the papers are—and I have no doubt they will be safely restored to him.Henry Crabb Robinson (1775–1867; ODNB), diarist and journalist; see 3:108TC to HCR, 12 July 1824; friendly with TC in the 1830s, but with little contact since. TC last noted seeing him at the Athenaeum Club in 1853; see 28:69TC to JAC, 10 March 1853. Crabb Robinson had been a friend of William Blake, and apparently lent Alexander Gilchrist material for the Life of Blake (1863).

If you had written to say you had got another box of good teaNeuberg also gave them tea the previous year; see 37:114JWC to JN, 1 Feb. 1861. I should have
thought it a better Valentine Love to your Sister and the nice little NieceNeuberg’s sister Rosetta Frankau, and her da., Gertrude. yours faithfully / J Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 17 Feb. MS: NLS 517.33 inc. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: My “work“ (sorrow on it), at this point is such a struggle among dancing atoms, that it has been going on even with unusual confusions, slowness and difficulty: otherwise I shd not have been silent to you so long. I heard indeed, and I suppose you hear, thro’ the Dr (who has a peculiar tendency to stuff old Letters into his cover, by way of saving trouble to his own pen):John A. Carlyle wrote, 20 Feb., to James Carlyle Jr. an apparent confirmation of TC’s comment: “I will send the last two leaves of your letter by this day’s post to your uncle in order to correct his impressions of you, which I know were similar to mine stated above. I have not told him anything about your illness, so I keep back the first leaf of your letter.“ Although John may have been writing less to TC, he was corresponding frequently with James Jr., often with detailed advice; e.g., he wrote, 22 Feb.: “I remind you of the necessity of taking only the quantity of Pills that will produce one painless & complete evacuation, when required; & that quantity is ascertainable only by repeated trials. Too large doses might help to bring on again what you felt last Sunday, just as any undue stagnation in the bowels would tend to do. Regularity is the thing to be aimed at. I don’t think you have any actual disease of the heart; &, by taking good care of yourself for a month or two, I hope you might get quite free again. / Your letter of March last I have entirely forgotten, as well as the conversation in April; but I have no doubt your recollection of them is quite correct. It is really useless to return to the subject. Your magniloquent beginning, ‘I need not again attempt to lay the ghost of swaggering & pretension, who seems to be a periodical visitor,’ is itself what I should call a specimen of loose swaggering. When one has to treat of serious matters, it is much better to write in a simple & clear style & avoid all attempts at irrelevant smartness. I also thought the sketch you sent me from Moffat of the offer you intended to make to Mr Stewart was written in an inflated style, with many repetitions of shall wrongly used—neither Scotch nor English; & last autumn my wavering in regard to the farm in Lewis [see 37:237–38TC to JAC, 24 Sept. 1861] was mainly caused by the headlong style in which you wrote to me at the time. In this world it is much easier to fail than to succeed. I do believe you would succeed in anything you had made yourself fully master of; for you have many sterling good qualities & would be sufficiently zealous & industrious & prudent, if you had a fair chance. Let this suffice; & let us wholly devote ourselves to trying whether any such chance can be found for you. / 24th / I did not get this written till after post-time on saturday, & also missed the post of yesterday. At present I am very busy with one thing and another, & have little time for letters. I don’t keep yours, & therefore cannot refer to any of them. In that phrase of your last, quoted above, the swaggering consists in your presuming to take it for granted that I have come to this time of life without knowing what ghosts are at least as well as you; but I feel quite sure you were quite unconscious of any tendency to swaggering at the time you wrote it, & only meant to say something very smart“ (MSS: NLS Acc. 9086). but it is always better if one get a word now & then from the fountain head.

We are not unwell in any respect; nay Jane is very much better than common; strangely recovered out of four months of close confinement attended often with utter weakness, sleeplessness &c &c; & continues so in spite of the fickle and inclement weather. As cold and bitter as Spring can be we had it yesterday, and for a week before,—after a longish tract of muddy heat;—and, on a sudden, this morng we have mist, damp, and the old form of heat to an unpleasant degree amid the glar.— I call yesterday, in the course of my ride, at yr James’s door: he was unluckily just gone for a walk, and I cd not wait or return by that route; I expect we shall see him next Sunday. He has a nice clean little sitting room, is in the finest neighbour hood for Hills and airy Country walks; and yesterday I saw, for the first time, his old Landlady, who is an uncommonly nice-looking simple old body.James Aitken had recently moved; see TC to JCA, 31 Dec. 1861; his landlady not further identified. James I believe I may define to you as doing well in all respects.

Your eyes, I hope, do not trouble you farther.Jean Carlyle Aitken wrote, 30 Jan.: “I have been wanting to write to you for a week or more but I have been bothered with sore eyes for abt ten days … which is a most uncomfortable thing as I cannot bear to sew or write—one of them is better today however & I hope they will soon be all right.“ I had the disorder once, above 50 years ago and not again; but have never forgotten it since.— Have you settled the form of the House,The Aitkens had hoped to buy a house (see 37:68TC to JCA, 21 Dec. 1860) but decided to build one instead. It was built in Lochmaben Rd. and named The Hill. then? You ought to be starting straightway to take the good weather with you; I wish I cd help you with an idea that were useful! For one thing, I shd say, plenty of room being so undeniable a benefit, two stories are surely preferable to one,—in point of cheapness, were it nothing else? I confess too I regard, with suspicion, all the modern ornamental “cottage“MS ends here. Jean enclosed a genealogical tree with her letter, 30 Jan.: “a branch of the ‘tree’ wh John has copied off in a rough way for me using the end of a pirn to make his circles—this is our entire branch; & is unfortunately somewhat incomplete in two of the names—‘the ink in the old papers being unreadable.’ … Well not to tax your patience too far the story begins with ‘Crinan of the Western Isles’ & after 23 generations ends with ‘George Lord Carlyle son of George of Dumfries who was Grandson of Michael of 1573 succeeded William 3rd of Locharthur.’ / But I will not attempt any of the side branches or indeed any more of the matter here—we have got a copy of the document which will cut no bread lying snug in a drawer till sometime you have leisure to look into it“ (MS: NLS 1768.22). TC wrote beside his grandfather Thomas Carlyle’s entry: “[T]his, then, is my Grandfr,—whom I remember, abt 84. Must have been born, 1720. Had 4 sons (my Fr 2d) & 3 drs.“ Thomas Carlyle (1722–1806); see 1:138TC to JCE, 2 Sept. 1818, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 17–21. TC wrote on the envelope: “‘Carlyle Pedigree’ ‘keep carefully; / don’t copy.’“ For a detail of the family tree, see oppabove.

figure.p: “Carlyle Pedigree“ (detail)

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, 23 Feb. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries N. B. PM: London, 24 Feb. 1862. MS: NLS 607.586. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:94–97 inc. Quot: Wilson 5:448; Bliss, JWC 291–92; Simpsons 102–3; Southern, “The Carlyles and St. Luke“ 480.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
Oh my Dear what a horrid thing! It still makes my flesh creep all over, whenever I think of it!—and I think of it—a great deal oftener than there is
occasion for! since, thank God, he is now on foot again! But—I have seen that Safe! I can appreciate to the full, the crash of it’s lid, smack down on human fingers!— Mercy! what a piece of capital good stuff the Dr must have been made of originally, that his fingers should have stuck together thro’ such an accident instead of being all pounded into mush! That is not what surprises me most however, in the business! What surprises me most is, that the Dr, being a Dr, and a good, skilful one, should have gone about after, braving such a hurt, as tho’ he had never in his life heard of lockedjaw, or gangrene, or fever! I dont wonder that you were terrified! I wonder rather that you are not, now when your nursing is no more, needed, in a brain fever yourself! The longer I live, the more I am certified that men, in all that relates to their own health, have not common sense! whether it be their Pride, or their Impatience, or their Obstinacy or their ingrained Spirit of Contradiction that stultifies and misleads them—the result is always a certain amount of idiocy or distraction, in their dealings with their own bodies! I am not generalizing from my own Husband. I know that he is a quite extravagant example of that want of common sense in bodily matters, which I complain of. Few men (even) are so lost to themselves as to dry their soaked trowsers on their legs! (as he does) or swallow five grains of mercury in the middle of the day, and then walk or ride three hours under a plunge of rain! (as he does) &c &c But men generally—all of them I have ever had to do with—even your sensible Husband included you see!—drive the poor women who care for them to despair; either by their wild impatience of bodily suffering, and the exaggerated moan they make over it, or else by their reckless defiance of it, and neglect of every dictate of Prudence! There! you may tell the Dr what I say! It wont do him the slightest good against next time; but it is well he should know what one thinks of him! that one does not approve of such costly heroism at all!
I have nothing new to tell you. Which is lucky. As the things that have happened, this long time back, have been of a disastrous sort.

I go out now occasionally for a drive—walking tires me too much— I have even been twice out at dinner last week! and was at a WeddingThe wedding of Isabella Barnes and John Simmonds. besides!!! The two dinners were of the quietest; at the one (Miss Baring’s) nobody but Lord Ashburton who had come up from the Grange for a consultation—at the other (Lady Sandwich’s) nobody but the Marchioness of Lothian,Lady Cecil Chetwynd Kerr, dowager marchioness of Lothian. who having lived thirty years in Scotland is as good as a Scotch woman.Lady Kerr was born in Staffordshire but after her marriage, 1831, lived at Newbattle Abbey, Midlothian, about 9 mi. (14.5 km.) SE of Edinburgh, and at Monteviot, Roxburghshire, about 45 mi. (73 km.) SE of Edinburgh. But the wedding was an immense affair! It was my Dr’s little Daughter who was being
married after a three years engagement, and as soon as she was engaged she had made me promise to attend her wedding. I had rather wished to see a Marriage performed in a Church with all the forms—the eight bridesmaids &c &cWeddings in Scotland were generally much simpler, often taking place in the bride’s home. The Carlyles’ own wedding was at Templand, home of JWC’s maternal grandfather, Walter Welsh; the only guests were JWC’s mother, Grace Welsh, her grandfather, her Aunt Jeannie, and TC’s brother John. JWC wrote to her aunt Margaret Welsh, 1 Oct. 1826: “I would invite you to my wedding if I meant to invite anyone; but, to my taste, such ceremonies cannot be too private: besides by making distinction, among my relatives on the occasion, I should be sure to give offence“ (4:141); for the arrangements, see 4:147JBW to TC, 3 Oct. 1826, and 150–51TC to JBW, 9 Oct. 1826.— But I had renounced all idea of going to the church—for fear of being laid up with a fresh cold, and meant to attend only the breakfast party after—in which I took less interest. But imagine how good the people here are to me. Our RectorGerald Blunt. in whose church (St Luke’s) the marriage was to take place, being told by his wife,Frances Blunt. I wished to go, but durstn’t for fear of the coldness of the Church, ordered the fires to be kept up from Sunday over into Tuesday morning!! besides a rousing fire in the Vestry where I sat at my ease till the moment the ceremony began— I was much pressed afterwards to acknowledge how superior the English way of marrying was to the Scotch and asked how I had liked it. I said my feelings were very mixed—‘mixed?’ the Rector asked—“mixed of what? Well I said, “it looked to me something betwixt a Religious Ceremony and a—Pantomime!“— So it is!— There were 44 people at the breakfast!

Countess Pepoli has rallied quite wonderfully. I forced myself to pay her another visit last week—and was rewarded by finding her less ungenial and aggravating. Erasmus WilsonSir William James Erasmus Wilson (1809–84; ODNB), physician, surgeon, and dermatologist. told her Servants she could not possible recover—a good many weeks ago—but London Great Doctors make the wonderfullest blunders!— Poor Mrs Twisleton is suffering less for the time being
I hope you wont be long of writing as I shall feel anxious to know for certain that the Dr goes on well and that you have not fallen quite ill
docBody.name: J W Carlyle
docBody.note: Frances Blunt wrote in her journal, 21 Feb.: “G. and I drank tea with the Carlyles. Met Mr. Ruskin. … Very friendly and pleasant“ (Reginald Blunt, Memoirs of Gerald Blunt [1911] 81). Thomas Erskine wrote TC from 41 Charlotte Sq., Edinburgh, 22 Feb.: “I hardly pass a day without thinking of you—and yet I have allowed many months to say the least to roll away, without any direct word to or from you— I cannot allow this to go on any longer on my part—though I am far from making any demand on your time, which I daresay is occupied to overflowing. Your old friend Sir G. Sinclair has been in Edinburgh for the last two or three weeks—& I never meet him without some talk of you. He seems to hope for a visit from you this summer, after Frederic is fairly out of hand, in which case, I may have a chance of a sight of you in passing. He is somewhat annoyed by some of the unfavorable accompaniments of age, but yet seems to have the capacity of enjoying life little impaired, as his kindly affections are in full strength & exercise. … We, domestically, are much in statu quo—making allowance for advancing years, which as yet press lightly on us—and we all desire to send our most kindly salutations to you & Mrs Carlyle who I hope is well.“ Erskine and his sisters Christian Stirling and David Paterson spent winters in Edinburgh. For TC’s visit to Sir George Sinclair in Thurso, Aug.–Sept. 1860, see vol. 36.

div3.sourceNote: TC-[WM][WCM], [23 Feb.]. MS: Sold by Parke-Bernet, 3 Nov. 1943, from the collection of “the late Alba B. Johnson.“ The Parke-Bernet catalog notes the letter, “21/4 pp.,“ was “To Thomas Macready. With a portrait,“ but the sentence they quote indicates that it was to William Macready, about his son Edward.
div3.head: TC TO [WILLIAM MACREADY]

docBody.p: [“A kindly letter reading in part as follows: ‘ … Probably you have no news at all of your unfortunate prodigalEdward Neville Bourne Macready (b. 1836). TC had written to Duffy about him, enclosing a letter from Macready, in 1859; see 35:70–71TC to GCD, 13 April 1859, and Duffy 202–10. TC also commented on Edward to Forster in 1860; see 36:42TC to JF, 14 Jan. 1860, and 51TC to JF, 24 Jan. 1860. Toynbee noted about Edward: “[E]ducated at Westminster, Sherborne, and Addiscombe. Joined the Indian Army, but soon resigned his commission and became a ‘rolling stone,’ finally trying the stage but with little success. Of a bright, active disposition he lacked ‘ballast,’ and became a source of much trouble and disappointment to his father in after years“ (Diaries of William Charles Macready, 1833—1851, ed. William Toynbee [1912] 1:277). … but the poor fellow actually seems to have, of himself, begun reforming from the bottom; and may yet become a better (far better and braver) man, than if he had never fallen! … ’“]

div3.sourceNote: TC-WA, 3 March. MS: NLS 3823.127. Pbd: Allingham 135–36.
div3.head: TC TO WILLIAM ALLINGHAM

docBody.p:
Dear Allingham,—We got the little Ballyshannon Almanack; and, tho’ there is nothing said of you in print or ms. there, I recognise very well who wrote the pleasant and excellent Historical Introduction;Ballyshannon Almanac, North-Western Directory, and General Advertiser for 1862 (Dublin, 1862); Allingham wrote its unsigned introductory survey describing the history and geographical location of Ballyshannon and the location’s importance in the development of the town. whh might (if its laudable modesty wd permit) boast itself to be perhaps the very best ever written anywhere for such a purpose. I have read it with real entertainment and instruction on my own behoof, and with real satisfaction on yours. So clear, so
brief, definite, graphic; and a fine genially human tone in it. That is the feat: to extract a little Poetry (whh is not Fiction) from the bleak rocks and bare hillsides of the Irish Fact lying round you, squalid enough and contradictory enough!TC visited Ireland in 1849 and described the area around Ballyshannon as “ugly, bare, moory country“ (Carlyle, Reminiscences of My Irish Journey in 1849 [1882] 224). He breakfasted there, 1 Aug. 1849, and commented on the “steep narrow street of ‘Bally-shannon’; mills, breweries, considerable, confused, much white-washed country town“ (Irish Journey 225). You have read well,—or fairly begun to do so,—and to think; and be silent, till you find out. Persist in that course, if you are hero enough; and you will decidedly come to something.Allingham asked TC’s advice previously about the study of history; see 25:107–8TC to WA, 29 June 1850, and 25:192–94TC to WA, 4 Sept. 1850. TC wrote to Allingham, 25 Dec. 1865: “I thot, and think, the Introductn there showed a very pretty talent, and remarkable diligence in investigating,—to whh add patience, sagacity, sobriety in ditto and you have the basis of all talent for History“ and then encouraged Allingham to write more on Irish history (MS: NLS 3823.131).— I ought to say also that I saw, in some accidental No of a Nth British Review, a Song of yours,Allingham and his poem “Mary Donnelly“ were featured in Gerald Massey, “Poets and Poetry of Young Ireland,“ North British Review 35 (Nov. 1861): 440–41. whh I thot a real bit of rhythm and melody. Very good that too, when one can have it of the genuine kind. A little of that too, if you find it come: a little, not at all very much, and only by way [of]Omitted on MS. fringe or shirt-frill to the other sort!— These things are really my meaning; and I have not above 10 minutes to write them down in.

I am myself still tugging at the galley-oar; one of the most tired of all enslaved creatures. I thot to have got free last year; but it will, at the very best, be the end of this year, before I get my chain filed thro’. My Wife (who has been very weakly, but is now improving fast as the season mends) sends her kind regards. I remain Yours truly
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JD[JAD], 8 March. MS: NLS 1797.63. Quot: Fielding and Sorenson 273–74.
div3.head: JWC TO JANE DODS

docBody.p:
Was it you, Dear, who sent me Good WordsLiberal, evangelical monthly magazine, pbd. Edinburgh, Jan. 1860–Dec. 1907.—not “out of your own head“Coterie speech; see 33:87JWC to WDO, 19 Sept. 1857. (as the children say) but out of other peoples heads?— Confused amongst so many Lady-handwritings, that I am seeing every day, I couldn’t have formed
even a guess, who wrote the direction on the Magazines; if it hadn’t been for the Post mark! But “Haddington“ pointed distinctly to someone there, still remembering my existence, and even caring for me—to the extent of showing me a spontaneous attention! And I can count up only four such exceptionally mindful and well inclined Individuals, still extant for me in the old Home, where I had been used to believe myself (little Goose!), an object of undying interest to the Community!— Just four Individuals, within the whole range of the Haddington Post-mark, to be considered capable of having sent me Good Words! (“Oh devouring Time!“)Cf. Ovid, Metamorphoses bk. 15, line 234. And these four are—?— You— Your Husband Mrs D Davidson,David Davidson’s aunt Janet Davidson. and Jackie Welsh!JWC’s cousin John Amelia Welsh, known as Jackie. But it was not your Husband who had directed those packets; I took in the look of his handwriting in the course of the Mathematical lessons,See 36:22JWC to MR, 9 Dec. 1859, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 43–44. in my thirteenth year; and could have recognised it anywhere, and any time between then and now! Yes! I am certain I could have recognised William Dods’s handwriting however it might have taken me by surprise!—suppose it had fluttered down on my head from a Balloon(!) (as a printed Bill actually did one day in Sloane Street!) or suppose it had been washed to my feet in a corked bottle by the waves of the Sea! “The force of Supposition can no further go!”

Neither was it Jackie Welsh who had written the direction. For, curiously enough she writes our family-hand; only with a certain crampedness from want of practice! Yes! it is a fact worth notice for both Physiologists and Moralists, that Jackie is admirably Legitimate in her handwriting!

So the doubt is between you, whose handwriting I have not been favoured with a sight of often enough (the more’s the pity!) for recognising it infallibly without the corroborative evidence of a signature; and Mrs Davidson who writes, I recollect (just that and no more), a wonderfully good and modern hand, for her years.

If it was you, then, dear woman, who sent the good words; accept my warm thanks and a good kiss! If it was Mrs Davidson, do, please, write and tell me, that I may send her grateful words for her good ones!

For the rest; I had ten days in bed after my last note to you; and more weeks on the sofa; and had to give up my usual winter visit in Hampshire.Both Carlyles had been invited to The Grange, but JWC was too ill; TC went alone, 27 Jan–1 Feb. All along of my Housemaid’s “Hysterical Tendencies,“ and my own “Excitability“; which between them caused me more fatigue, and exposure, and fright, than I had strength to bear. But the weather grew mild as milk; and one
evening, when a Lady who had been acting as Honorary sick nurseProbably Sarah Dilberoglue; see JWC to CC, [31 Jan.]. to me all winter came in, on the points of her toes, to ask how I was, she found me dressed in black velvet and pearls, just going out to dinner!! The poor Lady’s face expressed exactly what the Man Nicholson said to me, at Haddington, when I had scaled the Church Yard wall; “Weel then! I declare! there’s no end o’ ye!“See JWC’s “Much Ado about Nothing,“ 24:166.— In truth the people who come about me are subjected to surprises no less startling than those of the “Wee Wifie who lived in a Shoe, and had so many Bairns, she didn’t know what to do!“—
“She went to the market to buy a sheeps head“
“When she came back the Bairns were a—dead
“She went to the wrights to buy them a coffin
“When she came back they were a-sitting laughing“For another version of “Old Mother Hubbard,“ see JWC’s 1856 “Journal,“ 30:249.
(loffin it should have been!
I transacted a second dinner within the week, and a—Wedding!

My Doctors little Daughter was getting herself married; and it had been a promise for two years that I should witness the Ceremony. And our Rector ordered the fires lighted in St Lukes on the Sunday to be kept in till Tuesday (the day of the Wedding) “that I might run no risk of a chill“!! It was the most astounding “delicate attention“ ever paid me in my Life!— And me a Presbyterian too!—

I had heard much of the “impressiveness“ of the English-Church Marriage-Service, but never before seen it “performed“— What did I think of it? they asked at The Breakfast after— “Do tell us how you liked it“? “What did you think of it?“— I told them since they would have it, (three Clergymen were among the questioners) that I thought it extremely like a—Pantomime!—and so it was! with the eight, white robed, Garlanded Bridesmaids all flopping on their knees at the same moment! and the two white-surpliced “officiating“ Clergymen,Rev. Gerald Blunt and Rev. Brooke Cremer Barnes; see JWC to MR, 23 Feb. attitudinizing at the Altar and reading, by turns, out of gigantic Prayer books! and the white-veiled Bride, like a little “Castle Spectre,“ arranged between her Father and her Bridegroom “before the Altar“!Castle Spectre (1796), Gothic melodrama by Matthew Gregory “Monk“ Lewis (1775–1818; ODNB), ends with a dramatic reunion between the heroine, her lover, and her father.— And the Pews and Galleries filled with gaping Spectators!—“Impressive“!— If I had doubted still about my descent from John Knox, I should have been satisfied of it, there and then; by the natural, genuine, burning desire I felt to sweep all that so called—‘religious’ Play-acting—white-surplices, crimson Altar and all the rest of it! out of Creation!

Since then, we have had again a fortnight of cutting East wind; during which I have again personated the Bairns “lying a dead“—but since yesterday that the wind turned to West, I have been the Bairns “all sitting laughing“!
Isn’t it humiliating to be acted upon by Wind, as if one were no better than a tin weathercock!

And now goodby! Write to me! Remember me to your Husband. You may tell him, he gave me such a horrid fright the day you and he were here,Jane and William Dods had planned to visit Chelsea Oct. 1861(see 37:230–31JWC to WDO, 16 Sept. 1861), and apparently did so. by his unamiable ways; that my hair showed signs of turning rapidly grey for a fortnight after!! But the prospect of “looking more respectable“ has again receded into the vague.
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle
docBody.note: Walter Mantell wrote to JWC, 8 March: “Our last English mail has not come & we are at a loss for the reason of its not coming. Whether war with America has thrown it into the hands of the gentlemanly skipper of some Yankee pirate or whether it be only delayed by one of the usual breakdowns of steamers, we cannot guess. Wanting the stimulus of recent news we shall find letter-writing hard this month—for me, I give in before this additional difficulty and shall probably not achieve a line beyond these few. Writing by every mail to everybody is silly dreariness after all— When I watch my flowers day by day they seem provokingly inprogressive but if I am away for a week their growth amazes me— Now my friends insist on watching me monthly and are of course disgusted at my apparent inertness & I catching the infection come to regard myself as one of the most useless of God’s creatures. I have half a mind to hide myself for a year or so from this too constant surveillance. / Tell Mr Carlyle that I have indeed been ‘patient with fools’ but am getting impatient with the only one I now see much of—myself.“

div3.sourceNote: TC-BC, 9 March. MS: Bodleian Lib., Oxford. Text from longhand copy.
div3.head: TC TO BLANCHE CLOUGH

docBody.p:
I had, the year before your marriage,The Cloughs had m. in 1854. three or perhaps four little Notes or LettersBlanche Clough wrote to TC, 6 March: “I saw Mr Froude a few days ago, who told me that you had still in your possession some letters from my husband, which he thought you would be willing to send me. I need not say how interesting they would be to me, if you do not object to letting me have them, & I am not giving you too much trouble.“ (intended to give me a business view of matters there,Clough wrote to TC when he visited New England, Oct. 1852–July 1853. but running out into pleasant snatches of general description now and then); whh I remember liking very much for their frankness, vivacity, fidelity, and very graphic power of setting both writer & subject before one. They shd be
infinitely at your service now,—if I only knew where to lay hand on them. They (or most of them) were read by E. Darwin,Erasmus Darwin. and I suppose by others of the circle interested in you and yours. I certainly cannot have destroyed these letters: but where they lie, or whether in my possession at all, is beyond my power to guess. It is above 10 years since (in these late confused operations of mine) there has been any sorting of private Papers here.— My wife has undertaken to search and examine, in chase of these New Engld Notes; and will do her best: if they or any of them do turn up, be sure I will at once let you have the good of such success. But, alas, I consider it doubtful (in spite of her excellt powers of search); and, in these months, am so hurried abt early & late, that I can myself do nothing effectual to assist.Apparently JWC did not find them, as none of Clough’s letters to TC were included in the vols. of Clough’s letters pbd. by Blanche Clough in the 1860s. They were, however, found later (perhaps after TC’s death), since three are pbd. in The Correspondence of Arthur Hugh Clough, ed. Frederick L. Mulhauser, 2 vols. (Oxford, 1957) 2:342–44 (3 Dec. 1852), 2:394–97 (16 March 1853), and 2:420–23 (21 April 1853).

closer.salute: Believe me / Your, Dear Madam, very sincerely

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JF, [12 March]. MS: NLS 607.587A. Hitherto unpbd. Dated in another hand on MS.
div3.head: JWC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: Monday then, dear Mr Forster! Of course the day makes no difference to us who have no engagements; tho you never will believe that!

Oh yes! “a small Person“Eliza Forster. (bless her!) made me a visit yesterday; but—observe the contradictory nature of Better-halves!—she arrived at this door before three! and I was gone in “a neat Fly,“See 34:247TC to CRB, 1 Dec. 1858. to leave cards at doors. I was home by four, and was told, the first thing, that Mrs Forster “had been“! I enquired particularly, at what time,? and the answer was; “about three—it couldn’t be later, because it was before Master went out riding!”

Nevertheless she is welcome to—another black kitten—if she likes! It isn’t born yet, but I am expecting its birth every hour— Did She really express a wish for a second kitten? or have I only dreamt to that effect?
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle
docBody.note: Sir George Sinclair was visiting his son, John George T. Sinclair (1825–1912), at Norwood and wrote to TC, 10 March: “I must rob the great Frederick of a few minutes of your valuable time, to announce, that I arrived here (at my son’s) on Saturday Evg, & I propose to remain some weeks. … The far more powerful magnet of enjoying your society & that of dear Mrs Carlyle will no doubt draw me one of these days to Chelsea. … If you should make up your mind to ride in this direction, let me know the day before.“

div3.sourceNote: TC-Duke of A[DOA], 23 March. MS: NLS Acc. 2423. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO THE DUKE OF ARGYLL

docBody.p: It is expressly against law for me to dine at all, in these sad Prussian times of mine:—but I decide to be a bad boy for once, on such temptation; and will give myself the pleasure of waiting upon you on Friday 4th, if nothing bad intervene.TC enjoyed meeting the duke and duchess of Argyll at The Grange in Jan.; see TC to JWC, 29 Jan.
With many regards to My Lady Duchess, I have the honour to be
docBody.name: T. Carlyle
docBody.note: John A. Carlyle wrote to James Carlyle Jr. about his stepsons, 23 March: “T. F. Watt … is in Australia again & has got a small farm of his own, not far from Sydney. Henry & Arthur are both well. The latter was in London last week, & got out of Chancery. He found all pretty well at Cheyne Row“ (MS: NLS Acc. 9086).

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A[LAI], [ca. 25 March]. MS: NLS 20767.68. Hitherto unpbd. Dated between the death of Viscountess Lady Henrietta Dillon, 18 March, and of Countess Elizabeth Pepoli, 7 April.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY AIRLIE

docBody.p: It was very kind of you to write that note;Presumably announcing the death of Viscountess Lady Henrietta Dillon, b. Browne (1789–1862), Lady Airlie’s maternal grandmother. and I thank you from my heart for it!

Nobody can better sympathiz[e] with Lady StanleyLady Airlie’s mother, Lady Henrietta Maria Stanley. than I, who lost, as suddenly, an adorable Mother,Grace Welsh, d. 1842. and who have never had any joy in life since!.
And in all your sorrows, Darling, I must ever take part; loving you as I do! and have done since you were a child, and wrote me a little half-text note about my cardcase! Do you remember?

It is only three days ago, that looking at Lady Dillons portrait in Miss
FarrersAnnie Louisa Farrer. Drawingroom, I was thinking, for the twentieth time, how good she looked, and how young and handsome to be the Great Grandmother of your children! Even me who knew her so little, your news shocked and saddened.

You will come so soon as you have heart and leisure?—and I hope to be then more at home than I am in these days. My old Scotch friend Countess Pepoli has been at the point of death, and in the absence of all her Sisters, I need to go to her for some hours every day. Her eldest Sister will arrive from Italy, I expect in a few more days,Jessie Fergus arrived soon after; see JWC to MR, [14 April]. and then she will be wellcared for without me.
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TW[TWO], 27 [26] March. Pbd: Woolner 216. Quot: Wilson 5:451. Woolner dated 27, but JWC writes on Wed., 26 March; Woolner’s sq. brackets. For Charles Dodgson’s photograph of Thomas Woolner, 2 July 1860, see above.
div3.head: JWC TO THOMAS WOOLNER

docBody.p: Can you come to tea on Friday (the day after tomorrow) at eight o’clock. It would be a charity towards my Husband! A pretty little new-married girl is to bring her HusbandJohn Simmonds, recently m. to Isabella Barnes; see JWC to MR, 23 Feb. to make acquaintance with Mr. C. that evening; and I don’t, for my part, see the least in the world how the said Mr. C. is to get thro’ it, without your or some as efficient help!

figure.p: Thomas Woolner, by C. L. Dodgson, 2 July 1860

p.hi: Courtesy of A. P. Watt Ltd. on behalf of the Trustees of

docBody.p: He has been doing what he could about the Herbert Statue;Woolner had evidently asked TC to support his bid for a commission for a statue of Sidney Herbert (1810–61; ODNB); for Herbert’s death, see 37:204JWC to TC, 7 Aug. 1861. The commission went to John Henry Foley (1818–74; ODNB). but whether the least good will come of his speaking God, or the Devil, knows!

div3.sourceNote: JWC-IES, [28 March]. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Pbd: Blunt, Forum 66:543; Blunt, CR 162–63. Dated by JWC’s invitation to Woolner for the same evening of Fri., 28 March; see JWC to TWO, [26 March].
div3.head: JWC TO ISABELLA E. SIMMONDS

docBody.p: (as the Marcioness of Westmeath writes to the “Co respondent“)The Times, 28 March, reported the divorce proceedings of George Thomas John Nugent (1785–1871), marquis of Westmeath, and his wife, Maria, b. Jarvis (b. ca. 1842), accused of adultery with George Edward Chapman (b. ca. 1838), son of the British consul in Dieppe. The case depended on the marchioness’s letter to Chapman, written when she was ill with a heavy cold, beginning “I have not been able to leave my bed to-day, my darlingest pet.“ She gave the letter to her maid Ellen James to post, but James took the letter to the marquis, who immediately initiated divorce proceedings. The marquis was granted £500 damages against Chapman, not the £5,000 that he claimed.—Come as you are, tonight. I don’t mean, come in a state of nature—but, in your wearing gown—for nobody will be here except, possibly Mr Woolner the Sculptor. The other new married LadyPresumably Christina Stewart, m., 20 Feb., James Alexander Rogerson. Jewsbury wrote to Mantell, 23 Dec.: “Chrissy Stewart is to be married on the 24th of February or thereabouts she is a good girl & deserves to be happy but will she be“ (Mantell). Christina’s father, Duncan John Stewart, lived in Victoria St. I spoke of, cannot come, because—I have not asked her! I set out one day to make the due “call,“ preparatory to asking her, and was overtaken by the rain in Pimlico, and having no umbrella and a velvet coat, and seeing no cab or other refuge, I plunged madly into an Omnibus that was standing at “the three compasses“The Three Compasses public house, 58 Upper Ebury St., Pimlico. and was trundled away—I knew not whither but “eventually“Coterie speech; see 33:41JWC to TC, 20 Aug. 1857. (as the horrid penny-a-liners say) I found myself at the Blackwall railway Station in Fenchurch Street!!!Blackwall Station was the eastern terminus for the London and Blackwall Railway.
Then, the rain continuing I had just to sit still and come back again, and get myself into a cab at Hyde Park and come home—damped and wretched!

I have never been able to get up the steam to go at that call since and to ask her without calling would I am sure have been an offence to the new-married female Inverness mind! The more’s the pity for her!
docBody.name: J W C

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 30 March. MS: NLS 525.89. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Many thanks for your Letter; whh is a kind bit of charity to me. You are just and good in excusing my defects and delays of writing: I did mean to write on Friday last; do often “mean“;—but it is literally true I have seldom 20 available minutes at my disposal; many days not five. Be patient with me, till I get thro;—by Heaven’s favour I do still count on getting thro’, before this Year end! The oftener you can throw me a word of tidings, it will be the better, and always a gleam of cheer to me.

My poor Book is going on rather better, and affairs generally are,—surely not worse,—since I last wrote. The Chapmans urging, I have consented to let Vol iii come out by itself; better, in many ways, they argue,—especially now when I have discerned and been obliged to decide that “Vol IV“ will have to fall in two, and become Voll. IV and V! No helping of it: I have taken up a great deal of time squeezing things together as with a Bramah-Press;Hydraulic press invented by Joseph Bramah (1749–1814; ODNB); for his firm Bramah & Co., see 33:40JWC to TC, 20 Aug. 1857. and find that more elbow-room is indispensable for getting on with any ease. Vol iii is itself above 100 pages too long;—capable enough of standing on its own legs:—and now there are to be Voll IV and V, of less bulk, but equal price; “too big & costly a lot for selling all at once,“ urge the Chapns. Well, well!— Vol IV (that now is) has advanced a good way: indeed it is all written, and even part of Vol V), and fully half of it printed off;—but betn writing and printing off, it is not to be imagined what bother upon bother intervenes! If I get honourably thro’ the thing (as I now hope I shall), it will be no matter at all. Poor Neuberg can yie[l]dLetter omitted. me no help more: sunk overhead in his own abstruse work of “translating“ (nearly as impossible to him as mine);Neuberg also had heart trouble; see 37:176TC to JAC, 24 June 1861.—and his poor Sister, some months ago, privately entreated Jane, That (oh, alas) his brain was softening, and I must forbear! “Brain softening, on those terms? By all means, thrice & a thousand times!” He comes every third Sunday, no busss now;—and only Larkin remains to me. Who is going to be married one of these days,Larkin was m. 24 April. and to live next door (whh is a fine clause); but stands to his Maps &c with a great deal of sense and fidelity.

Jane is a very decidedly better; I too am mostly free of teeth, ears &c, have only a rheumatic leg, plus the usual outfit or a rather lighter. Spring now
come, too; this day fairly of April sort. Hoffen wir [We hope]! Adieu dear Brother. Yr affecte T. Carlyle

ps.p: send back this Berlin Scrap if it amused you for a moment. The StatueStatue unidentified. is really very good,—face proud & young, only something of Jamie AitkenPresumably James Aitken, Jean’s son, rather than her husband, James. in it!

div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Dear Larkin I was, and am, in great haste for a little Copying; I expected you all day yesterday, but of course you cd not know to come. Today I will hope to see you so soon as you arrive in these regions.

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, [July 1859–April 1862]. MS: Huntington Lib. inc. Hitherto unpbd. [This letter, originally pbd. at CL 45:218, has been assigned a document date of 2 April 1862 and moved to its proper chronological location.]
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Dear Larkin,—Wd you now demand Thackeray’s ChathamFrancis Thackeray, A History of the Right Honourable William Pitt, Earl of Chatham, 2 vols. (1827).; TC used the book while writing about the Seven Years’ War in Frederick; he had more or less finished by Aug. 1862; see 38:127TC to JAC, 6 Aug. 1862. at Londn Library, for me:

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, [July 1859–April 1862]. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd. [This letter, originally pbd. at CL 45:218, has been assigned a document date of 3 April 1862 and moved to its proper chronological location.]
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Dear Larkin,—These 2 BooksBooks unidentified further. turn out to be quite other than I expected; and are good for nothing to me.
Try if you can get them exchanged for No 2841, whh is just of the same price as both together.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JS, [early April 1862]. Pbd: Autobiography of Henry Taylor, 1800–1875 (1885) 2:204–5. James Spedding (1808–81; ODNB;ODNB; see JWC to JCA, mid-Aug. 1835, and TC to TSS, 20 Sept. 1845), literary ed. and biographer. Dated in 1862 by Taylor (2:204) and in April by a notice in the Athenaeum, 29 March, advertising Spedding’s book in “New Books of the Season“ (417). [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 3 April 1862.]
div3.head: TC TO JAMES SPEDDING

docBody.p: Dear Spedding,—I have been in the BaconThe first two vols. of James Spedding, The Letters and Life of Francis Bacon, 7 vols. (1861–74). Although the title pages have 1861, they were not pbd. until 1862. up and down,—a fine placid daylight attending me everywhere, disclosing curious old scenes in their now more or less ruined condition; and trust to read it all with complete deliberation one day, were I out of my own Serbonian bog,Marshy swamp in the Nile delta, where whole armies are fabled to have been swallowed up; see 18:169TC to RWE, 5 Aug. 1844, and Carlyle, Sartor 50. and safe on dry land again, for a little time more. You are much to be envied with the goal now in viewSpedding did not complete his work until 1874. to such a pilgrimage as few or none in our day have made. A more honestly done bit of work I do not anywhere know; and in these times I may further call it unique in that respect, and almost miraculous in contrast with the beautiful creatures we everywhere see busy in the Devil’s dust line, which is a much more compendious one. Courage! I hope we shall live to get out, both of usHenry Taylor wrote, 18 Aug., to “Miss S—“: “The reading I have accomplished is of Spedding’s ‘Bacon’ (vols. i. and ii.) and Carlyle’s ‘Frederick’ (vol. iii.), the first with infinite satisfaction and admiration, the second with as much amusement and admiration—great books both, and such as one year has not often brought forth. The defect of Carlyle’s is one which belongs to the author, and which I once ventured to mention to him, that he does not know the difference between right and wrong“ (Correspondence of Henry Taylor, ed. Edward Dowden [1888] 241). in not many months now—and will not that be a “reward“ like no other?

I prize my copy very much and keep it as a memorial,Spedding gave TC an autographed copy of each vol.; TC wrote to Edward FitzGerald, 1874: “I have gone through Spedding, seven long long volumes. … I found it a most creditable and even surprising Book, offering the most perfect and complete image both of Bacon and of Spedding, and distinguished as the hugest and faithfullest bit of literary navvy work. … There is a grim strength in Spedding … which I did not quite know of till this Book“ (Terhune, LEF 3:523). salutary and dear
to me in a good many respects.— With thanks, and Euge [well done], yours sincerely,

div3.sourceNote: TC-UC, 7 April. MS: Yale. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT

docBody.p:
I am very sorry to deny myself the great pleasure of waiting on you as proposed: but the sad fact is, no going out to dinnerThough he usually refused dinner invitations, TC still welcomed visitors. The poet and journalist Charles Boner (1815–70; ODNB), who lived in Munich, gave an extensive description of an evening he spent with TC and JWC in Cheyne Row: “April, 1862.— Found Carlyle sitting in dressing-gown and slippers looking over the proofs of his ‘Frederic the Great.’ Mrs. Carlyle sitting on the sofa by the fire.
