After a while the conversation fell upon Prussia. Carlyle said the Prussians were full of intelligence and activity. There was energy and perseverance in their character—there was much resemblance to the English. If they did not do something there was little hope for Germany. Elsewhere in Germany he could see little else than talk and noise, and wretched radicalism. … / Parliaments, the press, the English army, he abused royally, but in language so quaint, so droll, so unlike anything I ever heard before, that once or twice I burst out laughing, though it was evident he saw nothing humorous or out of the way in his expressions. One thing was evident, his detestation of any and everything approaching dishonesty or inconsistency. Another was his utter appreciation of conscientious work. … / He is full of humour, but he does not seem to know it is humour, for he goes on gravely, as though the humorous thoughts were merely strict reasoning. F[roude] told me when going home, that another time he might quite probably take the opposite side, and abuse uncontrolled authority as much as he had done constitutional government. … / Carlyle’s long, wild, grey hair, hangs over his forehead. His eye is bright and lively,—his complexion healthy and his look generally betokens a man who leads a calm life. … His wife told me she took in the Daily Telegraph, in order to know what was going on in the world. Her husband never reads the papers. He speaks slowly, and as if what he says were well weighed beforehand, as if all had been thoroughly thought over long ago. His way of stating opinions shows that there is not a shadow of doubt in his mind as to their correctness. He makes you feel, too, he has no thought of changing his views, or allowing himself to be influenced by aught another may say. His mind is made up, once and for ever. / Nothing here written conveys any idea of his conversation, for the words he used were so strange, and the flow of his conversation so copious, that it is impossible to remember all“ (Memoirs and Letters of Charles Boner, ed. R. M. Kettle, 2 vols. [1871] 2:5–12). is other than extremely hurtful to me;—nor is by law permitted me at all in these hard Prussian times,
unless in cases (once in the six months or so) whh are or seem to me of the most peremptorily exceptional character.
Believe me / Yours with many thanks & regrets / T. Carlyle

ps.p: If you write to Madam von Usedom,Olympia von Usedom; see 34:159TC to JWC, 27 Aug. 1858, and 36:237JWC to TC, 9 Sept. 1860. & will send my very cordial remembrances, I shall be much obliged.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 7 April. MS: NLS 525.90. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: My dear Brother,—I have got yr Newspaper and Second Note this morning; I had read Alick’sTheir brother Alexander Carlyle, living in Canada. Letter, with great satisfaction, two days before. Poor fellow, he is somewhat sad and sombre of humour, in his far-off exile yonder; but ever affectionate, truehearted; and prospers as well as cd be expected,—indeed, essentially, far beyond the average of adventurous mankind in our time. Be sure you send him my poor remembrances, my assurances (whh he does not need) of unchangeable brotherly regard.John forwarded TC’s letter, presumably to either their brother James or their sister Jean, writing in pencil: “Your letter has come today with this. Post to Canada on Thursday. If you have any note for Alick send it by tomorrows post from Dumfries.“— As you wished to have the Letter back before answering, I despatch it today, first thing of the morning, lest obstructions shd intervene abt 3 p.m. when the riding crisis comes.

Jane has been at HastingsTown on the Sussex coast, 64 mi. (103 km.) SE of London. (carried down by Frc Chapman & his Young Wife)Clara Chapman. since Friday afternoon; is due, home, today for dinner,—much cheered & healed by the sea-air, she says. Friday night, with a great effort, I attended the Duke of Argyll’s invitatn to dinner (“dinner of the sages,“Cf. Plutarch, “Feast of the Seven Sages,“ Moralia 13. a poorish lot of us; but the Host & Hostess very good goodWord repeated at turn of page. affable people: Dke of Newcastle was there too; & I cd almost have spoken abt Maurits Busss,See TC to JAC, 14 Feb. had it now been time! Adieu dear Brother. I must to work. Yrs ever T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAF, 14 April. MS: Gordon N. Ray. Pbd: Cate 100 inc.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES ANTHONY FROUDE

docBody.p: Ruskin, I have got to understand, is at last beginning upon his Political Economy. I think, if you were to send him a word or two of incitatn, you might actually get a Paper out of him for yr next No;—whh wd be a beautiful thing to begin the Summer with! The simplest few words will do,—if any will.Froude, as editor of Fraser’s Magazine, followed TC’s suggestion. The hostile reception to Ruskin’s first series of critical essays on political economy when they were pbd. in the Cornhill Magazine (1860; see 37:29–30TC to JRU, 29 Oct. 1860) provoked him to explore the subject in greater depth; the essays were later pbd. as Munera Pulveris (1872), in the preface of which Ruskin wrote: “[A]s I had taken not a little pains with the Essays, and knew that they contained better work than most of my former writings, and more important truths than all of them put together, this violent reprobation of them by the Cornhill public set me still more gravely thinking; and, after turning the matter hither and thither in my mind for two years more, I resolved to make it the central work of my life to write an exhaustive treatise on Political Economy. It would not have been begun, at that time, however, had not the editor of Fraser’s Magazine written to me, saying that he believed there was something in my theories, and would risk the admission of what I chose to write on this dangerous subject; whereupon, cautiously, and at intervals, during the winter 1862–63, I sent him, and he ventured to print, the preface of the intended work, divided into four chapters. Then, though the Editor had not wholly lost courage, the Publisher [John William Parker] indignantly interfered; and the readers of Fraser, as those of the Cornhill, were protected, for that time, from farther disturbance on my part“ (Ruskin’s Works 17:143).
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: “John Ruskin Esq / Denmark Hill“ that is the address.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [14 April]. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries / N. B. PM: London, 15 April 1862. MS: NLS 607.587B. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:243–45; Bliss, JWC 292–93 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: It has been in my head to write to you any day these three weeks. But I have put off and put off, watingLetter omitted. for a livelier mood, which has never come, and looks no nearer; so I write now in the mood that is—a dismal one—rather!

You have probably seen in the newspapers the Death of Elizabeth Pepoli.“At 11 St. George’s Terrace, South Kensington, on the 7th inst., Elizabeth, Countess Pepoli, eldest daughter of the late Walter Fergus, Esq. of Strathore“ (Scotsman 12 April).
To the best of my recollection, when I wrote to you last, I told you how sad it made one to go and find her always so evidently ill, and getting worse and worse; yet shutting herself up in her proud stoicism, from even me, her friend of so many years, and, as I still felt sure, the most trusted friend she had in London. But her stoicism had to give way at last poor Dear! when she was seized with violent pain (in the bowels) and absolutely could not get out of bed. She then wrote to me a few blotched lines, the very handwriting of which showed how far gone she was, begging me to send her my DrDr. Alfred Barnes.—the fine Physician from town,Unidentified. whom she would only see rarely, having “done her no good.“ I went to her immediately and my Dr went—and his first words to me when he left her room were— “The thing which ails this friend of yours is—old age! and you know whether there be any cure for that“! Still he gave me hopes that she might rally a little, for a while. And she did seem slightly better for the new diet and medecines. But to see her all alone there in such a critical state was very miserable for me, She was at last persuaded to let her Sister Miss Jessy come from Italy—any of them would have been only too glad to come long before, had she not misled them to believe her nearly well! To Pepoli she had sent no such permission not wishing him to “leave his affairs in Bologna to wait upon her.“See JWC to MR, [13 Feb.]. But he was telegraphed to by Mr Fergus from another Italian city, and started half an hour after, and travelled without rest till he arrived at her bedside which he hardly ever left for the next ten days, when she died. Certainly he looked the most devoted of Husbands. And tho dreadfully displeased at his coming she seemed glad enough to have him—after a little while. Miss Fergus came two days after him. So she was surrounded as she ought to be at the last. After the Sister’s coming I went seldomer, for a fortnight before I had been with her every day. But she did not feel my visits made superfluous by the presence of the others. The cook told my maid that “the Countess had been crying out for Mrs Carlyle“! And the last day, I saw her, tho’ her mind was wandering, she was so sweet and loving to me—like her old self! That was a comfort! And tho’ I am very sorrowful just now about her loss—Such an old and true friend!—still I know in my heart that her living on in infirmity was not to be wished for her—for her of all people! with a Husband still in middle age, on whom she could never have reconciled herself to the idea of being a burden.Elizabeth Pepoli was four years older than her husband.

This business made me poorly, you may conceive; and I accepted an offer made providentially just then, to be taken for three days to Hastings.With Frederic and Clara Chapman; see TC to JAC, 7 April. The sea-air did me the good it always does, and I took “penny worths of it,“ like
old Mrs Hepburn of Thornhill,Possibly Mary Hepburn (b. ca. 1784), a widow and pauper living at 153 North Drumlanrig St., Thornhill; otherwise unidentified. with better success however! The last two or three days of intense cold and East-wind have undone the benifit for the present. But this sort of thing wont last it is to be hoped

Wasn’t I enchanted to get a note from your Husband— And yet— If I had known he was to take the trouble of thanking me for that book,Unidentified. I doubt if I should have ventured to address it to him— I have learnt, from my own Husband, a perfectly sacred respect for the time of Men!

The two numbers of the story I sent you the other day will be followed up, to the end. And I am sure you will like it, and even the Dr may read it with satisfaction— The Author is one of the best Novelists of the day.Margaret Oliphant; “Chronicles of Carlingford: Salem Chapel“ appeared anon., Blackwood’s Edinburgh Magazine, Feb. 1862–Jan. 1863. It was then pbd. anon. in two vols. (Edinburgh, 1863).

Of course I had no photographs of Mr C. or myself, or you should have received them by return of post. Plenty of Photographers have offered to bring their apparatus to the house (!) to do Mr C. But he wont be done! that, like every thing else with him, is postponed “till his Book is finished.“ As for me, my photograph has been waiting these two years! till I looked a little less haggard! But I put it to you, if at my age one is likely to improve! by keeping—!
Good night. I am feeling as if I were all made up of separate particles—of glass! a nice state! So I will go to bed soon. Love to the Dr
docBody.name: JWC

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 17 April. MS: NLS 553.239. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p:
Dear Neuberg.—I hope you are better; sickness is a bad Reisegefährte [companion] in those uphill roads! The Mitchell ExcerptsSir Andrew Mitchell (1708–71; ODNB), diplomat, minister to Prussia 1756–71, instrumental in securing the British alliance with Prussia during the Seven Years’ War; he accompanied Frederick the Great on many of his campaigns. TC found his papers in the British Museum of immense value; see Works 17:35–36. are undiscoverable here; I spent last night in rummaging; found several things (yr Berlin News-Writer, whom I called the “Demon Frenchman,“Idée de la personne, de la manière de vivre et de la cour du roi de Prusse: juin 1752; see Works 16:338–48. TC later identified the “Demon Frenchman“ or “demon news-writer“ as M. de Bonneville, secretary to the marechal de Saxe; see Works 18:182–84. The pamphlet was also attributed to Voltaire and to his rival Laurent Angliviel de La Beaumelle (1726–73); for a history of that dispute, see Claude Lauriol, La Beaumelle (Geneva, 1978) 362–63. in doing him myself lately;
yours will still help in the Proofs),—several things, but of Mitchell no trace. Nay in reading what you sent last night, my private guess begins to be (in whh, however, I do not ask you to share) that I never had those Notes at all, Fair-written or otherwise,—so new is everything to me! At all events I do not design that you shall trouble yourself writing or re-writing (whichever it may be) these things for my behoof;—and the point I am now curious upon (namely M.’s first interview with Frh and final one of 27–28 Augt)Mitchell first met Frederick in early summer 1756 (Works 17:36); their final interviews before the outbreak of war took place 26–28 Aug. 1756 (Works 17:44–45). seems never to have been there. I can pretty nearly do witht that too; but since you can walk straight to it (for I have written to Mr HamiltonNicholas Esterhazy Stephen Armytage Hamilton (1829–1915), assistant keeper of manuscripts at the British Museum 1852–72. abt you), you might read over what is there and in the other places Mr Hn thinks “remarkable,“ and report to me what you think of them: that is all.

Nor do I hope much from yr search in Keith;Robert Keith (ca. 1697–1774; ODNB), diplomat; his letters were in the British Museum.—but any glance of him by you will be better to me than none at all. I don’t expect very much that you will discover the date of K.’s Applicatn & Ma Tha’s refusalKeith was ambassador in Vienna, 1748–57, to Maria Theresa (1717–80), empress of Austria; he requested her aid in the event of a French attack on Hanover, but she refused; TC did not discover the date; see Works 17:15–16. (1755 jany, abt the time of Braddock’s sailing,Maj. Gen. Edward Braddock (ca. 1695–1755; ODNB), sent by William Augustus (1721–65; ODNB), duke of Cumberland, to clear the French out of North America. He sailed Dec. 1754. I shd guess; then humm-ing & ha-ing till Bradk got defeated;In an attack against the French garrison at Fort Duquesne, 9 July 1755, Braddock’s forces were ambushed and routed; Braddock was fatally wounded and d. 13 July; see Works 16:398–400. after whh, No): but I can do witht this too;—the doomed “Historn“ of Frh must prepare himself to do without innumerable requisites he might have hoped for at this epoch;—and to work his way thro’ the belly of the infinite mother of Dead-dogs,Coterie speech; cf. Pope, Dunciad 2:271–72; see 35:68TC to RWE,9 April 1859. at the very swiftest rate of speed now possible, if he wd escape alive, Swift, is the word—ah me!— — Freytag’s ToggenburgerGustav Freytag, Neue Bilder aus dem Leben des deutschen Volkes (Leipzig, 1862) 336–51, included excerpts from the autobiography of Ulrich Bräker (1735–98), Swiss weaver and self-taught scholar, known as “the poor man of Toggenburg“ (Ulrich Bräker, Lebens-geschichte und natürliche Ebentheuer des armen Mannes im Tockenburg [Zürich, 1789]). Bräker described his kidnapping by a Prussian recruiting officer and his own eventual desertion at the battle of Lobositz, 1 Oct. 1756. TC did not refer to Bräker in Frederick. is one of the frankest liars I have met with! I had to think it
quite uncertain whether he was in Lobositz at all. Freytag does not trouble his friends with going to State-Pr offices!— Yours ever T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lord A[LOA], 21 April. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LORD ASHBURTON

docBody.p: I was at Bath-House today; but you were both just gone. I am very sad about our dear old Lady;Lady Sandwich d. 19 April. I little expected it, so on the sudden. She was lively and beautiful as ever, last time I saw her,—the very day before that blast of cold weather.Probably early April; the Times reported, 16 April, “The weather since Friday [11 April] has been extremely severe,“ and JWC wrote to Mary Russell [14 April], of “[t]he last two or three days of intense cold and East-wind.“ Brave old Soul, how she had struggled on just to the gate of Summer; and there, was obliged to fall, and be hidden from our eyes!— I have lost another of the now very few figures precious to me in this Earth.

We are both of us well disposed to the Addiscombe Enterprise;The Ashburtons’ farm nr. Croydon, Surrey, where TC and JWC had been invited to stay 26–30 April. and ready for it, whenever the Sovereign Lady shall appoint,—subject to the following condition. I suppose you are for the Funeral; I also feel bound to be there (since Lord S. invites):Lady Sandwich’s son, John William Montagu, 7th earl of Sandwich.—if I cd meet you at Bath House, at Battle-BridgeBattle Bridge was the old name for the area around King’s Cross Station, from where the train left for Huntingdon, the nearest stn. to Hinchingbrooke; see 36:102TC to LS, 24 April 1860. or anywhere, and go and return with me,Thus in MS. I shd like that best. At any rate, on or after Saturday, I am free to come (the Wife, from Thursday I think?)—and both of us wish it. Let the Lady speak and order.
And please send me a word about meeting (Thursday, some time, some where, for Hinchinbrook).
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 28 [26] April. MS: NLS 517.34. Hitherto unpbd. TC misdated; he returned from Hinchingbrooke 25 April, and JWC left for Addiscombe 26 April.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: I got home from my journey, safe, yesternight at 11: the expedition had been sad, but parts of it were very beautiful and touching to me. The funeral was 18 miles inland from Huntingdon; we drove to the place and back yesterday in a five or so of Carriages; found a beautiful queer old English Village, and near it the old “Chapel of Barnewell“The church of Barnwell All-Saints, village of Barnwell, 78 mi. (125.5 km.) N of London. The church had been pulled down in the 1820s, but the chancel was preserved as a mausoleum for the Montagu family. where all the Montagues are buried for many generations for many generations:Phrase repeated by TC. the Hearse &c was there attended by servants who had come with it by train from London: we walked bare-headed in procession, all very sad & silent (the only non-kinsman was myself, and the good old Lady had been loved by everybody); and so she was laid in her last home,—as we shall be in ours before long; apart from one another, parted however dear, till the Eternities come! Her son a strong, solid oaken kind of man, and her two grandsons nice lads,John William Montagu had three surviving sons: Edward, Victor, and Oliver. were weeping at last; and silence and sadness on the part of all made it a kind of religious ceremony more than such things usually are in this loose time. I shall never forget that little old Kirk standing on its little knoll amid its graves in the green Country with the poor villagers and Spring skies looking on;—and her whom we left there yesterday.

Today we were to be off for a little Holiday of 3 days at Addiscombe with the Ashburtons: Jane is actually there at this time;—and I, on beginning this Note, expected to be on the road thither in five minutes:—but a Servant is just come to say that poor Lady Ashburton’s Mother (a very aged Highland Dame, beyond Inverness is just dying);Mary Elizabeth Frederica Stewart-Mackenzie did not die until 28 Nov. and so that is all up for the time. My horse, whh is still waiting, I shall take a common ride; and Jane, who went driving, will wait till her horse rest, and return direct.TC still joined JWC there the next day, Sun., 27 April. This is all at prest;—my blessings added. Your affecte Brr T.C

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 29 April. MS: NLS 525.91. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: For almost a week past I have been daily purposing to send you a small word; and daily,—not by business in my own kind, for the pen has been a stranger to me totally all that time, and only locomotion and confused sauntering and extraneous affairs my sole occupation,—I have been hindered by one poor thing and another from so much as writing a Note to my Brother, much more to any other person!

The Ashburtons had asked us out hither from about Wednesday last: Wedny last I had got fairly thro’ a most extremely ugly set of Proofsheets again; & was ready for a day or two of recreation: but, alas, before that there had things befallen whh sent me elsewhither in the first place. My good old Lady Sandwich, my late Friend’sLady Harriet Ashburton. aged Mother, always very weak, but very good, graceful interesting, age now 81,Lady Sandwich was 81 on 3 April. had weathered the winter, I thot rather better than usual; but in the last gust of cold weather had caught some poor whiff of cold; and far agt my expectation, on Sunday gone a week, calling for the third time I found that she was dead the night before. Ah me, ah me!— Ld Sandwich, who is a fine solid man much in my esteem, distinguished me by an invitation to the Funeral (the only person not of kin who was there); and on Thursday I had to set off for Hinchinbrook on that melancholy business whh had to take place next day. The ride thither was silent, sad, solitary not unbeautiful; but the agitations there, the driving, the &c (all the Funeral people being there) confused me into sleeplessness: and next day the drive of 18 miles (and as far back) in very beautiful weather, and the touching little solemnity (a fine innocent old Chapel, in the rurarlThus in MS. midlands, not far from Oundle Northamptonshire)Oundle, village in Northamptonshire, 80 mi. (128.5 km.) N of London., followed by the hurries at Hinchinbrook, and the unpleasant railwaying home, had a good deal tired me out: so that I wd much rather not have been due at Addiscombe on the morrow. But there was no help; Jane too was very eager for it. Her I got shot away, with all the luggage, in a fly or brougham; then went myself to a sofa for some snatch of sleep;—and was just about mounting horse, when an Express arrived, “Don’t! The Lady’s Mother“ (far away, beyond Inverness) “is dying; we must put you
off!”— Well, I thot, as to the latter clause; and went out for a common ride. But it did not stand that way either! Jane having arrived was kept; a new message was returned by the Sylvester Driver,JWC had traveled in one of the livery stabler Silvester’s carriages. “Come on, still!” In short I cannot tell you what confused choppings & changings there were (new telegrams from Inverness, and the poor old Lady out of danger) &c &c,—the general result being (in whh alone you are interested) that I am here since sunday, not to return till tomorrow (Wednesday),—totally idle, very idle truly; and in spite of the excellt weather, kindest of welcomes and all other furtherances, am but an unprofitable and far from a happy object! Lord A. & I went out for a ride yesterday (the first to him these many weeks, for he is commonly in very poor health, of late); but it had nothing of sufficient emphasis of continuance: today I am going by myself, and trust to have a far more effective & properly dietetic bit of exercise. If so, it will be the one good thing I have done here! Jane enjoys it considerably; I suppose we shall both be the better for it perhaps;—at any rate I ride home tomorrow, and it ends.

I have been reading the Life of Edd Irving;Margaret Oliphant, The Life of Edward Irving Minister of the National Scotch Church, London. Illustrated by his Journals and Correspondence, 2 vols. (1862). am thro’ Vol. I. It is a work not witht some genius; and has a beautiful loyalty and veneratn for poor Edd,—interesting really here and there, but to us that knew him often ghastly and distressing! Correct likeness of man or work there is little or none; that is a grievous fault:—yet one is glad to see such a thing done, in the absence of anything else whatever.In an early review in the Athenaeum, 19 April, Henry Fothergill Chorley (1808–72; ODNB) concluded: “Be we right, be we wrong … the book is not one to be read lightly. It should be considered by all who grapple with those most momentous of questions, sincerity, opinion and mistake“ (526).
Adieu dear Brother, let me hear from you quàm primùm [as soon as possible]. Ever Yr Affecte / T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MO, [early May]. MS: NLS 23210.183. Pbd: Oliphant, ed. Coghill, Autobiography and Letters 186–87; Trela, “Unsung Friendship“ 37; Fielding and Sorensen 274 inc. Quot: Wilson 5:457; Hansons, NE 499; Elisabeth Jay, Mrs Oliphant: “A Fiction to Herself“ (Oxford, 1995) 245; Trela, “Margaret Oliphant“ 159. Dated about the time of the opening of the International Exhibition, 1 May. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 1 May 1862.]
div3.head: JWC TO MARGARET OLIPHANT

docBody.p: Already “The Exhibition“The International Exhibition, 1 May–1 Nov., held in S. Kensington next to the Royal Horticultural Society gardens; sponsored by the Royal Society of Arts, Manufactures and Trade, it included over 28,000 exhibitors from 36 countries and attracted over six mil-lion visitors. has borne me the fruit of one Scotch Cousin,Maggie Welsh, who visited London for “six weeks“ before going to Devon; see JWC to MR, [5 June]. who will be coming and going all this week; and I have other things laid on my arms, like the Baby in the Omnibus!JWC’s image for unexpected responsibility: “the baby which the Gentleman in the Omnibus incautiously undertook the holding of, while the mother stept out“ (17:309JWC to JW, 16 March 1844); see also 30:205JWC’s Journal, 28 Oct. 1855. And on the whole I fear I must put off my visit to you till the week following. But if you will name any day of that, I shall take care that no pigs run thro’ it!Coterie speech; see 14:226JWC to MAWE, 15 July 1842. D.V. [Deo volente: God willing]

I do long to see you to tell you—not what i think of your Book; but what Mr C thinks, which is much more to the purpose!The Life of Edward Irving. F. D. Maurice (1805–72; ODNB; see 30:28230:biographical note) wrote, 28 May, to J. M. Ludlow (1821–1911; ODNB), lawyer, social activist, who intended reviewing the Life: “All I have heard and known of Mrs. Oliphant is most favourable. Carlyle, who knew Irving well, and the best part of whose mind and heart comes out in speaking of him, likes the book on the whole very much, saying it is the most loyal biography he has read for a long time“ (The Life of Frederick Denison Maurice Chiefly Told in His Own Letters, ed. Frederick Maurice [1884] 2:403). I never heard him praise a womans Book, hardly any man’s as cordially as he praises this of yours!

You are “worth whole cart-loads of Mulochs and BrontesDinah Maria Mulock (1826–87; ODNB) and Charlotte Brontë (1816–55; ODNB), both better known at this time than Oliphant; both also known to the Carlyles; for Mulock, see 24:288–89JWC to JF, 13 Nov. 1849, and 27:387JWC to HW, 30 Dec. 1852, and for Brontë, see 25:113JWC to HW, 4 July 1850. and things of that sort“— “You are full of geniality and genius even“!— “Nothing has so taken him by the heart for years as this biography“!— You are really “a fine, clear, loyal, sympathetic, delicate female Being.“ The only fault he finds in you is “a certain dimness about dates and arrangements of Time! In short I never heard as much praise out of his head at one rush!After a visit to Cheyne Row around this time, Oliphant reported to her publisher, William Blackwood (1836–1912; ODNB): “I spent last evening with Thomas Carlyle, whom I am sorry you don’t like, but whom I do like heartily and more than ever. He has added to all his great qualities a crowning touch of genius—he likes my book! and has spoken of it in terms so entirely gratifying that for the space of a night and day I was uplifted, and lost my head. He was at home and alone, with his clever and original wife, and I never was more delighted with any man. I am ready henceforth to stand up for all those peculiarities which other people think defects, and to do battle for him whenever I hear him assailed“ (Oliphant, ed. Coghill, Autobiography and Letters 188). And I am so glad!

figure.p: Margaret Oliphant, by Hayman Selig Mendelssohn, ca. 1883–88

p.hi: Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

docBody.p: For me, I am not in a state to express an opinion yet, having read only “here a little and there a little“Cf. Isa. 28:10. in whichever volume Mr C was not occupied with; and amidst “a pressure of things“!— All the worse for being trivial things. But tomorrow I shall begin at the beginning. Mr C got to the end last night. and the last part is the best of all; he says— And that he is “very glad—very glad indeed that such a biography of Edward Irving exists“! Now tell me a day next weekPossibly the visit about which Oliphant wrote later: “Cecco [Francis] … had a momentary illness,—a little convulsive fit which frightened me terribly. … It was a day on which Mrs Carlyle was coming for the afternoon. When she arrived I was sitting before the fire (though it was summer), with my baby wrapped in a blanket, just out of his bath. … He was only two and a-half. Mrs Carlyle sat by me, so kind and tender and full of encouragement, as if she had known all about babies. … I think I can see her by the side of the fire, telling me all kinds of comforting things; and by the first post possible that same evening, I got a letter from her telling me that Mr Carlyle had made her sit down at once and write to tell me that a sister of his had once had just such an attack, which never was repeated. God bless them, that much maligned, much misunderstood pair! That was not much like the old ogre his false friends have made him out to be“ (Oliphant, ed. Jay, Autobiography 103).—if you are to be at home and at leisure and believe that I love you very much and try to love me a little
docBody.name: J W Carlyle
docBody.note: For the photograph of Oliphant by Hayman Selig Mendelssohn (1847–1908) at his studio, 27 Cathcart Pl., Kensington, see 90above. Mendelssohn was there 1883–88.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 3 May. MS: NLS 525.92. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
The first of yr Notes reached me at Addiscombe very shortly after mine had gone away; the second followed us thither, and did not arrive here till Thursday. We looked for you on Wednesday night; I was too late for calling at Brompton Road,John A. Carlyle’s London lodgings, 48 Brompton Row; see 37:249TC to JAC, 17 Oct. 1861. on my midnight walk of “disappointment“; indeed I reflected that you had probably gone direct to Jermyn Street, and might be in
the Hôtel there.Unidentified further. It was far better that you had not the disagreeable fatigue and bother of coming at all.

I am afraid this “breaking of arrest“ is a bad affair in the military sense;William Watt, John A. Carlyle’s stepson, was in trouble at the Royal Military Academy in Woolwich. John wrote to his nephew James Carlyle Jr., 29 April: “Last week I was kept in a state of painful uneasiness by news from Woolwich, & perhaps I may have to go to London this week. On the 12th … William Watt was ‘guilty of drunkenness,’ & was put under arrest … on the 17th he ‘broke the arrest & absconded himself,’ & was again reported. The … sentence for the first offence was only ‘rustication’; but now for the two offences combined the sentence is ‘dismissal.’ … It is a bad business, & I dont yet see any remedy.“ Military regulations specified the gravity of the “breaking of arrest“; the penalty was “cashiering by sentence of a general court-martial“ (Col. H. L. Scott, Military Dictionary [1861] 54).
and you must not be surprised if the Authorities take it gloomily, and refuse yr Petitn. You did your duty in writing such a thing: but it seems to me the military career may now prove to be shut agt yr young man. Poor young fellow; the getting into arrest was nothing or little; but the breaking of it! If he do continue his soldiership, let him understand better what an adamantine law presides over that profession,and must preside, if it is to be a profession at all. Failing soldiership, there are other trades a many; and the whole world is still open to a youth with those resources.The Watt boys inherited money from their mother’s estate when they reached 21. If he will apply them with fidelity! Let him not become a “wandering Willy“;Cf. Robert Burns, “Here awa, there awa, wandering Willie,“ and blind Willie Steenson’s tale, “Wandering Willie’s Tale,“ Walter Scott, Redgauntlet (Edinburgh, 1824) “Letter XI.“ but plant himself down again, and hold firm agt the winds, whatever his new busss be.

I seem to have got little good of my rustic locomotions. I am not ill either; only the stomach torpid; and a great want of the willing velocity that wd be so useful in my new operatns. I am about starting on the finale of Vol 4,—a Piece that ought to be perhaps 100 pages, and is on paper mainly tho’ in confused form;Vol. 4 of Frederick was not pbd. until 1864.—it is indescribable how “stiff to ye reise“Coterie speech; see 28:101TC to AC, 8 April 1853. I feel about it!— — Vol iii is not out; not coming till Thursday,Thurs. was 7 May. Frederick was extensively reviewed; Horace Stebbing Roscoe St. John (18321830–88; ODNB) wrote in the Athenaeum, 3 May: “After a few preliminary passages, the narrative in this third volume, rushes grandly and swiftly on, most rapid and most brilliant when the leading figure is that of Frederick himself“; he concluded: “When we have said the third volume is of more immediate and unfailing interest than its predecessors, we have said all that is necessary“ (585, 588). nor then except one or two things hit as they have undertaken.I.e., presumably, if all goes according to plan. Yr Copy shall arrive on the instant. Perhaps all the Annandale Copies had better be sent you. We are kept in perpetual noise with that beggarly chimera of an “Exhibitn“ (sorrow to it!)—and the hot weather is all turned today into grey cast. Adieu dear Brother.
docBody.name: T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JD[JODO], 8 May. Addr: 1 Eldon Road / Kensington. PM: 9 May 1862. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd. For TC’s first attempt to help Downes, see TC to JODO, 26 Jan.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN DOWNES

docBody.p: I have just received from Mr Froude the inclosed communication;Froude wrote, 8 May: “I am applied to to recommend some one for an English Professorship at Calcutta.— The Salary 450 a year is not likely to tempt Oxford or Cambridge men to face an Indian Climate.—It has occurred to me that your Scotch friend whom you recommended to me for Frasers might do. / I do not know enough of him to recommend him on my own separate responsibility— I have even forgotten his name—& he has not written to me since I was obliged to refuse his first Paper—except once to acknowledge my general reasonableness and to promise something else. / It was plain to me however that he was a man of great straightforwardness—integrity & industry—with sufficient intellect for the purposes of the Indian Board and quite sure to do his duty manfully. / If you will communicate with him to ascertain if it would suit his views—and then endorse my opinion—I will send in his name. He had better write direct to me—to save time.“ and make all speed to send it you; hoping it may be welcome, and turn to good as he expects.
I will, if you embrace the proposal, certify with great readiness, and cooperate as Mr Froude wishes; so that the post seems to be yours if you care to have it. The one Condition is to lose no time.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle
docBody.p: I ansr Mr Froude that I am not sure of your being in London; and that he must give a day, on the chance of yr being in Edinr instead. Of course you will write to him instantly. No need of writing to me till the haste is over.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 10 May. MS: Yale. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—I got yr Notes; many thanks. I have been, and am, fencing with the Dust-monsters (as usual), and in very low mood.— It is long since we saw you: come on Sunday Evg, if you can, and tell us the news.— Yours always / T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lord S[LOS], [ca. 10 May]. MS: Catalog of Donald A. Berry. Dated after the death of Lady Sandwich, 19 April, and after TC’s return from Addiscombe, 30 April; copies of vol. 3 of Frederick were not available before Thurs., 7 May; see TC to JAC, 3 May.
div3.head: TC TO LORD SANDWICH

docBody.p: Dear Lord Sandwich, Will you do me the kindness to accept this poor volume,A copy of vol. 3 of Frederick, inscribed: “‘To the Earl of Sandwich &c.’ T. Carlyle.“ The MS of the letter was inserted in the vol. wh’h was intended for Another,Lady Sandwich; TC had previously sent her vols. 1 and 2 of Frederick. Berry’s catalog describes the lot, advertised for sale for £5 10s.: “History of Friedrich II. Of Prussia … 4 vols. original cloth, uncut, covers damp stained. … Volume I. is inscribed to ‘The Dowager Lady Sandwich’ etc., T. Carlyle.“ whom it can now never reach:—a very sad thought to me,—but I request you to give them place in some corner of yr. Library, and to let them stand so long as they can, in silent memorial of the regard I had, and will not cease to have, for certain of the House of Hinchinbrooke whilst in this World.

div3.sourceNote: TC-UC, 12 May. MS: Warwickshire County Archives; pasted in “Autographs of royal, noble and eminent persons,“ originally belonging to the earls of Denbigh. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT

docBody.p: “Dost thou love thy life, then take care of thy time, for that is the stuff life is made of.“Cf. Benjamin Franklin (1706–90), Poor Richard’s Almanac (Philadelphia, 1746).
docBody.name: T. Carlyle
docBody.note: TC often obliged acquaintances with autographs; see 22:20TC to UC, 26 July 1847. Reginald Blunt later recalled: “When the big bazaar was being got ready in the Rectory in June, 1874, G. B. ventured to ask Carlyle’s help in a contribution of autographs. ‘A barrow-load, if you like,’ Carlyle at once good-humouredly promised; and he wrote on half-sheets of note-paper some dozens of his favourite verses and sentences, which, of course, sold well, and added considerably to the total of receipts“ (Reginald Blunt, Memoirs of Gerald Blunt [1911] 92). For a less obliging response, see 26:125TC to UC, 8 Aug. 1851.

ps.p: Chelsea, 12 May, 1862

div3.sourceNote: JWC-IES, [mid-May]. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd. Dated during Maggie Welsh’s visit to London in May; see JWC to MO, [early May]. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 15 May 1862.]
div3.head: JWC TO ISABELLA E. SIMMONDS

docBody.p: My Pet! I should have been delighted! But a female cousin is coming on Friday, to dine with me on patriarchal principles at two o’clock. Couldnt you come and lunch with us then—and—ask me another day?
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-[JH][JHO], 31 May. Addr: Burtons Cottages / Clifton View / York. MS: NLS 7197. Hitherto unpbd. Recipient identified as John Hoggard or Haggard from name and address written on the MS in another hand; Hoggard/Haggard not further identified.
div3.head: TC TO [JOHN HOGGARD OR HAGGARD]

docBody.p: The Photographs have come quite safe; they seem to be elaborate performances in that kind: thanks for the trouble you have taken.

The Lady FauconbergMary Belasyse (ca. 1637–1713), Countess Fauconberg, da. of Oliver Cromwell (1599–1658; ODNB); portrait unidentified. is from a difft Picture than the Checquers one,Chequers, Tudor mansion nr. Ellesborough, Buckinghamshire, 40 mi. (64.5 km.) NW of London, home of Lady Louisa Frankland Russell (1790–1871), descendant by marriage of Oliver Cromwell; it contained a large number of pictures and relics of the Cromwell family. TC visited the house May 1860; see 36:120–21TC to SWPG, 24 May 1860, and 131–32TC to EAPG, 5 June 1860. The Chequers portrait of Countess Fauconberg was painted by Cornelius Johnson (or Janssens) (1593–1661; ODNB). but is strikingly like that, only the eyes a little more shut. The OliverOliver Cromwell; portrait unidentified. is not witht resemblance; but is far inferior to the Cooper Portraits.Samuel Cooper (1607/8–72; ODNB), miniature painter, who painted several pictures of Cromwell. Both the Cooper and the maskThere was a Cooper miniature of Cromwell at Chequers in the mid-18th cent., sold sometime in the 19th cent. In an 1839 catalog, only one miniature (set in the oval bezel of a gold ring) was noted; see John Gilbert Jenkins, Chequers (Oxford, 1967) 126. For the Cromwell death mask at Chequers, see 36:131TC to EAPG, 5 June 1860. whh they have a[t]Letter omitted. Checquers (strange to say) are of inferior quality,—the Mask in particular is of the kind that may be called spurious.

The mystery to me, in this case of yours, is, How any busy Lawyer or
Lawyer’s Clerk shd have found time and faculty to execute a “Pen-Drawing“ (if such it be)Not further identified. by way of preliminary to his Copying a Writ!—
In great haste, I remain
docBody.name: T. Carlyle
docBody.note: TC attended a dinner at R. M. Milnes’s house, 16 Upper Brook St., 20 May; Frederick Pollock (1815-88; ODNB), lawyer and author, sat next to him and recorded: “Louis Blanc was there, on the other side of the table, whom Carlyle described as a little man looking as neat as if he had just come out of a bandbox, and with no great commendation of his accuracy as a historian. Then he asked if I would like to be introduced to him after dinner. I answered rather emphatically, ‘No, thank you!’ which amused him. Presently afterwards it happened that with the same words I successively declined several dishes and wines that were handed round, and Caryle remarked, ‘So it’s always “No, thank you,“’ and he got into one of his uncontrollable and boisterous fits of merriment, laughing enormously every time I repeated ‘No, thank you.’ I could not help joining in the laugh, until at last Milnes called out to us and wanted to be admitted to share the joke, which of course was impossible with Louis Blanc sitting opposite us, and so it passed“ (Personal Remembrances of Sir Frederick Pollock [1887] 2:106–7). J. J. Louis Blanc (1811–82), French socialist politician and historian, in exile in London since Aug. 1848; for TC’s first positive reaction to Blanc’s work, see 22:274TC to MAC, 22 March 1848, and to his person, see 24:11TC to JWC, 4 April 1849; see also 23:203TC to LA, 29 Jan. 1849. F. D. Maurice wrote to J. D. Lowell, 30 May, after visiting TC the previous week: “There have been times when I have accepted your judgment of Carlyle, and have added to it some bitterness of my own, arising out of the disappointment that a man who has taught me so much should outrage some of my strongest convictions. … I went to his house with much reluctance and some fear. After a long conversation with him, I came away with a strong conviction, that very much more is expressed in that oscillation of his mind between democracy and absolutism … than you are willing to admit. … There are terrible contradictions in his thoughts, which express themselves in his wild speech. But the contradictions belong to the time: we may find them in ourselves. And they cannot be resolved, as you fancy they may, into the mere worship of might. That comes uppermost at times; often he recoils from it with the intensest horror, and affirms and feels Justice to be the one ruler in heaven and earth. … I hope you will not let your dislike of Carlyle, which if you will search into it you will find to be more democratic than divine, colour your judgment of his friend [Irving], whom, in spite of enormous prejudice against him, I was forced and am now more than ever forced to reverence and love“ (Life of Frederick Denison Maurice, ed. Frederick Maurice [1884] 2:404–5).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCM, 2 June. MS: Robinson Lib., Newcastle Univ. Hitherto unpbd. James Augustus Cotter Morison (1832–88; ODNB), author; of private means, Morison had contributed £5 to TC’s fund for Samuel Johnson’s goddaughter; see TCCDJF to T, 23 April 1856. Morison’s money came from the invention of Morison’s Universal Pills by his father, James Morison (1770–1840; ODNB). TC named bk. 1, chap. 4 of Past and Present “Morrison’s Pill“ (Works 10:23–27); see TC to JCA, 29 Oct. 1842 (where James Morison is misspelled Morrison); see also John Ulrich, “Morrison’s Pill,“ The Carlyle Encyclopedia, ed. Mark Cumming (Madison, N.J., 2004) 340.
div3.head: TC TO J. COTTER MORISON

docBody.p: I am very glad to hear your Book is to be printed.James Cotter Morison, The Life and Times of Saint Bernard, Abbot of Clairvaux. A.D. 1091–1153 (1863). Without looking at “Book I“ for the object you allude to, tho’ I will for others,—I can at once ansr you on that small extraneous matter, “Yes certainly“;Presumably Morison’s dedication (v) to TC: “To Thomas Carlyle this volume is dedicated, (by permission), with deep reverence and gratitude.“ and add, according to the best horoscope there is, that I judge you will do me nothing but credit, yr Book and you. May it prove so, in very fact, to the utmost,—now and afterwards!
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [5 June]. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries. PM: London, 6 June 1862. MS: NLS 607.588B. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:98–100 inc; Bliss, JWC 293–94 inc. Quot: Twisleton, Letters 315–16; Hansons, NE 500. TC dated the letter and the envelope “5 june, 1862.“
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
I cannot count the letters I have written to you in my head within the last six weeks! they have been so many! I have written them mostly before getting out of bed in the morning; or while lying awake at night. But in the day time,—with pen and ink at hand, I have been always, always, always, too sick or too bothered, to put them on paper!—have indeed been writing to nobody, —if that be any excuse for not writing to you The beginning of warm weather is as trying for me in a different way as winter was. and so many sad things have happened. just when the freshness of one sorrow was wearing off there has come another. First Elizabeth Pepoli, then Lady Sandwich, then Mrs Twisleton.Ellen Twisleton d. 17 May. Jackson’s Oxford Journal, 31 May, quoting the Banbury Guardian, reported TC’s attendance at the Twisleton funeral: “The remains of the lamentedlady were interred on Saturday, in the churchyard of Broughton, beneath the shade of a laburnum—a spot she had herself specially selected for that purpose in her life time, in preference to the family vault within the walls of the church itself. … Amongst personal friends, not related to the family, … were … Mr. Thomas Carlyle, Mr. R. Browning.“ “A very beautiful and clever little Boston lady, wife of Hon. Edward Twisleton, and much about us for the six or seven years she lived here. I well remember her affecting funeral (old Fiennes Castle, in Oxfordshire), and my ride thither with Browning, &c“ (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:98); Broughton Castle, home of the Fiennes family. the three people in all London whose friendship I had most
dependence on. Nobody will believe the loss Lady Sandwich is to us. They say “a woman of eighty!—that is not to be regretted.“ But her intimate friends know that this woman of eighty was the most charming Companion and the loyalest, warmest friend, was the only person in London or in the world that Mr C went regularly to see—twice a week he used to call for her—and now his Horse makes for her House, whenever he gets into the region of Grosvenor Square! and does not see or understand the EscutcheonAn escutcheon given a black surround and hung at the front door of the deceased person’s house to indicate mourning. that turns me sick as I drive past. Dear little Mrs Twisleton—so young, and beautiful,For a daguerreotype portrait (ca. 1846–50) of Ellen Twisleton (on the left) with her sister Elizabeth Dwight Cabot (1830–1901), see 98above. and clever, so admired in Society and adored at Home—is a loss that every one can appreciate, and the strong affection she testified for me thro her long terrible illness has made her death a keener grief than I thought it would be.

figure.p: Ellen Twisleton and Elizabeth Dwight Cabot, ca. 1846–50

p.hi: Courtesy of The Schlesinger Library, Radcliffe Institute, Harvard University

docBody.p: I should have been thankful to be away from here—anywhere— — at the bottom of a coalpit—to think over all this in quiet!, safe from the breaking in of all the Idlers “come up“ to that great vulgar show of an “Exhibition“ and safe from the endless weary chatter about it! Nothing could keep me here for an hour, but Mr C’s determination to stay—since at the top of the house he is safe enough from tiresome interruptions simply refusing to see anybody! which alas makes it all the more needful for me to be civil! Here he will stay and work on, (what an idea you have all got in your heads, that, having published a third volume, he must be at ease in Zion!Cf. Amos 6:1.—when two more volumes are to come and one wholly unwritten!) and to leave him in the present state of things is what I cannot make up my mind to— If I go on in this way however, I shall die! and just before it comes to that extremity I shall probably muster the necessary resolution.

Poor Mrs Grierson—will you tell me about her death— It must have been sudden; for you did not say she was ill when you wroteHelen Grierson, b. Sibbald (1789–1862), whom JWC had sometimes visited when staying with Mary Russell; see 34:210JWC to MR, 1 Oct. 1858. She d. 24 May after suffering from pneumonia for four days.— So much the better;
for that son of hersThomas Boyle Grierson (1818–89; see 37:26JWC to LAI, 24 Oct. 1860), doctor and naturalist, known for his gentle and attractive personality; his mother lived with him at 31 Drumlanrig St., Thornhill. was not likely to be much of a nurse It is little of comfort or happiness she had ever known on earth—and latterly her life looked nothing but a sad, weary waiting for the release that is now comeFor JWC’s tale of Helen Grierson’s marriage, see 37:26–27JWC to LAI, 24 Oct. 1860.— A more innocent Being never went to meet the unseen Future!

Maggie Welsh has been in London six weeks—not living here, but with her
old friend Agnes Baird;Agnes Baird, an old friend of the Welsh family; see 16:309TC to JWC, 23 July 1843; possibly living at 50 Weymouth St., Portland Pl. but she came and spent the part of the day, often, during which she couldnt be in Mr C’s way.

She saw more “Sights“ than I ever saw all the years I have been in London put together! She is now gone to Devonshi[r]eLetter omitted. to visit a Mrs Henry LiddellPossibly Alice, b. Darling (b. 1823), wife of Henry Liddell (b. 1809), nephew of James, Eliza, and Isobel Liddell of Auchtertool; see 36:28336:biographical note. MaryMary Welsh, Maggie’s sister. is well, at Auchtertool; hindered from coming I believe by want of funds. Mary being always immersed in dress-makers bills! One would say “the game wasn’t worth the candle“Proverbial; see 28:116TC to WA, 21 April 1853, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 362.—on the top of a hill in Fifeshire!

Mr C’s comfort under the confusion of the Exhibition is that “it is to be hoped it will end in total bankruptcy“! They say the Guarantees will be called on to pay 25 per centThe International Exhibition overcame a number of financial obstacles, finally facing the rather modest shortfall of £10,612, which was made up by Sir John Kelk, the builder of the main exhibition structure (Report of the Commissioners for the Exhibition of 1862 to the Right Hon. Sir George Grey, Bart. G.C.B. [1863] lx, 87).—
Kindest love to the Dr a hearty kiss to yourself.
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-CAW, 14 June. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Pbd: Times, 29 June 1914 inc.
div3.head: TC TO C. A. WARD

docBody.p: I am obliged to you for your good—word, and your good—will. What you say of Vol iii is (bating what modesty forbids me to &c &c) very much the truth of the matter. It happens also to be the first criticismPresumably in Ward’s letter to TC, rather than in an untraced review of Frederick. I have seen, or heard of, on the subject: if it happen farther to be the last,—that too, in present circumstances, will be very suitable! In wd a twelvemonth hence, if I can work well, I hope to have done;—whh is pretty much all the interest I at present have in the affair.

Nor am I surprised, or sorry, at yr present disgust in regard to matters Literary. When you have got something duly pressing to be said (whh may be before long, and will be in the course of time), you will speak again.Ward’s most recent publication had been The Sutherland Clearance: A Ballad (Glasgow, 1860); see 36:262TC to CAW, 24 Sept. 1860. By merely attending to that rule of Nature, a man might become one of the most
Original Writers of his Time, as Times now are!— Courage! He of the “bulbous nose“Possibly the prime minister, Lord Palmerston; otherwise unidentified. must be left to his stertorous dreams; but by and by Events will strike him broad awake, poor devil; and then if anybody have wise notions, they may be in the highest degree useful.
Wishing you health of soul, body and fortune,—Yours truly
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 18 June. Addr: 6 (? Used to be ‘25’) Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: 19 June 1862. MS: NLS 553.243. Hitherto unpbd. Neuberg’s house at 25 Adelaide Rd. had been renumbered 140; see TC to JN, [26 and 27 June].
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—Volumes V & VI of yr WeberKarl Julius Weber, Deutschland, oder Briefe eines in Deutschland reisenden Deutschen, 3. Auflage [edn.], als Reisehandbuch eingerichtet, 6 vols. (Stuttgart, 1843–44). are here; and have his acct of Saxony and of “Saxon Schweitz [Switzerland],“—whh is a very loose story, totally uninstructive to me, and contains no notice of that Book of the Country Parson’sWilhelm Lebrecht Götzinger, Schandau und seine Umgebungen, oder Beschreibung der sächsischen Schweitz (Dresden, 1812); see Works 17:85. whh I once had. Witht it I can do; witht the Title too I can,—but had rather not, tho’ I see not clearly how you are to help me.TC also asked Erasmus Darwin for help; Darwin wrote to his brother, Charles Darwin, 20 June: “I dont know if it will be in your power to give Carlyle a helping hand about a book. On some former occasion he borrowed a book from the Jermyn St Museum [Museum of Practical Geology] he does not remember thro’ whom or the exact title. It was an 8vo with a cold geological map on the ‘Saxon Switzerland’“ (Correspondence of Charles Darwin [Cambridge, 1997] 10:262). On the whole, don’t mind.
One other thing you may do whh I want;—by calling at the London Library, within the next 8 days. And that is:

To ascertain in what Book (surely in Förster’s or in watery Pauli?)Friedrich Förster, Friedrich Wilhelm I, König von Preussen (Potsdam, 1834); Karl Friedrich Pauli, either Leben grosser Helden des gegenwärtigen Krieges, 9 vols. (Halle, 1758–64) (TC’s copy: HCC), or Allgemeine Preussische Staats-Geschichte, 8 vols. (Halle, 1760–69), described by TC as “eight watery quartos, intolerable to human nature“ (Works 12:70). I have read abt the Great Elector’s Project (Project set before him, and examined but not acceded to) of founding a Latin Town;Frederick William (1620–88), elector of Brandenburg, popularly known as the Great Elector because of his military and political skill; great-grandfather of Frederick the Great. For his Latin Town project, see Works 16:359.—& to give me chapter-&-verse
for a Footnote that is necessary! That is all; but it may not be quite easy. Pauli (such a vol, such a page); or Forster (do do), or whoever it was.TC cites neither Förster nor Pauli, but Gustav Adolf Harald Stenzel, Geschichte des Preussischen Staats, 5 vols. (Hamburg, 1830–54). Right well I remember the dreary reading and, disgust of the same, but not in what longeared Farrago it was!—

You need not keep that other Guide Book on Saxn SchwietzThus in MS; unidentified further. at yr City Place;The offices, managed by Neuberg, of his late brother-in-law, Adolph Frankau, at 25 Clements Lane, Lombard St.—I do not expect it can contain anything for me.

Come on Sunday Evg.— By the blessing of Heaven, all this melancholy slavery will end;—Pharaoh’s bricksSee Exod. 5; a favorite phrase for the writing of Frederick; see 35:7TC to JN, 7 Jan. 1859, and 36:89TC to LLA, 27 March 1860. were but an emblem of it: not even straw allowed one, and stubble not discoverable always.— Patience, & shuffle the cards!Cf. Cervantes, Don Quixote, pt. 2, chap. 23.—
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 18 June. MS: NLS 517.35. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Your Note came this morning; thanks. I am glad to hear of Hy Watt’s engaget; I saw him here,—and strongly advised him to stick to his trade, steadily in any form rather than in none, and to end these continual interludes.Henry Watt seemed to have spent much of the previous two years in Edinburgh; TC was probably referring to Henry’s having obtained another position on a ship, rather than that he was already engaged to Jane Hunter, da. of John A. Carlyle’s friend John Hunter (1801–69; see 8:161JWC to SS, June 1835), whom Henry m. in 1863. John Carlyle wrote to James Carlyle Jr., 16 April, suggesting that Henry “might be able to help you to some occupation in Liverpool, now that he has got so much more common sense than he used to have“ (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). Whh he himself seemed disposed to do. Of his youngest Brother he seemed to have no definite expectations.William Watt was in trouble at Woolwich; see TC to JAC, 3 May. Poor fellows, their little outfit of money is positively a great and almost insuperable hindrance to them!— I am happy to think you have nearly done with the affair.

James of Scotsbrig’s adventureJames Carlyle Jr. was hoping for a post with William Baird & Co., an ironworks company based in Gartsherrie, Lanarkshire, run by James Baird (1802–76; ODNB). They owned coalfields and ironworks in various parts of Scotland, as well as extensive lands in N Lanarkshire. John A. Carlyle had arranged an introduction for James Jr. to a Mr. Wallace, probably David Wallace (d. 1877), m. to Janet Weir (1836–1902), James Baird’s niece. John wrote to James, 19 April, telling him that Mr. Wallace was “anxious to have men of good & respectable connections & character in the employment of the Bairds“ and that he wanted to see James; John concluded: “[W]e may infer … that Mr Wallace has really taken up your case, & perhaps also that he may have some post in view for you, if he finds your qualifications suitable“ (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). is, of course, far more interesting to me.
The present posture of it seems to me the difficult one,—so far as I can understand. If he likes to undertake in real earnest the charge of their model-Farm, I have no doubt he can and will respectably do it: but hanging on as a led horse, is not good on strange roads! If you can use any means to shorten the probatn, or help (with him or with them) towards a good issue, it will be very charitable.Model farm untraced; James Jr. was offered an office job; John wrote, 2 June, that Mr. Wallace hoped to see James at Gartsherrie next week: “He says it is a thriving place, & you will be able to get lodgings under the guidance of people in the office. … The project of farm management can stand in the background meanwhile“ (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). James Jr. took the job on probationary terms; John wrote, 27 June: “[D]o not make yourself miserable whatever the result of the probation may lead to. Something else will be found, if you fail with the Bairds. It seems already pretty clear that you cannot stand the confinement of the office; & if the Baird you speak of seems an unreasonable man you had perhaps better keep clear of any permanent engagement with him“ (MS: NLS Acc. 9086).— Did Js never think of fairly starting, on his own account, as Tiller of the Earth, in N.S. Wales?In 1860 James Carlyle Jr. thought of going to Australia; see 36:96TC to JF, 13 April 1860. The climate promises health; & I have never seen anything else deficient in him hitherto. A 3 or £400 of outfit, whh might be got for him, wd buy a aWord repeated at the turn of the page. reasonable bit of land to start with:—why not? Or does his Father (what is possible) object? I have been really sorry for the poor lad, in late years; for I think he is really well-gifted, if fairly got in harness.James Carlyle Jr. worked for several years in the offices of Stevenson & Co., Glasgow, but in 1859 returned to Scotsbrig because of ill health; see 35:228TC to AC, 7 Oct. 1859. See what you can do,—in this Baird busss or otherwise.

We have very wet weather; today wild wind from the nth, still with a shower or two. My head is occasionally threatening want of sleep agn; but I take care. No pills here do anything but torment me for trying them. A dozen of the “Hop“ kindHop pills were well known as a remedy for sleeplessness; see 32:108JWC to MR, 24 March 1857. TC had used them the previous year; see 37:96TC to JAC, 16 Jan. 1861. agn,—is that worth trying? I am up to the chin in Printer’s slips & clippings: heigho! Book xvii (end of vol iv) will not be out of my hands by last day of june,—ah no; but I am pushing, what I can. Still in the Garret; whh is one of the best of lodgings in cool sumer. Jane is weakly, but still stirring as usual. Adieu dear Brother. Yours ever— T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-IES, [ca. 22 June]. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd. Dated soon after the arrival of Elizabeth, the Carlyles’ new maid from Haddington, and before 23 June, the date of a letter from Geraldine Jewsbury to Walter Mantell, in which Jewsbury refers to Margaret’s recent departure: “Kee [George Cooke] told me that Margaret had left Mrs Carlyle of her own accord & had carefully kept her ignorant of her future intentions“ (MS: Mantell). JWC’s dateline “Sunday“ suggests no later than 22 June (she was in Folkestone Sun., 29 June).
div3.head: JWC TO ISABELLA E. SIMMONDS

docBody.p: Will that nice maidUnidentified. of yours be going to Church tonight? If so, will you desire her to do me the great favour to call here on the way—(that is; out of the way—) and take my ScotchwomanPossibly either Elizabeth Lyall (b. ca. 1834) or Elizabeth Gray (b. ca. 1840), both listed in 1861 Haddington census. along with her.

She the Scotch woman will not be found a brilliant companion I fear. At all events I am positive she is a safe one—as harmless a piece of human nature as was ever put in my hands to work up into a “good, plain, Cook“—oh, so very ‘plain’ it must be!
Tell the Bearer by word of mouth if your Paragon will come? and at what hour of the evening
docBody.name: Jane B W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-UC, 25 June. MS: Breckenridge Long Autograph Collection, LC. Pbd: Charles Eliot Norton, ed., Two Notebooks of Thomas Carlyle, from 23d March 1822 to 16th May 1832 (New York: Grolier Club, 1898) facsimile 281–83, printed 284. The catalog of the unknown dealer from whom Breckenridge bought this letter stated: “This letter … was written to a now well-known writer when a youth.“ As the MS was sold and pbd. in the U.S., it is possible that the “well-known writer“ might be Henry James Jr. (1843–1916; ODNB), living in Newport, Rhode Island, at this time, and writing many short stories; his story “A Tragedy of Error“ was pbd. in the Continental Monthly Feb. 1864. His father, Henry James Sr. (1811–82) had visited the Carlyles in the 1840s and 1850s (see TC to JAH, 11 Nov. 1843, and JWC’s Journal, 24 Oct. 1855). But since the “Tragedy“ sent to TC was apparently a drama, it seems unlikely that its author, the recipient of this letter, was Henry James Jr.
div3.head: TC TO UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT

docBody.p:
“Seekest thou great things, seek them not!“Cf. Jer. 45:5. I cd do no good with your “Tragedy,“ after never so much endeavour, it depends on Playhouse Managers
&c &c;—and is, I must say, likely to have been an unreasonable, tho’ innocent attempt, on the part of a Young Man, inexperienced in Life, much more in the suitable ways of Delineating and Expounding what Life is and shd be.

Forgive my plainness of speech. But it is my standing advice to all young persons who trace in themselves a superior capacity of mind, to select, beyond all other conditions, a silent course of activity;—and to disbelieve totally the babble of reviews and newspapers, and loud clamour of Nonsense everywhere prevalent, That “Literature“ (even if one were qualified) is the truly noble human carreer. Far other, very far! since you ask my opinion. The greatest minds I have known, or have authentically heard of, have not been the Speakings Ones at all,—much less in these loud times; raging with palaver, and with so little else, from sea to sea!—
In very great haste (wishing you well, not ill), / T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [26 and 27 June]. Addr: 140. Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: 27 June 1862. MS: letter NLS 553.240; envelope NLS 553.241. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: If you like to enclose a Card of yours, without other writing—
docBody.name: T. C. / (Thursday)
docBody.note: Written on a separate sheet with TC to JN, [27 June]; Thurs. was 26, and Fri. 27 June. Presumably TC intended Neuberg to put his card in with Charles Darwin’s letter for presentation at the museum (see n. 3).
docBody.p: Dear Neuberg—Thanks for yr victory in the Latin Town. I believe I must employ you in Jermyn Street,The Museum of Practical Geology, Jermyn St. Erasmus Darwin wrote to TC, 23 June: “If you would not mind the bore of calling at the Museum any day that you are out riding, the Librarian would be able I should think to identify the Book for you without any delay. / I enclose a species of introduction to Mr Trenham Reeks which would at all events save the trouble of explaining tho’ otherwise I have no doubt quite unnecessary.“ He enclosed Charles Darwin’s reply to himself, 21 June: “My friend Mr Trenham Reeks, the Secretary at the Museum Jermyn St, would, I am sure, gladly give any information or aid to so distinguished a person as Mr Carlyle. … Carlyle could, if he thinks fit, take this note as an introduction to Mr Reeks“ (MS: NLS 553.241). Trenham Reeks (1823–93), sec. of the Museum of Practical Geology. after all. I rode up the other evg; but they shut at ‘5 p.m.’

Come on Sunday night,—if with laurels after readg the inclosed.TC enclosed Charles Darwin’s letter to Neuberg, writing at the top of Darwin’s letter: “To Erasmus Darwin Esqr—in help of me (T. Carlyle)“ and at the bottom “If Mr Reeks wd extend his charity to Mr Neuberg on my behalf?— / T.C.“ (MS: NLS 553.241).
docBody.name: T. C. (Friday, Chelsea).

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [29 June]. Addr: 5 Gt Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Folkstone, 29 June, 1862. MS: NLS 607.588C. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:247–49 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.dateline: FoxtonFolkestone. / West Cliff Hotel Sunday [29 June 1862]
docBody.p: I dont know what would have become of me if it hadn’t been for Miss Davenport Bromley,Caroline Davenport Bromley. whom I met on the platform at Folkestone Station! The Heavens had chosen that particular moment to pour down a deluge! I had taken no umbrella, and no outer wrappage; No “carriage“ was waiting, nor servant; But Miss Bromley was also bound for Lady Ashburton’s. and her MaidUnidentified. plunged about and procured a Fly—to which we had to walk some space as thro’ a waterfall! and in which we were packed all too close for my wetted velvet cloak; the wreck of which was total! It was a bad beginning; and I am very sorry about my poor cloak, which is not fit to be put on again! and which I got from dear Lady Sandwich. But I suppose I should be thankful that I didn’t catch a great cold besides!
Note Bena: 1st Not to travel again without umbrella. 2d not to have a cloak again, which is spoiledable by rain— 3d not to put my dependance on Lady A’s memory.

I found Lord Ashburton on crutchesLord Ashburton suffered from gout; see TC to JWC, [27 Jan.].—Baby better—and the Lady improving;Lady Ashburton was recovering from a miscarriage; see Surtees, Ludovisi 88. Miss Anstruther (the niece)Probably Annie Nairn Anstruther. is here; and Miss D BromelyThus in MS. who is amiable, and an acquisition. Lady A asked “DID I think you would come?“—and said she “almost expected to see you with me“!TC came 5 to 7 July; see JWC to JF, [2 July]. Still she didnt give me the idea of having expected you, or exactly meaning you to come just at this moment. Perhaps the party is as large as the premises admit of—but I shall watch, and ascertain, if possible, her precise meaning. Perhaps she would like best that you came when I went home. It is a wonderfully quiet House, to be a Hotel. My room was undisturbed till the servants came into the adjoining sitting-room in the morning—except for Baby who is located overhead, and who appeared to have more than one bad dream; when nurses tramped about to the rescue, and Baby’s cries rose to a pitch! The objection, to the bedroom, for you, would be only the light! there is a white muslin blind, and
white muslin window curtains over a rather large window. But you could pin up your railway-rug; as you have done ere now.

The surrounding country—so far as I have seen yet from the windows is flat and prosaic; the sea not so near as one could wish and, the weather being dull, not clearly definable from the sky. It isn’t to be compared to Hastings as a place!JWC had been to Hastings with Frederic and Clara Chapman in April; see TC to JAC, 7 April. Still a day or two by the sea anywhere would do you good. If Lady A would only say frankly, what she wishes as to both of us! instead of leaving one to guess! I havent a notion whether she expects me to stay two days or two weeks or what!— And shall have to find out before I can feel any pleasure in being here. What I should like to do is just to stay half as long as she means me to stay. For the rest, she is as kind as kind can be, and the sea-air always revives me—at first. And KatePresumably a maid. is very attentive, brought me a cup of tea at eight oclock in my bed.

I do hope you will be properly fed! ElizabethThe new servant at Cheyne Row; see JWC to IES, [ca. 22 June]. is very anxious to do right, and will attend to every wish you express—if you will only give her brief and plain directions.
But I dare say I shall soon be there to interpret for her.
And now I shall go and take a little walk before the rain comes—which I see in the wind—
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JR[JRU], 30 June. MS: L. E. Brown. Pbd: Cate 99–100. Quot: W. G. Collingwood, Life of John Ruskin (1900) 207; Edward Cook, The Life of John Ruskin (1911) 2:57. Text: Cate.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN RUSKIN

docBody.p:
It was, and is, yr duty to send some tidings of yrselfRuskin, traveling in Switzerland and Italy, was currently in Milan. to this address. We are more concerned abt you than you seem in the heart to believe;—and therefore reigns no despair here upon the black state you are evidently in: nothing is considered the least essential but that your bodily health shd keep good, and clear itself of those superficial presences wh have been annoying of late. Take every precaution then, I do earnestly counsel you! The want of every such counsel to myself, or of my following any such, has been such an item in the general invoice to me (invoice highly considerable, you wd say if you
knew it) as swallows all the others, and how fitly has with a shudder when I look back on it! [ … ?]Cate’s ellipses. dePossibly a misreading for “te [you].“ expecto [I look forward to seeing you]. If you are wise you will.—For the rest, you ought to write regularly to Chelsea; some kind of answer will be sent (quite regular ansr, if we were once thro’ this Book); and if no ansr come, still you are bound to write.

I am finishing vol IV; busy as a poor spent costermonger’s ass getting its head over the last hill but one. For years past I have ceased writing Notes pretty nearly altogether:—not a wise step, I begin to see but it now cannot be mended. Well, and the case at present is: I have read, a month ago, your First in Fraser;The first of Ruskin’s four “Essays on Political Economy,“ pbd. in Fraser’s Magazine, June 1862; see TC to JAF, 14 April. and ever since have had a wish to say to it and you, Euge, macte nova virtute [Well done, good luck with your new resolve].See Virgil, Aeneid 9.641. I approved in every particular; calm, definite, clear; rising into the sphere of Plato (our almost best), whh in exchange for the sphere of Macculloch, Mill and Co.John Ramsay McCulloch (1789–1864; ODNB) and John Stuart Mill; “and Co.,“ presumably other unidentified political economists. is a mighty improvement! Since that, I have seen the little green Book, too; reprint of your Cornhill operations,John Ruskin, Unto This Last (1862) pbd. June. The essays originally appeared in the Cornhill Magazine 2 (Aug., Sept., Oct., Nov. 1860): 155–66, 278–86, 407–15, 543–64.—abt ⅔ of whh was read to me (known only from what the contradictn of sinners had told me of it);The essays had been greeted with considerable hostility; TC read at least the fourth essay and wrote to Ruskin to praise it; see 37:29TC to JRU, 29 Oct. 1860.—in every part of whh I find a high and noble sort of truth, not one doctrine that I can intrinsically dissent from, or count other than salutary in the extreme, and pressingly needed in Engld above all. This “wish“ has been steering me more than ever since the green Book. So now I have written. We are tolerably well. Adieu, write!
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 30 June. Addr: West-Cliff Hôtel / Folkestone. PM: London, 30 June 1862. MS: NLS 615.553. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:249.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Dear Goody mine,—I am very sorry for yr poor velvet cloak, and poor self under these bits of mischances in your poor weak state! I hope and pray you may get some good of the sea-air, however; whh will be a fine return for
everything. Courage my poor brave Jeanniekin; come back to me a little better; that is all I want!—

You were hardly gone when Blanche Lady Airlie came driving to the door; I need not inclose her card, as there was not order given that I heard of: but some hours later, the same day, Mrs Dilbue with Cushman came, and expressly charged (I know not whh of them did it, the gigantic or the middle-sized,)The “gigantic“ was presumably Charlotte Cushman; she was about JWC’s height, 5 ft. 5¾ ins. (1.68 m.) (see 19:138JWC to TC, 10 Aug. 1845) while JWC described Sarah Dilberoglue in 1853 as “a little little creature neither pretty nor graceful“ (see 28:21JWC to KS, 28 Jan. 1853). As TC was 6 ft. (1.8 m.), he was possibly referring to her girth, as compared to Sarah Dilberoglue’s, rather than her height. For a picture of Cushman in 1859, see oppabove. that their “Cards were to be forwarded,“—whh I have brot up stairs,
and will inclose, accordingly: more power to them! George Cook also called (I out riding), and that was all.

figure.p: Charlotte Cushman, 1859

docBody.p: Nothing is wrong abt the House (girlsThe maids Maria and Elizabeth. washing today &c), nor have I failed in sleep, or had other misfortune; nevertheless I am dreadfully low-spirited, and feel like a child wishing Mammy back. Perhaps too she is as well away, for the moment! The truth is, I am under medical appliance,Presumably blue pill; see JWC to TC, [1 July].—highly “successful,“ and whh will yield good fruits for days coming, but whh renders me for this day the wretchedest nearly of all the Sons of Adam not yet condemned in fact to the Gallows.— I have not spoken one word to anybody since you went away (only to Jamie Aitken, a very few, yesternight); and, my work lying aback too, am at a low pass for the time being.

No Proofsheets have come; no nothing:—I have cleared off all my Note writing, the Ruskins &c &c; and am trying this day to resume Friedrich the Unique in earnest. Vol V now; hurrah, after all. Don’t bargain for my coming just now, even if you have chance. Your coming back, a little better, is the best news that cd come to me. But don’t hurry; don’t at all! Do as you are proposing,—ready at the good time;—and any way let me hear largely from you. I mean largely if you can but don’t make a Corvée [required labor] of it. And Oh for God’s sake, take care of yrself. In the Earth I have no other! Compliments to both Lord & Lady.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [1 July]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Folkstone, 1 July 1862. MS: NLS 607.589B. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p:
Thanks Dear! It was “a good joy“Coterie speech; an expression of one of Leigh Hunt’s children; see 10:167JWC to TC, 9 Sept. 1838. to get your letter this morning; the time looks so long since I left home! I don’t mean it passes heavily, but it is so full of movement and variety! “There need be no reflections for want of“Coterie speech; cf. 29:253JWC to TC, 12 Feb. 1855, and 33:4JWC to TC, 3 Aug. 1857. Bath chairs and Pony Carriages! I am almost constantly in the open air from breakfast time till dinner time (half after seven) and I feel a little stronger and
have actually got a little colour—tho’ only as yet in the point of my nose!— Lord A has laid aside his CrutchesSee TC to JWC, [27 Jan.]. and Bath chair, and walks and drives with my Lady—so that I have not seen her alone these two days; and havenot been able to come to any conclusion about the length of my visit. I feel confident enough of having not overstaid my welcome yet. But am not sure that it would be safe to stay over the week. I shall tomorrow “find an opportunity or make one“ of speaking to my Lady. Not a question has been asked or word of any sort spoken about your coming, since what was said on my arrival: en revanche [on the other hand] there is much celebration of your Book and your Genius, and your “poetic language.“ And meanwhile Dr Quain has been here a day and night; and two of the Thornton children (from Candover)Francis Vansittart Thornton (1816–95), rector of Chilton Candover, Alresford, Hampshire, and his wife, Mary Louisa, b. Cholmondeley (1826–89), had 10 children. came yesterday “for a little sea bathing to do them good“!
Miss Bromely goes home tomorrow, and will be a decided loss. She is gentle, intelligent, and perfectly well bred.

Miss Anstruther is little more than a LayWebster includes the meaning “lacking extensive knowledge of a particular subject“ for “lay“; possibly JWC meant that Annie Anstruther added very little to the gathering. figure

I wish you had said whether your dinners were satisfactory. But in the valley of the ShadowCoterie speech; cf. Ps. 23.4. of Blue Pill (that being what I understood you to mean by “medical appliance“) nothing can be satisfactory; and if I were there, ever so bodily; it would make no difference!
