We have had a much longer drive than usual today, Miss Bromley and I, and there was only an hour till dinner, for resting and dressing—and I stupidly trusted to having time enough for writing instead of resting, or over and above resting; and now it wants just twenty minutes of the half hour!
But when I have said that all is going on well enough, what more need I say—being so soon coming back with the tongue in my head?Cf. Merchant of Venice 2.2.—
docBody.name: Jane W C

ps.p: Ever so little a note please!

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 1 July. Addr: West-Cliff Hôtel / Folkestone. PM: London, 1 July 1862. MS: NLS 615.554. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:249.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: “Nothink for Craigenputtock today Ma’am!” Nothink, the poor Goody was too busy; nor did I feel disappointed, tho’ I shd have been glad. I was upon coffee today again; I did not actually stop BullockJohn Bullock, the Chelsea postman. in the Margaretta Quarter,Margaretta Ter., Chelsea, just to the E of Cheyne Row. “tho’ I had half a mind to!” All is going on right here, Goodykin; take no care or anxiety abt it: I am myself a bit stronger today;—and have done far more than usual of work; whh is not saying much, tho’ it is a happy circumstance. No news, no speech even,—how can there be news? I sat reading (Fredk pluisters, pencil in hand, last night, till Maria came in “near 12 o’clock, sir; no hamper come!”Presumably the weekly hamper of butter, cream, etc. from the Ashburtons’ farm at Addiscombe; see 36:59TC to TLMM, 6 Feb. 1860. upon whh I ordered her to bed, and sprawled out myself, disconsolate among the Cremorne cabs.The cabs coming from Cremorne Gardens, amusement park W of Cheyne Row. The Times, 28 June, announced: “The coming week will be one of unusual brilliancy, and will present a Succession of Special Performances, Fêtes and Banquets, for which the most perfect arrangements have been made.“ No hamper came; nor let it come! I was too late in getting to bed (will not be agn), but got a fair sleep notwithstanding. Today I may walk, if it seem good, and go and seek talk at any time, shd I want it. Silence even of the saddest, sadder than death, is often preferable, to shake the nonsense out of one. Last night, in getting to bed, I said to myself at last, “Impossible, sir, that you have no friend in the big Eternities and Immensities, or none but Death, as you whimper to yrself. You have had friends, who before the birth of you even, were good to you, and did give you several things! Know that you have friends, unspeakably importt as appears, —and let not their awful looks, or doings, quite terrify you! You require to have a heart,—like theirs in some sort: who knows?“ And fell asleep on that honourable pillow of whinstone.

Yesterday I forgot to tell you that on Sunday Evg I rode by Forster’s; saw poor Fr himself for a few minutes, who looked agitated, earnest and friendly poor soul, but had got a little glimmer of hope, “Wife said by the Drs to be a thot better,“—“was up this day (or shifted some way), and certainly had a quieter night: but so weak, oh so weak!” I have not been since nor at Milnes’s since (was it that same night) they told me, “HeR. M. Milnes. complained of his night as very bad; but the Doctors counted him decidedly better.“ These are
my two bulletins. And now I will run out for a mouthful of air before dinner. Adieu, Dearest, T. C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [2 July]. MS: NLS 607.589C. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:100–102; Fielding and Sorensen 274–75 inc. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:145. For TC’s headnote (Froude, LM 3:100), see JWC to JF, [2 July]. The MS is torn in several places; missing words are in sq. br.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Thanks Dear! especially for telling me about Mrs Forster. I had been so vexed at myself for not begging you to go again and send me word.

Lady A came and sat in my room a while last night—and speaking of Miss Bromley’s departure, I took occasion to say; that “as she and I came on the same day, I felt as if I [ought] to have also gone on the same day.“ The answer to which was a very cordial “Nonsense! my dear friend!“— I was expected to stay, she then said, “as long as they did,“—or (when I shook my head at that) “as long, at all events as I could possibly make it convenient.“ There was no doubt whatever about her present wish being to that effect! And then came up the old question as a new one “did I think He would come? “It would be such a pleasure to Bingham,Lord Ashburton; for a lithograph of him by T. R. Way, see oppabove; the Catalogue of the Third and Concluding Exhibition of National Portraits … on Loan to the South Kensington Museum. April 1868 noted that the portrait was loaned by Lord Northbrook and was “After Sir Edwin Landseer.“ But A. Carlyle recorded it as “From a Portrait ‘done at one sitting,’ by Landseer“ (NLM 2: list of illustrations). According to Virginia Surtees, Sir Edwin Landseer (1802–73; ODNB) gave this portrait to Lady Ashburton “in the summer of 1862“ after he had completed his portrait of her and her da. Mary Florence (Surtees, Ludovisi 85–86); he had perhaps painted it earlier as Lord Ashburton appears in vigorous health, compared to the photograph taken of him in Oct. by Vernon Heath; see 248JWC to EFO, 30 Oct. now that he could move about“

figure.p: Lord Ashburton [ca. 1862], lithograph by T. R. Way from a portrait by Landseer

p.hi: New Letters and Memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle

docBody.p: I said you might perhaps be persuaded to come for a very short visit; but &c &“— That was it!—a short visit was evidently what she wanted—and she does want that! but she didn’t see her way thro a long one, in the circumstances I could see; and I [don’t] wonder! She would write [to]day herself she said and urge you to come on Saturday and stay till Monday— “You might surely do that!“
Now that is just what you must do! Even two days of Sea will benifitThus in MS. you and it can be had at little sacrifice of anything!

You dont need to trouble about clothes what you [c]ould bring in your carpet bag would be enough, there is no elaborate dressing for dinner here; and the tide is convenient;For sea bathing. and there is a horse!

And Lady A says she can give you “a perfectly quiet room“—indeed mine is quiet as the grave from outside noises! Not a cock nor a dog in all Foxton I think! and the cookery which objected to as all too Eng[lish] would suit you— Constant loins of roast mutton and constant boiled chickens! Now pray take no cou[n]selLetter omitted. with flesh and blood but come straight off on Saturday morning according to the invitation that will reach you (I expect) along with this And in all likelihood we will go home together on Monday,
If you don’t come; I will stay away as long as ever they will keep me, just to spite you!

Look up in your topographical Book for Saltwood Castle.Saltwood Castle, about 4 mi. (6.5 km.) W of Folkestone. Although a fortified position since Roman times, the castle itself was rebuilt and extended by Hugo de Montfort in the 11th cent. It later became renowned as the rendezvous of the murderers of Thomas Becket (1120?—70; ODNB). More or less in ruins, it was currently owned by William Deedes (1796–1862), M.P. for E. Kent. See also TC to JWC, [4 July]. Lady A asked,
when we were [the]re today, if I thought you [w]ould be able to tell us about it and I said “of course“ you would. Saltwood Castle near Foxton?— There is here too a Review of Frederick in the Corn Hill which would amuse you! adoring your genius; but absolutely horror struck at your “scorn“ which “is become normal“!The eds. George Henry Lewes and Frederick Greenwood (1830–1909; ODNB) wrote the review in the Cornhill Magazine, 6 (July 1862): 107–9; Frederick was “[o]riginal—grotesquely original—it is so utterly unlike every other biography, or history, that the notion of applying ‘critical standards’ would be preposterous. … [It is] a book of strange power, of immense research, patient and accurate to the point of being at times oppressive, irradiated with wild humour, and darkened by very serious faults. It exercises a potent spell, because it is a work of genius. But we resist the fascination, and feel that the genius is not working with a beneficial influence. … Carlyle, as an artist, may disregard all our established rules; as a teacher he is bound to regard them. … Scorn is an attitude perilous even to a mind like his, pernicious in its influence on weaker minds. Every serious man will at times be moved to indignant sarcasm at what is base. But in Carlyle, always too disposed to scorn, this attitude has become permanent, not occasional“ (6:107–8).— How you dare to utter such blasphemies against les respectables Messrs Leibniz and Maupertuis!!Gottfried Wilhelm von Leibniz (1646–1716), German philosopher and mathematician; Pierre Louis Moreau de Maupertuis (1698–1759), French mathematician and philosopher. Lewes and Greenwood complained: “Leibnitz may not have been the greatest of men, but he is worthy of more respect than he receives from Carlyle, who not only scornfully insists on his long nose, bandy legs, and huge periwig (as if those were the most notable points in a great thinker!), but in one place sneers at him as a ‘wiseacre.’ Again, Maupertuis, the butt of this volume, is nicknamed ‘Flattener of the Earth,’ and is presented to the reader in the most contemptible light. He had his vanities and weaknesses, which might have excused a little quizzing; but this achievement, which suggests the nickname of Flattener of the Earth [Maupertuis proved that the earth was oblate, rather than prolate], was very important to mankind, and removed an obstacle to the acceptance of Newton’s theory; and his labours altogether were of a kind which render Carlyle’s unvarying scorn as odious as it is unjust“ (6:108).I couldnt help bursting out laughing at the man’s sacred horror as if he had been speaking of Miltons Devil!See Milton, Paradise Lost.
docBody.name: JWC

ps.p: Horrible paper! I have no other.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 2 July. Addr: West-Cliff Hotel / Folkestone. PM: London, 2 July 1862. MS: NLS 615.555. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dear Goodykin, Thanks;—a Letter well worth reading over one’s coffee. Only don’t be in a hurry, especially as you are getting good; I do not see or guess the least sign of yr becoming superfluous in such a conjuncture,—and tho’ it is proper to be prompt, as gunpowder to spark, when that symptom arises, it is isRepeated at turn of page. wrong also and very troublesome to anticipate it, and go off without spark! Yr Miss Bromley, I conclude will be a real loss to you: she seemed to me all you say;—and besides, I heard, wanted to make yr acquaintance in particr!—

Be under no bother or apprehension abt yr women here. They feed and lodge me perfectly well;—capital pudding yesterday, “dinner“ always what it shd be hitherto, as everything else is. Keep yrself quiet, then.— I had a sublime walk, thro’ the Foreign UglinessesPresumably referring to foreign visitors at the International Exhibition. & &ceteras, up as far as Bath House last evg and back (no riding)—I had slept an hour in spite of the hammerings;—I was in bed soon after 1 p.m, and never woke till 10 this morning,—shame on me! Work rather lagging in consequence. But you see.

Fancy what a dull thump of authentic tragedy lay in this poor scrap whh lay waiting me for tea last night. Poor Tom WallFor Watt; the “t“ s are uncrossed. home from Australia, just arrives to die!Presumably a note announcing Thomas Watt’s death, 1 July, possibly from his brother Arthur. John A. Carlyle wrote to James Carlyle Jr., 2 July: “Today I have heard from London that Mr Thomas F. Watt died there yesterday at noon; & I have to start this evening for 48 Brompton Row to attend the funeral on friday first—/ Mr Watt came back from Sydney only last sunday, & died of aneurism“ (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). I had seen the ArthurArthur Watt.(did I tell you?) one evg on the Streets: he then knew nothing of any such Advent. Poor Mad Tom; cd he help being mad,—& here is the end of him all at once!

Maria has announced dinner, brot up Orley Farm,Anthony Trollope, Orley Farm, pbd. in shilling installments monthly by Chapman & Hall, March 1861–Oct. 1862; see also JWC to TC, [4 Sept.]. and put on the stand, since I began writing. Now waits solenlyThus in MS; in error for “solemnly.“ below, and I must down. Adieu, and all blessings.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p:
a Letter from John just come; as usual has nothing or nearly so.— Do you
want Punch, Good Words, All the Yr round?Punch, weekly satirical magazine, Good Words, monthly review, and All The Year Round, weekly literary newspaper ed. by Charles Dickens.Speak if so, for they are all three here since yesternight—

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JF, [2 July]. MS: NLS 607.589A. Hitherto unpbd. “We were there with the Ash-burtons; She first for a week or more, then both of us for perhaps a week longer.—Ay de mi! (29 Octr 1869)“ (TC’s note on MS); Froude attached it as a headnote to JWC to TC, [2 July].
div3.head: JWC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.dateline: Wednesday [2 July 1862] West Cliff Hotel / Folkestone
docBody.p: I am unwilling to add the smallest grain of trouble to the heavy burden you are having to bear! But it takes so long to hear round by Cheyne Row—especially as Mr C posts his letter before going out.
And I am very very anxious about HerEliza Forster; see TC to JWC, 1 July.—as every one who knows her must be—dear sweet gentle soul!
So may I beg you to send me just one word—(literally)—if “better“ be the word, it will be a great relief to me at this distance.

I shall stay here I believe till next week. It was become very needful to go somewhere—try something—and I am repaid for the violent effort I made in leaving home, by feeling a degree less weak and languid.
Mr C was glad to have seen yourself that day.
I am sure if sympathy could be any use to you, you have both his and mine from the bottom of our hearts.
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A[LLA], 3 July. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
You are always good! I am strongly tempted to come;—nor is there anything, I hope, absolutely to prevent; tho’ two sudden things have come today: first, a huge body of Proof-sheets (very ugly); and second, a Brother out of Scotland, called up at a minute’s warning,John A. Carlyle, arriving for Tom Watt’s funeral, Fri., 4 July. whom I have not seen for long!
The Proofsheets I shall perhaps be able to despatch before tomorrow night, by sticking fiercely to them; the Brother I may hope to persuade to wait my coming back. If so,—Return Ticket, and Saturday to Monday with you, by the shore of the Many-sounding Sea!Cf. Iliad 1:34–35. Tomorrow I will say positively, to the Wife or you.
Salutations to his Lordship, and to the important Little Being!Mary Florence Baring.— In very great haste / Yours ever, / T. Carlyle

ps.p: (Such a day of down-pouring!)

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 3 July. Addr: West Cliff Hôtel / Folkestone. PM: London, 3 July 1862. MS: NLS 615.556. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: My Dear little Wifie,—You are better than expectn with yr nice little Bulletins. I had slept ill last night,—thanks to a heap of Proofs that did tumble in at last, after much waiting! Nor is this all. But let me first say, I saw FuzForster’s nickname. himself yesterday again, and his Wife is fairly better. Round the Corner, poor Fuz thinks, but hardly dare.

Well, and the next item is: John this morning abt 11 comes tumbling in from Dumfries,—up for poor Tom Watt’s Funeral, whh is tomorrow! Had ridden all night; not a corner vacant at the Brompton place;I.e., 48 Brompton Row; see TC to JWC, 2 July. Dr HunterProbably John Hunter; see TC to JAC, 18 June. there &c &c. I had called outThus in MS; for “on.“ the poor Watt BoysPresumably the surviving brothers, Henry, Arthur, and William, were in London for Thomas Watt’s funeral. last night as I rode home; some warning of the Dr’s possibility;—this morning too a line of his own from Dumfries (whh I thot announced the arrival for tonight). On the whole Maria (as she does hitherto) must take care of him.— — If I can do the Sheets tomorrow (as is probable or possible), I will bid him wait; and go ahead in the Return-Ticket way, as you advise. Positive Yes or No tomorrow (“Yes,“ I hope); & do you name to me the train. To Lady A. I have so written. Adieu
docBody.name: T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, [4 July]. Addr: West-Cliff Hôtel / Folkestone. PM: 4 July 1862. MS: NLS 615.557. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: I am coming tomorrow, Ducky (tell my Lady & yrself): if you have named a train, very well; but if not, I am likeliest by your train, and cannot say!— By intense speed I am thro’ my Proofs (just this moment, as MaMaria Chamberlayne.enters to say Dinner ready): JackJohn A. Carlyle.is perfectly at home, too! Last night there rained in upon me (only think of it, as I was ending my first cup) successively Ten Persons who needed Tea, and sat till 10–11 p.m! We did well enough,—with concealed effort (in the Tea season).

Saltwood is a fine old Historical Place; the builder an acquaintance of mine. That Henry de Essex who duelling for life (see Past and Prest)Henry of Essex (d. after 1163; ODNB), constable of England and the king’s standard bearer, lived at Saltwood Castle and substantially rebuilt it. ‘observed St. Edmund on the rim of the horizon;After dropping the king’s standard during the battle of Counsylth in 1157, Henry of Essex was accused of treason, and had to fight a duel to clear his name. According to TC, while dueling, he had a vision of St. Edmund (d. 869; ODNB) “at the rim of the horizon,“ which caused him to feel such shame at his misdeeds that he fell down as if dead; on recovery, he entered a monastery; see Carlyle, Past and Present 111–12. (very angry; (big as Teneriffe, and . . angry,TC’s ellipses. TC inserted “1“ and “2“ above the line to indicate the order in which the words were to be read: “on the rim of the horizon; big as Teneriffe, and . . angry, very angry.“ Teneriffe, or Tenerife, one of the Canary Islands, is dominated by Mt. Teide at 12,200 ft. (3,718 m.).— whh entirely did Hy de Essex!— Saltwd used to be the Archp of Canterbury’s place of delight in Cathc times;From 1026 until the Reformation in the 16th cent., the See of Canterbury was the feudal overlord of Saltwood Castle; from the 13th cent., it was often used as the archbishop’s main residence.— I shall be very happy to look at it, if within reach.— — Dinner, dinner;—and adieu till tomorrow!
docBody.name: T. C.

ps.p: (Chelsea, Friday [4 July 1862])—

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [4 July]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Folkstone, 4 July 1862. MS: NLS 607.589D. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Oh my Dear! my Dear! How tiresome you are! Never can, at least, never will say a good, even down ‘yes’ till the last possible moment!

At all events you must come now! for Lord A has put off going to London till Monday, in the expectation of your coming. “A Sudden thought had struck him“ to go up on Sunday evening. He is knocked on the head by “sudden thoughts,“ every hour, now! My Lady too talks of “going up“ next week “for a concert“—and returning here—which latter clause of the Programme my Lord declares “out of the question.“ In short there is a general confused movement as of Bees about to skepp! and you must come tomorrow; if it were only that I may go handsomely away with you on Monday. That is “what ‘England expectsCoterie speech; see 33:13JWC to TC, 7 Aug. 1857. No closing quotation marks. of me I perceive. Happily it is also what I expect of myself!

You had best consult with Larkin about the hour. I was desired by him to leave my own house at twenty minutes before 1–for the Boat.The Thames steamer from Cadogan Pier to London Bridge Station, terminus of the South Eastern Railway; see 30:30JWC to TC, 14 Aug. 1855. I think the Train starts at 20 minutes after two—but I had long to wait, and am not sure—
All the rest will keep without detriment until you come.

Oh I should tell you one thing. They will ask whether you want your ticket for Folkestone Junction or Folkestone Pier—and you are to say Junction— It is nearest to the West Cliff Hotel— You will find plenty of Flies and Om[n]ibuses;Letter omitted. if no carriage is sent. and the distance is short—about a mile and half, I should think, or less—
If you were to start in the morning wouldn’t it be worthwhile?—to have a long afternoon on the shore— It is very pretty down there.
docBody.name: JWC

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 10 July. Addr: 147. Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: London, 10 July 1862. MS: NLS 553.242. Hitherto unpbd. Neuberg’s house no. was 140.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—Let us see you on Sunday Evg: my Brother is here;—and you, I suppose, are looking towards GaisGais, canton of Appenzell, 40 mi. (64 km.) E of Zurich, NE Switzerland, famous for its goat’s milk. Neuberg stayed there, summer 1861, attempting to improve his health (see 37:214TC to JN, 17 Aug. 1861); he tried again in Bavaria in Aug.; see TC to JAC, 6 Aug. again?

I have got the Saxn-Swiss Book-Title;The Museum of Practical Geology did not have W. L. Götzinger, Schandau und seine Umgebungen (see TC to JN, 18 June, and TC to JN, 26 and 27 June); Erasmus Darwin wrote to Charles Darwin, 1 July, asking for a letter of introduction for TC to the Geological Society at Somerset House, then wrote again, 2 July: “If you have not already written me the letter, never mind, as the obliging sub Lib of the Museum went to the Geolog: & did the necessary. / It is really wondeful [sic] the trouble Carlyle takes for such a minute point— I have had 4 or 5 letters & he has probably written half a dozen besides“ (The Correspondence of Charles Darwin [Cambridge, 1997] 10:290). glory to Heaven!— — The Queries
on the other side of this paper-snip are quite otherwise importt to me. Pray try yr best as a farewell service! We have been in Folkestone; I for 48 hours, and 2 sea-dips only.
docBody.name: T. C.

ps.p: Somewhere in Preuss (big Book)Johann D. E. Preuss, Friedrich der Grosse, eine Lebensgeschichte, 5 vols. (Berlin, 1832–34). it is stated How many millions of national populatn (Austrn, French Russian &c) were engaged agt Frh in the 7 Years War*:—and either there or elsewhere, I suppose, the following other particrs might be ascertained. Wd be very welcome to me at this moment.
1“°. Exact cipher of Frh’s own Populatn in 1757 or ’6.

2“°. Of his revenue.— 3°. Of the Schatz [wealth]TC wrote in bk. 18: “Friedrich’s own Dominions at this time [1757] contain about Five Millions of Population; of Revenue somewhat less than Two Millions sterling. … His Schatz … is, I doubt not, well filled,—express amount not mentioned.“ The estimation of the populations of his enemies was “above 100 millions,“ with 430,000 armed soldiers, while Frederick had 150,000. TC cited his sources as Stenzel, Leopold von Ranke, and Preuss, but complained: “[S]ubstantially true, I doubt not; but little or nothing of it so definite and conclusively distinct as it ought, in all items, to have been by this time,—had poor Dryasdust known what he was doing“ (Frederick, Works 17:105). Dr. Jonas Dryasdust, Sir Walter Scott’s fictitious pedant, frequently used by TC as a representative pedantic historian.

*Their revenues too if one cd approximate to them at all?Charlotte Cushman was visiting London; she and JWC had an outing together, 10 July, and she wrote to JWC, 12 July: “How happy I was with you on Thursday. Did you feel the cold I did … I did not reach my door until past 10 o’clock so cold & shivering! I hope you escaped. It was very dear walking with you, & dearer listening to you. If I come in an open Carriage will you drive with us on Monday afternoon? that will be nicer for all will it not? Send me one word to reach me on Monday morning at 9. Cunningham Place—St Johns Wood (where I shall rest my bones for the next three weeks) to say Yes!”

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady L[LLO], 21 Aug. [July]. MS: NLS Acc. 11476. Hitherto unpbd. JWC misdated Aug.; this is the “refusal“ letter referred to in JWC to MR, 30 July.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY LOTHIAN

docBody.p:
“Tiresome“!! dear Madam! I think, that in tolerant kindness you are only “a little lower than the Angels“!Cf. Heb. 2:7.— My Husband was quite touched by your
letter of yesterday; and recognised “the patient courtesy of that Lady“ with an emphasis which made even me (who know him) anticipate a new decision.

How not to hope he would go, after all; when I saw him, in the midst of breakfast, plunge into an investigation of Blickling,Blickling Hall, 15 mi. (24 km.) N of Norwich, one of the many homes of Lord and Lady Lothian; probably originally 14th cent. substantially rebuilt early 17th cent.; Lord and Lady Lothian were making further improvements. as intently as if it had been a Prussian Battlefield! upsetting cups and cream-jug with Walkers English Atlas, Cappers Topographical Dictionary, the last new Railway Map, and last Bradshaw?John and Charles Walker, British Atlas comprising separate maps of every county in England, first pbd . 1837 with several further edns. to 1862; Benjamin Pitts Capper, A Topographical Dictionary of the United Kingdom, first pbd. 1808 with several further edns. to 1829; there were various railway maps, including Stanford’s Railway and Road Map of England and Wales (1861), Cruchley’s Travelling Railway Map of England and Wales [1859], Cruchley’s Railway and Station Map of England and Wales [1860], and Bradshaw’s Railway Map of Great Britain and Ireland (1860); Bradshaw’s Monthly General Railway and Steam Navigation Guide.— What use of ascertaining, to a nicety, the distance from London to Norwich by railway, “and the distance as the crow flies“(!); and how far Norwich is from AylshamThe distance by rail from London to Norwich: about 120 mi. (193 km.) or, as the crow flies, about 100 mi. (161 km.); Aylsham, the nearest town to Blickling Hall: 14 mi. (22.5 km.) N of Norwich. and how situated towards it; and the time, to a minute, that it takes to go from here to Norwich by the Train,The train journey from London to Norwich took 3 hrs. 45 mins. &c; unless with a view to going there?—

But, when he had accumulated all the information accessible, he retired to his work, declining to answer “for the present“; and alas! the work is going ill just now! and in the evening, he told me, not for the first or hundred and first time, that he was “an unfortunate wretch, chased by The Furies (!); with no human life permitted him to lead!” If he could travel about like other people, he said, “visiting and amusing himself, with impunity; Blickling, where so courteous and cordial a welcome was offered him, would be the place of all others, after the Grange, that he would choose to go to! but—alas! but—“ in short it was to remain as it had been settled.— Pity and forgive him! for he really is chased by something! and one may call it “The Furies,“ without being far wrong; only a little more metaphorical than is customary in modern times!
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, 30 July. Addr: Holmehill / Thornhill / Dumfries. PM: London, 31 July 1862. MS: NLS 607.589E. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:102–5 inc., misdated 20 July. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:466–67; Hansons, NE 500.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: When you wrote last you were going somewhere—to see your cousinUnidentified. I think Is that visit paid? and what other visits have you to pay?—and how are you? I fear but poorly from your late letters! but are you well enough to feel any pleasure in— —in—in seeing me if I should come!!

Look here! I am not sure about it! But Mr C said something this morning that I am determined to view as permission for me, to go away by myself—where I please—and when I please for a very little while.

We had got into words about an invitation to the Marquis of Lothian’s in Norfolk. I had written a refusal, by his Mr C’s desire, and Lady Lothian had written to me a second letter, holding out as inducements for altering his mind, that there was a wonderfully fine Library at Blickling Park,Blickling Hall library, famous for its large, valuable collection of books, housed in the Long Gallery, was collected by Sir Richard Ellys (1682–1742; ODNB), 3rd bart., book collector, of Nocton, Lincolnshire. and that Lord Lothian’s health prevented company“ and Mr C tempted—a little—by the Library, and the no-company, had suggested I might write, that if the weather got unbearable—! and if he got to a place in his work where he could gather up some papers and take them with him—! and IF—if—if ever so many things he might perhaps—that is we might ‘perhaps’—come “by and by“!!!— I had said “by no means“— “I have written a refusal, by your desire; I shall gladly now write an acceptance by your desire—but neither yes nor no—or yes and no both in one—I cant and won’t write!—you must do that sort of thing yourself!— And then he told me “since I was so impatient about it“ I had better go by myself— To which I answered that it wouldn’t be there that I would go by myself; nor to the Trevelyans, nor the Davenport Bromleys,Sir Walter and Lady Paulina Trevelyan lived at Wallington Hall, Northumberland; Rev. Walter Davenport Bromley and his da. Caroline lived at Wootton Hall, Staffordshire. but—to Scotland—to Mrs Russell— “Then go to Mrs Russell—pack yourself up and be off as soon as you like“—. Now it wasnt a very gracious permission

Still it was a permission—at least I choose to regard it as such! and if I had been quite sure how you were situated; whether you were at home, without other visitor, well enough to be bothered with me, &c &c—I should have said on the spot—“thanks!—I will go then on such a day!”—

I know to my sorrow that if I should be long absent things would go to sixes and sevens and I should find mischievous habits acquired in the kitchen department which it would take months to reform—if ever—

But my week at Folkestone with the Ashburtons passed off with impunity —and theirTC wrote “the Servts’s“ above in blue pencil. moralities might surely hold out for a fortnight or so—which would give plenty of time to see you and look about on the dear old places and go round by Edinr for a kiss of old BettyBetty Braid.—
You see how it is however—for I have told you exactly what passed—and you see it is not a very settled question.

Without further speech with Mr C; I cant just say “I am coming—if you will have me“!—but, if you say you will have me—can have me soon—without inconvenience,—then I will myself open the further speech, and ascertain if he means to stand to his word—and look favourably on my going for a week or two—

Pray forgive me coming to you year after year with these indecisions! Next to being undecided oneself the greatest misery is to be mixed up with undecided people— I myself know always mighty well what I want—and buts and ifs and possiblys are not words in my natural vocabulary—for all so often as I am obliged to use them!— If I plague you with my uncertainties believe me I plague myself quite as much or more!—

So Mrs Pott has another Son!JWC’s cousin Janet Pott’s son Gideon, b. 21 July; she already had four sons. what a woman for War-times! She wrote me a pleasant letter just before her confinement—which confirms the notion I had when she was last here—that her nice honest HusbandGideon Pott. is taking the nonsense out of her— I will see if I can find the letter and send it— Burn it— Love to the D
docBody.name: J Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [2 Aug.]. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries. PM: London, 2 Aug. 1862. MS: NLS 607.590. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:105–8 inc. Quot: Bliss, JWC 294–95.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
Your letter of this morning had the same effect on my heart, that a glass of port wine, administerd in my babyhood, was recorded to have had on a less
dignified organ! “Port wine“ (I was said to have said to my Mother with the suddenness of Balaams AssCf. Num. 22:21–33.) “maks Belly aa cozzy“!One of JWC’s childhood phrases; see 10:157JWC to TC, 30 Aug. 1838, and Reminiscences 71 and 153.

So indeed did your cordial letter mak Heart aa cozzy!—on the stren[g]th of the cozziness, I said right out to Mr C sitting opposite; “How long had you to wait at Carlisle for the train that put you down at the Gill at 7 in the morning?“— No opening could have been better! He was taken quite by surprise, and before he had time to consider my going as a question, he found himself engaged in considerations of the best way to go! after that, he couldnt well go back upon his implied assent.“Alas! how little did I ever know of these secret wishes and necessities—now or ever!” (TC’s note in LM 3:106). The only “demurrer“ he could put in with a good grace, was to ask “what did I mean to do with my foot?“— I meant it to get well, I said; in a few days! Of course I shouldnt think of going from home on one leg! This related to a bruised, or sprained, or some way bedevilled foot that I came by, the very day I had written to you!—as if—I almost felt—with a shudder—at the time—it was the monition of Providence that I should go no such journey!

I was returning from Islington, where I had been, to ask after the lamed foot (!) of the little Lady who was my honorary Nurse last winter.“Mrs. Dilberoglue (?)“ (TC’s note in LM 3:106). Geraldine Jewsbury wrote to Walter Mantell, 20 July: “I saw the Dils a fortnight ago—Mrs Dil had sprained her foot & was a prisoner on the sofa.“ The Islington Omnibus put me down within some eighth part of a mile of my own house. I had one rather dark street to pass thro first (taking the shortest way) and it was near eleven o’clock at night. I didn’t care for being alone so late; but I didnt want to be seen by any of the low people of that street, alone—so I stepped off the pavement to avoid passing close to a small group standing talking at a door— When I had cleared these only people to be seen in the whole street I was stepping back on to the pavement, when the curb stone being higher than I noticed in the shadow, I struck the side of my right foot violently against it—and was tripped over—and fell smack down, full length, on the pavement!“I remember, and may well“ (TC’s note in LM 3:107). Considering how easily I have broken my ribs, it is wonderful that the fall did me no harm! I scrambled up directly but the foot I had struck on the curb stone, before falling, was dreadfully sore—and it was made worse, you may believe, by having to use it after a sort, to get myself home. How I got home at all, even in holding on to walls and railings, I cant think But once at home, on a chair, I couldnt touch the ground with it on any account!— Mr C had to carry me to bed, at the imminent risk of knocking my head off against the lintels! so I wouldnt be carried by him any more; my head
being of more consequence to me than my foot— It was dreadfully swelled for a couple of days. but today, tho’ I still cannot get a shoe on, or walk, it is so much better, that I am sure it will be all right presently.
In a few days I hope to be able to write that I am roadworthy. and I will only wait for that.
It is a most provoking little accident; for delays are so dangerous. I should have wished, after my experiences of late summers, to go to you at once, before any “pigs“ have time to “run thro“!

I would go to the Chambers’sUnidentified further. to call for Mrs VeichMary Russell’s friend Agnes Veitch.—but for the shoelessness and hopping process— But I hope she will call for me. Tho’ to believe Miss Chambers (the only one I have seen) we shouldn’t suit each other— I remember when I called at their house, and spoke of Mrs Veich this girl said; “Mrs Carlyle I have known Mrs Veich a long time—and you I have only seen for five minutes; but I am confident that two people more unlike, and more certain to get on ill together don’t exist!”— “Yet the same Lady is the particular friend of us both“ I said. “No matter for that!” said the brisk young Lady.
And now I needn’t be saying more— But that god grant nothing may prevent our meeting this time!— Love to the Doctor
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-TE, 4 Aug. Pbd: Froude, Carlyle 4:252–53 inc; Wilson 5:468–69 inc. The ellipses are in Froude.
div3.head: TC TO THOMAS ERSKINE

docBody.p:
Dear Mr. Erskine,—Here is a very bright little book of Ruskin’s, which, if you have not already made acquaintance with it, is extremely well worth reading. Two years ago, when the Essays came out in the fashionable magazines, there rose a shriek of anathema from all newspaper and publishing persons.Unto This Last; see TC to JRJRU, 30 June; for the hostility to Ruskin’s essays, see also 37:29TC to JRU, 29 Oct. 1860, and TC to JAF, 14 April. But I am happy to say that the subject is to be taken up again and heartily gone into by the valiant Ruskin, who, I hope, will reduce it to a dog’s likeness—its real physiognomy for a long time past to the unenchanted eye, and peremptorily bid it prepare to quit this afflicted earth, as R. has done to several things before now. He seems to me to have the best talent for preaching of all men now alive.Erskine replied, 7 Aug.: “I am thankful for any unveiling of the so-called science of political economy, according to which, avowed selfishness is the Rule of the World. It is indeed most important preaching. … The little book is valuable on its own account, and coming from you, it is doubly so.“ He has entirely blown up the world that used to call itself of ‘Art,’
and left it in an impossible posture, uncertain whether on its feet at all or on its head, and conscious that there will be no continuing on the bygone terms. If he could do as much for Political Economy (as I hope), it would be the greatest benefit achieved by preaching for generations past; the chasing off of one of the brutallest nightmares that ever sate on the bosom of slumbrous mankind, kept the soul of them squeezed down into an invisible state, as if they had no soul, but only a belly and a beaver faculty in these last sad ages, and were about arriving we know where in consequence. I have read nothing that pleased me better for many a year than these new Ruskiniana.

I am sitting here in the open air under an awning with documentary materials by me in a butler’s tray, desk, &c. for writing, being burnt out of my garret at last by the heat of the sun.For TC under his awning in 1857, see 32:176TC to JWC, 9 July 1857. I hope by this time twelvemonth I may be at LinlathenErskine’s home near Dundee. again; at least I do greatly wish it, if the hope be too presumptuous. There is a long stiff hill to get over first, but this is now really the last; fifth and final volume actually in hand, and surely, with such health as I still have, it may be possible. I must stand to it or do worse… London has not been so noisy and ugly for ten years, but this too is endingReferring to the current International Exhibition and the 1852 Great Exhibition. … Adieu, dear friend!
docBody.name: T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 6 Aug. MS: NLS 525.93. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:251; Wilson, Carlyle 5:464.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Since that morning when you whisked away from me again (wd you had staid a while longer!) you have written me three little Notes, whh were very welcome and kind in my solitude; and I have been, day after day, of mind to write in answer; but cd never manage it,—for the reasons you know.Presumably the pressure of his work on Frederick.

The hot weather has, as you supposed, driven me out, and got the awning up,—under whh I now sit (3 p.m.) tho’ there has been rain today. Very busy, sadly tumbled abt from post to pillar; and in general rather more feckless than when you saw me suffictly so. It is not the heat only; it is, still more, I take it, the new vegetables; the want of food that my capricious inner-man can make
away with at all. An almost complete strike of work on the part of said inner man; till, abt Saturday last, we got to a crisis; three considerably sleepless nights &c, till today I hope it is rather over again. Next time I must apply to blue-pill; the poor liver, I suppose, is quite awry: a bad enemy;John A. Carlyle replied, 7 Aug.: “[W]hat you need above all things is some period of rest from labour just now. Most of the derangements you mention arise from nothing but overwork affecting the whole nervous system.“ tho happily my worst, and almost only great one, at prest.

Volme Fourth is like to be as dour as any of the others: no end of haggling, fash and impediment; so difficult exceedingly (and never yet tried at all) to make the Seven-Years War march abreast (the many-columned marching Entity), and shew itself for what it was, in any measure! Only one consolatn there is: it is perhaps better worth doing than some of the other foul tasks I have had. At times I am quite downcast on my lonesome long interminable journey thro’ the not Mount-Horeb Wilderness,The desert around Mt. Horeb through which Moses and the Israelites traveled after their flight from Egypt; see Exod. but the beggarly “Creca-Moss“ mossMoorland about 4 mi. (6.5 km.) NE of Annan; “moss“ repeated. one:—then at other times, I pick up heart; and think with myself: “Creca, and the Infinite of barren brambly moor is under Heaven too,—what if thou couldst shew the blockhead populations that withal!God gave Moses the Ten Commandments on Mt. Horeb (see Deut. 4:10); TC hoped that his own humble work might give the people something of benefit. And get honourably out of this heartbreaking affair,—pitied by the Eternal Powers!”— If I can hold out another year—surely before this time twelvemont[h]Letter omitted. we shall have done.

There is no visible chance of my getting to the Country. Jane is for Nithsdale &c; whh I am very glad of, hoping it may strengthen the poor weak soul agt the Winter that is coming on. She lamed herself, the other night; hastening home from some Brompton Omnibus, down that dark little Street (Arthur-Street,Now Dovehouse St., N of Cheyne Row. I think), she had the ill luck to hit her foot agt the Curb-stone (outside part and little toe); fell, and came hirpling home in great trouble; had fallen &c, tho’ her wrists saved her, and soon mended. The foot, too, is now rapidly mending: after that, she is for off at once. Goes by the train you went by; Larkin busy inquiring. Cannot understand Js—Aitken’s “return-ticket“;Their nephew James Aitken, presumably going home to Dumfries on holiday. The Times advertised during July and Aug.: “London and North-West Railway. Tourists’ Tickets, for One Month are issued at the Euston Station, and other principal stations for Scotland.“ gives that up; learns that her Carlisle-Dumfs train does not stop at Cummertrees
(where she thot of staying with Mary), but does go on to Thornhill;John A. Carlyle replied, 7 Aug.: “I wish I had been at hand to give Jane instructions for her journey to Dumfriesshire. The 10 a.m. train is by far the best, as I found; & the corresponding train, which goes on to Dumfries & Thornhill from Carlisle without delay, stops at Ruthwell—only one mile farther from Gill than Cummertrees. … I would advise Jane … to choose either a monday or thursday 10 a.m. train for her journey.“ &c &c. She will probably be away abt a month; and I, hoffentlich [it is to be hoped], all the busier.

Neuberg is gone to the Molken-CurGoat’s milk diet; see TC to JN, 10 July. (in yr old Berchtesgaden neighbrhood somewhere),Berchtesgaden, health resort in Bavaria, 18 mi. (29 km.) S of Salzburg. John Carlyle had stayed in Ischl, a resort in Austria about 28 mi. (45 km.) ESE of Salzburg, in 1839; see 11:126TC to TSS, 9 June 1839.—uglier than ever; luck be with him! All people are away, or fast going, except that “International“ miscellany; whh also will have to go and make us rid of it. Courage!— — I attended you in thot that Sunday when you saw Scotsbrig again,John wrote to James Carlyle Jr., 23 July: “I … shall most likely go to Scotsbrig on the friday or saturday“ (MS: NLS Acc. 9086), but had presumably been delayed until Sun.,27 July. both the Jamies with you,—and alas some others wanting! I hope you continue to get some good there; and look peaceably back, tho’ pensively, in the poor ever-loved native spot. My kindest brotherly regards to Jamie. Jean tells me Jenny is not looking well; hurt by some bad bedroom; poor little Jenny.Their niece Jenny Carlyle; John replied, 7 Aug.: “Whenever I get to Scotsbrig I set about contriving remedies for Jenny’s room. It is now all stoothed & papered, a good large tent bed has been put into it, instead of the close wooden one, & the upper sash of the window is hung so as to admit fresh air in small or large quantities. The bed is as big as yours, & like it curtained all round. Due ventilation will now be possible & the papering will keep the room dry. The old arrangement had gone on too long & made poor Jenny quite unwell. I hope she will speedily recover: the worst symptom was vomiting after breakfast, evidently owing to bad air during the night.“ Take care of her, the good child.— If you go Cressfield agn, recomend me cordially to Miss Maxwell (now Miss Little, alas);TC omitted “to.“ Cressfield House, Ecclefechan, built by TC’s father, home of the Ecclefechan doctor, William Little (1760–1847), and family; his das. Mary (1796–1857) and Maxwell (b. 1799) continued to live there (see 34:77TC to JWC, 28 July 1858); after Mary’s death, Maxwell was “Miss Little.“ you may say with truth that I remember her vividly and best as a blooming little Bairn, now that such a change has come over us all. Adieu, dear Brother. My love to Scotsbrig thro’out.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [6 Aug.]. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries. PM: London, [6] Aug. 1862; Thornhill, 7 Aug. 1862. MS: NLS 607.591A. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: My foot has been getting steadily tho’ slowly better. Yesterday I got on a shoe—a large one—and today I walked some quarter of a mile, with only a moderate limp. So at this rate of progress I guess I shall be quite road-worthy by next week— —the first day of it that is, first available day—Monday. The train leaves Euston Square at ten, that I shall come by—and after only twenty minutes waiting at Carlisle I get on to Thornhill fifty minutes after 7 at night.

My first idea was to cut off a bit of the long journey at the end, and stay all night at the Gill—as I could get set down at Ruthwell, close by the Gill— But on reflection, I have decided to push on the whole road however tired. I shall get rested beside you, better than at Mary’sMary Austin, at The Gill. where Mrs Aitken might “feel it her duty“ to come and meet me!Jean Aitken, from Dumfries. and I should be expected to be amiable and make myself agreeable—which you, dear considerate Soul will dispense me from the first night!
I can see Mary on the road home—or run down and see her for a day, without luggage.

I got a “considerable of a fright“ a day or two after I had written to you that I would come! Mr C came down one morning and said that he found on looking at the map, the Marquis of Lothian’s placeBlickling Hall; see JWC to MR, 30 July. was fifty miles nearer London than he had thought— It would not be difficult for us to go—“oh well, I said, do you go“— “But it would be best for me to go too, he said, and then, “if I was still bent on Thornhill I could push on there afterwards“— “No, I said—I had best go to Thornhill first—and then if you like I will push on to Norfolk afterwards“—so the suddenly revived question was let go to sleep again—

I went out in a cab this morning to buy myself a pair of larger shoes. and the Chamberses and Mrs Veitch came just in the hour I was absent— How provoking! I will try to go to her tomorrow but of course she will be out next! I neednt be writing long and broad with the prospect of seeing you on Monday evening! I can hardly believe it! Shall not believe that I am really to get—till I am there!
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [8 Aug.]. Addr: The Gill Annan. Longhand copy: NLS Acc. 7864. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.p: If you will be on the knowe when the London train passes,The Gill was less than 1 mi. (1.5 km.) from the railway line. about or soon after seven, on Monday evening; you will, please God,—[see]Word omitted. the train!—with a moderate certainty of my being in it. And I will see you—even at that distance—standing out clear, the little figure of you, against the horizon. My first intention was [to]Word omitted. offer to stop and sleep at the Gill, and give you “the first rush o’ me“!Cf. “ye first rush o’ ye tea“; coterie speech; see 11:78JWC to MAC, 13 April 1839. But on considering, like the Pipers Cow,See 7:269TC to JAC, 15 Aug. 1834, and 36:174TC to LS, 12 Aug. 1860. and turning over all the outs and ins of the matter; Mr C and I both agreed, “to push on to the far end,“ would be the wisest thing to do; and arrange, from Thornhill, a meeting with you under less exhausted circumstances, than I shall find myself in, on Monday night!

It is all my own force of character that has brought this journey to a bearing. I am only coming for a fortnight or so; but I am coming, and mean to give you before I return the heartiest kiss, you have had “this seven years“ (as Mr C would say). God bless you and all your belongings.
I am hurried.
docBody.name: Jane W. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, [11 Aug.]. Addr: Dr Russell’s / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 11 Aug. 1862. MS: NLS 616.558. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:250. TC wrote on the reverse of Lady Ashburton’s letter, 9 Aug.; see TC to LOA, 31 Aug.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Good morning, Dearest; I hope and pray to Heaven you will have arrived safe, and got some sleep when this comes!—
I am “a desultory widow“Coterie speech; source untraced; see 16:182JWC to JW, 27 May 1834. railly,TC presumably spelled thus to emphasize the Scots pronunciation.—but that avails not.

The thing at present is, I positively prohibit yr touching one penny of yr poor Allowance for such expences;—and I positively order that there be no pinching abt money at all at all! Fie, fie!— Here is a Draft“11 Augt 1862 / to Jane (just gone to Thornhill!) / £15..0..0“ (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). whh Dr Rl as BankerDr. James Russell, listed as banker and farmer in the 1861 census. will pay when you ask,—and whh nobody can steal (“two strokes“ you see) till you do!— Adieu; you wd not have me spend my poor sleep-time
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-[Lady A] [LLA] , 12 Aug. [1862]. MS: Trevelyan Papers WCT 331.32, Newcastle Univ. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
JWC
TO [LADY ASHBURTON]

docBody.p:
Almost the last “burst of Eloquence” I heard from C before taking flight, “in wera Desperation”; (as Sam Weller said; the poor in London “rushed out to eat oysters”!)Coterie speech; see 11:168 JWC to TC, 18 Aug. 1839
, and 34:181 JWC to CSO, 10 Sept. 1858
; cf. Dickens, The Pickwick Papers (1837)chap. 23. was in reprobation of my having forgot to give you his message “about the tobacco.” that it was “the most exquisitely ethereal tobacco & &—but of such a heavenly mildness, as fitted it for being smoked only in particular rare states of mind! &c &c”—and he had laid it by to meet special contingencies”!— A smoker, I suppose, would know what that means in plain English! I don’t pretend to! For the rest; I told him; my voluntary confession of having forgotten should have saved me a scolding. As one never scolds, or professes to never scold the servant who breaks one’s china provided she tells! And I further told him, that I meant to write immediately on my arrival here, and could give the message then. So now it is given!

I was getting worried out of my remaining senses in London, and took a sudden resolution to be off on Monday! Not considering that the following day would be the 12 of August,The date for the beginning of the grouse-shooting season. and that I should have to travel with a frightful conglomeration of Sports men and pointer-dogs, & squeezed up amongst gun boxes & &c &c! in result of which, the train was precisely one hour longer on the road than it ought to have been. But in spite of all; the fatigue of a days travelling was rest, in comparison with the two previous days of talk-talk-talking, with Scotch CousinsPresumably her first cousin Alexander Welsh and his wife, Sophy, from Liverpool; see TC to JAC, 17 Aug.
and acquaintances “come up to the
Exhibition”!— My absence will deliver Mr C from these visitations, and so make up for any loss he may feel in it! And Maria Chamberlayne declared she could “Do for Master perfectly! and he should be kept quite happy”! It will be the first time in his life, if he is!

I am not to be long away. And shall go back refreshed for the Battle of Life; like one of the old Giants after coming in contact with his Mother Earth!In the Greek myth, Antaeus gained his strength from keeping in contact with his mother, the Earth. You may form some notion of the gentle disposition of the Lady I am staying with, from this little fact— She gave up her own room to me, without letting me know it was hers; because from all the visitors Bedrooms one can see, half a mile off, the white houseTempland; for T. R. Way’s lithograph from a late 19th-cent. photograph by John Patrick, see opp. above ; for Templand in 2008, see also opp.. where my Mother lived after my Marriage, and where she died!—

figure.p: Templand, lithograph by T. R. Way
A. Carlyle, ed., New Letters and Memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle (1903)
Templand in 2008

docBody.p:
It is a lovely place and the people are true, good people and my Mother is still adored over the whole district! Ten days of such existence will sooth my worn nerves, like boiling a cracked china basin in sweet milk!Cf. 30:204
JWC’S Journal, 26 Oct. 1855
.

I wont begin on another small sheet with this steel pen the only attainable sort— I not only cant write but cant spell with it!Cf. coterie speech; see 35:199 JWC to HL, 13 Sept. 1859
. It is like writing with a darning needle! But I feel myself to such extent your property, that I ought to report myself in a new place.
docBody.name: JWC

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [12 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Gt Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 12 Aug. 1862. MS: NLS 607.591B. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:249–52 inc; Bliss, JWC 295–97 inc. Quot: Hansons NE 500; Fielding and Sorensen 275–76.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.dateline: Holme Hill / Thornhill Tuesday morning [12 August 1862]
docBody.p:
There Dear! You would get a letter “next morning“ after all! From here it would have been impossible! But I told JaneJean Aitken. to rush home and write to you; and she was sure to do it! She was to tell you that I had got to Dumfries, at least, without a turned feather! really not physically tired the least in the world!Coterie speech. only worried morally with the confusion of the business at Carlisle!JWC changed trains at Carlisle, 8 mi. (13 km.) S of the border, terminus in England of the Caledonian, Glasgow, and South-Western Railways.
and with the longest Roman nose I had ever seen in this world, and a pair of cruel, close-together eyes over it, which fronted me from Rugby Town in Warwickshire, 83 mi. (133 km.) NW of London. to Carlisle and magnetised me antipathetically!

It was very cheering to see the face of Mary, looking in thro’ the glass window, dimmed with human breath, at Ruthwell! (I had been forced into the middle seat, and the wretches would keep both windows shut within an inch at the tops, so I hadnt been able to wave my pocket handkerchief opposite the Gill as I had meant to! and wasn’t sure whether there was a figure on the knowe or not!) It was such an old wrinkled face!, and was so full of disappointment for the moment! She had not recognised me under the spicy little black hat and white feather! But I flew at the window, and without even a “pardon me“ dashed it down! and Mary clambered up like a cat; and we kissed, with enthusiasm, regardless of consequences! It was only a minute’s interview; but if short, it was sweet! and I went on the cheerier for it; tho aware I couldnt reach Thornhill till nine—exactly an hour after time!—“owing to the 12th of August“ being next day! At Dumfries I found Jane and her Husband, and eldest Daughter!Anne Aitken. and the Carriage being then cleared of all but myself, and the time longer, we had plenty of talk; and I took tea with them!!— It was the most practically kind thing I ever saw Jane do! She had actually brought a little jar of “warm tea—at least it had been warm when they left home an hour before“! and a tumbler to drink it from, and some sweet biscuits which I pretended to eat, but stowed slyly into my bag— And then she would be in time to write to you; so “altogether“Coterie speech; see 16:262JWC to TC, 11 July 1843. “it was a good joy“!— (And this is such a bad steel pen— Oh Dear!) I was apparently the only soul in the train at Thornhill!—the whole apparatus stopping there!— So Dr Russell had no trouble in finding me and my box—which by the way came by a horrid scratch on the top, and I wish now I had made a cover for it! It was better it was so dark, that I couldnt see anything, till I was put down at Holme Hill door, and received in the arms of Mrs Russell! What a different welcome from the fashionable welcomes!

It is a lovely place and House they have made of old Holme Hill!This was JWC’s first visit to the Russells since they had moved to Holmhill in 1859; see 35:244–45JWC to MR, 26 Oct. 1859; for a photograph of Holmhill, see 37:110JWC to LLA, 1 Feb. 1861.— The rooms are none of them very large but there is a good and beautiffully [sic] done up Dining Room and Drawing Room and two handsome Bedrooms with dressing rooms, and a kitchen, and larder and store room, and “the usual trimmings“ all on the ground floor!! Above, there are plenty of bedrooms—one fine one— But Mrs Russell put me into the ground floor room; and I know why—because the up stairs windows must, some of them, look towards
Templand, Oh how kind they are, and I feel that kindness, partly out of love for my Mother and Aunt Jeanie,Jeanie Welsh, JWC’s maternal aunt; see 2:368JBW to TC, 6 June 1823. so much more keenly than kindness I derive from Lion-worship—even tho’ the Lion be you my Dear!— (Good Heaven one might as well write with a scewer as this pen!)

I had a famous tea, and went to a most comfortable Bed in deepest privacy — But, of course, tho’ feeling no tiredness, I couldn’t go to sleep with my mind in such a tumult, and the idea of Templand half a mile off!— But between four and five I at last fell into what you call a doze (is it s or z?) and to day I am “better than I deserve“!Coterie speech; see 24:319JWC to MR, 31 Dec. 1849. But it is pouring rain—! so I must rest at home— Best thing I could do perhaps in any case,

At Carlisle, when I was rushing madly after my Box, which couldnt be found; but finally was perceived to have “cam haim with its tail behind it,““Simon Brodie Had a Cow,“ Scots nursery rhyme; see 26:174JWC to TC, 14 Sept. 1851. into the Thornhill van! I noticed a dark Gentleman turn in passing, and look after me—and then I saw him, with the tail of my eye, trying to look at my face; which, fancying the proceeding some delusion, (arising out of the spicy little hat) on the Gentleman’s part; I turned resolutely away. When a voice said at my back; “surely it is Mrs Carlyle that I see“! I wheeled round and found the dark gentlemans face “quite familiar to me,“ but couldnt for my life identify him till he named himself, “Huxley“!Thomas Henry Huxley (1825–95; ODNB), biologist, naturalist, and educational reformer; recently appointed to the Royal Commission on Fisheries, he made frequent trips to Scotland to study fish catching methods.— He was going to Edinr, and we did a good deal of Portmanteau hunting together, amidst distracted Pointer-dogs and more distracted Sportsmen!— I never saw such a lively representation of ‘Confusion worse confounded.’See Milton, Paradise Lost 2:996. Every Passenger had lost his luggage!, and the Porters their senses!, and the Dogs barked and yelled! and the gentlemen swore! and the women implored!
Since I began the last page your letter has come. Oh thanks! but— Dont you see?—, I shan’t dare go away again if you take the expense of it! Perhaps you mean that!—,“Wretch“ and “Devil“ as I am!

I have not read the Ladys letterTC’s letter was written on the reverse of Lady Ashburton to TC, 9 Aug. yet—it takes time to decipher but I am very glad of your few lines and the fact of there being a letter from you already has raised you to the stars in Mrs Russells opinion. “As attentive a Husband as Mine“ (she says)
Now to Father Son and “Tolly Gohast““Holy ghost“; coterie speech; cf. 31:88. JWC
Recollect about my letters—
Oh please to forward the two punchs together when the next comes to Mr George BraidBetty Braid’s son, George, to whom the Carlyles regularly sent copies of Punch. / Stenhouse / Greenend / Edinburgh

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, 13 Aug. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: London, 14 Aug. 1862. MS: NLS 607.591C. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:108–9 inc. Quot: Hansons NE 500.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Oh my Dear! I wish they hadn’t commenced that carpet-lifting, and chimney-sweeping process so immediately, but left you time to recover my loss (if any) in the usual “peace and quietness“!— That chimney in my bed-room had to be swept, however, before winter came; and no time so good as when I was on my travels.

You don’t complain; but your few lines this morning make the impression on me of having been written under “a dark brow[n] Shadd“!Letter omitted; coterie speech; see 16:264JWC to TC, 12 July 1843. I told Maria if she observed you to be mismanaging yourself, and going off your—sleep, and all that sort of—thing; to tell me, and I should be back like a returned Sky-Rocket!

For myself, I am allright today. I was in bed before eleven struck, with a stiff little tumbler of whisky toddy in my head; and I went to sleep at once, and slept on, with only some half dozen awakings, till the maidProbably Jannet McKinnlee (b. ca. 1838). brought in my hot water at eight o’clock!

My foot, as well as my “interior,“ is benefited by the good night. It was too lame for anything yesterday! But there was no temptation to use it much yesterday; it rained without intermission. Today is very cloudy, but not wet as yet; and we are going for a drive in the close carriage—

Dr Russell has both a close and an open carriage, the lucky Man! Indeed he has as pretty and well equipped a place here, as any reasonable creature could desire. But Mrs Russell has never ceased to regret the tumble-down old House in Thornhill!!! where “there was always some thing going on“!! “Looking out on the trees and the river here makes her so melancholy, she says, that she feels sometimes as if she should lose her senses! The wished-for, as usual, come to[o] late! ease with dignityCf. Cicero, Oratore pro Publio Sextio 15.98. when the habits of a life time have made her incapable of enjoying it!

Edward Hoggan’s WifeEdward Hoggan (1793–1867), Writer to the Signet; see 14:178TC to JWC, 3 May 1842, and 25:183TC to JWC, 30 Aug. 1850. He had formed an “illicit connexion“ with Elizabeth, b. Craigie (1813–75), in Edinburgh in 1831; they had two children, and he wrote her several letters stating his intention to provide for her financially and that he would leave a declaration at his death so that she could claim a pension from the Writers to the Signet Widows Fund; he insisted that this must all be kept secret or he would face “utter ruin“ (Times, 23 April 1839). She petitioned the Court of Session in Scotland in 1834 to declare that this constituted a valid marriage, and won the case; Hoggan appealed against the decision, but in 1839 the House of Lords upheld the judgment of the Scottish Court of Session (Times, 30 April and 24 Aug. 1839). has taken up her abode with him and his Sisters at
Bellevue!Hoggan lived at Bellevue, Keir, nr. Thornhill, with his sisters Mary (1796–1875; see 34:243JWC to JPR, 23 Nov. 1858) and Charlotte (1792–1875), widow of Rev. William Gillespie (1776–1825). It seems he had been in the habit of going to stay with her for weeks together at Carlisle! and there is a son of some dozen years only!Possibly Henry Hoggan (b. ca. 1850). What a poor weak wretch of a man! It is expected Miss Mary Hoggan will leave the house; Charlotte (Mrs Gelespie), who has the temper of a Devil, rather enjoys the mischief.

Would you tell Maria to put a bit of paper round the little longshaped-paste-board box, in my little drawer next th[e] drawingroom, containing the two Ornamental hair-pins and send them to me by post—they are quite light! I want them to give away. Also if you were to put a couple of goosequill pens of your own making in beside the hair pins “it would be a great advantage!”Coterie speech; see 35:217JWC to TC, 26 Sept. 1859. I have written to Lady ASee JWC to [Lady A][LLA], 12 Aug. expressly about the tobacco.
Oh please do go to bed at a reasonable hour—and dont overwork yourself, and consider you are no longer a child!
docBody.name: JWC

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TW[TWO], 13 Aug. Pbd: Woolner 226. Quot: Wilson 5:467.
div3.head: JWC TO THOMAS WOOLNER

docBody.p:
A thousand thanks for having done for me so much more than you led me to hope! I shall be glad and thankful to possess even a plain photograph of Mrs. Twisleton; for either money or love or for the credit of Mr. Dickinson’s name!Dickinson Brothers, artists and photographers, 114 New Bond St.; see JWC to TC, [15 Aug.]. The long letter amounts to this, it seems to me, “if we had known
that the obscure looking Female who stalked quite promiscuouslyCoterie speech; see 10:72TC and JWC to JCA, 1 May 1838. into our shop had borne the not obscure title of Mrs. Thomas Carlyle, we would have treated her with less abruptness and hauteur!”— But on any terms as I have said, I shall gratefully receive the photograph which can be got nowhere else!

Go and see my unfortunate Husband who, like “the last rose of summer is left blooming alone“Thomas Moore, “’Tis the Last Rose of Summer,“ Irish Melodies (London and Dublin, 1808–34) vol. 5; JWC could presumably play it, as she asked for music for the song in 1825; see 3:254JBW to EA, 18 Jan. 1825. at Cheyne Row! And go often, if you please, till I come back! I cannot expand myself on paper, because of the pen! which is a steel one, and it is like writing with the point of a scewer! Tell me if anything happens to you while I am here—and believe me always,

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, [13 Aug.]. Addr: Dr Russell’s / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 13 Aug. 1862. MS: NLS 616.559. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Yr Letter to breakfast over:—many thanks to you and everybody. Write me that you have got one sleep; then I won’t push you, will give you some respite, hoping you will often volunteer.

“Land-of-gold“Unidentified. was in due waiting last night; kept me till 11 p.m.;—I did not at once fall asleep; & have made a bad day of it! Pooh—four o’clock striking! I was summoned to dinner some minutes ago: time now! Bless you, dearest.— T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, [14 Aug.]. MS: NLS 616.559. Hitherto unpbd. Dated the day after JWC to TC, 13 Aug.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
All right, my poor little Dear; and thanks to Heaven and to you. I meant to write; but have been bothered,—and below is “dinner“ standing. I sat up too late yesternight (totally alone, and wanted to make a bad day good; had got a
glorious gallop too, on Wimbledon Common):Wimbledon Common was approx. 1,140 acres (461 ha.) of heath and woodland, S of the Thames, about 5 mi. (8 km.) SW of Chelsea. I might have spilt any night, but did not; will not do the like again!—
Today (ever since midnight last) is considerable wet: I begin to be sadly afraid of yr weather at Thornhill. Use the close Carriage any way!

Fine reaping scenes occasionally yesterday; wheat not so bad;—must be
all in a swim today. Scott (less power to him) is coming with Russell & Another (enigmatic to me quite) “on Friday Evg.“Alexander J. Scott; possibly Arthur John Edward Russell (1825–92; see 33:73JWC to TC, 6 Sept. 1857), M.P. for Tavistock, 1857–85; George MacDonald (1824–1905; ODNB), Scottish poet and novelist, moved to Manchester mid-1850s, where he became friendly with Scott. Scott wrote, 12 Aug.: “I met the other day with Russell and George MacDonald, both of whom expressed a strong desire to see you, in which I heartily joined. It was agreed that I should make you aware of our intention, unless our visit would be inconvenient to you, of being with you on Friday evening about 8 o’clock.“ TC wrote at the top of Scott’s letter: “(Saw Scott this time; never agn).“ For C. L. Dodgson’s 1863 photograph of MacDonald, see 139above.

figure.p: George MacDonald, by C. L. Dodgson, 27 July 1863

p.hi: Courtesy of A. P. Watt Ltd on behalf of the Trustees of the C. L. Dodgson Estate and Princeton University Library

docBody.p: I will try to be tacit. Adieu dearest.— T.C.

ps.p: no end of Letters to you. Item Two Pens!JWC asked TC to make and send two goose quill pens; see JWC to TC, 13 Aug.—
I do lock up yr Letters: n.b.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JCA, [14 Aug.]. Addr: Assembly Street / Dumfries. PM: Dumfries, 14 Aug. 1862. MS: NLS 607.591D. Pbd. A. Carlyle, NLM 2:253–54. Quot: Hansons NE 500.
div3.head: JWC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: I have been meaning to “kill two Birds with one stone“—(an economy of Action which never does succeed with me!) Meaning to repeat my thanks; still lying quite warm at the heart of me, for your and James’s welcome to Dumfries—so hearty, and practically beneficent as it was! And at the same time to fix a time for seeing you “more in detail“ (as the DrJohn A. Carlyle. would say). But I must have still a few days, for arranging my further plans, which were best left in abeyance till I had looked about me here, and rested the sprained foot I brought with me from home.

Hitherto it has rained pretty constantly, and I have only once crossed the threshold,—for a short drive between showers yesterday— Today it is fair, as yet; and we are going to Keir.They visited the Hoggans at Bellevue and the Menzies at Keir Manse; see JWC to TC, [15 Aug.].

In a few days, I shall have subsided from the nervousness of finding myself here—at the foot of Templand Hill! with so many houses within sight, once occupied by people who belonged to me, or cared for me! and then I shall be up to forming plans. So far; I merely sit bewildered in presence of my own Past! How long I stay, will depend chiefly on the accounts I get from Cheyne Row. I am in hopes Lady Ashburton will persuade Mr C to go off with them to the Grange—where I could join him on my return. Whether I shall go back
the road I came, or round by Edinr,To visit Betty Braid, and her aunts Ann, Elizabeth, and Grace Welsh. will depend on answers to letters which I have not yet written!

In a few days, as I have said, I will “consider“ (like the Piper’s Cow) and then tell you whether you will next see me on the way home, or on the way to Edinr—or merely from here, to return here. However to see you and Mary being one of the greatest pleasures I promised myself in coming to this country, you are safe to have me plump down on you someday.
I will write again “whenever I see my way“ (to quote again from the Dr)—

It is the beautifulest House this a reasonable mortal could desire! But Mrs Russell cannot reconcile herself to it—is always regretting the tumble-down old rambling House in Thornhill where “Papa’s room“ is! “The room he died in“!Mary Russell’s father, Rev. Edward Dobbie, d. 1857. She is the dearest gentlest hearted woman! Ever affly yours / Jane Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [14 Aug.]. MS: NLS Acc. 7864. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:110–12.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.dateline: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries Thursday [14 August 1862]
docBody.p: Oh my little woman! how glad I was to recognise your face thro’ the glass of the carriage window, all dimmed with human breath! And how frightened I was, the train would move, while you were clambering up like a school-boy to kiss me! And how I grudged the long walk there and back for you,Ruthwell Station was about 2 mi. (3 km.) from The Gill. and the waiting! Still you did well to come! for it (your coming) quite brightened up my spirits for the last miles of my journey, which are apt to be mortally wearisome!—

I had meant to wave my handkerchief from the window when we passed The Gill—but I found no seat vacant except the middle one—and disagreeable women on each side of me closed the windows all but an inch, so to make any demonstration had been impossible! The more my gladness to catch sight of your very face! And Jane and her Husband and Daughter were waiting for me at Dumfries, having heard of my coming from Doctor Carlyle. So “the latter end of that woman (meaning me) was better than the beginning“!Cf. Eccles. 7:8.

Dr Russell was waiting for me,—had been waiting more than an hour, like every one else,—with his carriage, in which I was conveyed thro’ ways, happily for me, clothed in darkness, so that the first object I saw was Mrs Russell at the door of their new home.

It is a most beautiful house and place they have made of old Holme Hill! And I do not see Templand from the Windows, as I feared I should!— The trees have grown up so high!— The first night, I couldnt sleep a bit for agitation of mind—far more than fatigue of body! the next night I slept—last night again not! So today I feel rather ghastly!— Then it has rained pretty much without intermission! Yesterday we took a very short drive between showers—and that was the only time I have crossed the threshold! Besides the bad weather, I brought away with me a recently sprained foot which makes walking both painful and imprudent—

Under these circumstances I have not yet formed any plan for my further travels— But shall tell you in a few days whether I will pay you a little visit on the road home, or run down from here, and back again. I will certainly not let that brief meeting stand for all, unless you forbid me to come. But I have all along looked to being guided by circumstances in this journey. My stay to be determined by the accounts I get of Mr C from himself, and, (still more dependable), from my Housemaid Maria. And my road back, whether as I came, or by Edinr, to be decided on, when I shall have heard from Lady Stanley and another English friend on the North Western line.Caroline Davenport Bromley lived at Wootton Hall, Staffordshire, and Lady Stanley at Alderley Park, Cheshire; both are in NW England. But I wouldn’t leave you wondering what was become of me—or if it had been really me or my Wraith you had seen!
In a few days then you will hear further meanwhile
docBody.name: JWC

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [15 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Gt Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 15 Aug. 1862. MS: NLS 607.591E. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:254–56 inc. Quot: Hansons, NE 501.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p:
Yes indeed, Dear! You may well be “afraid of my weather“! I have only twice got over the threshold since I came! and that hurriedly, between showers! I begin to have more sympathy with Mrs Russell’s melancholy impressions of her beautiful new home! But I don’t weary as yet; the situation has still novelty enough to keep me from wearing. And within doors, it has not been so dull as you might think! The day before yesterday there plumped down to us a little man, on his way home from “The Exhibition“—(can’t get rid of the Exhibition even here; you see!). Arthur Burnet, the Sheriff of Lanarkshire,Arthur Burnett (1797–1877), lawyer, sheriff-substitute of Peebles 1839–68; any previous office held in Lanarkshire is untraced. whom you may remember. He was a round faced, cherry-cheeked, black
eyed young man, of the entirely uninteresting sort, when last seen by me!Previous meetings untraced. Now he has got transformed into the most ridiculous, yet touching likeness of Jeffrey!Lord Francis Jeffrey. The little shock grey head, and round brow, the arching of his eyebrows, the settling of his chin in his neckcloth the jerking movements, the neither scotch nor English speech bring Jeffrey before one as if he were alive again! I have been instituting searching inquiries as to the character of Mrs Burnet of Monboddo;Helen Burnett of Monboddo (ca. 1759–1833). for I have not the slightest doubt in my own mind that Arthur Burnet is Jeffrey’s Son (unofficially). I find that this Mrs Burnet was the Daughter of Monboddo,James Burnett (1714–99; ODNB), Lord Monboddo; Scottish judge and philosopher. and contracted a secret marriage, with her Fathers Secretary, one Williamson,Kirkpatrick Williamson (ca. 1756–1833) eloped with Helen Burnett; they m. ca. 1781. who had “eventually“ to take her family name.When Lord Monboddo died, Helen was his only surviving child; he left his property to her and Williamson with the proviso that Williamson change his name to Burnett of Monboddo. A woman who commenced with an irregular marriage, you see! quite easy to arrive later at an irregular Baby!—

Mr Burnet left us this morning but last night another visitor turned up, with a boy in his hand—the Revd David Smith of the parish of Tillycoultrie> (!!)Rev. David Smith (1806–81), minister of Tillicoultry, Clackmannanshire, about 7 mi. (11.5 km.) E of Stirling, and his son, David James (b. 1849). He is a nephew of an old Smith of Morton,William Smith (1786–1861), lawyer; he had lived in Thornhill, Morton parish. you have seen; and holds forth solemnly, in a loud falsetto voice, or rather in many loud falsetto voices. He will do us “neither ill nor gude“!Coterie speech; see 4:369TC to MAC, 20 April 1828.— Yesterday, we (Mrs R, Mr Burnet & I) called at Bellevue, and drove up the Penfillan avenue, and surveyed the remaining wing of the old house,Penfillan, the home of JWC’s paternal grandfather, John Welsh; see 2:369JBW to TC, 6 June 1823. and then drove away—to the open mouthed astonishment of two Servant girls!Probably Mary Rae (b. ca. 1844) and Margaret Wilson (b. 1844). and then we called at Keir Manse, (poor old Graham’sWilliam Graham, often referred to as “poor old Graham.“ Mr Menzies)Rev. William Menzies (1797–1869), minister at Keir since 1827; see 6:365TC to JAC, 29 March 1833. A sad Manse it has been—this some time! the eldest son met with an accident and died after long agony—the Mother went melancholy in consequence, and is on the verge of insanity the eldest Daughter is gone wholly insane, and is in the Asylum!Menzies and his wife, Agnes, b. Elder (1795–1880), had three sons, William (1830–33), John (1831–75), and James (1833–60); it is not clear which son had the (untraced) accident. Agnes (1834–1910), their eldest da., d. in Murray’s Asylum, Kinnoull, Perthshire; two other das. were Jane (b. 1837), and Mary (d. in infancy 1838). And Menzies himself has just undergone an operation for stone after long suffering! His sorrows “have
been blessed to him“ (as the phrase is)!Cf. 28:364. such a changed expression of face I never saw!

I have ever so many letters to write! so, must spend no more time on you. One of the letters you forwarded was from Miss Dickens apologizing for not inviting us.
