(her Aunts illness &c)Mary Dickens, eldest da. of Charles Dickens; her aunt Georgina Hogarth (1827–1917; ODNB), who lived with them, had been ill since early summer. Dickens wrote to William Macready, 2 July, of the “sudden decline of the health and spirit of Georgina. She is labouring under degeneration of the heart. … The change that two months have made, is extraordinarily great. All that alacrity and ‘cheer of spirit’ that used to distinguish her, are gone. She is quite unfit, even for the distraction and disturbance consequent on the presence of a few visitors in the house“ (DL 10:99–100). I must assure her that we are not too much disappointed! A letter from Betty says “O der me! you did not dreck (direct) the peper this wick and I can do nothing—&c &“Betty Braid; JWC asked TC to send “two punchs together“ to George Braid 12 Aug.; see JWC to TC, [12 Aug.]. Charles Paulet writes for my “cooperation“ in restoring his Church!!! “The Bishop having said it ought to be restored“!Probably Charles Newton Paulet (b. ca. 1830), son of JWC’s erstwhile friend Elizabeth Paulet, b. Newton (1806–79; see 13:189TC to JWC, 19 July 1841); he was vicar of Kirk Hammerton, Yorkshire, in the diocese of Ripon; the bishop was Robert Bickersteth (1816–84; ODNB). The Dickinsons of Bond Street send me a spoiled photograph of Mrs Twisleton declining to receive money for it—“didnt know who I was“ &c People should be always civil and then they wouldnt get into trouble
docBody.name: J W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 17 [16] Aug. Addr: Dr Russell’s / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 18 Aug. 1862. MS: NLS 616.560. Hitherto unpbd. Sat. was 16 Aug.; the day confirmed by TC’s reference to the “Scott party last night,“ i.e., Fri., 15 Aug.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: My poor drookit Dear, what weather for you, all a drowsy lazy soak; and ours is no better,—except that today our rain has grown windy and colder! Along with that of mankind at large and their Harvest, I regret the weather much on your acct;—and get, myself, only one benefit out of it, Those nice little Letters you write me. Patience; it is “the Lammas Flood,“ nothing more; and will probably take up soon.

I am, as usual, in huge hurry; but if I write nothing, you will be sure to fancy something gone wrong. All is right enough, let me write that at least: on me a
blue-pill crisis, whh I had been looking forward to for a fortnight; the inevitable now come: shall be cautiously dealt with (I assure you); and, we can expect, be wholly over abt Monday;—when I begin my grand feat of Proof-correcting (and so end Vol IV by one noble effort for ever and a day!),—these miserable tedious hagglings abt “Copy for vol. V“ (whh they are now busy with) being at last got done. I think clearly, If the Ashburtns now practically propose, I will after that Proof job is over, go to The Grange, & ride abt bone-idle for a week. All otherwise is in statu quo here. Except that today I incidentally learned poor RoncaDominic Ronca, previously at no. 6 (see 28:367JWC to MR, 30 Dec. 1853, and 29:238TC to JAC, 13 Jan. 1855), now lived at 4 Cheyne Row. was thot to be in extremis [at the point of death]. Passing the door this morng, I noticed a dark little figure, but as usual looked at nothing: dark figure toddled after me; proved to be Hacking the IronmongerWilliam Hacking, ironmonger, 3 Prospect Pl., Cheyne Walk, Chelsea. (sent for, as ghostly counsellor, I suppose, by some of the women, who are Protestants:Ronca and Hacking were presumably Roman Catholics; the women not further identified. alas, alas!)—from Hacking, who did not seem intrinsically to care a straw abt it, I got the intelligence; and went musing, all the sadder, along. Inexorabile fatum [implacable fate]; ja, ja!—

Here is Maria with “dinner, Sir“;—she was very proud of her three-cornered dainty, I noticed, this morning: she & the other do really well by me in yr absence. I sent away the Punch, the two Punches in due succession— My Scott Party last night cd not be said to harm me. Enigmatic figure, proved to be one “Macdonald,“ a blossomy Scotch figure (somewhat of the SymingtonAndrew James Symington (1825–98), Glasgow merchant, poet, and biographer; see 36:28736:biographical note. For C. L. Dodgson’s 1863 photograph of George MacDonald, see 139TC to JWC, 14 Aug. order, only pock-marked, grizzled and not such a goose); MackintoshPossibly Robert James Mackintosh (1806–64), gov. gen. of the Leeward Islands 1850–55, who lived at 2 Hyde Park Ter.; see 35:241TC to JF, 26 Oct. 1859. came too; Scott said little, silent, estranged, gloomy and ugly; but little Russell chatted: and I got them all safe away.— What dainty budgets of news you send from Nithsdale! Don’t scandalise poor Mrs Monboddo:—who knows? I myself have seen the little brown Dottle of a Body;Arthur Burnett. satWord repeated at turn of page; TC’s line above second “sat.“ opposite to him in a railway 7 years ago,—& did perhaps find somethg of Jeffrey too.— Dinner is cooling, cold!
docBody.name: T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 17 Aug. MS: NLS 525.94. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: My dear Brother,—I shd have written to you long since; and would have—had I had time! Whh I never have. Jean has been so kind as write to me twice: she is my only source of Scottish news, at least of Annandale. I am greatly sensible of her kindnesses (in every way, Letters only one of them) since Jane came into those neighbourhoods. Say I will surely write, and that before long. Today I know not well where you are: but judge, on the best guess I can form, that you may be in Assembly Street.Where Jean and James Aitken lived in Dumfries. This therefore will be a sign of life and remembrance to both of you at once.—

I am extremely busy; chin-deep in horrid chaotic rubbish:—not ill in health (not to call ill), except that in the general soak of Nature, I did this morning (having a blue pill within me, not of gaiété de coeur [lightheartedly]!) catch a lumbago that is rather provoking. Nothing else;—and I mean to assault that with “Castor“ (not Pollux or any other Heathen God)TC puns between his medicinal castor oil and Castor and Pollux, twin sons of Leda in Greek mythology. tomorrow morning!—

Our weather seems to be as wet as yours. Great crowds of blockheads still tumbling wd on the Exhibitn score. Alick Welsh and WifeAlexander and Sophie Welsh; see JWC to [Lady T], 12 Aug. were here last sunday (to dinner) with &c in the Evg,—poor Jane totally unslept for the prior night, and to be off next morng: Ach Himmel! I have had Scott too (Friday night with Russel &c): Scott was very gloomy and unbeatiful,Thus in MS; either from “beatify“ or in error for “beautiful.“ spoke little: Russel has a Book of yours (safe, coming to Hanovr StreetJohn Carlyle’s Edinburgh lodgings. by and by); Scott had “written to you twice, but got no answer“ (time of his Sister’s death,Possibly Scott’s sister Margaret (b. 1806) or one of his sisters-in-law, Mary (b. 1797) or Grizel Ker (b. 1808); see 19:172TC to JWC, 27 Aug. 1845. I think).— — Jane seems to be doing well enough at Thornhill: but this deluge of a “Lamas Flood“Heavy rains in early Aug.; see 3:368TC to JBW, 10 Aug. 1825. is of course much agt her.

I shall have to go and ride under a mackintosh (better than walking under do with such a back); dinner, by the clock, is within 2 minutes.— You may send me back the UsedomBaron Karl and Baroness Olympia von Usedom. Letter (or send it round by Jane if you like, for she never saw it, & it is good); the Meyer,Possibly J. E. B. Mayor (1825–1910; ODNB; see 32:7TC to CHC, 7 Oct. 1856); otherwise unidentified. yr old acquaintce’s, you may burn.
Willisen,Karl Wilhelm von Willisen; he had previously called at Cheyne Row in 1843, when TC was away in Scotland; see 16:323–24JWC to TC, 28 July 1843. is in the Country, left no address; is to call in a few days.See TC to Lord ALOA, 31 Aug. Adieu, blessings on you all
docBody.name: T. C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [18 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 18 Aug. 1862. MS: NLS 607.591F. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: No letters went from these parts, yesterday, Dear!— A place too religious for letter writing on Sundays!— And what is much worse so far as I am concerned no letters come here on Sundays—have to wait reverently at Carlisle, over Sunday; making two blank London post days in succession!

So if you wrote to me on Saturday, (as I think you would; seeing that next day was Sunday)There were no postal collections or deliveries in many parts of Scotland on Sundays; see 35:210JWC to HL, 20 Sept. 1859. JWC implies there were also no collections in London on Sundays. the pleasure is still on the road! and may be here any minute!

But I had best not wait for the somewhat irregular post-boy;William Milligan (b. 1835). having promised Dr Russell to be “ready punctually at eleven“ to be driven with all the rest to Glencairn,Glencairn, parish in Upper Nithsdale, Dumfriesshire. where having calls to make, we cannot, he says, be home till dinner-time (four o’clock) and the post which takes you a letter at breakfast-time leaves at five. There is another post leaves at night;The last post at Thornhill left at 8:30 p.m. but by that you would not get the letter till the following after noon.
So this is just a notekin to explain why you haven’t a letter; and to keep you from worritting—

Here are the letters! my gracious! such a many! I have read yours, Mary’s Jean’s,—Miss Cushman’s and Miss Bromley’s (who I see signs herself ‘die Lerche [the Lark]’ and my Aunt Anne’s,Ann Welsh in Edinburgh. I must leave till I have finished with you, and dressed myself to be ready for Dr Russell, who is as dreadful about being “in time“ as I am myself! Besides all these letters make me feel like die Lerche myself!
Poor Ronca!— Hacking helping him to die looks to me the saddest part of it!
I like extremely your notion of going to the Grange a week of idleness anywhere but especially there would do you a world of good.
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [19 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Gt Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 19 Aug. 1862. MS: NLS 607.592A. Quot: Hansons, NE 501.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Really, young Man! that “Dinner“ of yours is becoming as inevitable an interruption as used to be my Cousin Maggie’s Bonnet and Shawl!— “Now, dear Cousin, I must go and put on my bonnet and shawl“ cut short every letter she wrote me for some years!Cf. 23:188. Well! “I like a letter when I can get it; and when I cannot get it, I can do without!” Besides “in the valley of the Shadow of Blue Pill“ a man is to be dispensed, I suppose, from making what poor William Gibson used to call “a sootable return.“William Gibson (d. 1853), Scottish-born American merchant; see 8:198TC to JCA, 17 Aug. 1835, and 18:266JWC to HW, 12 Nov. 1844.
So here goes! on “the voluntary principle“!Coterie speech; see 32:48JWC to IC, 10 Dec. 1856.

First: in case of forgetting again. Did I tell either you or Maria where the key of the wine cellar was? The doubt struck thro’ me like a knife; while I was apparently absorbed in contemplating from the window the most beautiful “view“ in the world!— Open the side-board drawer where the wine and brandy is, and feel with your hand along the side of it, next the window far back, and you will find the key hanging from a nail—unless indeed I did tell Maria and give it into her keeping. Having got the key, as I trust in Heaven you will, give me assurance of the fact in your next! for the idea of your finding yourself at the end of your wine, and unable to get more, made a cold sweat break all over me!
Please to send the “all the year round“ that comes tonight to Cheyne Row, along with the one that came last Tuesday. That, I think, is all I have to say in the nature of business.

We have had a day or two of lovely weather! The drive to Glencairn yesterday was “delicious“! I saw poor, white, little Mrs Robert MacTurk; who they say, in spite of her bodily frailty and broken heart, carries on the Farm with more money-result than her Husband did!Janet McTurk had been ill for many years; see 36:127–28JWC to JDO, 2 June 1860; her husband, Robert, d. 1860. They wonder she has survived:
but nobody with a turn for money making dies of grief; except at the breaking of a Bank!—

We called also at the Dunbar’s,Rev. William Burnside Dunbar (1815–68), minister at Glencairn Church 1855–64 (see 37:184TC to HL, 8 July 1861), and Margaret Juliana Maria Dunbar, b. Orde (ca. 1812–83). and found the Duchess’s NieceMargaret Dunbar’s maternal aunt was Susan Euphemia, b. Beckford (1786–1859), duchess of Hamilton. as preposterous-looking a Ministers wife as ever!— But the pleasantest meeting of the day, was accidental—with the Scotts of Craigmai (?)William Scott (1783–1866) and Helen Scott, b. Goldie (b. 1787), of Craigmuie, near Moniaive, about 7 mi. (11.5 km.) SW of Thornhill. Their carriage passed ours, and I just caught sight of Mrs Scotts face, and put my head out, and shouted; and the coachman took up the shout; And Both Carriages stopt; and Dr Scott descended from one and I from the other, and met in the middle of the road! They were going to meet Mrs Skirving (Margaret Scott)William Scott’s sister Margaret Lindsay Skirving (1789–1868), of Camptown, Haddington; see 33:126JWC to AHO, 23 Nov. 1857. at the Station and bring her to Craigmuie (?) And the interview ended in an engagement that the Russells and I should dine with them tomorrow.

Friday I am to spend with the widow of John Hunter, who is a nice woman, living at a nice place in Tynron.Catherine Hunter, b. Brown (1820–1912), widow of John Hunter (1795?—1858); see 34:242–43JWC to JPR, 23 Nov. 1858; now living at Milton, an estate in Tynron parish. Then we are going to Sanquhar to visit the Miss WhigamsMary Whigham (1821–1905), farmer and coal proprietor (1861 census) at Burnfoot, Sanquhar, Dumfriesshire, and her sisters, Jemima Lucy Maxwell (1827–80), Georgina Helen (1829–1915), and Elizabeth (1833–1884). and Mrs Veitch of ElochAgnes Veitch.— And I have promised to dine with Mrs Gladstone (Elizabeth Clarke whom you used to like) at KessnochElizabeth Gladstone. JWC means Capenoch House, 4 mi. (6.5 km.) SW of Thornhill.— So you see I am like Mrs Rennie of Phantasy’s currie “uncommon popular the day“!Possibly a phrase of George Rennie, old Haddington admirer of JWC. Marion Rennie (1775–1858), of Phantassie, East Lothian, George’s mother.

And now I must write to Die LercheCaroline Davenport Bromley. and some others. Our minister and SonRev. David Smith and his son, David; see JWC to TC, [15 Aug.]. are gone this morning—to my satisfaction if to no one else’s!
I am not tired yet. I dont soon tire when I am much made of
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

ps.p: Our Minister told me he once sat up in bed all night reading your—Life of Schiller!!The Life of Friedrich Schiller (1825). It is pouring to day again.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JCA, [20 Aug.]. Addr: Assembly Street / Dumfries. PM: Thornhill, 20 Aug. 1862. MS: NLS 607.592B. Hitherto unpbd. TC wrote on the envelope: “’62 / Holm Hill Autumn (1862 / (1862).“
div3.head: JWC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: We are just starting to spend the day with the Scotts at Craigmore (?Craigmuie; no closing bracket. Every day we go somewhere since the weather cleared up. I have so many old friends here who are kind enough to be glad to see me! Meanwhile you will be wondering why I dont come. Well! I am coming, “if I be spared“ next Tuesday. And will go on to the Gill by the same train that took me there before. It will depend on what I hear from JamieJames Carlyle. in answer to a note I sent him, whether I go on to Scotsbrig for a day, or not— At all events I shall go down without luggage, and come back here on my way to Edinr, Mrs Russell having offered to drive me to meet the train at ElvinfootElvanfoot, railway stn. on the Caledonian line, about 16 mi. (26 km.) NE of Thornhill.

I have only just decided on going to Edinr— My Aunts were going to have been “much hurt at the strangeness of my [conduct“]Words cut away; see JWC to TC, [21 Aug.]. had I kept to my first intention of going no further north. It is too far to go, for all the time I have to stay. I dislike being away from home long with Mr C there to amuse his solitude in overworking himself and swallowing blue pills!
Mrs Russell thanks you for your kind invitation— She says she will go down with me and call for you—but she never dines in Dumfries—
docBody.name: Yours af[fly]

div3.sourceNote: TC-PB, 21 Aug. MS: Emmanuel College Lib., Cambridge. Pbd: K. J. Fielding and Peter Jackson, “Carlyle’s Reminiscences: Dr Peyton Blakiston and Bessy Barnet—A Note,“ Carlyle Newsletter No. 9 Spring (1988): 54.
div3.head: TC TO PEYTON BLAKISTON

docBody.p:
I was delighted to see Miss Barnet, the other day, again;Bessie Barnet was the da. of a housekeeper to TC’s old Birmingham friend John Badams (ca. 1792–1833), chemist; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 297–99. She was the Carlyles’ first servant at Cheyne Row, June 1834, employed despite rumors that she had been Badams’s mistress; see 7:216–17TC to JAC, 17 June 1834. and to find that she had made so valiant a struggle in her difficult situation, and triumphantly
gained for herself such friends in the world,—such a friend, and by noble services done to him and to others!

I have known dear “Bessy,“ as we always called her, since she was a little girl, one of the prettiest cleverest creatures I ever saw; full of ardour, of affection, and every fine quality;—but tragically isolated and agitated, when I had seen her last, as a beautiful young woman:Bessie left the Carlyles, Dec. 1834, because of her “unhappy unwholesome state of mind“ (see 7:330TC to JAC, 28 Oct. 1834); see also 7:314TC to MAC, 23 Oct. 1834.—I can truly say there has nothing happened to me, for a long time back, whh has given me so much pleasure as her sudden reappearance, the other day, on those new terms.
May your marriage be happy, dear Sir and Madam:—so far as I can judge wd it, there is every sanction to warrant such a union; and if I have ever known a born Gentlewoman, your intended wife is one.

It will give us much pleasure to see you and her, when matters are all settled on their new basis,—when I too (let me hope) may not be in such a whirlpool of confused labour as at present and for a series of years yearsWord repeated at turn of page; TC’s line above second “years.“ bygone. With many kind wishes, I remain, Yours and Hers,
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-WA, 21 Aug. Addr: Buckingham Street / W.C. PM: London, 21 Aug. 1862. MS: NLS 3823.129.
div3.head: TC TO WILLIAM ALLINGHAM

docBody.p: Dear Allingham,—Froude’s Town Address will not at prest find him: he is in the Isle of Wight (I forget specially where). You must go to Parker’s (Publisher of Fraser, West StrandJohn William Parker; his publishing office was at 445 Strand. Allingham was presumably delivering the manuscript of his verse novel Laurence Bloomfield in Ireland, or Rich and Poor in Ireland, pbd. monthly in Fraser’s Magazine from Nov. 1862.); and they will tell you what to put on the Packet. Adieu
In a bushel of hurries (and a pack of troubles) Yours
docBody.name: T. Carlyle
docBody.note: Allingham arrived in London earlier in Aug.; he recorded, 10 Aug.: “Being up from Ballyshannon for a holiday, I was at Cheyne Row to-day. Mrs. Carlyle received me with great kindness. I had a new hat of some shape that amused her; she tried it on. … Carlyle has grayer hair than when I last saw him, and patches of white in whisker“ (William Allingham, A Diary, ed. H. Allingham and D. Radford [1907] 80).

ps.p: Chelsea, 21 Augt [1862]

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 21 Aug. Addr: Dr Russell’s / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 21 Aug. 1862. MS: NLS 616.561. Pbd: Bliss, TC 355–56 inc.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest,—I have been held all morng in the usual flurry of clearing away rubbish (for action, not yet acting),—and what is far more disgusting have had a great deal of other with other people’s busss, whh in no sense was my own at all.“[O]ther people’s busss“ included TC’s letters to Peyton Blakiston (see TC to PB, 21 Aug.) and to William Allingham (see TC to WA, 21 Aug.). William Lattimer (see 28:340TC to WL, 15 Dec. 1853) also wrote, 18 Aug., asking for help in placing his article on the slavery question. This I confess provokes me as nothing else does: a poor old wretch staggering, to the edge of falling, under his own load; begging the unbeautiful people all round, not to help him (whh he knows well they will not, cannot, hardly wd if they cd), but not to stand on his skirts, begging him for help! Nearly unendurable, that. So to cool my mind a little, I will write you a word before going farther;—as preface to the poor hour or so that may remain of day’s work!—

The girlsMaria and Elizabeth. are all waxing chairs &c in the back area; great puff of apparent work;—indeed the poor souls are very attentive to me: and all is right on that and other practical sides. But what I must explain to yr curiosity is the Bessy Barnet history.

Three days ago Maria came up, “A Lady who says you will know her by the name of Bessy“! “Not a bit of it!”—till after a minute or two, I bethot me of Barnet, & said if she is “Bessy Barnet; yes, for a few moments!” And Bessy all in wide flowing black silk, but very modestly shaped and with crapes, if I remember, sailed in; kissed my hand (almost like to kiss myself), all in tearful tremble and emotion; “had come to thank me“ (for what?)—and got seated, a second time kissing my hand. Poor soul; she was at least succinct in narrative; and indeed did look highly respectable and a great deal wiser, as well as much older when she came close.

“Had gone home,Bessie Barnet returned to her family in 1834; see 7:314–15TC to MAC, 23 Oct. 1834, and 7:329–30TC to JAC, 28 Oct. 1834. as we knew; very wild and foolish,—remembered all I had said to her (that was the “thanks,“ thanks for nothing at all; on whh I got brevity observed): “Nursed old Mr BadamsJohn Badams’s father; see 7:124TC to JAC, 27 March 1834. for a year till he died; then her good Mother, who fell ill nobody cd say of what, and died slowly 25 years ago.Bessie’s mother apparently suffered from chronic heart disease; see Reminiscences 299. One of her last Doctors was Dr Blakiston (known to Genl Sabine and
poor John Welsh),Edward Sabine (1788–1883; ODNB), physicist and astronomer, and John Welsh (1824–59; ODNB), meteorologist, JWC’s cousin; see 27:307JWC to TC, 25 Sept. 1852. then just come to Birminghm: he, and the late mother’s clergymanUnidentified. were good to Bessy; who took up a school in Birmm (poor soul) and got 35 pupils, and was a sad but a wiser-growing woman,—not anWord repeated at turn of page. endlich Toll-werdenden [one who finally goes mad] any more! Mrs BlackistonFrances Blakiston, Peyton Blakiston’s first wife. had thot she might do as Nursery-GovernessThe Blakistons had five sons: Francis (b. 1828), John Richard (1829–1917), Peyton (1831–65), an unidentified son (b. 1833), and Matthew (1835–1906). (“Nurse,“ I think Bessy called it); and she went there, with success and effect: oh such work; had scrubbed and worked, Cap not off (or on, I forget whh) for 3 weeks at a time;—in short, became highly useful in the house; and has been there now for 25 years in a piece. She told all this with great modesty, swiftly And I saw she had something else to tell, after mentioning how all the young people were married &c She accordingly drew from her pocket 2 or 3 Letters; and rapidly owned to me that Mrs B. had died 2 years ago or 3; that Dr Bln being old &c had wanted to marry her this year & half; and that now verily it was to be. The Letters were from friends of Bn’s (Genl Sabine or his WifeElizabeth Juliana Sabine, b. Leeves (1807–79), translator of scientific works. one of them) approving &c,—as did I (heartily, tho’ discouraging Dr Bn’s intended “call“ upon me): and therewith poor Bessy, again kissing hand, and passionately speaking abt Badams (as she had repeatedly done, in the style of some antique nun, I must say) went her way.— — I was really glad the poor girl had gone such a road; and felt quite gratified by the adventure.

She is to send us word when the marriage is actually done;The date of marriage is untraced. and will call on you (“May I? Might I?“— “Surely, yes“), and will explain for you with the utmost minuteness of Historical Detail, I have no doubt.— One of the inclosed Letters (just come, and whh had to be answerd, sorrow on it!) is a Codicil to the busss;—and I will not say one other word on it here.— Craik’s Newspr has in it that story we got from the Newspaper (abt you and Edwd Irving and me) as we went down to Folk[e]stone:Letter omitted. George Lillie Craik sent The Belfast News-Letter, 19 Aug.; it included “Thomas Carlyle’s Courtship,“ which told the story of TC and JWC’s first meeting: “To this lady, whom we can discern to have had all the piquancy of a brilliant young man combined with all the grace and tenderness of a beautiful young woman, Irving introduced that gentleman who … was soon exalted to a higher place in her affections than himself. The gentleman introduced was Mr. Carlyle. At first Irving, though he seems even then to have met one who enthralled him more completely than his pupil, was piqued. But his noble, brotherly nature could harbour no unworthy feeling, and so entirely did he possess the confidence of both lovers that he could write to his ‘dear and lovely pupil,’ and enclose the letter to ‘T. C.’“ For Edward Irving’s letter to JBW, 9 Feb. 1822 (pbd: Oliphant, Irving 1:134–36), see 2:39TC to JBW, 13 Feb. 1822, and 37:157–58JWC to MO, 29 April 1861. Presumably TC meant that they read it while they were at Folkestone in July, since they did not travel there together. you remember? It will
abolish (by its circulating in the dirty newspapers) that dirty Espinasse story of the “veterinary“For the article, signed “M. D. Walsall,“ in Illustrated London News, 23 Oct. 1858, referring to JWC’s father as a veterinary surgeon, see 34:235JWC to JC, 1 Nov. 1858 (where author was spec-u-latively identified as John Burton [ca. 1806–81]); TC apparently thought the author was Francis Espinasse (1823–1912), journalist and writer; see 13:227JWC to TC, , and 24:257TC to GCD, 29 Sept. 1849. (and be hanged to it and him):For a previous expression of irritation with Espinasse, see 26:171TC to JWC, 13 Sept. 1851.—and that is all the good it will do.
I will write no more, Dear;—no more for a week to come! Pen most contradictory too, day most hot. So that I must shift to the awning; 2 o’clock striking; pooh, pooh!
Take care of yr little Self, and come home to me better. Ever yours such as I am / T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MC[MCH], [21 Aug.]. MS: Duke. Quot: Fielding and Sorensen 276. Dated the Thurs. after TC’s “blue-pill crisis,“ Sat., 17 Aug.
div3.head: JWC TO MARIA CHAMBERLAYNE

docBody.p: I want you to write me another nice little letter; which was more to the purpose than any, professing to give an account of matters at home, that I have received since!!

Mr C writes always with “dinner on the table“! “dinner cooling“ and so forth!TC mentioned dinner in his letters to JWC of [13 Aug.], [14 Aug.], 17 [16] Aug., and [19 Aug.].— It takes away one’s breath to read his hurried scraps!

I want to know if he is really better of that horrid blue pill?See TC to JWC, 17 Aug. and if he goes to bed not more irrationally late than usual? You can guess well enough, (being a smart girl!) the sort of things I want to know about!

For me; I am doing well in all respects except sleep! I have the most comfortable of bedrooms! quiet too as a tomb! and still, in spite of being so much in the open air, I can seldom close my eyes before four or five in the morning. But nevertheless I feel stronger and have a better appetite. And every body is so fond of me, and kind to me that I should be a Brute if I wasn’t rather happy!

Could you lay your hands on the Haddington newspaper I sent to Elizabeth?
It had been at Cheyne Row once already, and was redirected here by Mr C, and I, having no leisure to read newspapers in a general way, returned it to Elizabeth; whom it might interest, and as a sign of rem[embrance]MS torn. from myself. Now comes a letter from Miss Welsh at Haddington,JWC’s cousin John Amelia “Jackie“ Welsh. mentioning this newspaper as “containing more fun about myself“—by which I have confirmed to me what somebody here said the other day, that “not one but several “articles“ about my youth and childhood were going the round of all the newspapers!!!One of the articles was “Thomas Carlyle’s Courtship,“ Haddingtonshire Courier, 15 Aug.; it was also printed at least in the Belfast News-Letter (see TC to JWC, 21 Aug.) and the Caledonian Mercury, 16 Aug.; the Courier was apparently sent to Chelsea (presumably by one of JWC’s Haddington friends [see 36:20JWC to WDO, 30 Nov. 1859]), directed by TC to Holmhill, and redirected back to Chelsea by JWC. The article concluded: “Of Irving’s pupil, long since become Mrs T. Carlyle, the last the world has heard occurs“ in TC’s Life of Sterling; the article then quoted John Sterling’s reference to JWC’s dialogue “The Bird and the Watch,“ sent to Sterling in 1837 (see 9:320–35JWC to JOST, 30 Sept. 1837, and Carlyle, Works 11:148): “Now that Mrs Oliphant’s book informs all men that the authoress of the Watch and Canary Bird [as Sterling called it] conveyed in her girlish years a profound impression of her genius and accomplishments to two such men as Edward Irving and Thomas Carlyle, may we not respectfully beg that curious readers shall be permitted to hear the tick of the Watch and song of the Canary?“ Pleasant!— Now, if you could send me back that Haddington paper, I should just look to see what the “fun“ is! as probably the reality would annoy me less than my imaginations about it! All this comes of Mrs Oliphant’s Life of Irving!The Haddingtonshire Courier, 4 July, abridged a review from the July number of the Scottish Review of Oliphant’s Irving; the unidentified reviewer wrote that Irving was “promoted next to be the tutor of Jane Welch, now Mrs Thomas Carlyle, then a little girl, the only daughter and heiress of Dr Welch, a distinguished physician of that town“; the reviewer then commented: “One who has had the pleasure of meeting with that lady, with her pale and marble beauty, her statuesque figure, the fine disdain dwelling on her rather cynical lip, and her almost queen-like manners, not to speak of her varied accomplishments and powers, can hardly believe that she was once a doll-keeping girl. There have been many rumours as to the subsequent relations of these parties—sweethearts it is generally understood they became—but a married couple never.“—

Now good by! Ask for Mr Parson and Mrs RoystonMr. Parsons, carpenter (see 28:275TC to JWC, 22 Sept. 1853). Isabel Royston, a neighbor at 1 Cheyne Row. when you write— Compliments to ElizabethSignature cut away.—

I cant get home at the end of the “fortnight“ without mortal offence to my Aunts in Edinr But I shall soon fix the time of my return If you find the newspaper put a stamp on it and I will pay you all stamps when I come

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [21 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 21 Aug. 1862. MS: NLS 607.592C. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: “I also, Monsieur, have a dinner“!—not “cooling“ but cooking for me, at Burnfoot, Sanquhar!Home of the Whigham sisters; see JWC to TC, [19 Aug.]. We (Mrs R and I) go by the midday train; and I have certain petticoats to repair, before starting.

“I begin to be weary of the treatment I experience here“!Coterie speech; see 5:424JWC to TC, 11 Sept. 1831. such infinitissmal notes! or else scraps on other peoples letters! I have a good mind to leave you a week without sign of Life! Not even to tell me about Bessy Barnet!—to postpone even that!Apparently TC wrote briefly to JWC mentioning Bessy Barnet’s visit, 18 or 19 Aug.; for TC’s detailed letter, see TC to JWC, 21 Aug. Good Lord! I all but screamed at the ideaCoterie speech; see 31:204JWC to TC, 30 Aug. 1856. of her walking in! whom Tom HolcroftThomas Holcroft (d. 1852), journalist; see 6:50TC to JAC, 13 Nov. 1831; brother-in-law of John Badams. reported dead a quarter of a century ago! I want to know if she be married as well as alive?—where she lives? If I shall see her? I really dont think your time would be wasted, in cultivating your Human Nature a little more! One doesn’t write the better for growing into a Historical Abstraction! There! put that into your moral pipe!

I have not quite settled my further programme yet. “Wealth“ you know “makes wit waver“!Scottish proverb. If I had had only my allowance in hand, I should have indulged in fewer prjects! As it is, I feel almost as locomotively powerful as if I owned Prince Houssain’s carpet or Fortunatus’s cap!Prince Houssain’s magic carpet, Arabian Nights’ Entertainments; Fortunatus’s wishing-cap could transport him anywhere, 16th-cent. German story; see 10:194TC to TSS, 27 Sept. 1838, 33:89JWC to WDO, 19 Sept. 1857, and Carlyle, Sartor 117 and 342. So when my Aunts wrote that they would be “much hurt by the strangeness of my conduct, if I did not come to see them when I was so near“; I began to think that perhaps such ‘conduct’ would be strange! and to entertain the idea of going on to Edinr, tho’ only for three days— But the journey from Edinr to London at one mad rush always kills me! So—being so rich—what was I going to do next? Break it (the journey) somewhere—or come back by Carlisle and die LerchenJWC wrote “Lerchen,“ plural of “Lerche,“ her nickname for Caroline Davenport Bromley. [the Larks]—or what? being so rich, I might do which I liked! Wealth making wit waver! Thus far I am decided, to go to the Gill—without luggage on Tuesday evening (I am engaged every day till then!) spending the day with Jane on
my way, then—if Jamie will ‘come’ like LeonidasLeonidas, king of Sparta; cf. Plutarch, “Leonidas,“ “Apophthegmata Laconica,“ Moralia; see 35:232JWC to WMAN, 9 Oct. 1859. and ‘take me’; to go over to Scotsbrig on Wednesday back to the Gill on Thursday, and back to Thornhill on Friday. To pick up my luggage and start for Edinr Mrs Russell having offered to drive me to Elvinfoot to meet the train—and at the same time give me the opportunity of stopping at CrawfurdCrawford, nr. Elvanfoot, about 18 mi. (29 km.) NE of Thornhill; the churchyard was where JWC’s mother was buried.—which I had made up my mind to visit before I left home. This is all I can tell you now—and I wouldnt begin on a new sheet—under the circumstances—unless I was obliged to I wish you would tell me about your dinners not about their “cooling“ I know all that! but whether they are rightly cooked and to your mind.
docBody.name: J Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 22 Aug. Addr: Dr Russell’s / Thornhill, Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 22 Aug. 1862. MS: NLS 616.562. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: My Dear you are very snappish, very clever; and yr Letters, write how you will, are right welcome; and I only pardon all your unreasons on the spot!— You are greatly to be praised for writing so punctually; & I am grateful, never doubt.

Today, being dreadfully busy, I designed silence: but finding it was Friday and that the Pharisean Sabbath wd intervene,If TC delayed writing until Sat., 23 Aug., JWC would not receive the letter until Mon.; the Pharisees were supposedly strict in ritual observance, while lacking in charity.—I decided (while dining) that it must not be— This is after dinner, accordingly, and deducts itself from sleep (you ingrate little Cutty!)

My dinners are perfectly well, and all is so; and I often tell you, what is habitually true, that the girls go on really well with me;—and that you have no business to fret yr little Self, and spoil the few days of holiday you have. And don’t be in a flurry at all; make the most of prest opportunities, and do what you find nicest.— Tho’ you were to be home as on Monday,—do you recollect?JWC originally intended only a fortnight’s trip. Never mind. Addiscombe sends its hamper, twice weekly,—and I take all the cream; flowers too are on the table, and flowers are given away:—but there is not a word from BrahanLady Ashburton’s family home near Dingwall, Ross-shire; she was visiting her mother, who was very ill. or from the Grange. Nor shd I be ready yet;—not yet 3 slips or 4 done, and above 40 more to do!

But what I had to say was upon yr journey of Tuesday. Surely, it wd save Mrs Russell and yrself a great deal of troublesome driving, if you took yr luggage with you, & started from Scotsbrig for Crawfurd,—getting out there, and pausing till the next train for Edinr! It is a sore drive to Crawfd from Thornhill, & back in one day.— Think, inquire; decide as you ultimately like. And so adieu dear Goodykin; I am off to sleep, if I can. There will be a Letter tomorrow, won’t there?— T. C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [22 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Gt Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 22 Aug. 1862. MS: NLS 607.592D. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:256–57. Quot: Hansons, NE 501.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: There! That is something like a letter! And I feel my good humour restored.

Nothing in this Bessy-Barnet Romance surprises me so much, as the cool manner in which you seem to have taken the fact of her being alive! I at this distance screamed to hear of her being alive! And you—having a “Bessy“ announced to you, calm[l]y ask was it Bessy Barnet—! after she had been dead and buried (according to Tom Holcroft) for a quarter of a century!

I do hope she wont be gone when I return! Mercy of Heaven! If I had met her at FolkestoneTC presumably told JWC in the missing letter of 18 or 19 Aug. that Bessy lived in Folkestone, where JWC visited for about 10 days from 29 June. and she had spoken to me! what a fright I should have got!

We spent yesterday in an excursion to Burnfoot dining with the Miss Wighams (formerly of Allington).Allanton, an estate in Dunscore parish, formerly owned by the Misses Whighams’ father, George Whigham (d. 1842); see 6:245TC to JAC, 17 Oct. 1832. I haven’t seen any such perfectly beautiful scenery as that betwixt here and Sanquhar, since I used to ride there on a wee pony beside my Grandfather Walter—when he took me by new paths “to va-arry the schene Miss“! And I used to come home and mimic him to the others! little wretch!Coterie speech; see 31:189JWC to TC, 23 Aug. 1856, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 72.

Today we are to dine with Mrs Hunter of Milton, going early that we, that is I, might go up the glen to take a look at dear old Strathmilligan.Strathmilligan, once farmed by her maternal grandfather, Walter Welsh; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 125. For the farm in 2007, see oppabove. These old roads where I have been both as child, and young Lady give me a feeling half charming half terrible! The people all gone or so changed! and the scenery so strangely the same!— You remember that Couplet you criticised so sharply and which I admired
“And my Youth was left behind
“For some one else to find!”See 32:202JWC to TC, 26 July 1857; Ireland, JWC 106; and Fielding and Sorensen xx.
That is what I feel in these places—that there “my Youth was left behind“ and that some one else had found it! at least that I, in looking ever so wistfully about, can’t find a trace of it!

figure.p: Strathmilligan in 2007

docBody.p: It is raining today however, and I shall have to make my little pilgrimage in a covered carriage. But I shall find some woodruf to bring back to Chelsea from the same place where I gathered it more than forty years ago!

Did you know anything of Mr Rogerson an antiburger preacher here?William Rogerson (1794–1857), minister in Thornhill 1817–57, first of the Antiburgher Church (the stricter branch of the Secession Church), latterly of the United Presbyterian Church (formed 1847). TC’s parents belonged to the Burgher Church, the less strict branch (see 1:357TC to MAC, 4 May 1821, and 17:46TC to JWC, 14 Aug. 1843); the two reunited as the United Secession Church, 1820. he died a year or two ago. and, Mrs Russell tells me, he talked so incessantly of your works that his Congregation wishing to give him a Testimonial, presented him with your Life of Cromwell—
You deserve a better letter for once but I have no more time to spare you—
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, [24 Aug.]. Addr: Dr. Russell’s / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 25 Aug. 1862. MS: NLS 616.563. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Dear Goody mine,—I know not when this will reach thee: it will get to Thornhill monday night; and at any rate, be in time on Tuesday morning to
wish thee good luck, poor little soul, on thy bit of journey.— I am “a desultory widow“ tonight, really; and deserve pity, not anger. Maria, polite but careless, put everything down, wishing me “good night,“—and when I look up, half an hour after, the fire is out, the milk still cold &c. And it is latish (you may understand); and I have not a moment’s time to write. For I was obliged: the Printers clamorous (“idle till you send us some proofs“);—and the botheration of dirty wretches calling upon me (mostly dirty, not all) has been great and aggravating. Enough, I am now done, in very fair case (an excellt sleep this afternoon) and my head quiet. Half an hour of the fine night air; and then to bed.

“Not all dirty“ I said: my Prussn GenlKarl Wilhelm von Willisen; see TC to JAC, 17 Aug. called today; and I saw him this time; and we had a long brisk talk,—whh indeed wasted my forenoon, but not to no purpose. This is an excellt old gentn, with his honest granite face, a soldier every inch of him, and full of knowledge abt my affair. Is to come back, some night, warning me in the morning. He had a Son with him (Lieutt in the Potsdam Guard) item a Nephew; fine yg fellows,Willisen’s son, unidentified; the nephew, possibly Friedrich Emil Adolph (1830–79), son of Willisen’s brother, Friedrich Adolph von Willisen (1798–1864), Prussian general. whom I also liked. This was a good visit; and the only good one for months! The Allinghams, the WoolnersNeither William Allingham nor Thomas Woolner were yet married; presumably TC uses the plural to make them representative visitors. (here again last night), still more the “Exhibition“ Wretches (an Edinr Body of Hannay’s sending,James Hannay, ed. of Edinburgh Evening Courant, apparently suggested that friends attending the International Exhibition should visit TC. and be hanged to him!)— —on the whole, say nothing! The truth is, I am getting on with my Book, daily more or less; and I am at least as well as when you left me.

Take yr own plan wholly in journeying. But I begin to see yr way to the LarkCaroline Davenport Bromley. will be by Manchester; that is to say, back either by Thornhill or by Scotsbrig! Ask John abt it, Tuesday at Dumfries (no better authority in the world!)John A. Carlyle’s letters were full of railway advice; see, e.g., 36:210TC to JAC, 29 Aug. 1860. And make my respects and excuses to them all. And take care of yourself, and come back better (in foot, in sleep, an improved Goody!) Poor Arbuckle is dying or dead.Robert Arbuckle, physician and longtime friend of John A. Carlyle (see 5:341TC to JWC, 17 Aug. 1831, and 17:98–99TC to JWC, 28 Aug. 1843), d. 24 Aug. Ah me!— Adieu Dearest, God keep thee. T. C.

There will be a Newspapr tomorrow,—with a Trial in it. Huge brute of a MillionnaireWilliam Roupell (1831–1909), M.P. for Lambeth 1857–62. The Examiner, 23 Aug., reported “one of the most extraordinary cases ever brought before a court of justice.“ At Guildford Crown Court, William Roupell, illegitimate son of Richard Palmer Roupell, a lead ash smelter of Roupell Park Estate, Streatham, confessed to forging his father’s will in an attempt to defraud his younger, but legitimate, brother of his claim on the family estate; tried 24 Sept., he was sentenced to “penal servitude for the term of [his] natural life“ (Examiner, 27 Sept.). been swindling, again!
You have never but once said how you slept,—as if that cd never be a questn with me. Speak!—

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [24 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 25 Aug. 1862. MS: NLS 607.592E. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:258–59 inc. Quot: Hansons, NE 501.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: “Snapish“ or not my Dear; it seems to have answered the end in view; and that, it strikes me, is the highest merit of a letter! With your two little letters in succession, and Maria’s long one, full of interesting details, I am pretty well up in the vie privée [private life] of 5 Cheyne Row at present! Please tell Maria I was greatly obliged by her immediate attention to my request, and her excellent fulfilment of it;Presumably Maria Chamberlayne wrote about TC’s health and sent the Had-ding-ton-shire Courier as requested in JWC to MC, [21 Aug.]. This may well be the letter, signed “MI. “ that Froude published an extract from: “I hope you do not think of returning home. Should Mr. Carlyle become rampageous I will set Mrs. — on to pray for him. Should you, during your absence, require any transaction in London to be carried out with more than usual intelligence and finesse, remember / MI“ (Froude, Carlyle 4:250). and that I will write to her, “all to herself,“ when I have “seen Mrs Braid“ Dear old Betty! she has “nited“ me “a pair of stokins“; and won’t she be glad when I come and take them! I am afraid she goes for more in my purpose to take Edinr in my way—or rather, out of my way—than my aunts!— At the same time, as they were going to be much hurt had I gone back without seeing them; and as Elizabeth has been “very frail indeed“ of late; and as after all they are my Fathers Sisters, and my only near relatives in the world now; I should have oughted to go whether there had been a dear old Betty in the case or not! I shall not put off time there however—shall write to the Auchtertool peopleJWC’s cousins Walter, Maggie, and Mary Welsh, living at Auchtertool Manse in Fife. to come over and see me, instead of, (as Betty used to say) “tashing myself aboot, back and forrit ow’r that fell water“!The Firth of Forth, separating Edinburgh from Fife.

As for your suggestion about the journey; It wasn’t without due consideration and consultation, that I agreed to Mrs Russells plan. Certainly it would have been best to go on from Scotsbrig; had trains been like Omnibuses passing every half hour or so, and setting one down where one liked. But
there are just two trains in the day; stopping at Elvin foot.—not at all at Crawford. one twenty minutes after ten in the morning the other twenty minutes after five in the afternoon. So I must have been set down, with my luggage, at Elvinfoot, exciting observation, and brought into contact with the Inn people;The Elvanfoot inn was owned by Alexander Cranston (b. ca. 1816). and obliged to stay about there the whole day alone—stared at—and very miserable! and suppose it were a pouring wet day! one can never tell in the morning just now what the day will turn to before night!

Then I get thro’ my Annandale visits so much more easily for myself and “others,“ with no luggage, but my night things, in my carriage bag! I feel as “degaggé [released]“ as old Mrs BatesPossibly Lucretia Augusta Bates, b. Sturgis (ca. 1785–1863); see 33:148TC to LOA, 4 Jan. 1858; otherwise unidentified. described herself, when I can just jump out of a train or gig and no more about it!

We dined at Ceppnoch yesterday. A superb place the Gladstones have made it! and they are really nice people. It was quite a High-Art style of dinner—even to the two different kinds of ice! “By God sir I believe it was (not) a woman“! (You remember that speech of the Poodle’s when he had dined to his dissatisfaction)Hon. Frederick Gerald “Poodle“ Byng (1784–1871), socialite, member of Ashburton circle; see 18:116TC to JWC, 8 July 1844. “‘Poodle’ (Byng), in winding up a diatribe against the dinner at Lord Ashburton’s the first time after the advent of the new Lady Ashburton, exclaimed to Carlyle, with a tragic-comical look, ‘Gad, Sir, I believe it’s a woman!’—meaning that the French chef of former times had been supplanted by a female cook!” (A. Carlyle’s note, NLM 2:258).

The original old John Gladstone’s portrait was facing me, and a harder, cunninger old Baker I never saw!Sir John Gladstone (1764–1851; ODNB), merchant and politician; Thomas Steuart Gladstone’s uncle, and father of William Ewart Gladstone. John Gladstone’s first business was in the grain trade.— not unlike BruntonJames Brunton, baker, 44 Cheyne Walk (at the intersection with Gt. Cheyne Row), until ca. 1856. that lived in our street. with the nose reduced to straitness and slimness.
Will you mention if poor Ronca is dead?

I write now (Sunday evening) because tomorrow we start again early to spend the day with Mrs Veitch of Ellock—home from London now— And you had better not expect to hear on Wednesday as I shall go to Dumfries by the first train on Tuesday—my next will be written at the Gill most probably
I cannot get that Bessy Barnet redeviva [restored to life] out of my head.
docBody.name: J W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 27 [26] Aug. Addr: Mr Austin (The Gill, Cummertrees) / Annan / N.B. PM: London, 26 Aug. 1862. MS: NLS 616.564. Hitherto unpbd. Tues. was 26 Aug.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Welcome to The Gill, my little Dear,—a quiet warmly hospitable haven, where I have liked to be safe! Perhaps it will suit you for a couple of days? And you may go abt in a gig,—on Solway sands, looking at the poor old Sea, and CriffelGranite mountain ridge, SE Kirkcudbrightshire. & the mountns! Mary will be kind to you, beyond all women. Perhaps you bade some of them write from Dumfries, to direct me tomorrow as to where the aim is. I will write if I can guess or know. But Today—alas, I have eaten my dinner! All this is at the expence of Sleep; and you don’t wish me to continue. I have got a fair stroke of Proof-work done, too; let us be thankful.

You are quite right wd the roads; I had forgotton the fewness of trains;—and will not bother you at all with advice that is not needed and may perhaps be foolish.— Go carefully (that is all I will say), and not too far in a day,—whitherward your own genius bids. Tell Mary’s LassesFive of Mary Austin’s eight das. were still at home. I have found two (missed) Nos of Dickens,Issues of All the Year Round. and will send them tomorrow
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 27 Aug. MS: NLS 517.36. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: You have been very kind, in regard to Jane, and in the matter of writing; for whh I need not utter my thanks in speech. I heard yesterday of you and yr visitors; the Dr did not tell me, probably did not know, whether Jane was to leave The Gill on this day for Scotsbrig, or wait till tomorrow.John A. Carlyle wrote from Dumfries, 26 Aug.: “Jane has just arrived from Thornhill with Mrs Russell. She is looking very much better than when I last saw her. Mrs Russell & she have had little excursions almost every fair day. … The weather today is warm & genial … very favourable for going on to Gill, as Jane means to do by the evening train.“ I guess she will be in some degree of hurry northward and then homeward; but hope [not]Word omitted. be too rapid.

I am going on here, bird-alone (exceptg “Exhibition“ blockheads) tolerably well; making some actual progress; regular as clockwork; and, if saddish-humoured, not miserable at all. Yr James was here, Sunday night gone a week; tell him to come back “next Sunday“ after you write to him next,—he is very delicate, poor fellow, and shudders to think of intruding himself, tho’ evidtly glad to come (to the Nothing I have to offer him in present times!)— My Work, now that I see daylight thro’ it, is not so dispiriting; and I stand to it like Death;—but shall be very glad, too, to have a “week of complete holiday“; whh, I hope, is appointed me at The Grange or somewhere. Poor Arbuckle;John was with Arbuckle at his death: “The doctor’s end … was most peaceful, he merely ceasing to breathe without struggle.“ ah me, ah me!—

The inclosed Letter will not amuse you, or the Dr to whom you are to give it. Perhaps it is worth reading, for the immense absurdity of my share in “The Wallace Monument“ adventure!A committee was formed, 1856, for the building of a national monument, in Stirling, to the Scottish patriot William Wallace (d. 1305; ODNB), with Rev. Charles Rogers (1825–90; ODNB) as the committee secretary in charge of fundraising. TC, among many distinguished people, had joined an “Honorary Committee“ (Charles Rogers, Leaves from My Autobiography [1876] 142). The foundation stone was laid 24 June 1861; in Aug. 1861 Rogers organized a “Supplemental Committee“ to raise further funds for a statue of Wallace on the monument (Rogers, Leaves 185). The monument was completed in 1869. Rogers faced various accusations of manipulating the finances of the project for personal gain, although he was finally vindicated.— If John like, or think good, he may write a word of protest, just now, to the dud of a Lawyer Body;The letter that TC received was presumably from a lawyer instructed by James Scrym-geour, who had been employed by Rogers to help raise funds for the supplemental committee. Scrymgeour claimed he had not been properly paid and was threatening legal action against various members of the committee; see TC to JWC, [9 Sept.]. John reported, 1 Sept., that JWC took the lawyer’s letter to show Dr Russell “& ask him what ought to be done, he once having been the chief man for the Wallace monument in this district,“ and that Dr. Russell “says you are not at all liable for any debt of the Committee, even tho’ you did suffer your name to remain on the list sent to you, since you were never present & never took any active part in the concern.“ Both John and Dr. Russell advised TC not to answer the letter.—tho’ I suppose the whole thing will die of itself, witht notice taken. He is to do as he likes;—but, in mercy, to keep the beggarly inanity screened away from me, as far as he can!—

We have East-wind here, occasionally with hot Sun; very good harvest-weather. But the harvest itself, there can be no doubt, will be bad. And do we much deserve a good one (to crown our “International“ and other Balderdash); or wd it do us much good?

Adieu dear Jean; recommend me to James & to everybody,—and tell me how the House is getting on.The Hill, Dumfries, the new house that Jean and James Aitken were having built. It was ready for roofing; see JWC to TC, [27 Aug.]. Your affecte T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 27 Aug. Addr: Scotsbrig / Ecclefechan / N.B. PM: London, 27 Aug. 1862. MS: NLS 616.565. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dear Goody,—Had I known for certain whither to address, I might have written on a slightly bigger Paper;—tho’ indeed nothing that I have to write is of the least novelty: but it wd be doubly absurd to have it jumbling abt the Country following after you, and the proving to be zero when it got up. John writes to me this morning, that you are looking far better than when he saw you last before;See TC to JCA, 27 Aug. but does not say (in fact, I suppose, cd not) whether you wd be at The Gill one day or two days. I aim at Scotsbrig therefore; which is sure, if even a day later, as I think it will not be.

Ronca is not, that I hear of, better or worse; I shd think, surely not dead,—or there wd have been signs in the shop. But, except what Hacking told me that morng, I am totally ignorant.— Bessy Barnet, I now recollect, lives not “at Folkestone,“ but at St Leonard’s on Sea,St. Leonard’s-on-Sea, 2 mi. (3 km.) E of Hastings, Sussex.—the Hastings Outskirt, where I reflected how curious it wd have been had yr liability to meet her taken effect. For my own part, I never had the least notion that she was dead: if Tom Holcroft told me or you, I must have thot him ill-informed, and given no belief! You will see her by and by, and get all manner of particrs from her till yr utmost appetite is satisfied.

Both yesterday and the day before, I fell in with De Lane;John Thadeus Delane (1817–79; ODNB), editor of the Times 1845–77; for an earlier meeting in Hyde Park with Delane, see 32:95TC to LA, 23 Feb. 1857. and had a great deal of loose-jointed, blown-up and irregular talk with him,—whh was a great Contrast to my usual Dialogue with the Silences and with my Horse. He (De Lane), in the Cockney and Times-Editor form, is really a clever kind of fellow; inclines towards a just view in regard to very many things; and in the absence of all solid instruction, reflexion and study, has glanced into the ever-whirling Babel of Balderdash-and-Fact, with a knowing kind of eye.— Today I aim to leave a Card for my Prussian,Karl Wilhelm von Willisen. if I can find his place;—“won’t be at home“: tant mieux [so much the better]. I have got 20 of my Proofs done: have abt 20 more to do,—worse over.

Poor ever-dear old Scotsbrig. Ay de mi, Alh[ama]!Word unclear.— You will be in the room that was that of some now far away.Presumably TC’s parents and perhaps also his sister Margaret. My kindest regards to Jamie & everybody. Yrs ever T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [27 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Annan, 27 Aug. 1862. MS: NLS 607.593A. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:259–63 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Your letter, written on Sunday night, reached me yesterday morning (Tuesday) just before I started; and was read, “with the same relish,“Coterie speech; see 5:331TC to JWC, 15 Aug. 1831. on my way to the station. At Dumfries I read also a later letter from you (to Dr C). Then; I had been still further favoured with a note from Woolner, to tell me you “seemed to be thriving so remarkably well, delivered from the cares of a wife; that, if I were considerate, I would stay away a long time &c &c.“ So all is right on the Chelsea side.

It was a very confused and confusing day at Dumfries; the chief ingredient being the Dr! going back in the evening to poor Arbuckle’s funeral.John A. Carlyle wrote, 26 Aug.: “I … have to start again for Auchenhay in the afternoon at five o’clock. The funeral is to take place tomorrow & poor Mrs Arbuckle seemed very anxious that I should attend it; & I cannot well avoid doing so. I hope to get back by a late train tomorrow night. I came across yesterday because I knew the movement wd do me good, & it took me out of the details of preparation for the funeral.“ Auchenhay, Kirkcudbrightshire, about 20 mi (32 km.) SW of Dumfries. Many live-camels and Dromedaries were also parading the streets! preparatory to an Exhibition of Wombel’s menagerie!George Wombwell (1777–1850; ODNB), founder and proprietor of a traveling menagerie, continued after his death by members of his family.— I have a curious luck for falling in with wild beasts in retired places! Recollect my being kept awake the first night at Moffat with the roaring of Lions and HyenasJWC stayed with John A. Carlyle and his wife, Phoebe, in Moffat, July 1853, when there was also a visiting menagerie; see 28:187–88JWC to TC, 8 July 1853.

The only collected act of volition I accomplished was a call on poor Miss Willie Richardson; in spite of her being represented to me, as “insane, and a monster of fat—the eyes invisible in her head!”—mad or not—overfat or not, I thought it was right to show her the respect of calling for her; considering the kindness of her MotherWilhelmina (Willie) Richardson and her mother, Catherine Eliza Richardson, whom the Carlyles knew in the late 1820s when at Craigenputtoch. to you and me when we were less “celebrated“! So I made Jane come with me to Maxwelton to find her out. And a very pleasant call it proved! She opened the door to us herself—her one domestic, a small girl,Unidentified. Maxwelltown, on N bank of river Nith, opposite Dumfries. being raising potatoes in the garden— She didn’t recognise me at first but received us nevertheless with all her Mother’s hospitable politeness.
And when I told her my name the poor creatures delight over me (Mrs Carlyle! Jeanie Welsh! that my dear Mother was so fond of!) quite brought tears to my eyes!— So far from being “a monster“ she is a handsomer woman now than she was as a young Lady. very like her Mother in both appearance and manners, and in wellbred kindliness. She told me all about her Mothers death, and, listening to her, with her clear, truthful eyes looking straight into mine; I couldn’t but admire the cruelty of the Dumfries gossip about this poor lonely reduced gentlewoman who I could “stake my head against a china orange“ (as I have heard you say) is as free from “insanity“ and from “drink“ as any woman among them!

I saw too Mr Aird, who, you know never did interest me, and who interests me now less than ever!Thomas Aird (1802–76; ODNB; see 6:361TC to JAC,29 March 1833), writer, ed. of the Dumfries Herald 1835–63; old friend of the Carlyles. John A. Carlyle wrote, 26 Aug.: “I saw Aird today looking pretty well, but stagnant as usual.“— Jane took me past the Station to see their new house, which is ready for roofing— It looks a handsome ‘willa’ sort of house which I cant help thinking will smoke!

Mary and Jamie Austin were waiting on the platform at Ruthwell a gig outside. Mary said the evening was cold, and wrapt me in three plaids!—but I could feel no cold thro’ the welcome she gives one. I had taken tea at Dumfries so declined tea—“would take porridge by and by“—so we sat by the fire in the parlour talking. I went to my bag for something, and heard a pronounced sound like a screw in a cork!— I looked round—she was in the press— “For God’s sake what are you doing?“ I asked— “I thocht ye’d maybe tak a wee soup wine till the porridge is ready!!” I had to wrench her out of the press in my arms!

The porridge was excellent and such milk! “of two sorts“Sweet milk and buttermilk; see JWC to MR, [27 Aug.].—! how I wished you had had it! My “interior“Coterie speech; see 32:193TC to JCA, 21 July 1857. felt so comforted by that supper; that I thought I should probably sleep! To tell you a melancholy fact, I have been having horrible nights ever since I left home! only two nights out of the fortnight that I have closed my eyes before 4 in the morning! in spite of the quietest of bedrooms, the wholesomest of diet, and constant exercise in the open air! At first I imputed it to the excitement of finding myself there; but that subsided —still the bad habit taken did not abate. And still Dr Russell, (very unlike Dr Rousse)Dr. James Rouse, the Ashburtons’ doctor. would not let me have any morphia! In other respects I was better; felt less languid, and required no—“what shall I say?“—pills! But I was content to try a new sleeping-place—mere change being useful in these cases, and I was beginning to feel a little delirious!

So having taken my nice supper last night, and read for an hour after; I lay down in the softest, most comfortable of beds, with a modest confidence that my luck was about to change! And so it was! The confusions of Dumfries after whirling round in my brain a while like a dingle-doozieA stick of wood or peat, lit at one end, and swung rapidly around in circles to form an arc of light; see 30:244JWC’s Journal, 17 April 1856.—faster and faster, were going black out! and I was falling into a heavenly sleep when, “wouf! wouf! wouf bow! wow! wow! wow!” commenced at my very ear—“the dogs“ chasing some belated cat thro’ the garden! galloping and barking over my prostrate body (it felt)!— What a mercy it wasnt you, that had happened to! was my first thought! you just arrived from London for example! My next thought made me laugh “like a cuddy eating thistles“! it was the recollection of those hyenas and Lions at Moffat! Decidedly my search after “a quiet bed“ was not so successful as Caleb’s search after a wife!Cf. Hannah More, Coelebs in Search of a Wife (1809); see 2:402JBW to TC, 21 July 1823.—

Well the Demons “carried on“ for some half hour without an instants cessation—then they seemed to gallop away to the distance—and were no more heard—! till the porridge and my good will for sleep had brought me again to the first stage of unconsciousness,—and then outburst again under my window the same demoniac Charivari! This was repeated three times—and I had given up all idea of closing my eyes again—when heaven knows how? I did close them about 4 in the morning (as usual)—and got two hours good sleep without the dogs or in spite of them! Mary will “shut them in the Barn tonight“ had thought “they would never have played wouf“ or she would have done it last night.— For I am to sleep here again tonight, Scotsbrig being given up— Jamie is just arrivedJames Carlyle from Scotsbrig. to tell me poor little Jenny is ill in bedJenny Carlyle had been ill for some time; see TC to JAC, 6 Aug.—has been ill some days—so that they couldn’t have me— So I shall go back to Thornhill on Friday morning—staying here over tomorrow— I cannot change everything now, or I might have gone to Edinr on Friday, since I havnt to go to Scotsbrig Your letter too is arrived— I send back DixsonApparently a letter to TC or JWC, from Thomas Dixon, corkcutter of Sunder-land; see TC to JWC, 29 Aug. He sent JWC some cork soles in 1865; see Wilson, Carlyle 6:39–40.—that you may do what you like with him— I dont know the name. Do you?
Dr Carlyle wrote to you yesterday. write to Thornhill
docBody.name: JWC

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [27 Aug.]. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: Annan, 27 Aug. 1862. MS: NLS 607.592F. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: I hope you weren’t quite ill when you got home, after all that weariness of the flesh!Cf. Eccles. 12:12. John A. Carlyle wrote to TC, 26 Aug.: “Jane & Mrs Russell & Jean have all gone out for a little walk before dinner which is to be at half past one. … Mrs Russell has not come back from walking with the two Janes—has calls of her own to make, as they had—starts for Thornhill at the same time I start for Castle Douglas.“

I had tea with Mrs Aitken so arrived here in a state of mind not averse to considerations of supper! Porridge with sweet-milk and butter-milk was what I decided on. and it was, my dear, like clapping a soothing poultice to my “Interior“ (as Mr C would say) I went to bed in such a blessed condition of calm stupidity that I felt sure of my sleep— And, actually before I had been ten minutes in bed, I was on the point of falling into Heavenly repose when “wouf! wouf! wouf! wouf! Bow! wow! wow! wow“! burst on my astonished ear! and made me feel as if a whole pack of dogs were galloping over my prostrate body.— This outburst lasted without a moments cessation for some half hour—then the devil[i]shLetter omitted. quadrupeds galloped off to a distance—and again I was at the sleeping point when again the dogs returned to “the garden“ under my window; and again I was torn out of my rest—this horror was repeated three several times till I gave up all idea of a minutes sleep that night— About 4 however I fell asleep, in an interval of quiet, and had some good sleep for three hours either without the dogs or in spite of them—I dont [know]Word omitted. which!—

James Carlyle from Scotsbrig is come—but not to take me home with him—his Daughter is ill in bed—has been in bed some days—with the Dr attending her. So I shall stay here over tomorrow which I should be heartily glad of if it wernt for the cause.

I cannot—positively cannot stay another half day in Dumfries on my way back! so your bad sixpence will be returned upon you by the Train which passes Cummertrees at a quarter to twelve—on Friday the Dr will find in Bradshaw (clever man that he is!) what time said train reaches Thornhill— I have had a long letter to write to Mr C

closer.salute: God bless you ever my Darling!

docBody.name: JWC

ps.p: Dont please forward any letters tomorrow (Thursday) I should get them hardly sooner—on Friday than if they wait for me perhaps wouldnt get them at all

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 28 Aug. Addr: Dr Russell’s / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 28 Aug. 1862. MS: NLS 616.566. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: My poor Goody, I am shocked and alarmed at that acct of yr sleep. That is worse than you had here! And those too vigilant animals—I have myself had to do with them; but Mary always locked them up on my speaking—sorrow on them for yr poor sake!

I had written yesterday; sent it on (after computatn) to Scotsbrig as the sure place. It has absolutely nothing in it; don’t regret or bother.— You have done nothing I more approve of than that of poor Willie Richardson

But you never saw such a bother & whirl as I am in,—“at ta vera hinner-end“! Proofs quite madly bad; & such etceteras. Foolish Letteres (abt nothing) whh I will send you tomorrow: and, lo! as I am just beginning to get on (after 3;½ of my hours had gone), “Genl Willisen“ in German of whh I cannot make out one word in 3,—is to come tonight. Well, I had rather it had been another; but— Then enter Maria: “Box of grouse, from Mrs Tomline;Fanny Charlotte Tomline (1830–83); see JWC to TC, [31 Aug.]. 5/9 to pay!” Botheratn, what am I to do with grouse, and Goody gone? Six of them, it appears (cost 1 / per); on considering, I can eat 2, “boiled to rags“; I will give Mrs Chalmers 2,The Carlyles’ neighbor at 4 Cheyne Row.—perhaps my old Genl two, tho’ he never dines at home.— In fine, Dearest, I shd go to sleep, shdn’t I? Oh dear, Oh dear!— Ronca still lives; “very bad, Sir“ (a little Boy ansd yesternight as I pas- (t.o.)Turn over to the top of the first page. passed. Friday, you will get this. Tell me farther what, when, and how yr route is to be. God keep you for me T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-CC[CCU], [28 Aug.]. MS: Charlotte Cushman Papers, LC. Pbd: Fielding and Sorensen 277–78.
div3.head: JWC TO CHARLOTTE CUSHMAN

docBody.p:
Your letter has just reached me here!JWC and Cushman were corresponding regularly, although few of their letters survive. I have a bad habit—I know it is a bad one—of putting off writing to those I love, till there comes an hour when I can do it with all the concentration of heart, and all the stillness of outward things, which they seem entitled to—and so all in wishing to express myself in the
worthiest manner; I keep a silence which looks, at least, ungracious. I must try to break myself of this! were it only for your dear sake!

Here is my first effort toward a better system! I have the daily letter to my Husband still to write—several letters which may be called “of business“—letters about my goings and my trains &c—am “surrounded by a“ sister-in-law or two!—have a twelve-mile drive in a gig to execute—had next to no sleep last night—nor any nights this fortnight back!—am busy, am wearied, amdThus in MS, in error for “am.“ worried, am delirious, am on my travels—and amidst all this I write!— but well or much you see clearly, Dear, is impossible!

When I told StaurosStauros Dilberoglue. I was preparing for Edinbr, it was an elliptical expression. I had several visits to pay on the road there. did not expect to arrive there till the end of this week. And now, I am going back to Thornhill to make a fresh start for Edinr, thence, next Monday! My programme of route having been deranged by the illness of one of Mr C’s nieces!Jenny Carlyle; see JWC to MR, [27 Aug.].

I had hoped to avoid going to Edinr. but my three Aunts there were going to find “such conduct very strange“—and after all they are my Fathers sisters tho’ little like him, and the only near relatives I have in the world; and one of them has been “getting very frail“— Clearly it was my duty to go on—and there is a certain—not much—but a certain satisfaction in the discharge of one’s duty!

Meanwhile the floods of sad and rather wild emotion that have been pouring thro’ this excitable heart of mine have ruined my sleep—utterly—and I am grown nervous, cowardly and “horrid badly“ (in the dialect of these Parts) I wish I were safe home again!

On Monday my address will be Craigenvilla Morningside Edinr—for a week.— I hope to be at Chelsea on the following Monday or Tuesday—and so to see you on your return from Paris.— I will write from Edinr— If I could write such a lovely hand as you do, I shouldnt hate so to send you a hurried letter—but my hand was spoiled by commencing to write at four years“Before she was five, she was put to school“ (Hansons, NE 6). to [cat]ch the Post. (and Mr C’s letter)

kindest regards to Miss S and Mrs CEmma Stebbins, and probably Emma Crow Cushman (1839–1920), wife of Cushman’s nephew and adopted son Edwin Charles Merriman “Ned“ Cushman (1838–1909), m. 1861. Your loving / Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [28 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Annan, 28 Aug. 1862. MS: NLS 607.593B. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: You must put up with an infinitessimal note today dear!

I have had to compose a letter to Miss Bromley which has taken about all the writing faculty out of me for this morning! and JaneJean Aitken. is coming up the road at this moment to spend the day! and I have had nothink from Chelsea today, to inspire me (of course you couldnt forsee I should be still here), and tho’ I did get a fair quantity of sleep last night thank goodness! it wasn’t sleep of a very refreshing sort—and I feel today, to tell the truth “badly“!

So I made up my mind “in a moment of enthusiasm“Coterie speech. to have nothing to do
with Wooton Hall, for only a day, and at a mad cost of fatigue and nervous excitement; the journey occupying from ten in the morning (from Ednr) to nine at night to Alton)!!Alton, Staffordshire, the nearest railway stn. to Wootton Hall. and only to be accomplished by a change of trains— A Lady at CeppnochPresumably Elizabeth Gladstone of Capenoch; see JWC to TC, [19 Aug.]. who understands Bradshaw as well as I do, what shall I say? George Sand!George Sand, pseud. of Amandine Aurore Lucile Dudevant, b. Dupin (1804–76), French novelist whose writings JWC read extensively; i.e., Elizabeth Gladstone understood Bradshaw as well as JWC understood Sand’s novels. explained the whole route to me till my brain span round!
Better to go home at one wild rush in the dark,

figure.p: Caerlaverock Castle in 2008

docBody.p: JamieJames Carlyle. and Jamie Austin and Mary and I went last evening in a sort of dog cart to the Brow wellBrow Well, a chalybeate spring nr. Ruthwell, 2 mi. (3 km.) W of The Gill; see 34:6TC to JCA, 2 July 1858. (exactly like Dobbson’s well at Haddington,Dobson’s Well, a chalybeate spring ½ mi. (1 km.) W of Haddington. to the taste) and then on on, without exactly meaning it, to Carleveroc Castle!Caerlaverock Castle, built in the 1270s, about 7 mi. (11 km.) SSE of Dumfries; see oppabove. I dont think it was altogether from having heard my Mother rave about it that I found it out of sight the beautifulest ruin I ever saw in this world! We did not reject the key (as you did)TC drove past Caerlaverock Castle Sept. 1846 (see 21:39TC to JWC, 2 Sept. 1846) and July 1856 (see 31:144TC to JAC, 30 July 1856), and rode past July 1858 (see 34:89TC to JWC, 31 July 1858). but went all thro and about it, and I found there the solution of a piece of mysterious family biography, which my Mother and my Uncle had sought in vain during thirty years.Presumably JWC’s maternal uncle John Welsh of Liverpool; mystery unexplained. I will tell you about it when I come.
It was a long drive however and rather exposed—and I will keep at home today—to be fit for returning to Holme Hill tomorrow—

Poor Jamie looked so vexed about not being able to take me to Scotsbrig, and so anxious about Jenny. She is wrongWith menstrual difficulties; Jenny’s difficulties were at least partly with irregular periods; TC to JAC, 13 Sept. 1862. as girls get sometimes Mary tells me—so I hope it will pass as with Sarah and MariaPresumably Cheyne Row servants Sarah Piggott, with the Carlyles Sept. 1860–June 1861, and Maria Chamberlayne, with them since July 1861. and others I have known
docBody.name: JWC

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 29 Aug. Addr: Dr Russell’s / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 29 Aug. 1862. MS: NLS 616.567. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dear Goody of my life, I hope you have got safe to Thornhill again; and got a little instalment of better sleep, and rest to your poor nerves before Edinr! But I was thankful abundantly to hear this morning of yr considerable tho’ bad sleep at The Gill;—any considerable sleep must have left you badly next day. I shd not have expected you wd like Caerlaverock to such a degree: the “finest ruin“; ah, by no means,—but there are memories connected. The drive, home or thither, with Solway & Cumberland sweeping far and aloft on flank, is magnificent, along that innocent moor-road.For TC’s description of the surrounding views, see 13:193TC to RMM, 19 July 1841.— I am sorry and concerned to hear of poor Jenny at Scotsbrig: she is a bit nice lassie;—and anything happening to her wd be such a blow to poor Jamie, who has suffered many. I hope we shall have better news soon.

You are wise, surely, not to think of the “Lark,“ on those terms; but to plunge home by a coup-de-main [direct assault],—if there is to be plunging, and forced-marching, at all. I counted that with Scotsbrig for a stage from Edinr, and one not very long ride thro’ Manchester, you might have done it, and made good the circuit by a rest at Wooton amid Lark-music better or worse: but a whole day of it,—oh, no! no!—

I slept too little (till after six, howr, and know what ails me) last night and this morning:—and am not worth my salt (at those cramp Proofs, whh have fallen quite perverse at the wrong moment): I at one time thot of rushing off to Fetter Lane (to scold the Printer, and get a little exercise): I contind however; & all that I have done is to take a bigger sheet for Goody,—and scribble it full of nothing at all. Be content! Here are Letters for you to read,—by way of supplement.

The “James Young“Rev. James Young (1800–1865), Free Church minister, sent TC his new edn. of James Caldwell, The Countess of Mar’s Arcadia or Sanctuary: Containing Morning and Evening Meditations for the Whole Week (Edinburgh, 1862; originally pbd. 1625); see TC to JY, 8 Sept. he of the black borders, is possibly known to yr Aunts. His little Book (very small, ill printed, and heavy-boarded) is not bad of its kind; but contains very little upon Ancestor Welsh,John Welsh or Welch (1568 ?—1622); JWC believed he was one of her paternal ancestors; see 32:13JWC to RMM, 17 Oct. 1856, and 34:137JWC to HL, 17 Aug. 1858. and nothing that one did not know before. It cost twopence, and the fash of wrapping; so I keep it here: my calculatn is, You will probably on returning, make a Gift of it,—it and a fat
vol. of Sermons “by Jabez Bunting,“Jabez Bunting (1779–1858; ODNB), Wesleyan Methodist minister; Sermons, 2 vols., ed. William Lockhart Thornton (1861–62); perhaps TC was sent the 2d vol. whh has just come to me, and which I will cheerfully contribute for you,—to Aunt Anne.The Welsh aunts were evangelical Presbyterians. To whom give my best regards any way.— He of the Yellow Envelope, “Dixon,“ is the Sunderland Cork-cutter:Thomas Dixon; see JWC to TC, [27 Aug.]. his destinatn was instantaneous fire.

My PrussiansKarl Wilhelm von Willisen, with an unidentified companion. came last night, having given unintelligible warning.
