Maria made the usual illuminatn, usual display of tea (and expended 3d for cream), but they drank, tho’ with professed joy, only one cup each; and our sole entertaint was talk. Really very good, rational, knowing, and far more instructive than usual,—on the old Genl’s part especially, who is a fine old grey lively figure; abt my own age, 6 inches shorter, and twice as thick. They are off for good. I sent the brace of Birds to Chorley.John Rutter Chorley.

There was something else to say,—was not there? If so I have forgotten it, Maria suddenly appearing with the cry that haunts you!JWC had complained to TC about his reports of Maria’s announcement of “dinner“ in several letters; see JWC to MC, [21 Aug.]. Adieu, Dearest.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: Dim day, without sun; wind east, and rather coolish

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [29 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea London. PM: Thornhill, 29 Aug. 1862. MS: NLS 607.593C. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p:
All right today! Dear, or pretty nearly so!— I do not know if you would divine, from my notekin of yesterday, that it was written in “a state of mind“;Coterie speech; see 23:70JWC to HW, 16 July 1848. but it was!— I had got up with a sore throat, unnatural depression of spirits, and other symptoms of a bad cold! “Horrible was the idea to me!”Coterie speech; see 18:83JWC to TC, 25 June 1844.—what was going to become of me if I were laid up away from my home; even tho’ I had left the key of the tea caddy!—and the worst was, that I had to keep these destracting apprehensions all to myself! Only, when it came to arranging about another drive; I had to own myself afraid of the exposure. — But it had
been settled the previous night that we were to drive to Margaret’s,Mary Austin’s da. Margaret living at Ernhirst farm; see TC to JAC, 1 Dec. 1861. and Mary was evidently vexed at my refusal, tho’ too well-bred to say much. And just then the sun burst out into a perfect glory! and I thought perhaps the drive, after all, with sufficient wrapping, might improve my spirits at least; and we went, and I came in better rather than worse for it; took more porridge and milk; went to bed at eleven; and actually slept—off and on—till seven; and now, having breakfasted, I find myself with a sound throat, calmed nerves, and spirits up to the occasion!
“Thanks God“!Coterie speech; Mazzini’s expression; see 30:209JWC’s Journal, 1 Nov. 1855.— We dropt JaneJean Aitken. at Ruthwell just in time for the train.

She showed me that most provoking legal document,See TC to JCA, 27 Aug. and gave me to understand that you were required to pay the whole 100£ yourself; till I made out from the letter that you were only one of a Committee required to pay it!— It seemed to me yesterday, in my nervous fit, quite a distracting business!—today it seems only a distracted business.— To the best of my recollection; you sent no answer to the application for a subscription; and then a paper was sent to you with a list of the Committee your own name therein; and you took no notice of that either.— am I right?— if so, they cannot surely make you pay for not protesting merely? But even if they can, legally; it will be no great expence 100£ among so many. not more than you would have given as a subscription, if they had behaved themselves. The Dr will manage it all without further annoyance to you, I hope; and it will be quite a godsend of a little “job of work“ for him!John A. Carlyle was often called on by TC and his family (in particular James Carlyle Jr.) for help and advice.

Every thing seems going on well here—except indeed that the parlour ceiling has fallen off in two places “breaking one of the strong chairs all to roons (?)“!— I have tried to keep my head always under on[e] of the places already stript!! You see the “workmen“ are no better in Scotland than in London! The girls look all healthy and handsome and useful. Jamie Austin in “an auld coat o’ the Drs“ and a whitish wide-a-wakeA wide-brimmed, low-crowned felt hat, of a kind that TC also usually wore; see 37:43TC to LS, 19 Nov. 1860. of his own is handsomer and more member-of-Parliament like than I ever saw him! Mary too seems well and hearty—in spite of the wrinkles, but beside Mary, one can never think of anything but just her kindness, and instinctive good breeding.

And now I must go and pack up my night things &c; for I must be at the station by twelve. Mrs Russell is warned to meet me with the carriage. What a
luck I hadnt settled to start from Scotsbrig for Edinr—as I wasnt to see Scotsbrig!
I am wondering if you sent any word for me to Scotsbrig—See TC to JWC, 27 Aug. at least you will have written to Thornhill surely?
Your next letter had best be addressed to Craigenvilla Morningside Edinr.
I shant be long away now—
docBody.name: JWC

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [30 Aug.]. MS: NLS Acc. 7864. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:112–13.
div3.head:
JWC
TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.p: In the first place; God bless you! and yours!
Secondly I am “all right,”Coterie speech. or pretty nearly so!

Thirdly I forward the proof-sheet of Mrs Oliphants Book The Life of Edward Irving (1862). which I promised—and something else, which was not promised, a photograph of my interesting self! taken by a Thornhill Hairdresser!Thomas Douglas; see 37:109 JWC to MR, 1 Feb. 1861
. For the photograph, see 178 above ; for the reverse of Douglas’s photograph, see 179 above . And not so very bad, it strikes me, as photographs go! This last blessed item of my Sending is intended as a present to your Husband—“all to himself”! (as the children say)

figure.p: Jane Welsh Carlyle, by Thomas Douglas, August 1862
Reverse of Thomas Douglas’s photograph of Jane Welsh Carlyle

docBody.p: A letter from Mr C to me was forwarded from Scotsbrig to the Dr and given to me at the station—and another letter from Mr C awaited me at Thornhill—a very attentive Mr C really!

I have no time to spare for writing more than the absolutely needful— Six letters by post this morning most of them needing immediate answer! and we are to drive to Morton CastleAnother picturesque ruin, Morton Castle, about 4 mi. (6.5 km.) N of Thornhill, originally built in the 13th cent., was destroyed, rebuilt, and destroyed again several times. before dinner
God keep you all well and mindful of me till I come again!
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [31 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 1 Sept. 1862. MS: NLS 607.593D. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:263–64, inc. Quot: Hansons, NE 501. The envelope has two 1 pence stamps, presumably because JWC enclosed two letters.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: There will be no time for writing tomorrow, Dear; so I shall write a few lines now, and leave them to be put in before post-time tomorrow: the very slit being closed,The post box opening. for the better observance of Sunday!

You would see, or might have seen, by the postmark on my Friday’s letter, that I had got to Thornhill. At the Dumfries Station, I had appointed Jane to meet me; rather than be stopping between trains in Dumfries again; and she came, attended by James Aitken and the Dr, and from the last I received your note (to Scotsbrig) which had been forwarded by Jamie that morning to him! Jenny was said to be rather better. The letter addressed here awaited me, and was the best possible welcome.

One of the letters you had inclosed was from Mrs Tomline to announce the game “that in case of my being from home I might perhaps wish to give orders that it should be given away“— In such uncertainty, people should really pay the carriage of the game they fire off at one!— The other letter was from Louisa Baring asking me to “fulfil my promise“ and come to her on the 8th! Don’t she wish she may get me!Coterie speech; see 29:307TC to JCA, 11 May 1855. She says Lady A is returned home! and Mrs Tomline says she had had a letter from Lady A, two days before, inviting them to go to her!!— I was going to add; “how are these accounts to be reconciled—and in the act of writing, the explanation flashes on me!— The invitation wouldn’t be to Brahan as I had taken it from preliminary words about Brahan, but to the Grange!— Have you seen them, then? or heard from them? She has never written a word of answer to my Two last letters.

Oh! so long as I remember it!—please send me an autograph that Mrs Russell wants for a LadyUnidentified.— It would come straighter addressed to herself—but if you dont like inclosing it in a blank cover, and at the same time dont like to write a line with it, just send it to me at Morningside.
I have been rather better at sleeping since my return from the Gill; and the “Chill“ passed off without “consequences“!

Yesterday we drove to Morton Mains,Morton Mains, farm near Morton Castle, family home of JWC’s maternal grandfather, Walter Welsh; see Reminiscences 118 and 122–30. Walter Welsh had at least two brothers, John (b. 1741) and William (b. 1748). The castle and adjoining properties belonged to the dukes of Buccleuch. and Castle. I couldnt get up a sentiment
about it, tho’ the Birth place of my Grandfather Walter and all his Brothers. It is so completely ducalized now! PenfillanHome of JWC’s paternal grandfather, John Welsh; see JWC to TC, [15 Aug.]. which I can see at any moment I choose to lift my eyes, is more pathetic for me by far.

What a pity about that young scamp! Such wretches do so much harm to ones benevolent feelings towards “others“— You may read the page in a shocking bad handwriting torn from “his wife’s letter“ by that dreadful young Skirving you once saw,Unclear whether JWC referred to an unidentified “young scamp“ or to Robert Scot Skirving (1821–1900; see 21:208JWC to RSS, 11 May 1847), farmer of Camptown, Haddington, and son of David Skirving (ca. 1777–1848) and Margaret Lindsay Skirving; see JWC to TC, [19 Aug.]. TC had met Skirving once, in London in 1847, when they had argued; see Ritchie 315–16. and inclosed in some stuff of his own, written on the Bank (Dr Russells Bank) counter on his way to the train—which he all but missed in consequence; and actually did leave his purse on the counter behind him!!— If you care to see how you are “appreciated“ by an East-Lothian farmers wifeRobert Skirving’s wife, m. 1852, was Elizabeth (Leila), b. Owen (ca. 1823–74).—!
Madame Venturi you will certainly read for the letter is charming Keep it safe for me—I havnt copied the address. and now God bless you
docBody.name: J W C

div3.sourceNote: JWC-WM[WMAN], [31] Aug. MS: Mantell. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by JWC’s departure for Edinburgh 1 Sept.
div3.head: JWC TO WALTER MANTELL

docBody.p: Your letter has just reached me amidst the “Woods and Wilds“See John Home, Douglas, A Tragedy (Edinburgh, 1792) line 1. of my Native Land—when I am on the point of starting for Edinr—with something like a dozen letters requiring immediate answer.

So I take a very small bit of paper, on which to write all you need for the moment; and will forward it to Dilberoglue; who for the rest knows that MargaretMargaret Sullivan, the Carlyles’ former servant; see JWC to IES, [ca. 22 June]. is no longer in my keeping.

She left me of her own accord some three months ago. and reappeared I am told at a hairdressers in Bond Street.Unidentified. Jewsbury wrote to Mantell, 22 July: “Kee [George Cooke] has heard tidings of Margaret tell Ellen she has got a place at a hair dresser’s in Bond Street. I fancy her leaving Mrs Carlyle was a case of ‘puddings every day’— She wanted to go back to more muddle than she got at no 5 Cheyne Row“ (MS: Mantell). The address known to Mrs Pullen.Rebecca Pullen (b. ca. 1799), owner of the lodging house, 47 Mount St., where Cooke lived and Margaret Sullivan had previously worked; see 37:164JWC to JGCO, 7 May 1861.
If she had chosen to stay with me I should have been glad—for she was a nice little Servant.

Why she left I dont know It seemed a very mysterious affair! She cried the whole day she gave me warning and spoke wildly of drowning herself in the Serpentine! I never had the least quarrel with her. Perhaps she didnt get on with the other Servant. I dont know,—I never could understand Margaret’s motives, or feelings or intentions, or anything about her, except that she was a nice, clever little servant!

If George Cooke said she was deceitful and told lies, lots of them! I am afraid he said nothing that wasn’t true of her! She lived a year beside me, and I understood her less and less every month—but her deceit and lies seemed her own affair not mine.For Margaret’s deceitfulness, see 37:185JWC to MR, 16 July 1861. In her dealings with me, as a servant, I hadn’t a fault to find with her, Except that she required more supervision than it suited me to give.
I should think it the best that could befal her to be taken away from the Pullens and disreputable acquaintances she associated with in London.
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lord A[LOA], 31 Aug. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LORD ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
Dear Lord Ashburton,—It is long since I began to hope some Note from The Grange, or Brahan, might drop into my mouth, with some notice how you were. I fancy you to be at The Grange, all this while, but have no certainty; and as to health &c, of you and the Tiny JewelThe Ashburtons’ da., Mary Florence Baring. there or elsewhere, I have no hint whatever, nor can get any in this empty state of the Town. My Lady, from Brahan, sent me a pretty Note,Lady Ashburton wrote to TC, 9 Aug., from Brahan: “Eternity seems so near—& the world so far away—& the world can Never be the same again to me, once her great Love has left it—it already seems to me colder, & more desolate—for she is more in another world already than in this—I cannot tell you the sadness & agony of this time—this taking the last look on everything—which has been hitherto part of one’s Life— I wish you had known her, you would have loved me better, for having known her—I always see you now with such a look of misery as there was on your face for some minutes the last night you dined at Bath Ho. Your thoughts had gone far away, to something that made you utterly sad—& they kept you there— Do you know that look has haunted me? I wondered if the Wife saw it. Give her my kindest love.“ but nothing on those points; I have always been (very impudently) hoping she might send me something more,—tho’ I never had the heart to answer anything, or intrude upon her sacred sorrows
yonder;Lady Ashburton’s mother, Mary Stewart-Mackenzie, was dying. and know not now whether she is yonder or not. My Wife went off for Scotland (Dumfrieshire, to return by Edinr) three weeks ago; I expect her back by the end of this week: not from her either do I get any tidings of My Lady or you. Three words from yr own hand, if you please;—merely the historical points.

I have been steady here in my garret, very busy with Proofs &c; companion-less as sparrow on the House Top;Cf. Ps. 102:7. all things,—“Brute of an Exhibitn“ (and especially the gaping blockheads hurled upon me by it), and indeed “Life at large,“ in its autumnal conditn physical and metaphorical,—looking rather ugly to me! I have got quite rid of Vol IV however (or shall do in a week); and see the Printer fairly into Vol V,—entering on the last long Hill we shall have to climb together. In 8 or 9 months I may be over the head of that too,—if my poor old sinews will still hold out. What a joy (or end of nigh deadly torment) to shake that vile harness off one’s back and poor neck and withers, to all Eternity!—

There was a very intelligt Prussian with me last week (Genl Willisen, King’s “Equerry,“ perhaps, or “Adjutt,“—much abt the King and acquainted with many things);—he was well worth seeing; and gave me hopes and lights abt Prussn Affairs.— Ruskin, in the Septr Fraser,John Ruskin, “Essays on Political Economy. Being a Sequel to Papers which appeared in the ‘Cornhill Magazine,’“ Fraser’s Magazine 66 (Sept. 1862): 265–80. has another valiant Article: shall I send it; are you there to read it?

The American affairs are getting quite hideous;—but will (after agonies enough) probably deliver the poor Country from a “Govt by Blackguards,“ at the long last!The same issue of Fraser’s contained Hiram Fraser, “North and South. The Controversy in a Colloquy“ (66:299–318). The “North“ lamented: “The night thickens; the storm increases; and our poor ship rolls heavily in the trough of the sea. The passengers are praying in the cabin, and the Pilot is trembling in the wheel-house. God of mercy, send us deliverance!” (66:318).
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 1 July [Sept.]. Addr: The Misses Welsh / Craigenvilla, Morningside / Edinburgh. PM: London, 1 Sept. 1862. MS: NLS 616.568. Hitherto unpbd. TC mis-dated July.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: My dear little Goody,—I seldom in my life have had such a day with Proofs as this (and Saty was only a shade better); I have already dined: “ye must just excuse us the day!”Coterie speech; see 7:199TC to MAC, 30 May 1834.

I did mean to have sent you an ample detail; but time surprised me on Saty;—yesterday had it not been for the Pharisean Sabbath at Edinr, I shd still have managed it (I tried by Dumfries, with Newspaper &c); but that foiled all my contrivances;—and here is where I am!

This morning I got a kind of fright. A Letter from Thornhill, and in Dr R’s hand: “Is my poor little Pilgrim fallen ill then!” I tear the thing open: nothing but, in a spotless sheet of paper, a very successful Photograph! Extremely like, indeed,—whh I interpreted to mean symbollically on Russel’s part: “She has left us this morning (Monday) for Edinr, and silently waves you adieu.“ A single word from him,—mere written day of departure, wd have been welcome as commentary! But accordg to my best guess, things are as above;—and I pray Heaven this may find you, Tuesday morning at yr Aunts’s, “refreshed with sleep“ (ah me), after such a day, as you will have had. Tomorrow I shall surely hear something.

Jean told me of her momentous Interview as you passed thro’ Dumfries; she says, on the road to Ernhirst, you kept them all amused with canty narratives &c (tho’ inwardly in wrestle with Cold)—a canty little Goody!— — I did nothing yesterday; saw nobody: a dim grimy day, very cold (as it still is, tho’ begun raining now);—in the evg, Allinghm ventured in, whh roused me to walk him out, & had no ill effect. He has found one to “change places with him“;William Allingham had worked for the customs service in Ballyshannon since 1855; in Sept. he exchanged his post for one in the London customs service (William Allingham, A Diary, ed. H. Allingham and D. Radford [1907] 79). and expects hencefth to be in London.— — The poor maid Sarah is going for Australia;Sarah Piggott; she left for Melbourne, Australia, soon after JWC’s return home; see JWC to MR, [28 Sept.]. came this day to take leave of you;—looked very douce and well (where I accidentally saw her), & I promised her good luck. No more, Dearest. Rest yrself. Write ThursoPresumably TC enclosed a letter from Sir George Sinclair of Thurso Castle. 2 words (if you like);—be patt, quiet;—and reappear safe! T. C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, 2 Sept. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Edinburgh, 2 Sept. 1862. MS: NLS 607.594A. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:113–14; Bliss, JWC 297–98 inc. Quot: Hansons, NE 500.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p:
Oh you stupid, stupid Good!JWC’s nickname for TC. Not to know my handwriting when you see it, at this time of day! It was I who directed that photograph, and posted it at
Thornhill on Saturday morning. I just turned my handwriting a little back, and sent it without a word; to puzzle you—forgetting that the post mark would betray where it came from. It was done by a Thornhill hairdresser; Mrs Russell and I got taken one day for fun; and if I had dreamt of coming out so well, I would have dressed myself better, and turned the best side of my face!For Douglas’s photograph of JWC, see 178JWC to MCA, [30 Aug.].

My departure from Nithsdale was like the partings of dear old long ago, before one had experienced that “time will teach the softest heart, unmoved to meet, ungrieved to part“ as “the immortal Mr Terrot once wrote!Charles Hughes Terrot (1790–1872; ODNB), bishop of Edinburgh, known to JWC since childhood, and who irritated her in adulthood; see 16:197–98JWC to JW, 15 June 1853. For Terrot’s verse, see 28:114–15JWC to KS, 20 April 1853. and then the journey thro’ the hills to that little lonely churchyard.“Crawford, where her mother’s grave is“ (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:113).— All that caused me so many tears, that today my eyes are out of my head, and I am sick and sore! and of course sleep was out of the question after such a day of emotion—when so ill to be caught at the best of times—and I have had just one hour of broken slumber (from five till six) and I was up at six yesterday morning.— So I mustn’t go after BettyBetty Braid. today—she would be too shocked with my looks!—Grace and I will take a short drive in an Omnibus (for a change)!Coterie speech; see 25:61JWC to TC, 7 April 1850.
Neither must I sit writing to you in detail—for my head spins round—and I could tell you nothing worth the effort of telling it
I left a letter to be posted at Thornhill yesterday.

So GaribaldiGiuseppe Garibaldi, Italian patriot. or, as a man in the carriage with me last evening was calling him Garri-Bauldy, is wounded and captured—already!— Lucky I should say! to spare the poor fellows he was leading to destruction!Garibaldi led a force of several thousand volunteers toward Rome with the intention of liberating it from papal rule. However, Napoleon III (Louis Napoleon [1808–73]), emperor of France from 1852, stationed French troops in Rome to guarantee the Papal States’ independence from Italy, and the Italian government was unwilling to intervene. On 28 Aug. Garibaldi and his troops were surrounded by government troops at Aspromonte, S Italy; he ordered his men not to fire against fellow Italians, and was himself shot in the thigh and left foot. After a brief imprisonment, Garibaldi was permitted to return to his home on the island of Caprera. Mazzini will be thankful—he must have reached Garibaldi; it is to be hoped he is not taken also—but he went with his eyes perfectly open to the madnessMazzini opposed Garibaldi’s plan and instead recommended an expedition to liberate Venice. He predicted that “if Garibaldi has to choose between two proposals, he is sure to accept the one that isn’t mine,“ but he collected funds from English friends in support of Garibaldi and left London, 25 Aug., to join him (Bolton King, Mazzini [1902] 201–2). Mazzini wrote to JWC, [19] Aug.: “No, I am not holding conferences with Garib; but I do not dissemble the fact that I am about doing so. Much as I deplore and find premature all this uproar, it is growing on Italian soil and is at the bottom responding to a sound feeling, that Rome is ours and neither Pope or Zouaves have any business there. That feeling is decidedly mine, and if I have done something towards it I feel partially responsible and bound to share in its palpable embodiment. … I go sadly: I do not feel fit for any task; neither morally nor physically. But I think I must try.“ He did not reach Garibaldi before the disaster of Aspromonte.—
Grace was waiting at the train for me, and instantly found me under my hat and feather! in the dark! Clever! she said it was by a motion of my hand.
They are all most kind—Elizabeth not so poorly as I expected to find her. Grace and Ann younger looking than last time. hair raven black! far blacker than mine.

Good by— I hope to sleep to night, for I will have a doze of Morphia now that I am near Duncan & FlockartDuncan, Flockhart & Co., Edinburgh chemists, founded 1833, manufacturers of opium substitutes and chloroform. and then I will be up to a better letter than this
I have left Grace to make out “the old goose““Some foolish letter to me“ (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:114); unidentified further.—and tell me the needful
docBody.name: JWC
docBody.note: Mazzini’s postscript, [19] Aug.: “You will find the photographs at Cheyne Row“; these are possibly the photographs of Mazzini in the Carlyle photograph albums, one (in vol. 1) of him standing by a table, with his head in his left hand, inscribed: “To Jane W. Carlyle / Gos. Mazzini“; the other (in vol. 4) inscribed “Gis. Mazzini“ (MS Collection, Carlyle, Butler Lib., Columbia Univ.).

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [2 Sept.]. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: Edinburgh, 2 Sept. 1862. MS: NLS 607.593E. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:115–16; A. Carlyle, NLM 2:264–66. Quot: Hansons, NE 501.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: Nature prompts me to write just a line; tho’ I am not up to a letter today—at least to any other letter than the daily one to Mr C, which must be written, dead or alive

Imagine! after such a tiring day; I never closed my eyes till after five this morning! and was awake again—for good—or rather for bad—before six struck!— My eyes are almost out of my head this morning—and—tell the Dr—or rather—dont tell him—I will have a doze of morphia tonight;Dr. Russell recently would not prescribe JWC morphine; see JWC to TC, [27 Aug.]. See also Malcolm Ingram, “The Carlyles and Opium,“ Carlyle Society Papers n.s. 22 (Edinburgh, 2009) 5–14.—am just
going in an Omnibus to Duncan & Flockart, for it!— It will calm down my mind for once—generally my mind needs no calming being sunk in apathy!

And this won’t do to go on!— Mr C writes this morning that he had received a letter in the handwriting of Dr Russell (!!!) (My own hand-writing slightly disguised) and “torn it open in a fright!!—thinking that the Dr was writing to tell I was ill! and found a photograph of me—“really very like indeed“ but not a word “from the Dr“ inside!— He took it as a sign that I was off! (Why? in all the world take it as that?) “but it would have been an aditional favour had the Dr written just a line!”
Grace was waiting at the Station for me, much to my astonishment—and discovered me at once—under the hat & feather actually!—she said by “a motion of my hand“!

The drains are all torn up at MorningsideThe houses in Morningside were originally built with cesspools. Work on removing open drains and installing sewers was “only now being completed“ (Dr. H. D. Littlejohn, Report on the Sanitary Conditions of the City of Edinburgh [Edinburgh, 1865] 115). and she was afraid I would not get across the rubbish in my cab without a pilot— They are all looking well I think—even Elizabeth Many friendly inquiries about you—and love to be sent
Oh my Dear my Dear! My head is full of wool! shall I ever forget those green hills and that lonely churchyard and your dear gentle face
Oh how I wish I had a sleep!
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

ps.p: The rootsJWC collected various plants to take home with her; see JWC to MR, [21 Sept.]. are all in the garden

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 2 Sept. Addr: Misses Welsh, Craigenvilla / Morningside / Edinburgh. PM: London, 2 Sept. 1862. MS: NLS 616.569. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Thanks, dear Goody; I got the pleasant Sunday Letter this morning (Russell must have had a chance on Dumfries, I think); and tho’ you do not yet say what day was the fixed Edinburgh one, I make no doubt it was yesterday; and will believe you to be there, better or worse. You wd have a most agitating day, poor little soul: Oh that Crawford Kirkyard; I never see it from the Railway but a whole world of things rush to mind, most sad and yet with a kind of blessing in them! I spent some strange hours there, long since, scraping
Letters right;TC went to Crawford, April 1842, when he copied out the inscriptions and borrowed a chisel and hammer to correct “one or two mistakes“ on the Welsh family gravestones; see 14:146TC to JWC, 14 April 1842; for the inscriptions, see 14:155–56TC to JWC, 19 April 1842. once afterwards I was there for one minute, hastily plucking a blade of withered grass for you; and that was the last time.TC stopped there briefly Sept. 1843; see 17:108TC to JWC, 2 Sept. 1843.— I do trust you have got some sleep. I am sorry there was no Letter lying for you, whh there shd have been. But I cd not manage it. Truly that Pharisean “Sabbath“ and mode of disarming Almighty wrath (by something better than the secret pour lui plaire [secret to please him]),“Ou que manger un hareng, / C’est un secret pour lui plaire?“; see “Epigram from the French,“ The Poems of Jonathan Swift, ed. Harold Williams (Oxford, 1937) 3:948–49. For TC’s note giving the French couplet, see 22:59JWC to TC, 11 Sept. 1847. it getting quite odious to me,—or inconvenient rather, for it has long been odious enough!

My Proofs have gone better today; so I have time for a deliberate Note, and even for a turn of walking after. The Proofs, if I continue diligt, will be done or well nigh, by the time you arrive: I shd then really like a bit of country, with holiday complete. I am not ill; but the interior does grumble,—begins to be weary of the treatt it experiences here! (Alas, there goes 3 o’clock, little time for walking, I shd think!) I have heard no whisper from any Ashburton; I wrote to him on Sunday (really anxious to know how he was); there may probably come something tomorrow or soon.

Never mind that foolish “Wallace-Mont“ thing; I care not a rush what becomes of it, and will never think of it more.— Parkes’sHenry Parkes. note (inclosed) will at least not fret you. His two Books are kindly meant;Presumably one was John Dunmore Lang, Notes of a Trip to the Westward and Southward, in the Colony of New South Wales (Sydney, 1862); see TC to HP, 15 Sept.; John Dun-more Lang (1799–1878; ODNB), Presbyterian minister and Australian politician, writer on emigration and colonization.—one of (beautifully bound, that one) is Peter Cunningham’s Book,Probably Peter Miller Cunningham, Two Years in New South Wales (1827); Cunningham (1789–1864; ODNB) was a Scottish naval surgeon and pioneer in Australia; see 8:82TC to JAC, 23 March 1835, and 98TC to MAC, 20 April 1835 (where TC mistakenly says that the book is about New Holland); brother of TC’s old friend Allan Cunningham (1784–1842; ODNB), poet and songwriter. whh I had already. This will be a nice gift for somebody.

The other night (Friday, I almost think) I was told on getting home, “Mrs Gilchrist been here; is in Mrs Chalmers’s, coming agn!” She did accordingly appear; consented to a cup of tea (one, with great dilution); and sat long and long over it,—till almost 10, I think. She looks infinitely better in health; quite composed, talks largely on “Blake,“ and seems to be still abundantly busied
with work on that.Anne Gilchrist was completing Alexander Gilchrist’s Life of William Blake, pbd. 1863; see TC to JWC, 29 Jan. She was “returning“ to her Mother’s;Henrietta Burrows lived at Earls Colne, Essex; see JWC to AG[AGIL], [6 Dec. 1861]. own House empty, and the Irelands gone to it,After her husband’s death Anne Gilchrist moved to Shottermill, Surrey, Feb. or March 1862, see JWC to AG[AGIL], [Feb.]; Edwin and Isabella Ireland were presumably staying in her house meanwhile.—you & I to go “next year“ &c &c.

Now, dear, rest yrself in the House of Friends for a day or two; don’t stir till yr bits of nerves are quiet agn. Then home to me, better than you went. Jenny at Scotsbrig is rumoured to be better. Mrs R’s Autograph—well here it is.See JWC to TC, [31 Aug.]. Adieu Dearest. T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 4 Sept. Addr: The Misses Welsh / Craigenvilla, Morningside / Edinburgh. PM: London, 4 Sept. 1862. MS: NLS 616.570. Pbd: Bliss, TC 357–58.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Nothing from Goody this morning,—tho’ I heard the bell from aloft, and made sure:—well, I will hope your poor Morphine has succeeded (in its sad way, poor little soul!), & that you are busy seeing friends, and doing Edinr with your best energy:—you got nothing either. Had I known the Morphine issue, I shd have wanted nothing. Take all pains you possibly can to be canny, to be quiet and well, what we have to call “well.“ Do not even predict when you are coming, till once you handily can. To me, to the inner man of me especially (for the Lasses are really careful abt the outward), it will be “the sooner the welcomer“: but, in all points, I wish you to follow what you find likeliest for being pleasant and profitable.

There has nothing come from The Grange yet; nor need it hurry. We can have a “week of country“ on our own basis well enough: or indeed, avoiding that horror of jumbling and squealing & of having oneself driven mad by railway tumult more or less,—7 idle days in the Town (Exhibitn Pictures &c &c) might do almost “quite as well“ (in DarwinianPresumably Erasmus Darwin. phrase)! I have still abt 7 Proof slips to do (very bad ones, mostly), then I am free for Rus [country] or Urbs [town].

Nothing has happened, nothing at all. Woolner came, and wasted one of my nights (monday, I think); Fritz galloped me yesterday on Wimbledon,Wimbledon Common.—it
is now darkish by the time I get home: dinner will have to change again before long.

Yesternight Ruskin’s servantFrederick Crawley (b. 1828), Ruskin’s valet until 1876, had been with him in Italy and Switzerland. came; had been, and then had waited; stept in to me at Tea:—a Message from Master; who is in Savoy not far from Geneva, moving himself as he has need to do. The poor Valet, tho’ he has no aitches or too many, seems to me a sensible loyal kind of fellow; and you know how comunicative he is. Master had grown decidedly better, ‘working on a fresco’ all the while, at Milan; but the heat became intolerable,—also there was a visit to be done in France (some of Rn Senior’s people, perhaps some “Claret“ man),John James Ruskin was a wine merchant. whh Master did not want. Master became quite languid; “cared nothing about the Halps, Sir; leant back in the Carriage,“ not raising his eye: at Geneva we staid 10 days; morning of departure having come, Master when I went up to say “Here is the Carriage,“ was pale, foredone, and cdn’t go. Dr is called for: “Chagrin, Monsr! Nothing immediately dangerous; but have a care, it is serious, and will be long in going, as it has been in coming.“— In brief, Rn is not coming till middle of Novr;Ruskin left Milan at the beginning of Aug. Despite promising his mother he would return to England for her birthday, 2 Sept., he decided to stay in Switzerland and rented two houses in Mornex, nr. Geneva. He wrote in his diary, 7 Aug.: “Resolve to have some more Turners and if I live, some of my own way at last. Stay here accordingly“ (Tim Hilton, John Ruskin: The Later Years [2000] 42). and then “only for a week,“—tho’ valet hopes, it will be for longer. “Chagrin, Sir,“ he said; doing the nasal not ill. Old Mr R. is “a great deal better“: still in the Norwood Hôtel,John James Ruskin suffered from kidney stones; they were staying at the Queens Hotel, Norwood (Reflections of a Friendship, ed. Virginia Surtees [1979] 196–97). their house full of Foreign Exhibitioners, &c &c. I mean to try and persuade Rn to a Lodging in London, if we saw him. Adieu Goody dear.— T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A[LLA], 4 Sept. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: You are very kind to write again, in those terms. It was only yesterday I heard by accidt that you were back from Brahan,—leaving things in better posture there than you found them,—and that Ld A. was very well. Let us be thankful, thankful!

There is no doubt but a few days of The Grange in this bright weather wd do me a great deal of good! Or even in the worst weather, with green fields,
free air and kindly quiet round one; and honest Forest-trees for company (were there nothing better), instead of street Cabs, and a Canaille [rabble] of Exhibitioners,—worse luck to them! “A great deal of good“:—and it is equally certain that I mean, and have been meaning, positively to try. And in a very short time now, since I hear that it suits.

Tomorrow or on the instant I cannot quite come;—but almost. I am on the fag-end of a sad mass of litter; and will now work with double diligence: I will try hard agt Tuesday next; not sooner, I fear; but then, if it prove possible. My Train is always that orthodox old-established one whh leaves this abt 1 p.m. and lands one at The Grange for Tea or sooner. If you hear nothing more, I may be expected on Tuesday:—alas, my rubbish is capricious in quality, and cannot quite be counted on; but I will do my very best; and surely I am anxious enough to come!—

My Wife, you perhaps know, is still in Scotland; at Edinbr, perhaps across to Fife, seeing cousins;—and does not fix a day for returning. It will serve her right (and indeed be very welcome to her, I know) to find me at The Grange instead of here.

Addiscombe Carrier,Unidentified further. punctual as the moon, has just come; brings me such butter, such cream,—whh I take all to myself, while housekeeping in single capacity! Thanks to some people.— — I know this cannot reach you till Saturday; tho’ I did not quite, at starting.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 4 Sept. Addr: 140. Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: London, 5 Sept. 1862. MS: NLS 553.244. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:470.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—It was a glad surprise to me to find that you were here;Neuberg had been in Berchtesgaden, Bavaria, for his health; see TC to JAC, 6 Aug. I hope, on no troublesome errand?
Come on Sunday Evg; you will find me, just finishing Vol. iv;—very weak and weary; but in prospect of running off to The Grange for a week of holiday.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [4 Sept.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Edinburgh, 4 Sept. 1862. MS: NLS 607.594B. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:116–18.
div3.head:
JWC
TO TC

docBody.p:
“Two afflictions make a consolation”Coterie speech: see 8:147 TC to JAC, 15 June 1835
.—of a sort!—The disappointment of not receiving the usual Good words from you this morning comforted my conscience at least, for having failed in my own writing yesterday. I could figure you eating your breakfast at Cheyne Row, without any letter from me, with no particular pang of remorse; when I was eating my breakfast here with only the direction on Orley Farm TC apparently sent an installment of Anthony Trollope’s Orley Farm (probably the Sept. one) to JWC in Edinburgh; see TC to JWC, 2 July . for a relish to my indifferent tea! It was partly the Morphia that hindered me yesterday, and partly the rain; the Morphia which answered the end capitally—procured me the only really sound sleep I have had since I went on my travels—made me feel too listless for writing before going to Betty’s; and the walk thro’ the rain to the cab when we returned made me too tired for writing after—in time for the Morningside post.Letter collection was three times a day in Morningside, 10:30 a.m.,2 p.m., and 6:30 p.m.

Well! I have seen Betty! and Betty has seen me!Cf. “I saw the moon / and the moon saw me, / God bless the moon / and God bless me” (nursery rhyme). Poor Dear! It wasnt so “good a joy” as it might have been! for Ann and Grace wouldn’t in their kindness let me go by myself. And the three of us were too many for the wee house! and for Bettys nerves which aren’t what they were— But she made the best of that, as of every thing else! “It’s weel they’re sae kind to ye, Dear! and its richt!” she said, during a minute we were alone together. She gave me the “stokns” (beautiful fine white ones) and a little packet of peppermint lozenges were lying beside them “in case I ever cam”!— Dear kind soul! her heart is the same warm loyal heart! but these seven years of nursing have made terrible alterations on her! her hair is white as snow, and her face so fined away, that it looks as if one might blow it away like powder. I dont think she can stand much longer of it! George (poor patient “Gorg”) is neither better nor worse—his mind not weakened at all I think which is wonderful! Old Braid keeps himself in health by much working in his garden which is prolific. “Sic a crapp o’ gude peas, Dear! Oh if I could hae sent Mr Carlyle a wee dish o’ them to cheer him up when he was his lane poor man! ”— —“Oh Dear!” she said again catching my arm excitedly, “Wud ony body believe’t? He—yer Gude man direks punch till us every week! his ain sell! to sick as us!”

Mr Braid didn’t know me at the door when I went in the first, and when I taxed him with it, he said “How should I ken ye? ye lookit like a bit skelt o’ a Lassie, wi that daft wee thing a-tap o’ yer heed!”Probably the same hat JWC wore in Thomas Douglas’s photograph; see above.

figure.p: Jane Welsh Carlyle’s hat Detail from photograph by Thomas Douglas, August 1862

docBody.p:
I mean to get home please God the beginning of next week. I cannot fix the day just yet, being “entangled in details”Coterie speech; see 27:305 JWC to TC, 25 Sept. 1852
. with the Auchtertool people—

I have seen nobody here but the Braids— Indeed there is nobody I much care to see! It is a most uninteresting place Edinr become! I would like to spend an hour at Haddington in the dark. But I “dont see my way” to that. I was glad to hear that Scotsbrig Jenny was getting over her bad fitJohn A. Carlyle wrote to TC, 1 Sept.: “Reports of some illness of Jenny had made me uneasy. … I learn from John [Jenny’s brother] that she is nearly quite well again.” —
Grace is just come in and sends her regards.
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 5 Sept. MS: NLS 525.95. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
My Dear Brother,—I thank you very much for yr little Note; & wish greatly you wd send me another from Scotsbrig; being much concerned abt my little Jenny,See JWC to TC, [4 Sept.]. and anxious to hear (if such be happily the case) that she is in a good way again.— My hurry at this moment, is immense: but I cd not let the
Sunday intervene, witht some kind of word to you more or less. How Jenny really is in yr opinn: that is the most interestg news you can send.

Jane is still abt Edinr; talks of Auchtertoole,Thus in MS. of Haddington &c, but promises to be home “early next week.“ I am over head and ears in difficult Proofs,—pretty well thro’ now: and have undertaken (provisorily) “to be at The Grange, Tuesday next“! Where Jane might join me for a week &c &c. I now fear the remainder of Proofs will be tougher on me than expected; and that it will hardly be “Tuesday.“ You shall hear, or Jean shall if I don’t know yr Address.

Neuberg called yesterday, did not see me. Home from Berchtesgn Country, “only for a day or two,“—something in the Shop,Neuberg helped run his late brother-in-law Adolph Frankau’s business, “patentees, manufacturers and importers of pipes and fancy goods“ (1862 PO Directory). I suppose.

One “Wesley Thomas“ (the Revd) of Leek in Staffordshire has sent me the PurgatorioJohn Wesley Thomas (1798–1872; ODNB), Methodist minister, sent TC his trans. of The Trilogy; or Dante’s Three Visions. Part II Purgatorio, or the Vision of Purgatory (1862). part (in blank verse)It was in the terza rima of the original, not blank verse. of [what he]Words missing because MS cut away to remove TC’s signature on reverse. calls the “Trilogy of Dante,“—the Inferno done, I suppose, already.Thomas translated Inferno, or the Vision of Hell, 1859, and Paradiso, or the Vision of Paradise, 1866. He seems to be a man of small moment; but I have only read lines here & there of his Prefatory matter (goes upon orthodoxy, RosettiGabriele Pasquale Giuseppe Rossetti (1783–1854), prof. of Italian literature, King’s College, London, 1831–47, had written on the antipapal significance of Dante. Thomas believed that Dante’s Christianity was closer to that of modern Protestantism than Catholicism; he insisted: “[W]e make … allowance for Dante … on account of the age in which he lived and the circumstances by which he was environed, we are bound to admit his perfect sincerity as a member of the Church in which he was brought up, and to give him credit for a degree of freedom from the debasing influence of superstition to which few, if any, had then attained.“ He continued: “[W]hile, in the external and literal sense, Dante speaks with high respect of the Papal Chair, and of those by whom it was occupied … the allegorical sense appears intended as a covert but severe censure of the pride, unfaithfulness, avarice, and other corruptions of the Papacy, and its systematic hostility to Italian freedom and unity“ (Purgatorio xi, xxvi). The book is dedicated “To Garibaldi and the people of Italy.“ &c &c),—and shall probably never read more, even of that.— — If it be in the very smallest a wish of yrs to see the Book, say, and it comes.John A. Carlyle completed his trans. of Dante’s Inferno 1847; Chapman & Hall pbd. it 1849; see 22:5TC to AC, 3 July 1847, 23:190TC to JCA, 6 April 1848, and 24:16TC to AC, 6 April 1849.

closer.salute: My affectionate regards to Jamie, to Jenny too poor soul, and the good John. Yours ever,Signature cut away.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [5 Sept.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Edinburgh, 5 Sept. 1862. MS: NLS 607.594C. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:119–21.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Thanks Dear! Here is a nice little letter this morning, which has had the double effect of satisfying my anxieties, and delivering me from “Prayers.“ I ran up to my room with it, and shut myself in, and when I issued forth again Prayers were well over!! What luck!— My Aunts are as kind to me as they can be, all three of them, and they exert themselves, beyond their strength, I can see, to make my visit pleasant to me; but still I am like a fish out of water in this element of religiosity;At times, JWC found her aunts’ religiosity irritating; cf. 31:188 and 33:38. or rather, like a human being in water—and the water hot!

I am glad you have heard from ‘my Lady’Lady Ashburton. In his letter to JWC, 4 Sept., TC had not yet heard from the Ashburtons; but since he heard from Lady Ashburton the same day (see TC to Lady ALLA, 4 Sept.), he presumably inserted her letter into the envelope with TC to JWC, 4 Sept. at last. I was beginning to not understand it! to fear either you or I must have in some way displeased her! If you could bring yourself to go to the Grange at once! I shouldnt at all mind your being away when I arrived!—should rather like to transact my fatigues and my acclimatizing “in a place by mysell.“Coterie speech; see 28:182TC to JAC, 1 July 1853. And we might still have the ‘sacred week’ of idling and sight-seeing, (an exceptional week in our mutual life, it would be!) after your return.

I find I cannot get off from Auchtertool. I shouldn’t dislike a couple of days there (tho’ many days couldn’t be endured!) if it werent for that “crossing“! But, like it or not, I must just “cross“ and recross! Maggie is returned; Walter has put off joining Alex at Crawfurd;Alexander Welsh, Walter’s brother, fishing at Crawford, Lanarkshire; see JWC to MR, [8 Sept.]. they are all expecting me; and the only expedient by which I could have avoided visiting them without offence to their kind feelings—viz: inviting them all to spend a day with me here cannot be “carried out“—for “reasons which it may be interesting not to state“!Coterie speech; originally used humorously by TC against himself; see 13:240TC to JWC, 2 Sept. 1841.—after all, I have no kinder relative or friend in the world than poor Walter! Every summer, when invitations were not so plenty, his house, and all that is his has been placed at my disposition It is the only House where I could go, without an invitation, at any time that suited myself; and, considering all that, I must just “cross“ tomorrow; in the intention however of staying only two days. I should have gone to day but for a letter of Walter’s “missent to Liberton,“To the Braids, in Liberton. and so not reaching me in time.

I am now going off to Town with Grace, to get her Photograph taken “for Jeanies Book“;Probably the “photograph Book“ JWC bought April 1861; see 37:140JWC to IEB, 3 April 1861. she says, but I doubt the singleness of the alledged motive! I shall call for Mrs SterlingPresumably Christian Stirling (sister of her old friend Thomas Erskine) in Charlotte Sq., where they often stayed; see 37:256TC to JJR, 29 Oct. 1861. For an 1855 photograph of her, see 31:186TC to JWC, 21 Aug. 1856.—who else? alas my old friends are “all wed away“!“Flowers of the Forest“ (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:120). For the song, see 37:245JWC to MR, 14 Oct. 1861.

I return the letter which seems to me perfectly serious. and rather sensible only what of Shakespear?Either William Shakespeare (1564–1616; ODNB) or Shakespear the Chelsea milkman; see 35:65TC to JAC, 5 April 1859.— “Shakespear never did the like o’t“!Coterie speech; an analogy with the phrase “Tishon [Titian] never did the like o’t“; see 27:280JWC to TC, 12 Sept. 1852.
Address here. I shall find it (the letter) on my return from Auch[t]ertool,Letter “t“ omitted. if I am not here before it.
It was thunder and lightning and water-spouts yesterday. terrible for laying the crops surely! Yours ever
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [7 Sept.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Kirkcaldy, 8 Sept. 1862. MS: NLS 607.594D. Pbd: Bliss, JWC 298–99.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p:
Another move you see! am not I, like the man’s watch, “a speedy little goer“?Untraced.— How very glad I shall be now, when I am at home, and may run down!— However I am bound to say I never “crossed“ as easily! There wasnt a ripple on the water; and I carried no luggage. I saw from the deck of the boat old John and ‘Donald’John Whyte (b. ca. 1795), Auchtertool servant (see 35:200JWC to TC, 14 Sept. 1859), and his horse. and the dog-cart—and ran against MaryMary Welsh. on the pier, neither of us at first recognising the other. Mary not knowing me in a hat, and I not knowing Mary in the immense amount of atoms she has accumulated! She is as fat as—anybody you ever saw! as fat as the Princess Mary!!Princess Mary Adelaide (1833–97; ODNB), philanthropist, second cousin to Queen Victoria.— There were here two Lady-visitors which—(I should say who)—had been
kept secret from me, in case I shouldn’t come, knowing of them—a daughter of old Mr Leishman’s and a grown up grand-daughter.James Leishman (1782–1839), partner with JWC’s uncle John Welsh in Leishman & Welsh, coppersmiths and brass founders, Liverpool; see 11:15TC to JAC, 4 Feb. 1839. His da. and grandda. not further identified.
But it didn’t matter for all the time!

But I must be dressed for dinner—luggage or no luggage, it seemed! and dressed I was with a vengeance! A black lace gown, all trimmed over with black velvet and gold braid (!) and a pink wreath on my head!! The furnishing of the attire and the putting it on me was little Mary’s work and you may form some idea of her width from the fact that her gown was too long for me!! Mary has been acting as housekeeper for the last seven months, in Maggies absence,Maggie Welsh was in London from mid-April until early June, and then went to visit friends in Devonshire; see JWC to MR, [5 June]. and has not yet resigned the seals of office. And a capital little Housekeeper she seems to make! so far as comfort goes—but I dare say it is “d—n the expense“A phrase previously associated by JWC with TC; see 12:303JWC to MAC, 27 Oct. 1840, and 17:231JWC to JW, 2 Jan. 1844. with her!— She had a fire in my room last night—(her own large room, which she had given up to me,—“the only mortal on Earth that she would have turned out for“; she said) and a perfect illumination of wax candles (equal to Maria’sMaria apparently used a lot of candles; see TC to JWC, 29 Aug.)! Maggie’s face looked so long at sight of it; that I hastened to assure her I would extinguish all the wax candles but one, so soon as Mary had brought me my arrowroot which she was preparing, herself; but in the mean time I didnt like to thwart her, “Oh said Maggie, it is very cheerful, the blaze, certainly!

I intend returning to Morningside on Tuesday, and till then I shall get no letter! If one by any chance arrived on Monday it wasn’t to be forwarded; for fear of crossing me on the road. But on Tuesday I hope to hear you are off to the Grange! now don’t be boggling at it! It will do you good even if it were disagreeable; and—that it wont be she is so anxious to please you in every way— I will write to Maria when to expect me home
docBody.name: J W C

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWT, 8 Sept. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN WESLEY THOMAS

docBody.p:
I have recd your Translation of Dante’s Purgatorio; and must not delay longer to return you thanks for such kindness. I purpose to examine the Work with a great deal more attention than has hitherto been possible, so soon as a
little leisure is granted me. What I read up and down, in the Introduction &c,TC read at least part of the introduction; see TC to JAC, 5 Sept. gives me pleasant foretaste, and assurance that I shall have a Scholar, and man of Intelligence, for company.
With many thanks, and wishing you good fruit of yr labours past and to come,
I remain / Yours sincerely / T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A[LLA], 8 Sept. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: I am sorry to report that I have fallen under the hands of the Doctor since writing last (seized me on Friday the day after I had written);—and that it is too evidt, Tuesday cannot be the day! The disorder is but a trifle; a biliary matter, of the season (I suppose, for I am hitherto my own “Doctor“), and seems to be mending, since yesternight:—but it positively enough prohibits. Does not much hinder the rubbish-Enterprise;TC’s proofreading. whh, I hope (Heaven helping), will actually be finished tomorrow.

You must graciously give me leave to fix another day,—the soonest I can. Wife is to be in Edinr again today; thence, I hope, straight home (one hideous night of it); and will probably be here before I can leave.

closer.salute: Yours ever (with complts to the shy Baby),

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 8 Sept. Addr: Misses Welsh / Craigenvilla, Morningside / Edinburgh. PM: London, 9 Sept. 1862. MS: NLS 616.571. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dear Goody is perhaps on the sea at this very moment,—and cd not have a calmer day (if Edinr weather is like London) for returning to Morningside. It wd have been shocking not to see poor Walter &c, so kind and faithful always:—but if it have done you ill, I think that voyage shd suffice for extras of the kind, at present.

My Grange Expeditn cannot by any means be Tomorrow, as one fixed! Not only is the rubbish not done (tho’ near it), but the bowels have risen in insurrection; rose suddenly, Friday afternoon (peuple Français debout contre
les tyrans [the French people risen against the tyrants]),See Carlyle, The French Revolution, Works 4:191.—and I must say, had every reason! Not the least of French-Cookery,An allusion to the Ashburtons’ French cook, Louis Gabriel Sedille (ca. 1814–72); see 34:169JWC to CSO, 3 Sept. 1858. Luxury Calipash,Green gelatinous substance found under the shell of the turtle, used in turtle soup.—or any fun allowed them in the process of oppression;—nothing but Prussian pipeclay and long continued botheration the cause of their intolerable state. So I tell you they broke out (ITC’s error for “a.“ tight ride home for it, I had, but did manage!) —and they have been going for three nights and days now, at a rate whh absolutely makes me laugh. For there is no pain or sickness in it, or next to none,—wholesome “British cholera“ fit for the Season, and whh I expect real good from;—but there is an incessancy in the small way, whh is quite marvellous! Saturday I rode with caution, in the Park only; yesterday I did not ride at all (nor walk, except a few steps); but was very diligent with Proofsheets (and very successful, feeling really in better spirits, better appetite &c almost than usual); however, at midnight I had decided on sending for Barnes if there were no improvet this morning. But there is, beyond question,—probably owing in part to a strong & hot tumbler of punch last night; whh I mean to repeat so long as needful or remedial. And so I have put off Lady A.; and think perhaps you will be home before I can set another day for her.

And this is my whole History; for I have seen nobody (nobody, I think, at all); and have done or suffered nothing, except in battle with refractory Proof-rubbish; battle more successful than usual, as I said, and now I trust within one day almost (say 2!) of being done. Neuberg’s beautiful “lark“ you will find proposed in his Note.Neuberg perhaps suggested some jaunt. I had asked Jamie Aitken for Sunday night to neutralise him; even he did not come: nothing but two clear candles, and a clear little fire, with work before me (in moderation), and Books if I had needed them. Instead of ride, I took a longer sleep. About dusk I repeated my morning’s round, nothing more; and in these 10 minutes, PeesweepNickname for Frederick Martin (1830–83; ODNB), who worked for TC Oct. 1856–March 1857; see 32:99TC to LA, 9 March 1857, and 189JWC to TC, 18 July 1857. had called,—left his card and was gone. Another Blockhead (Exhibitn Gawk, I took him to be) had called while I was asleep— ‘For the many mercies that are made to pass over our head,“One of TC’s mother’s sayings; cf. 26:2TC to MAC, 1 Jan. 1851.—thanks are due withal. Oh write my Dear; and say when you are coming,—yet don’t hurry either! Adieu best Goody. T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JY, 8 Sept. Pbd: Rev. James Young, Life of John Welsh, Minister of Ayr … With a Biographical Sketch of the Author (Edinburgh, 1866) xxvii; Wylie 94–95 inc.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES YOUNG

docBody.p: Accept thanks for your pleasant little bookThe Countess of Mar’s Arcadia, or Sanctuary; see TC to JWC, 29 Aug. and note, which have come safe to hand some days ago.

The ‘Arcadia’ of this notable ladyLady Mary, b. Stuart (d. 1644), countess of Mar, m. 1592, Sir John Erskine (1562–1634; ODNB), 2d earl of Mar. was well worth printing; and I read with pleasure your Introduction, concisely and faithfully done, and an agreeable remembrancer to me of a great many persons and things belonging to that memorable time. You give due references and vouchers, which is a most indispensable, though often omitted, requisite;—a little more distinctness in specifying what book you meant (its place, year, &c) would sometimes have been useful to me. There is a good deal of art in doing foot-notes well (in the right measure, at the right point, lucidly, at once, &c. &c.), as there is in doing anything whatever well!

Welsh’s Biography, if he could be made conclusively intelligible, as at least the public Church-History of his time could by right pains, might be a very acceptable book; the anti-Presbyterian procedure of King James, and scenes one has seen, of ‘all the women gathered weeping on Leith Sands,’ I think at two in the morning, ‘as Welsh and consorts lifted anchor for exile,’ &c. &c., represent a vivid state of thingsJohn Welsh and five other ministers were imprisoned at Blackness Castle near Linlithgow for protesting against James VI and I’s suspension of the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland, 1605, and were exiled to France, 7 Nov. 1606: “[B]rought from Blacknes to Leeth, and there the ship being readie, and many attending their embarking, they fell down upon their knees, on the shoare, and prayed two severall tymes verie ferventlie, moveing all the multitude about to tears in abundance and lamentation“ (John Row, The History of the Kirk of Scotland from the Year 1558 to August 1637 [Edinburgh, 1842] 240). “They wer callit againe by tuo houres in the morning. … Prayer conceivit as befoir, by Mr John Welsche, they imbarkit, giving many exhortatiounes to all to hold fast the truth of the doctrine quhilk they had deliverit“ (The Autobiography and Diary of Mr. James Melvill, ed. Robert Pitcairn [Edinburgh, 1842] 2:670). in what has now fallen altogether blank to common Scotch readers. Mr. David Laing printed somewhere, not many years ago, certain letters from Welsh in his exile—(“I dwine and dee!” was a phrase in one of them)—which to me were considerably instructive as to his affairs, and him.John Welsh wrote to Robert Boyd, 4 April 1611: “On greif tumbles on upon ane uther. My douleurs ar impossible to expresse, and sa mekle the mair intollerable to beir, that I have nane unto quhome I may communicate theme, and fra quhom I may receve ony consolation. … I dwyne and deis in langueur“ (“Letters of Mr. John Welsch to Robert Boyd of Trochrig. MDCVII–MDCXIX,“ The Miscellany of the Wodrow Society, Containing Tracts and Original Letters, Chiefly Relating to the Ecclesiastical Affairs of Scotland During the Sixteenth and Seventeenth Centuries, ed. David Laing [Edinburgh, 1844] 558). Mr Laing, you are no doubt aware, is worth all living aids put together in regard to such a matter.

I fear, however, there will be a great scarcity of real documents as to Welsh.James Young replied, 15 Sept.: “Touching a biography of Welsh, I have to say, that after intensely studying his life and character, I am satisfied that there is no man of his own time whose history supplies so many scenes of dramatic interest, or whose life is more sublime. … Your fear that there will be a scarcity of documents is, I am happy to inform you, without foundation. On the contrary, there is an exuberance of materials, and one great difficulty I have felt is how best to arrange and compress them.“ At Ayr, I suppose, there will be nothing;—unless, perhaps, his old kirk is still head uppermost, in an indisputable way? In Dumfriesshire (in Glenesland, Upper Nithsdale), you will still find the name of Colleston sticking to a patch of the property which was his father’s;John Welsh (d. 1600), laird of Collieston, also father of JWC’s paternal ancestor David Welsh, who inherited the farm. Colliston (or Collieston) farm, 3 mi. (5 km.) E of Craigenputtoch; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 108. but except that, and perhaps some inferences (of small moment) deducible from that, I doubt nothing more whatever.
Wishing you good speed in this, or in something else that is good, I remain, &c.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [8 Sept.]. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfrieshire. PM: Kirkcaldy, 8 Sept. 1862. MS: NLS 607.594E. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:121–23. Quot: Hansons, NE 501.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
So long as I am in Scotland, my Darling, I cannot help feeling that my head quarters is Holme-Hill! tho’ I go buzzing here and there, like a “Bum-bee,“ in the neighbourhood of its hive!— Everywhere that I go, I am warmly welcomed and made much of; but nowhere that I go, do I feel so at home, in an element so congenial to me as with you and the Dr!— At Craigenvilla; tho’ treated as a niece, and perhaps even a favourite niece, I am always reacting against the self-assumption and the religiosity (not the religion, mind!); and here; tho’ I am “cousin,“—their one cousin—for whom their naturally hospitable and kindly natures are doubly hospitable and kindly; still I miss that congeniality which comes of having mutually suffered, and taken one’s sufferings to heart! I feel here as if I were ‘playing’ with nice, pretty-behaved children! I almost envy them their lighthearted capacity of being engrossed with trifles! And yet—not that!—there is a deeper joy in ones own sorrowful
memories surely, than in this gaiety that comes of “never-minding“!Coterie speech; see 13:85JWC to TC, 9 April 1841. Would I would you—cease to regret the dear ones we have lost—if we could? would we be light hearted, at the cost of having nothing in ones heart very precious or sacred? oh no!—better ever such grief for the lost; than never to have loved any one enough to have ones equanimity disturbed by the loss!

I came here on Saturday; was to have come on Friday; but had to wait for a letter of Walter’s “missent to Liberton“ I go back to morningside tomorrow forenoon. Unless it “rains cats and dogs“!—and then to London after one days rest!

And after all my haste—at least haste since leaving Holme Hill—the chances are I shall find Mr C just gone to The Grange. He had “partly decided on going next Tuesday (tomorrow)“! and if I wasnt home in time to go with him, he had engaged I would join him there!

Dont he wish he may get me? He will have to stay considerably longer than the “one week“ he talks of, before I shall feel disposed to take the road again! In fact I should greatly like a few days “all to myself“—to sleep off my fatigues and get acclimated, before having to resume my duties as Mistress of the House.

Alex Welsh came to Crawfurd the “next day“ as predicted; but “his Reverence“Rev. Walter Welsh. never joined him there—and Alex, finding the fishing as bad as possible, went on to spend a few days with the ChristalsJeannie and Andrew Chrystal. in Glasgow—before returning to Liverpool
God keep you, dearest friend—after the Dr,Mary’s husband, Dr. James Russell. there is nobody you are so precious to as to me!— I will write from Chelsea— Your loving
docBody.name: J Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [8 Sept.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Kirkcaldy, 8 Sept. 1862. MS: NLS 607.595A. Pbd: Bliss, JWC 299.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Oh my gracious! What a Stupid I am! Again I have sent off my letter without mentioning what has been in my mind to say this week back!

Did you fill up the Income Tax Paper and send it to the address indicated on the Paper? If you didn’t you must do it yet—even if after the appointed time—or there will be another hundred pounds or two clapped on to the Tax!
and I shall have to “appeal“ againFor JWC’s previous appeal over income tax, Nov. 1855, see 30:213, 219, and 220–22JWC’s Journal, Nov. 1855. or pay ever so many pounds to the end of the chapter!
You should hear my Aunts on the “atrocity“ of the Income Tax!
It was their wrath that reminded me that altho’ you had that paper in your hands before I left, and I told you had to fill it up; still I hadn’t made you fill it up before my eyes.

This will probably reach you along with the other letter tho sent to Kircaldy a day laterwhich is well—as I didn’t know that “the bag“ was sent away so soon,Letters went from Auchtertool at 1:40 p.m. and it is now waiting for “Cousin’s letter“
I hope it will find you at the Grange and that I will find a letter telling me so awaiting me at Morningside tomorrow
docBody.name: J C

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 9 Sept. MS: NLS 616.572. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dear Goodykin,—Half a word must do, and tell you the essential; tho’ there have come two Letters (last one 2 p.m.) this day;—and if I wrote nothing what a toss the poor little soul wd be in! But I have been bothered to desperatn, with many things,—income tax-paper one of them, bad Proofs the chief, and Dinner came on me by surprise.

Know, then, that the “insurrection“TC’s bowel problems; see TC to JWC, 8 Sept. is entirely laid; ceased yesterday afternoon by mutual consent;—and I expect improvet considerable from it, tho’ as yet somewhat in a confused unadjusted state,—much suffering from bad Proofs. That truly is it; the insurrectn, I am well persuaded, has done and will do me good.

Secondly the income Paper is all right. Long ago I signed it “No Change“; this everybody remembered; but nobody cd say whether this had ever been called for, yea or no. Considerable fluff of agitatn in consequence. At length MaMaria Chamberlayne. found the Paper; went off with it to Wing,Possibly Henry Vincent Wing (b. 1834) of Wing & Ducane, solicitors, 1 Gray’s Inn Sq.—who cordially received it, having been of mind to call by and by! By the same impulse I paid off some dud of “Assessd-Taxes Paper“ ((£20..17 or so, from Oughton)Probably Thomas Oughton Jr., collector of income taxes, Jubilee Pl., Chelsea. whh had been lying, with demand in its mouth but no hurry, for some time back. There now. Compose yr soul, will you, little wretch?

The inclosed from The Grange came this morning,—abt the time my new one wd be there. I do almost believe I shall get thro’ those Proofs tomorrow. I am ready to go then; but will prefer taking a breath or two of composure first: Shouldn’t I? The Lady has been told you wd probably be home directly.

Read that Narrative of Scrymgeour,TC enclosed a printed notice, dated Stirling, 5 Sept., by Charles Rogers, secretary of the Wallace Monument Supplemental Committee, disputing strongly James Scrymgeour’s claim, “this monstrous exaction,“ against the committee for payment of £100; see TC to JCA, 27 Aug. and say if ever Shakspear did the like o’ that!See JWC to TC, [5 Sept.]. God bless you, Dearest / T. Carlyle
—“Scrymgeour $EQ Master of the Escrimes (or Fencing-points), Escrimgeur!”—
Send this on to John, when you have done laughing at it. / T.C. (Tuesday)TC wrote his postscript on the reverse of Rogers’s printed notice (MS and printed notice: NLS 517.38B); see above.

figure.p: Thomas Carlyle’s postscript on Scrymgeour, 9 September 1862

p.hi: Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [9 Sept.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Edinburgh, 9 Sept 1862. MS: NLS 607.595C. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Oh my Dear! Here am I just arrived from Auchtertool and find your letter—and Betty!Betty Braid.—and “dinner to be ready in a few minutes Jeanie“! And I am all upset with the sailing; and vexed about your bowels; and hurried and flurried; and the post will be leaving Morningside by the time dinner is well over And so—no letter is possible in return for your long nice one; nice if the news about yourself weren’t bad.

I was meaning to stay over tomorrow to rest from the bother of todays journey. But I can’t stay in any comfort with the notion tormenting me that you are perhaps needing some thing to stop that bowel-complaint and are putting off sending for Mr Barnes.

So I shall start tomorrow night, and hope to reach home about the time Elizabeth cameThe Carlyles’ maid, who came from Haddington to Cheyne Row mid-June; see JWC to IES, [ca. 22 June].—between ten and eleven I think.
For Mercy’s Sake dont be either coming or sending to meet me! I really transact my railway business far best with nobody to trust to but myself!—
The visit to Auchtertool has been successful on the whole—good sleep and “nourishing diet“; but it was probably just as well that I made my head quarters elsewhere.

And I don’t feel as if that place could ever be a home for me again! at least never, so long as both Maggie and Mary are there to receive me! As soon go to live in “The Happy Family“ at Trafalgar Square,“The Happy Family“ was the name given to a collection of small animals (including cats, mice, rabbits, owls, pigeons, and hawks), kept in a cage in Trafalgar Sq., all supposedly living together in harmony; see 37:150JWC to WDO, 15 April 1861. only “kept from fighting by having their crops full Sir“! But I will tell you all about everything by word of mouth on Thursday please Heaven Meanwhile do take plenty of brandy and water but take it cold. Mr Barnes was particular on that point when he attended me in cholera Oh how I wish the horrid journey were well over
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

ps.p: I would go tonight if I could get ready in time and werent tired already and Betty here—not spoken to yet

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [10 Sept.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Edinburgh, 10 Sept. 1862. MS: NLS 607.595B. Hitherto unpbd. TC wrote on envelope: “1862 (Septr 10: at Edinr; is coming).“
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Oh my Dear! Dont be too disgusted! nor think I have changed my nature which up to this time has been remarked from punctuality! I am not going off by tonights train after all; I shall be home tomorrow please God—but at night instead of in the morning When I fo[u]ndLetter omitted. by your letter this morning that you were all right; I regretted that I had fixed to go at night. For since that blessed doze of Morphia I have slept every night, better or worse And the idea of a night in a railway, looked much more uninviting; when I might have passed it in sleeping in my bed! Still I kept to my plan; till on coming in from Morningside this morning to ascertain about the time of starting (nothing of that sort is to be learnt out at Morningside) I found that the night train leaves at half after ten! a horrible late hour to start—whereas the morning train which I had been told left at seven—too early for getting in from Morningside after Breakfasting —does in reality start at ten (as from London) It seemed so preferable this—and my nature shuddered so at setting out between ten and eleven in the dark night—that—as you were better—I have decided to break my appointment for once, And am writing this (without spectacles) at Mrs Dycer’sElizabeth Dycer (b. ca. 1831), wife of Dr. Charles Dycer (b. ca. 1827), 42 Gt. King St., Edinburgh; unidentified further.—that you may be sure of being warned before the last moment of my delayed appearance.
If you can read this it is more than I can do while writing it
docBody.name: J W C

ps.p: Between eleven and twelve at night expect me

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A[LLA], 1[1] Sept. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd. Date confirmed by JWC’s return, Thurs., 11 Sept.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
This is a great disappointment indeed! I had calculated on having one complete week of holiday and interval, after finishing out the last tag-rags of “Vol IV,“ and flinging it off from me forevermore,—one bright week, in the
pleasantest place I know in the world, and with the best friends I have now left in the world:—my bit of disorder is over, or as good as over; my rubbish is all fairly done; I expect my wife home tonight; and shd most probably have written tomorrow, appointing Monday as the first day of my sacred week,—the very day on whh you are to take wing. In this way we poor mortals go hopping and hoping after one another, to very little purpose oftenest!

I am to have my holiday at any rate, from practical considerations; but I must now spend it here, in sauntering about, riding out to Henry TaylorHenry Taylor, who lived in East Sheen, SW London. (whom I have not seen for above a year), trying for a sight of “the Pictures“The fine art collections at the International Exhibition were of the English school of oil painting (1750–1850), English watercolors, sculpture, engraving, architecture, and foreign schools of painting; see Francis Turner Palgrave, Handbook of the Fine Art Collections of 1862 (1862). (in that blessed Exhibitn Edifice),The International Exhibition was housed in a purpose-built structure designed by Francis Fowke (1823–65; ODNB), which consisted of a central building ornamented with two gigantic glass domes and two adjoining annexes; it was mostly demolished in 1864.—and otherwise sucking my paws, after the fashion of bears who are idle, in these dusty purlieus, instead of at The Grange beside you both.

If you pass thro’ Town on Monday on yr new route, and will give me notice, I shall have the pleasure of a transient interview, if punctual attendance at yr hour (barring accidents always!) will yield it me;—no better item in my Holiday will turn up.

If you do go to NiceThe Ashburtons rented the Villa Jaune in Nice for the winter; see Surtees, Ludovisi 89–90. for the Winter, it shall go hard with me but I will see you before going! But there will be no “Holiday“ afoot then; nothing but the old gin-horse, tugging in his old harness then, earnestly struggling and hoping to get in before he die. Perhaps Ld An will still relent to The Grange? I cannot pretend to the least faculty of counsel;—and pray only, for yr sake, and my own, that you may be guided to the plan whh is best. Adieu for today,
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 13 Sept. MS: NLS 517.37. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.dateline: Chelsea Saturday 13(?) Septr / 1862TC’s question mark; Sat. was 13 Sept.
docBody.p:
My dear Brother,—Thanks for yr Letter and the glimpses you give us of Scotsbrig, Craigenph &c. I am glad to hear that Jenny is at The Gill: Jane had
heard from questioning Mary that the poor little Jenny was fallen quite “irregular in her times“ (for six months past);Jenny Carlyle’s condition was more than physical. John A. Carlyle wrote to her older brother James Carlyle Jr., 12 Sept., that he had gone to The Gill and found her “much better“: “The disease she had at Scotsbrig was mumps at first, & mismanagement of diet &c. confined her to bed & made her much worse than she would otherwise have been. … One cause of languor & tending to illness lies in the discouragement she must feel from never having got things in the house at Scotsbrig put into any order resembling what her Mother used to keep; & yet she seems quite capable of accomplishing that if she were duly seconded by your Father & John [the brother living at Scotsbrig]; & would find the greatest comfort in it if it were done & kept done. I spoke to your Father on the subject & he will try what he can. … To Jenny herself I found difficulty in doing any thing farther than merely hinting at the defect & its remedy. She is very good & affectionate, & had an excellent training; but has hitherto been too young for managing servants effectively, & seems to have had no assistance of a steady sort from anybody, & she is very thin-skinned and sensitive“ (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). whh is a very serious matter for yg women;—a good lass of ours had to quit, last year, on that acct, and seemed to be almost dying: but is now recovered into bloom again, by “change to the Country.“Sarah Piggott; see JWC to TC, [28 Aug.]. Change, it seems, is what they recommend as the very first likely measure. Pray attend to poor Jenny;—and let her Aunts (now when she has no Mother)Jenny’s mother, Isabella Carlyle, d. 1 June 1859. Her aunts living nearby were Jean Aitken and Mary Austin. help her, in regard to this, with their counsels, their inquiries.

Jane came home to me, WednryJWC arrived back Thurs. night. night at half past 10; had run the whole course at one heat: safe and sound; looking a great deal better, as you said; and I hope is really considerably improved.

As for me, here I am still; and am like to be! I had settled Tuesday last for The Grange; and was busy getting ready, shoving Proofs aside at my swiftest, when,—on the Friday’s evg ride, there arose a mutiny in the interior man (you will understand of what kind), and I had to make rapidly for home! This lasted over Sunday, so that on Monday I had to write “Wait for me, please!” On Monday the affair seemed over (fashous [vexatious] and ridiculous, I reckoned it, and even beneficial rather than dangerous); but on Monday, by mismanaget I brot it on again, & it did not fairly go till Wedny morning; and just then arrived a regretful message from the Grange Lady, “We are for DevonshirePossibly to visit Sir Walter and Lady Pauline Trevelyan, who had a house at Seaton, Devonshire. (called thither) on Monday“ (i.e. day after tomorrow), “and going to Nice for the winter!”— — Very well, very well; my Proofs were all comfortably done; I had determined on my “8 days of complete holiday“;—and I am having it here, and will have! Whh may probably be quite as well. No more today. I saw Jean’s Boy the other night: quite well. Yours & everybodys,—T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-HP, 15 Sept. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
TC
TO HENRY PARKES

docBody.p:
