I recd your two Books;See TC to JWC, 2 Sept.
thanks for yr kindness. The Cunningham (Book and Author) I already knew; the Lang I had not seen, but intend to examine so soon as I have leisure.

figure.p: Thomas Carlyle’s List of Books for Henry Parkes, 1862
Henry Parkes, Fifty Years in the Making of Australian History (1892)

p.hi: Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-RO, 15 Sept. MS: Hilles. Pbd: Richard Owen, The Life of Richard Owen (1894) 2:55–56. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:470–71. Richard Owen (1804–92; ODNB), naturalist and paleontologist, whom TC first met Aug. 1842; see TC to JWC, 26 Aug. 1842; see also TC to RO, 17 May 1858.
div3.head: TC TO RICHARD OWEN

docBody.p: Dear Owen,—I hope you will get yr Museum.Richard Owen was superintendent of the natural history departments of the British Museum from 1856, and came to believe that the natural sciences needed a publicly funded museum of their own. I am, for my own share, no great judge of such matters; and have never myself been able to do much good in Museums: but it seems to me that a Nation ready to spend any amount of millions on any foolery that turns up, really might as well take counsel of its Chief Naturalist, and build such a Museum as will satisfy him, while its hand is in!

I read yr little Book,Owen’s recently published On the Extent and Aims of a National Museum of Natural History (1862), a plea to the general public to support a dedicated museum. The book discussed both the contents and the structure of the proposed building in S. Kensington, complete with plans and measurements. As a result of political and scientific rivalry, his scheme was not approved until the early 1870s and officially opened 1881. with intelligence more or less complete, and always with pleasure in proportion to my clearness. But what interested me more than the Museum Question was certain characteristics, brief, incidental, whh started up here and there,—characteristics of the now Pleader for such a Museum. For instance, that of the winged gentlewoman (in New Holland, I think) who gathers rotten leaves & fermenting substances, to do her hatching for her,—and how she fared in the Zoological Gardens here. Or still better, that of the cone-billed Passeres, who have “a marriage-bower“ (better luck to them); and how the British Jack-daw is still a Passer of that kind, retaining his old propensities, but checked in a crowded country, and in the meanwhile stealing bright objects to right and left, in hope times may mend in that respect!Owen described how a “pair of Talegallas, or brush turkeys, at the London Zoological Gardens, occupied themselves during the spring and summer of 1860 in forming a large hatching-mound. The females laid and buried twenty eggs, in a circle, … and on the 26th of August a young talegalla emerged from the mound, and ran about in quest of worms and insects; feeding independently, and without care or concern on the part of the parents“ (Owen, On the Extent and Aims 46). After describing the activities of Australian bower-birds, he continued: “It is possible, that the odd propensity of the Magpie, Jackdaw, and some others of our conirostral Passeres, to which the Australian Bower-birds are allied, to pilfer glittering objects, may be the remnant of a similar bower-building, bower-ornamenting, instinct, which the increase of human population has scared out of them; the conditions of our well-peopled, widely-cultivated island having reduced the daws and magpies to restrict their constructive propensities to the nests essential for the continuance of the species“ (48–49). These and the like of these seem to me eminently beautiful indications.

And in short my opinion is, If the said Pleading Professor wd gather himself steadily abt such a thing, and devote his whole soul to it for a few years, he might write, to be read by the like of me who am esoteric altogether,—say in two voll. with Portraits (for it ought to be very brief, and distilled to the utmost),—such a Book of Natl History as was never written before! Whh wd far outshine the biggest Museum even the British Nation cd build, and might a long time outlive such;—done by one’s own right hand or head, independt of Comittees! I am quite serious; more so than you think. Yrs always / T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [15 Sept.]. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries. PM: London, 15 Sept. 1862. MS: NLS 607.595D. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:266–68. Quot: Simpsons 146.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: Here I am, dearest Friend! Here I have been since Thursday night. I had fixed to arrive on Thursday morning. But I took a horror at the notion of the night journey, and stayed in my bed at Morningside instead. Travelling by night is all very well when one is having bad nights in one’s bed. But that morphia had not only got me a nights sleep; it seemed to have broken the spell of sleeplessness I was under. The journey as it took it, by Express—from ten in the morning till ten at night did not fatigue me in the least—I had the carriage all to myself during the last three hours—and could get both windows kept open—and by dint of having insisted on nobody meeting me, I got myself and luggage put in a cab, without any Professor-Huxley fussing,Thomas Henry Huxley, whom JWC had met at Carlisle Station on her journey north; see JWC to TC, [12 Aug.]. by a railway porter. and walked into my own house as cool and fresh as if I had just been out for a little airing.

Mr C was very glad of course to see me back. As for Maria; she went into a sort of hysterics over me! seizing me in her arms, and kissing me all over, and laughing in a distracted manner. A charming reception from one’s House-maid, certainly! if it weren’t that such emotional natures have always two sides; this loving and loveable one; and another, as quick to anger and jealousy and all unreasonableness!— All this impetuous affection for me, wouldn’t prevail with her to make any sacrifices for my sake; or to exert herself for my sake in any manner which was not agreeable to her inclinations. It is just the emotionalness of the Wesleyan Methodist! having its source in the Senses rather than in the Soul!

All Friday I was so busy unpacking, and putting things in their places, and (what the American housewives call “reconciling things,“Coterie speech; see 33:122JWC to MR, 19 Nov. 1857. that I put off writing to anybody even to you—till Saturday. and then—a horrid remembrance flashed on me. That Thornhill kept the Sabath in an all too exemplary manner, and that I might spare my haste!— On Sunday it is London which keeps the SabathJWC means there was no point writing on Sat. as there were no Thornhill deliveries on Sun., nor writing on Sun. when there were no collections in London; see JWC to TC, [18 Aug.].— So this is the first feasable day for writing.

I send along with this letter, but separately a packet containing the neck-brooch which you were to “like better“ than your old thistle—perhaps you wouldn’t like it better or as well, singly—but the set, to my taste, is prettier; and I care more for the old thistle—its oldness being its very charm to me!—the brooches can be worn as clasps down the front of the dress, also—and look very well on a dress of any colour)
Nevertheless my Dear if you don’t entirely like the exchange tell me truly —and your thistle shall return to whence it came.

Now, I shall feel rather anxious about that packet until I hear you have got it safe. So I beg you will write one line by return of post to say if you have it or not—it will be posted along with this letter— I shall not register the box because it draws the letter-carrier mind to the reflection ‘here must be something of value’!!— I have never registered anything that I sent by post, and never yet lost anything. Still I shall be uneasy till I know the brooches are in your hands.

Mr C thinks, as every body does that I am much improved in health and I myself, who should know best, think so too.TC later wrote “1862?“ here. “What could he do to show his gratitude to Mrs Russell for taking such care of me? Well he had read a really nice book that would suit her, he would send her that“— I shall send the book by railway parcel so soon as I hear the other packet has reached its true destination
You can’t think with what new interest my little picture of RippMary Russell’s dog, whose picture was in JWC’s dressing room; see 35:28JWC to MR, 8 Feb. 1859. looked out on me on my return!—
My kindest love to the Dr— Your ever affectionate
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

ps.p: My breast is quite well

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [15 Sept.]. MS: NLS Acc. 7864 inc. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.p: Here I am again, safe and sound! I came home last Thursday night, and made a prosperous journey of it. I found Mr C looking pretty well in spite of a little bowel-complaint he had had, and which had afforded him a pretext for putting off his visit to the Grange; and now it cannot come off at all, the visit, for the Ashburtons are gone away into CornwallAccording to TC they went to Devonshire; see TC to JAC, 13 Sept. He is really getting as hard to move as the Mountains! However he is giving himself a weeks Holyday at Home, which is better than nothing

I wish you would write me a little letter, and tell me about “Scotsbrig Jenny,“ who was with you when I last heard of her. And tell me if you liked my Photograph? “The smallest contribution will be gratefully received“!Coterie speech; see 18:261JWC to MR, 5 Nov. 1844.

I spoke to Dr Russell about Margaret’s childMary’s grand-da. Mary Stewart, da. of Margaret and Thomas Stewart. and described the mark as well as I could. He said he had seen a good many such, but not so large as I described this one. And sometimes, he said, the thing had decreased of itself, sometimes he had removed it by tying it with a thread. Cutting he considered a risk. but when the child is a little older I have no doubt from the way he spoke that something could and should be done. If I were Margaret, I would go at all costs to SymeJames Syme (1799–1879; ODNB), Scottish surgeon; he treated John A. Carlyle in April 1855; see 29:292TC to JAC, 20 April 1855. in Edinr with the Child.

I also spoke to him about Rob Austin’s Wife;Elspeth, b. Milligan (ca. 1823–1900), wife of Robert Austin (1815–74), Mary Austin’s brother-in-law; see 34:27034:biographical note. and he happened to be asked by Dr LorimerAndrew Lorimer (1802–84), medical officer for the parish of Dunscore, Dumfries; see Wilson, Carlyle 2:95–96. to meet him, to consult about a patient of his, while I was still at Holme Hill. He undertook to question him about her as a person whom a friend staying with him was interested in; without letting him know of course that I had expressed any doubts of the propriety of bleeding a woman so weak. He (D Russell) said this Dr Lorimer had a mania about Diptheria—he professed to have had 45 cases of it!! and corresponded with some Physician in Edinr about his cases. Accordingly Dr Lorimer assured Dr Russell Mrs Austin had had Diptheria in the beginning; but that of course was long over. the relaxed throat she was having now was the consequence he said of the
original Diptheria!! but he did not consider it in the least dangerous and on the whole he Dr Lorimer had no apprehensions whatever as to the state of her health at present. If you couldMS ends here.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A[LLA], 19 Sept. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
Dear Lady A.—My Wife came home the day I wrote to you; visibly much improved by her Scotch Excursion of five weeks. The “Holiday“ has since been going on, if not in a triumphant, in a punctual and faithful manner;—that is to say, I have strictly abstained from work; gone to ride at the best not the worst part of the day; slept at discretion, and in short, been perfectly idle, with or without advantage. My feeling is one of greater fatigue, not of less; my poor muscles seem actually to have lost all their strength at once,—and are taking (I suppose) their profit out of this unbraced condition of affairs! I have been to see Henry Taylor; found him greatly recovered from the worst symptoms of his disorder,Henry Taylor suffered from asthma; see 37:49TC to HT, 28 Nov. 1860. and reconciled to what remains of it;—in fact, very happy and contented. I staid too long with him in the hot day; had to ride home double-quick in the teeth of the east-wind; got something of a cold, and felt tired as if I had been fighting the Battle of Waterloo all day,—such my potency of strength at this time. Another day, I went to see certain “exquisite Historical Miniatures“Part of the “Special Exhibition of Objects of Art on Loan,“ South Kensington Museum, opened early June. in the Brompton Boilers.Popular nickname for the buildings of South Kensington Museum; see 35:91TC to FMB, 10 May 1859. The exhibition was held in a new building at the back of the museum. I had waited many weeks for a “Catalogue,“The exhibition opened without a catalog, an omission deplored by early reviewers. J. C. Robinson’s Catalogue of the Special Exhibition of Works of Art … on Loan at the South Kensington Museum (1862) was eventually produced. & had then studied the same, and prepared myself to walk direct to the objects wanted, carefully neglecting all the others: but, alas, found my Catalogue a merely imaginary quantity, and that all the “Historical Miniatures“ were lying higgledy piggeldy,The Daily News review, 5 June, noted the “very incomplete state in which the objects are displayed both as regards anything like systematic arrangement and as to the mere naming of the objects. … The miniatures form a complete portrait gallery of the greatest interest, many of the more famous personages being easily recognizable; but this is a part of the exhibition which loses nearly all for want of proper description.“ and most part of them false imaginary
and of no use to the thinking mind.“Historical Personages, as Illustrated in Miniature Art in the South Kensington Museum II,“ St. James Magazine 6 (Dec. 1862): 74–92, described “908 miniatures … [in an] invaluable and surpassingly interesting collection“ (6:91). “Here are sixteen momentous reigns of English sovereigns alone, brought upon the stage costumed and characterized“ (6:92). “Of Cromwell there are thirteen miniatures … [one of which] is the unfinished portrait which the Protector is said to have caught Cooper in the act of surreptitiously copying: a most extraordinary physiognomy—the solemn melancholy, mixed with heroic resolution, of one who had set his life on a cast, and had not yet won it“ (6:91). My fatigue was great; my humour tending towards the suicidal, on quitting those Cole Boilers.Henry Cole (1808–82; ODNB), civil servant, known to the Carlyles since the 1830s; one of the main promoters of the Great Exhibition of 1851, he was instrumental in developing the new site at South Kensington, both as a national center for the arts and sciences and as a venue for temporary exhibitions. Tomorrow is my only chance for a trial of the Exhibition;The International Exhibition. but it is not likely I shall dare to risk that adventure. The only thing achieved is, by the Wife’s energy, certain Photographs big and little, whh have long been talked of. If you be a good child, I do believe you have a chance of one of the ugliest Photographic Pictures of the human countenance you ever saw: an old grim fellow (much older than I thot he was) in wool-white hair; features full of gloom, hard as granite, and looking out quite relentless upon life.For one of William Jeffrey’s photographs of TC, see frontispiece [available on the CLO on the table of contents for this volume]. And in this way my Holiday is gone, and there are now only two days of it left!—

The Grange wd never have done, with the Sovereignties both absent. We will come in Octr, unless inexorabilities withstand in an unexpected way: you shall have vol IV (bound, this time) to read at Nice,—whh, alas, I see to be a fixed measure now, and must say nothing in complaint of. Most probably, indeed, it is a wise one. May this hit you in a lucky moment on yr circuit, and find you both well.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 19 Sept. MS: NLS 517.38. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:212–13 inc.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
As there is “Holiday“ established here, I must not neglect a little word to you at closure of the week. I have been as idle as need be; but doubt I have made little of it in that course. My weakness of muscle, my utter fatigue at the least labour were never so great in my life before! I went to see some “Historical Miniatures,“ in the Brompton Boilers, one day, TaitRobert Tait. accompanying (result
zero or minus quantities); I rode to see Henry Taylor again (weariness of body very great, in the burning sunshine of going, and the violence of grey east-wind in returning):—on the whole, the one thing we have accomplished, which is due to Jane withal, not to me except passively, is certain Photographs big and little;—of whh you will get copies by and by. Jane had been talking of this busss for years past: at Edinr latterly she found on sale, and going off at a great rate, some unpleasant scrub of a thing (“Came from Dumfries, Mam,“ said the Stationer;Bookshop or stationers of Princes St., Edinburgh; see JWC to MR, [21 Sept.]; unidentified further. “we thot it had been like!”)—whh had set her quite on edge on the matter. So, under guidance of Woolner,Woolner wrote to F. T. Palgrave, 12 Oct.: “I spent the best part of two days with the mighty Thomas to help get those phos. of him and am glad they have turned out so well“ (Woolner 228). and a selected Chief ArtistWilliam Jeffrey (1826–77), photographer, 114 Gt. Russell St.; his photographs of busts of Tennyson and Sir Thomas Fairbairn (1823–91; ODNB), art patron, were showing at the International Exhibition. here, there is now coming out a genuine article, whh will cut up the Dumfries traitor,Possibly John and Robert Ballantine, photographic artists, Dumfries; otherwise unidentified.—and set us all at rest on that side of our affairs. Highly important to think of!— In about 10 days, I shd imagine, there will be copies lying for Jean & you. Jean need not fret in the very least; only know her Dumfries Artist for a dishonourable scout in time coming.

I do not think I can stand the Exhibition at all,—especially under Tait tomorrow. Tomorrow seems to be my last chance; and I rather grudge (tho’ not much either) to miss the Pictures: the huge miscellany of remainder, it is like a dinner of a hundred acres in extent presented to a dyspeptic individual, who needs one mutton-chop, and is not ravenous even for that;—I know nothing in the world of a more distractive overwhelming and distressing nature.

The Ashburton Lady (who is full of zeal & kindness, but witht vestige of method in her habits) has had the vacant Grange, all this while, lying ready for us two; and writes today to say that it is so! We are to go for a week, middle of Octr, and that will do for Country.— Unless you dispatch, what becomes of “Aryshire Coast“?Thus in MS. John A. Carlyle wrote, 1 Sept.: “Jean & I have a project of going to some part of the Ayrshire coast for a week of seabathing.“ My affectionate regards to Jean. James junr is coming on Sunday night. Good be with you all. Your affecte Brother T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-[HP], 19 Sept. MS: Mitchell Lib., Sydney, Australia. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO [HENRY PARKES]

docBody.p: Dear Sir,—If you will come, Sunday Evg at the usual time (7½), you will find us here; very glad to see you once more. I had a Note from Duffy yesterday,Charles Gavan Duffy. with a most lucid and even entertaining commentary on the New Land Law,Duffy wrote, 21 July: “I send you a pamphlet on the new Land Law—not altogether expecting you will read it.“ The Legislative Assembly of New South Wales debated a new system of land law, Aug. 1862, introduced in S. Australia in 1858 by Sir Robert Richard Chute Torrens (1812–84; ODNB), which transferred property by registration of title instead of by deeds. The Torrens Act was passed in New South Wales in Jan. 1863. whh I had not been able to understand before. There will be a very small Packet (couple of Photographs or so)Presumably two of Jeffrey’s recent photographs. JWC also gave Parkes one of TC (possibly on this visit): “As I was on the point of leaving, never to see them again, Mrs. Carlyle gave me a photograph of her husband, with his name written underneath it; and that photograph is still among the most precious things in my quiet home in Sydney“ (Parkes 1:167). to entrust to you for Duffy before you embark in Octr
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-ET[ETWI], [19 Sept.?]. MS: Houghton. Hitherto unpbd. Tentatively dated about a week after JWC’s return to Chelsea, 11 Sept.
div3.head: JWC TO EDWARD TWISLETON

docBody.p: Oh thank you much! dear Mr Twisleton! I like to have this and like to have it from you.

The profile is no likeness—but I have a photograph of her—which I obtained with infinite difficulty from Dickinson in Bond Street— It was blemishedSee JWC to TC, [15 Aug.]. For another photograph of Ellen Twisleton, see 98JWC to MR, [5 June]. but I have mended it up—and have it framed in my bedroom— Not that I need any photograph of Her to keep her image clear in my heart— I loved her—love her so much! and she was not a sort of woman to be ever replaced in ones affections—
Dont stay away too long—as you are apt to do!

Remember me kindly to Mrs ParkmanMary Eliot Parkman, b. Dwight (b. 1821), Ellen Twisleton’s sister, living in Boston; see 32:55JWC to EDW, 15 Dec. 1856. Presumably Edward Twisleton was setting off on a trip to America.
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [21 Sept.]. MS: NLS 607.597A. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:268–71 inc. Dated the 2d Sun. after JWC’s return to Chelsea.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: My Darling Woman! I didn’t forget your autograph!See JWC to TC, 31 Aug. I sent it in the first letter I wrote you after my departure, that is a fact!! I received it from Mr C in his first letter to me at Morningside—the Tuesday morning—my first morning, with my Aunts—and I inclosed it in my letter to you! I think I can tell how you missed noticing it. It was one line—some short maxim (I forget what) with his signature; it was folded like a note; and you had taken it for a bit of blank paper put round the letter to keep the writing from shining thro the envelope. However it was; I could stake my head against a China orange, that I sent it. But that you didnt notice it is of no earthly consequence; except in the appearance of negligence the oversight gave me. Autographs can be supplied so readily! I send another, this time. Also I send you photographs for your Book. One of Mr C, two of myself! which ought to be better than the HairdressersThomas Douglas; see JWC to MCA, [30 Aug.]. being done by the best Photographer in London;William Jeffrey. one of Alfred TennysonThe columnist of the “Weekly Gossip“ section of the Athenaeum noted, 21 March 1863: “Very good photographic portraits of Mr. Carlyle and Mr. Tennyson have been produced by Mr. Jeffrey, an operator already favourably known by his reproductions of sculpture. Photographic portraits mostly fail from want of tact or taste in their producers. Men sit stiffly, or are thoughtlessly posed with regard to the light,—misfortunes the too faithful camera scorns to remedy. Mr. Jeffrey has thoroughly understood what he had to do, and so skillfully posed his sitters, with real feeling for the characters of each, that his works, both as portraits and photographs, are worthy of the originals“ (398). The National Portrait Gallery, London, lists several examples of Jeffrey’s photographs of TC, JWC, and Tennyson (http://www.npg.org.uk/collections). (with the wide-awake) and one of Mazzini, which you are to substitute for the head I gave the Dr, as giving a better notion of him, and besides, having his autograph on it.

An immense explosion of photographs has come off in this house! in consequence of Mrs Aitken’s indiscretion in lending the print of Mr C to a photographist in Dumfries, who tho “bound down to take only six copies,“ (Mrs Aitken confidently insisted, and therefore those in Mrs Kennedy’sAgnes Kennedy, b. McTurk (1795–1882), sister of JWC’s old friend Robert McTurk, and wife of John Kennedy, farmer at Kirkland, Tynron parish. book and Miss Dalzel’sPossibly Justina Dalzell (ca. 1813–63), Dumfries teacher. book. and other books “couldnt possibly have been done from that Print“) had nevertheless, as I thought at the time, sent these wretched
photographs out in shoals for his own gain! My aunt Grace had seen a great heap of them lying on a Booksellers counter in Princes Street! When I went to enquire at this Booksellerer, whom he had received them from, I was told “from dumfries“ and likewise the agreeable fact that the whole stock were already bought up!! “not one left!” What all my entreaties had not been able to obtain from Mr C—viz that he would go and be photographed by a right man here, was accomplished by his annoyance at being published over the world under so unlike a form. And having decided that last week was to be a holyday, he actually went with me to the best Photographer in London, who had been for years soliciting him to come and be done—for nothing!— He (the Photographer took a great many different ones, large and small; of which one of the large ones satisfied him, and is to be published and I think it the finest photograph I ever saw. But we have got no copies of it yet, except one for myself. Four or five different little ones will be published, and of these I like the one here sent the best. As of course Mr Jeffrey (the photographer) will make a good thing of supplying the shops with Mr C; he was very obliging in insisting on doing me—who had not laid my account with being done; and so, was at the same loss for a head-dress—as you were at the Hairdressers! But fortunately Mr Jeffrey’s Aunt, who assists him, offered me a white lace thing,Ellenor Ruding. For a photograph of JWC wearing the “white lace thing,“ see 225JWC to JCA, [30 Sept.]. so like one of my own loose caps; that I put it on without reluctance and the same helpful woman, seeing the black lace I wear round my neck lying on the table, snatched it up and suggested I should be done also in that (for headress). To complete my luck I had on, the day being cold, my last winters gown (from Madame Elise); so that I came out a better figure, than at the Hairdressers!! Still I have a certain regard for the queer little Thornhill likeness of myself;—not as a likeness—but as a memorial of the three happiest weeks that I have lived for a long long time; so I will ask you to get me another from the Hairdresser—as the one I sent to Mr C has been given away to Sarah, the Housemaid who went away ill som 14 months ago, and who came last night to see me, before starting for Australia. I gave her Mrs Pringle’s alias Potts’sJWC’s cousin Janet Pott. scarlet plaid, and my Photograph, and my blessing!

I was quite relieved to find the brooches had arrived safe. People always say it is so rash to send anything of consequence unregistered. And I, again, am so persuaded, that registering a thing only puts it in the head of dishonest postmen that the thing is worth stealing! So if that packet had misgiven; I should have had “both the scaith and the scorn“!SND records the phrase, dated 1760: “It is very hard to put up both with the skeath and the skorin.“ See also “Fair Annie,“ Popular Ballads and Songs, ed. and trans. Robert Jamieson (Edinburgh, 1806) 2:105, and Sir Walter Scott, A Legend of Montrose (1823) chap. 4.— My blessed Dear! what
nonsense you talk about my “depriving myself“ of this and that!— Depend upon it, when I give away a thing it is never with the slightest sense of “depriving myself“— Either the thing is a superfluity to myself; or I have more pleasure in giving it than in keeping it! I never give away anything which has what lawyers call a pretium affectionis [sentimental value] attached to it! At least I never did but once—in the case of that same pebble brooche—which I took from you again!! Nor had I ever regretted giving you that! (tho my Mother was with me when I was allowed to choose it! and my Father paid for it!)Possibly the brooch that JWC gave Mary Russell after her mother’s death in 1842; see 14:166JWC to HW, 25 April 1842. never till I saw it fastening your neck velvet, that day at Mrs Hunters;Catherine Hunter; see JWC to TC, [19 Aug.]. Then I thought first, that doesnt answer the purpose!—it should be more like a clasp to fasten the velvet—and only then, I thought next—surely I shouldnt have parted with that old Edinr Brooche! and then followed the bright idea of the exchange! Pray dont thank me for my brooches, as if they had been a present! or you place me in the odious position of having “given a thing and taken a thing!” (as we used to say at school)

I sent by the railway parcel company yesterday (carriage paid) the Book Mr Carlyle wished you to have, and read and keep for his sake.Unidentified. He bade me tie up with it a translation of DantePresumably John Wesley Thomas, The Trilogy; or, Dante’s Three Visions. Part II Purgatorio; see TC to JAC, 5 Sept. which some one had sent him— If you don’t happen to have a Dante in English it might amuse you in winter nights, he said
I have never told you yet about Auchtertool or Craigenvilla—and here are two sheets filled enough for one time!
Oh do write often Dear! Never mind a regular letter, just a few of hand lines—a how dye do? keeping one from feeling the long distance between! and long silences beside silences still longer
My best love to the kind Dr—
The little pot I brought from Crawford was emptied without shaking into our garden and seems to be taking root—also the Templand Daisy and the ivy—and the strathmilligan woodruff—
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

ps.p: The stamps are for the photograph

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady S[LST], 23 Sept. MS: Duke. Pbd: Fielding and Sorensen 278–79 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY STANLEY

docBody.p: Your letter affords a fresh example of a rule in Human Life, not taught us at school, but which every one has to learn for him or herself—namely; “The Wished for comes too late“!See Works 23:112.— To the energetic wisher whatever thing he sets his heart on is pretty sure to come; but only, never in the right time! Yes—everything in this world shares the fate of Lord Chesterfields patronage of Johnsons Dictionary, offered him when he was “old and could not enjoy it“; was “solitary and could not impart it“; was “known and did not want it“!Philip Dormer Stanhope (1694–1773; ODNB), 4th earl of Chesterfield, failed to give Samuel Johnson (1709–84; ODNB) the support Johnson thought he had been promised while writing his dictionary. When the book was about to be published, Lord Chesterfield wrote two articles in praise of it. Johnson then wrote to Lord Chesterfield, 7 Feb. 1755: “When, upon some slight encouragement, I first visited your Lordship, I was overpowered, like the rest of mankind, by the enchantment of your address … but I found my attendance so little encouraged, that neither pride nor modesty would suffer me to continue. … Seven years, my Lord, have now past … during which time I have been pushing on my work through difficulties … and have brought it, at last, to the verge of publication. … The notice which you have been pleased to take of my labours, had it been early, had been kind; but it has been delayed till I am indifferent, and cannot enjoy it; till I am solitary, and cannot impart it; till I am known, and do not want it“ (Boswell’s Life of Johnson 1:261–62).

Thus the announcement of your return, and your kind invitation to Alderly reaches us at oh such a perverse moment! the very day after Mr C’s holyday had expired, and he had set himself stiffly to “work“ again! Only one week’s holyday had the infatuated man granted himself, made almost necessary by a slight derangement of his health, and falling in, as it happened, conveniently with a pause at the printers. And that week I know he would have gladly spent with you at Alderley. But tho’ I have pleaded with him on my knees, with streaming eyes and flowing hairCf. “Her streaming eyes, wrung hands, and flowing hair,“ John Gay, “An Elegy on a Lapdog.“ (figuratively speaking) to take another weeks idleness, which would be so good for both the body and soul of him, no answer could I obtain but this: “My Dear! it is out of the question! I am up to the ears in a quagmire of Things again! Say every thing that is most kind from me to Lady Stanley; and—I say!—if you like—you can send her one of the little Photographs of me!”

My disappointment at not getting to you myself is great—for I was very happy at Alderley! But I may not say much about it; having just had a month’s
holyday in Scotland, I! I was feeling so ill and suicidal in London that I had to fling over all conjugal delicacies and leave him to the tender mercies of the Maids! merely writing to him a long letter every day to keep him in heart.
It is amazing how well he seems to have done without me!
Will you give my kindest remembrance to the “Bright Beings.“JWC’s name for the younger Stanley das.; cf. 36:214JWC to LST, 30 Aug. 1860.
docBody.name: Jane W. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-[UC], 25 Sept. MS: NLS 7197.75. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT

docBody.p: Accept my thanks for your great kindness,—for the distinguished honour you do us. I forbade Woollner twice over to trouble you on that subject; but he had beneficently persisted,—and procures me admission, after all, into that Edifice, under such terms as I did not expect. Next Sunday,The International Exhibition was not open to the public on Sundays. my Wife and I mean to proceed thither, and try the Gainsboroughs and Reynoldses: next Sunday again, if Wr have returned (whh it is by no means worth his while to do for that object), perhaps he will be able to accompany some farther survey, in the “six miles of gallery“The picture gallery was 1,150 ft. (351 m.) long; the whole exhibition building covered nearly 25 acres (10 ha.). whh I am told there are.
With many thanks and regards, I remain
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady S[LST], 25 Sept. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY STANLEY

docBody.p: Oh thank you dear Lady! I am so glad of that photographPresumably a photograph of the unmarried Stanley das. to add to the rest of the family! But I want yours—and Mr C says; “it is absurd not to have Hers, when you have all the nice Lassies and their Father! Tell her never to mind ugliness! we are all ugly! some of us very ugly indeed! So she must send her own photograph to make the Thing complete!”

To propitiate the Bright Beings I send them one in exchange which may comfort them as to ugliness!Either the recent photograph of JWC by Thomas Douglas (see 178JWC to MCA, [30 Aug.]) or one of the several taken more recently by William Jeffrey; for an example of Jeffrey’s, see oppJWC to JCA, [30 Sept.].
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady S[LST], [27 Sept.]. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd. Dated after JWC to LST, 25 Sept., when JWC asked Lady Stanley for a photograph of herself.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY STANLEY

docBody.p: That is very good of you!— Mr C likes the one with the bonnet “incalculably best.“—“Ugly?“ he says, “I can’t think what she means! that is a very goodlooking woman! Very composed and sensible (!) and—dont you think?—very well dressed!!”— Now—I agree to all that. Only—if it had been a little less “composed,“ and a little less “sensible,“ and a little less carefully dressed. I should have found it, permit me to say! a more agreeable likeness! I like one of the others better—one that looks as if you had that moment sat down, and would in another moment jump up again! and were keeping yourself still by a strong momentary effort of volition. and weren’t the least in the world tightened in your clothes; but could shake them all off, if you liked, cap and all! That is more like you I think! Now; there being such a difference of opinion between us; the only way to please us both would be, to let each keep the one he and she likes best Can you spare two? I keep the composed sensible Lady in the bonnet, in conformity with Mr C’s orders—and I return the other two as in honour bound. But—if you would send me back the one on which I have put my initials in pencil I shall be greatly obliged.
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JCA, [30 Sept.]. MS: NLS 607.600. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
JWC
TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: I am in a perfectly distracting hurry!

I am going to the Tailors after a coat! and trousers! John & George Sampson, tailors and drapers, 2 Princes St., Leicester Sq.; see 35:201 JWC to TC, 14 Sept. 1859
. TC noted in his checkbook, 22 Dec.: “Sampson Tailors / £5..14..6” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). —and you know what
that means!Jean Aitken frequently dealt with TC’s clothing requirements. And I have five letters that must be written before post time! And tomorrow I am going to Dover!!! for two or three days! and I had no sleep till 5 this morning, and only an hour’s, then! and I feel brashed and bedevilled as well as hurried. And nothing is to be expected from me this day but the barest needful! Which is to tell you that three of what I consider the likest and best done photographs I ever saw in my life are gone this day to the Post Office to your addressone for yourself, one for Mary Austin, and one
for Jamie of Scotsbrig. It was necessary to pack them with unbendable mill-board,A thick pasteboard, often used for bookbinding. that the Post men mightn’t crush them purposely; as they often do with such inconvenient parcels So Mr C thought the three should be sent altogether, necessetating only one piece of Mill board!TC wrote mistakenly on the letter: “Tait’s Photh (abt 1850?) / (june, 1855? Has own Photh?).” Robert Tait’s photographs were mainly taken 1856–58; for examples, see vols. 31–33.

figure.p: Jane Welsh Carlyle, by William Jeffrey, September 1862

docBody.p: So when you have chosen your own, will you send the other two, packed as at present, to Mary desiring her to send the remaining one, with the Mill board all to itself, on to Jamie at Scotsbrig; indeed I will charge her myself to that effect tomorrow— Please to send one line directly to put one out of anxiety as to the Photographs having arrived safe.
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

ps.p: I will write at leisure when I have any leisure

div3.sourceNote: JWC-KS[KST], [30 Sept.]. MS: NLS 1797.223. Quot: Fielding and Sorensen 280.
div3.head: JWC TO KATE STANLEY

docBody.p: Darling of the World! Here is what you ask for, and honour me by asking for!Presumably a photograph of herself.

I would try to set off its questionable charms, with a long letter of interesting news; if there were any interesting news known to me just now; except about—the Glasgow murder,Jessie McLachlan (1834–99) was accused of the murder of her friend and fellow servant Jess McPherson, 5 July, at Sandyford Pl., Glasgow. McPherson was butchered with a meat cleaver. The initial suspect was their employer’s father, James Fleming, but further evidence implicated McLachlan; her contradictory replies to questioning led to Fleming’s being released and McLachlan’s being charged. Found guilty, 20 Sept., her agent read a statement from her after the verdict; she claimed that Fleming had murdered McPherson, because she resisted his advances, and then persuaded McLachlan to help cover it up. Despite this she was sentenced to hang 11 Oct., but, because of the strength of public feeling, an investigation was begun, with the execution delayed until 1 Nov. She was reprieved but spent 15 years in Perth prison. She d. in the U.S. The case was widely reported in both Scottish and English newspapers. See The Trial of Jessie M’Lachlan, ed. William Roughhead (Edinburgh and London, 1911). For JWC’s response to the reprieve, see JWC to Lady ALAI, 30 Oct. and that is daily reported in the “Public Prints“;—and if, having some news worth telling, I had any time for telling! But I am in such a hurry Darling! executing as wild a gallop thro’ the Rain morally, as you did the other day physically! I am going to Dover tomorrow,
for two days or at most three; on a visit to a Lady I “swore everlasting friendship with, this summer—Miss Davenport Bromley. I had undertaken to visit her at Wotton Hall, on my way home from Scotland; and, after giving her no end of trouble in writing out Bradshaw details for me; I had taken fright about changing trains at Manchester, in an “unprotected Female“ phase; and about leaving Mr C so long by himself, (poor interesting Babe in the wood!) and in a manner at once impolite and ungrateful had rushed from Edinr to London by the straight road! She is now at Dover, and is goodnatured enough to still want to see me; and so, as it is not far, and as I neednt be gone long enough to be missed. I have agreed to go to her tomorrow.

Meanwhile Mr C wants a new coat and new trowsers! And Oh! if you knew what a job that is for both the tailor, and me! I have already been seeking vainly thro’ half the cloth-shops in London for “a piece of honest cloth, free from devils dust“Flock (wool or cotton refuse), made from old cloth, reduced by a machine called a devil; for an earlier use by TC indicating rubbish, see 30:77TC to JAC, 5 Oct. 1855. that may suit his ideas; and today I have to seek thro’ the other half! And I have various little matters to do for myself and the House! and five letters that must be written before I go out Pity me then! Mr C was greatly pleased with your sweet message! And ejaculated a very plaintive “Ah! Yes!“ when he heard of the wild ride at which he did not assist!
God bless you my Darling
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [30 Sept.]. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries / N B. PM: London, 1 Oct. 1862. MS: NLS 607.596. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:123–24 inc. Quot: Hansons, NE 500–501.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
I am writing two lines at this late hour; because I don’t want the feeling of closeness, that has outlived the precious three weeks we were together, to die out thro length of silence. For the rest; I am not in good case for writing a pleasant letter; having had no sleep last night, and the bad night not having been compensated, as my bad nights at Holme Hill were, strangely enough, by a good day! And I am bothered too with preparations for a journey tomorrow!“Went October 1“ (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:123). What a locomotive animal I have suddenly become! Yes! it is a fact, my Dear, that tomorrow I am bound for Dover! to stay till Monday with that Lady we call “the flight of Sky-larks““Miss Davenport Bromley; her great-grandfather at ‘Wooton,’ in Staffordshire, was the ‘Mr. Davenport’ who gave shelter to Rousseau“ (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:123). Wootton Hall was leased, 1766–67, to Jean-Jacques Rousseau (1712–78), French philosopher; he wrote part of Confessions there. Caroline Davenport Bromley’s great great grandfather Richard Davenport (ca. 1705-71) owned Wootton at the time. who was wanting me to come home by
her Place in Derbyshire. She is now at Dover, in lodgings, for benefit of sea-air; and has invited me there, since I wouldn’t go to Wotton Hall, and Mr C who thought I ought to have come home by her, wishes me to go. And I am sure I have no objections! for I like her much and I like the sea much. But I “am not to be staying away this time, he says, and leaving him long by himself again“! No fear! I must return to London on Monday, or I should not see Charlotte Cushman (who is now in Liverpool, and returns here on Thursday) before her departure for Rome. Indeed, charming as I think the “Flight of Sky Larks“ I should not be unsettling myself again; if only I had kept the better health and spirits I brought back from Scotland. It was too much to hope however that I would keep all that long. The clammy, heavy weather we have had for the last week has put me all wrong somehow. I am sick at stomach—or at heart (I cant tell which) and have a continual irritation in my bits of bowels; and horrid nights. for all which I dare say the sea is the best medecine. I will tell you how it has answered when I come back.

Yes Dear. decidedly I should like much to have a photograph of poor Robert Macturk. and since Mrs Kennedy will only bargain about it; I send not only the one she demands, but one of Mr C also—being liberal, i!— “The twelve stamps“ Bless you! it was the shilling for the hairdresser. You know I wanted another photograph of myself from him. And I am accurate in business matters you may have observed. When people give me anything voluntarily, I take whatever is given me gladly—if I like the giver But when I ask to have a commission done—however small or great I insist on paying for it. love to the Dr. Your own / J W C

ps.p: my compliments to MaryPresumably Mary Healady, Mary Russell’s cook; see 37:109JWC to MR, 1 Feb. 1861. please
if you like this one of Mr C better than your own exchange them.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-CC[CCU], [30 Sept.]. MS: Charlotte Cushman Papers, LC. Pbd: Fielding and Sorensen 279.
div3.head: JWC TO CHARLOTTE CUSHMAN

docBody.p:
Oh my dear dear Friend! Was there ever the like of this? What cross purposes! What have I gone and done? Is it I who have made a huge mistake, or you who have changed your programme? It was clear in my mind, that you
were not to start for Rome till the middle of October! How I came by that impression God knows; but there it was! and if it had only been there! but—I have acted upon it! thought myself safe to engage to spend a week at Dover, with a Lady whom I promised to visit in Derbyshire on my road home from Scotland; and I broke that promise, and so must keep this one! I was to have gone today, but put off till tomorrow being unwell. And now to day comes your dear letter telling me you return the very day after I shall have gone, and, far worse, that you leave for good before my “week“ is out! But that must never be! I will come back on Monday, to get one look of you—will try to come back on Saturday tho’ of that I am doubtful. I will write which day I shall be back, when I see what can be managed—without ungraciousness to the person concernd who is adorably kind to me, tho’ a fine Lady!“
And you—can you—not stay in London till Wednesday and spend Tuesday with me? all day write to me directly to the care of Miss Davenport Bromley, 1 Sidney Villas, Dover—one line will do.

I have been too ill all this day to pack my things or do any thing—so you will see why I write hastily and briefly now about midnight? I will come in the forenoon of Monday at latest and then couldn’t you bothCushman and her friend Emma Stebbins. come here for the evening
docBody.name: JWC

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [1 Oct.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Dover, 1 Oct. 1862; London, 2 Oct. 1862. MS: NLS 607.597B. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:125–27. TC wrote on envelope “(Dover, 2 Octr 1862).“
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.dateline: 1 Sidney Villas / Dover Wednesday afternoon [1 October 1862]
docBody.p: I may take a reasonable sheet of paper, Dear, for besides being not “too tired for writing,“ I have abbundance of time for writing. “the Larks“ being all far up, out of sight beyond the visible sky! looking for me there!— My journey was successful, and I stepped out at Dover worth ‘half a dozen of’ the womon I left Chelsea & curious what a curative effect a rail-way journey has on me, always while you it makes pigs and whistles of! Is it the motion? or is it the changed air?—“god knows“!Coterie speech; see 21:22JWC to TC, 23 Aug. 1846.

The first thing that befell me at Dover was a disappointment. no Larks waiting! not a feather of them to be discovered by the naked eye! The next thing that befell me was to be deceived, and betrayed, and entirely discomfited
by—a sailor! After looking about for the Larks, some ten minutes and being persecuted as long by pressing proposals from Cabmen and omnibus conductors, I was asking a porter how far it was to Sidney Villas. the Porter not knowing the place, a sailor came forward and said he knew it—that it was “just a few steps,“ I “would be there in a minute if I liked to walk“ and he “would carry my trunk for me!” And without waiting to have the question debated he threw my trunk over his shoulder and walked off. I following, quite taken by assault!

And we walked on—and on and oh on—such a distance—certainly two miles at least! the sailor pretending to not hear, every time I remonstrated assuring me “I couldnt find a prettier walk in all Dover than this!”—at last we reached 1 Sidney villa. and when I accused my sailor of having basely misled me, that he might have a job—he candidly owned: “Well, things are dear just now—and few jobs going“!! wiping the sweat from his brow at the same time, and looking delighted with the shilling I gave him! I thought it was all gone to the Devil together, when the man who answered the bell denied that Miss Bromley was there! On cross questioning however he explained that she did reside there; but was not at home. was “gone to the railway to meet a Lady“! and his eye just then squinting on my portmanteau, he exclaimed with sudden cordiality—“perhaps you are the Lady!” I owned the soft impeachment,Coterie speech; see 24:170JWC’s MAAN, 2 Aug. 1849; see Sheridan, The Rivals 5.3. and was shown to the bedroom prepared for me— And have washed and unpacked. Meanwhile Miss B’s maidUnidentified further. who had gone to one Station, while Miss B went to the other, to make sure of me, returned. and gave me a cup of tea, and then went off to catch the poor dear Larks who was waiting for me at a wrong station! There being a third Station (the one, at which I landed)! It hadn’t occurred to either mistress or maid to ask at which of the three Stations the three o’clock train stopt.The 3:00 p.m. train from London to Dover arrived at Dover Town Station at 5:57 p.m., and Dover Pier at 6:00 p.m.; London trains departed from Priory, the third Dover stn. (Bradshaw’s London Railway Guide, Aug. 1862).

Larks come! With feathers all in a fluff! “So dreadfully sorry“ &c &c, dinner not till 7—and to be enlivened by the presence of Mr Brookfield,William Henry Brookfield (1809–74; ODNB; see 20:156JWC to WHB, 1 April 1846, and 36:29JWC to WHB, 27 Dec. 1859), clergyman and school inspector. whom she had met while looking for me.— “7“! and I had only one small cup of tea and one slice of etherial bread and butter. But we “must make it do“!See Charlotte Brontë, Jane Eyre, chap. 8.

This house is within a stone cast of the sea, and also alas of the pier. So that there is as much squealing of children at this moment as if it were Cheyne Row nothing but a white blind to keep out the light of a large window— But
with shutters, and stillness and all possible furtherances I was finding sleep impossible at home; so perhaps it may suit the contradictory nature of the animal to sleep here, without them!
Now upon my word this is a fairly long letter to be still in the first day of absence!!
It will at least show that I am less ghastly-sick and with less worry in my bits of bowels, than when I left in the morning
docBody.name: J W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, [2 Oct.]. Addr: 1. Sidney Villas / Dover. PM: London, 2 Oct. 1862. MS: NLS 616.573. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Oh my dear, my dear! was the like ever heard of? Here am I sunk to the eyes in intricate half-maddening Proofsheets; 3 strikes: “send away the Horse!” & in a minute after Neuberg comes to ride with me;—and I have not a moment for poor Goody, not to speak of Proofs! “Pity, pity me!“— But it shall be better tomorrow.

Your Letter is almost pathetic to me, tho’ cheery of tone. I will make myself believe you did sleep (Heaven grant it), in whh case all will be well.— You were not half an hour gone when Bessie Barnet & Husband sent up their Card; I did not the leastTC wrote “[turn this]“ under “did not the least“ at the foot of the page. neglect them, & had refused to come down, tho’ I bethot me in time. Bessy looks very poorly (was infinitely sensible to yr Letter &c “too much so for writing)“; the Husband I found engaged with this bit of PaperTC presumably enclosed a note from Dr. Blakiston to JWC. on my entering;—a good-natured comonplaceOne of TC’s increasingly common abbreviations was to place a straight line above a doubled letter rather than repeating the letter. looking man; what he says (whh I have not read) is very poor to what Bessy wd say if she cd.

Yellow Letter I know to be from CorkcutterThomas Dixon; see JWC to TC, [27 Aug.]. (and there has come such a Box of Corks &c from him this morning: t’other I guess to be from Willie Richn;Wilhelmina Richardson; see JWC to TC, [27 Aug.]. t’other is from Jean for you (tho’ outside it was addressed to me. Box of rusks from The Grange last night; many and good;—how I wish you had had it yesterday afternoon! No more, no more: all is right here if you be all right. Good be with my poor Goody! T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 3 Oct. MS: NLS 616.574. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Oh Goody, am not I today a useless man! I am going to write you a few words; and go out into the fine air, before my time. With the consciousness of some rubbish annihilated (one Shelf of big Press swept out, ah me!) & of little else comfortable as it shd be.

You might (or perhaps, alas, you might and could not) have stuck into that Letter-cover I gave you, “Slept tolerably!” It wd have been a great comfort to me: but there came nothing. That horrible pluisterUnidentified. from Dumfries (4d to pay for it) came last night,—I cannot think from whom; but the Author ought to get the Cover quietly handed back to him. Alas, it is perhaps poor WilheWilhelmina Richardson. tho’?— The other made me run from my Coffee today to no purpose.

Neuberg was not more seraphic than usual when I got down to him yesterday; but I managed to be goodnatured, and not to golly; also, he is not coming on Sunday Evg: these were two comforts: in the small-rain or Scotch-mist whh had begun upon us. I came home rather fast, and escaped any wet that cd hurt. Too late for sleeping, tho’ I did try it: dinner & tea both very good (you wretch).— I had my beggarly Proof to take to agn; a mere fraction I was inserting; ought to have been done in five minutes (had the Prussn Dryasdust been other than he is!)—and it took me till midnight; and rather hurt one’s sleep after! However, it is reduced to the Cosmic state, and gone from me: the last botheratn of 10,000 whh I have had with that vol IV.— Piper’s sonJohn Piper had been the Chelsea postman until 1857, and was perhaps working there again; his sons were too young to be employed by the postal service, but perhaps helped their father unofficially; see 35:26235:biographical note. left me a whole sheaf of vol V Proofs;—whh I will have the virtue not to look at till tomorrow. This day I have (as you heard) devoted to extinctn of litter hitherto.

Perhaps you had better bid Maria answer the Cork-cutter,Thomas Dixon. if you don’t like to be troubled with him: her Book (because she “was good to him“) is a Goldsmith’s works,Oliver Goldsmith (1728 ?—74; ODNB), author. better than either of mine. Poor devil; a good kind of creature too, only dreadfully fond of writing Notes!

John, as you wd notice, is likely to be up again, and on a fine errand!For John A. Carlyle’s errand, see TC to JAC, 3 Oct. I must write three words to him; & then go. An AdorerUnidentified. has sent me several not quite
useless corrections (to Frh, Sterling & other Books; and does not sign his name. That is the method!— I long much for tomorrow morning (Punch is “addressed“ agn!)To George Braid in Edinburgh; see JWC to TC, [12 Aug.]. Adieu Dearest T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 3 Oct. Addr: Mr Aitken’s (Assembly Street) / Dumfries N.B. PM: London, 3 Oct. 1862. MS: NLS 525.96. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I have hardly a moment, and must be shorter than ever. Yr two Notes came; and were very welcome to me. I also read Jean’s yesterday, as it passed here towards Dover. I am very glad to hear of little Jenny’s being better;—and the hint you give of a likely visit to London is a pleasure and a surprise at once! We shall be right glad to see you beyond bargain: yr old room is vacant for you here;—and I will wish you every success in yr errand; whh will of course be a great kindness to the poor foolish BoyProbably William Watt, who had been in trouble at the Royal Military Academy, Woolwich; see TC to JAC, 3 May. if you can succeed in it, whh I hope is not impossible, since you do not judge it so.

Jane went to Dover Wedny last (day before yesterday): talked of being back “on Monday at latest.“ The miserable weather, of tepid mud for days,—I supposed it to be that,—had quite upset her again; and I was glad this little chance turned up. She reported great good from the ride merely: this morning I heard nothing,—but hope it may be for a favourable reason, and that she is driving abt all the more largely with her Hostess in the fine weather.

I am to have a week of The Grange after all: “abt the middle of this month“ (such is the program at prest, none of the surest) “to take leave before they go to Nice.“ HeLord Ashburton. is not strong by any means, tho’ better than usual just now; and after a great deal of swaying and shifting, has decided as above.

I got last night a great heap of Vol V Proofsheets;—sight of them enough to make one shudder! First half of that Vol. is going to be horridly tough (Seven-Yrs War conclusion); latter half will be I know not what! A tough climb surely; but, once over that hill, there is no other!— Say when you are coming. My affection to all. Yrs ever T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [3 Oct.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Dover, 3 Oct. 1862. MS: NLS 607.598A. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:127–29 inc. TC wrote on envelope: “Dover, Octr 3, / 1862.“
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Oh my Dear! I “did design“Coterie speech; see 3:203JBW to TC, 18 Nov. 1824. to write you a nice long letter today. But “you must just excuse us“ again. I am the victim of “circumstances over which I have no control!”Cf. Dickens, Bleak House (1853) chap. 55. I must put you off with a few lines, and lie down on the sofa of my bedroom, and try to get warm—or—it will be the worse for me!

You see, I am taking every day a warm sea bath, hoping to derive benifit from it—“cha-arge“Coterie speech; see 27:206–7JWC to TC, 5 Aug. 1852. half-a crown! I am afraid I remind you more of the young spendthrift who “lashed down two ounces of tea and a quarter of sugar on the table all at once“ than of “Peggy McGrah’s son that came home with the time of Day in his pocket“!“‘Bad luck to the day that I bore ye, and I wish that I had never rared ye! Ye’er little like Katie MacGrah’s son that came home wid the time o’ day [a watch] in his pocket!’ (Dum-fries Irishwoman to her son, on his returning from an unsuccessful tramp in England. —T. C.)“ (“Mrs. Carlyle’s Note-Book“ and TC’s comment; A. Carlyle, NLM 2:114). Coterie speech; see also 29:313TC to AH, 17 May 1855. But never mind! if I can stave off an illness at the beginning of winter, I shall save in Dr’s bills!

Well, my bath today made me excessively sleepy. and I lay down to sleep, and in five minutes I was called down to Luncheon!—and, after Luncheon I must go with Miss Bromley to call for Lady Doyle! with whom Miss WynneSydney Doyle, b. Williams Wynn (ca. 1814–67), younger sister of Charlotte Williams Wynn, m., 1844, Sir Francis Hastings Charles Doyle (1810–88; ODNB), 2d bart., poet, and civil servant, whom TC had known since 1841; see 13:88TC to JWC, 9 April 1841. just arrived from CarlsbadSpa town 114 mi. (183.5 km.) W of Prague. had been yesterday—might still be today. Our call executed without Miss Wynn; It was proposed we should drive on to Shakespears CliffThe cliffs at Dover; see King Lear 4.1. and when there, we were driven away “over the heights“—a most alarming road—all this time in an open carriage—and now that we are come in, there is not a fire anywhere—never is any fire!—to warm myself at—and so I am not at all in right trim for letter writing—and common prudence requires I should lie down and get into heat.

For the rest it is all right! I have slept very fairly both nights in spite of—
“many things“!See Luke 10:41. Miss B is kind and charming! the Place is “delicious!”Cf. 27:187JWC to TC, 27 July 1852.— And I am certainly much better for the change. But for all that, I am coming home without fail at the time I fixed— Not from any “puritanical“ adherence to my word given, but, that by Monday I shall have had enough of it, and got all the good to be got.

Miss B has pressed me earnestly to stay till Monday week! but no need to bid me “be firm Alicia“!Possibly quoting Edward or Hester Sterling, addressing their housekeeper, Alicia Campbell; see 22:112TC to JWC, 3 Oct. 1847. What a pity about poor Bessy!Bessie Barnet. Willie Richardson would be undecipherable for you— She says she “was always a worshipper of Genius—and recollects one day in particular when Mr Carlyle poured forth such a stream of continuous eloquence that she was forcibly reminded of the lady who spoke pearls and diamonds in the fairy tale!”Charles Perrault, “The Fairies,“ Histoires ou Contes du Temps Passé (Paris, 1697); see 31:201JWC to TC, 29 Aug. 1856. She is very proud of her book and Photographs That absurd Cork maker sends me his photograph!!! I will bring his letter for you, inclosed in mine as it is over weightJWC wrote along the edge of three sheets, leaving no room for a signature.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-ET, 4 Oct. Addr: Farringford / Freshwater / Isle of Wight. PM: Dover, 4 Oct. 1862. MS: Yale. Pbd: Fielding and Sorensen 280.
div3.head: JWC TO EMILY TENNYSON

docBody.p: Your kind note has reached me here, this morning; forwarded, unopened by Mr C, and undevined!

I will not put off answering it, till I shall have talked it over with him. I shall not see him till Monday; and cannot reach him by letter any sooner—tomorrow being Sunday— So I will answer at once, what I know he would bid me answer, were I beside him. That it is very beautiful and tempting what you propose! but—impossible! at this time!— He has a great pressure of work on him, he would throw over the visit to the Grange; only that he had promised it, and put it off, and promised again—and cannot hither and thither any more about it this time; as the Ashburtons are going away to spend the winter at Nice. It will be a very short visit however, and having performed his engagement, he must rush back home to his work—and not dream of prolonging
his holyday, by going on to FreshwaterThe Tennysons’ house, Farringford, was in Freshwater, village and parish in the W end of Isle of Wight. just now. He hopes another time—in happier circumstances, that “the Destinies“ (his particular friends)Coterie speech; see 35:102JWC to IEB, 3 June 1859, and Works 29:375. will permit him &c &c, I know as well that I should be bid say all that, as if he were there saying it!

I return on Monday, and shall then give him your note without telling him what I have written. And, if by possibility—or rather, by impossibility, I have put wrong words in his mouth, I shall be only too happy (I who am not writing Frederick) to unsay them dear Mrs TennysonEmily Tennyson offended JWC in 1858 by inviting her to Freshwater via Woolner and not visiting her directly in Chelsea; see 34:37JWC to TC, 12 July 1858, and 57JWC to TC, 19 July 1858.—
What a beautiful photograph of your Husband, that new one! and there is as good a one of My Husband by the same artist.For William Jeffrey’s photographs of Tennyson and TC, see JWC to MR, [21 Sept.].
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-HL, [5 Oct.]. Addr: 6 Gt Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Dover, 5 Oct. 1862. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by JWC’s return from Dover, Mon., 6 Oct.
div3.head: JWC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: I shall come by the train which leaves here at 12.20 and arrives at 3.30— I am afraid that hour will be too early for your convenience; in which case dont mind me—but if you can conveniently meet me of course I shall be glad. Also—should it be a pouring wet day, it will be better for me to go by a train stopping at the Victoria Station, and go from there in a cab— But let us hope it wont be pouring wet.
There is no use telling you about myself by letter when I am to see you so soon—
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 11 Oct. MS: NLS 525.97. Quote: Froude, Carlyle 4:246.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
My dear Brother,—I firmly intended to write on Thursday, then on Friday;TC writes on Sat., 11 Oct. but was so hustled abt among Proofsheets and botherations, I absolutely cd
not. I have only got done, and saved a minute for you this morning, by— awakening at six (very prematurely), and bolting out to my sheets again, since there was heavy rain, and I cd not bolt out into the air!— — A good big lump is in type (probably a full 4th of the whole Volume); but that is only half the battle; you never saw such a jumble of horrors as the first proofs are: in my bewildering index-less state, and with such Books and blockheadism,—I cannot, single-handed, deal with the thing, except stage after stage in that tentative way. Often enough, I am doing the very last revise, when (after such screwing and torturing) the really vital point of the matter, rule of all the articulation it must have;—will disclose itself to me; overlooked by the fifty Dryasdusts I have been compulsing!— I have only yet got one sheet of Vol V fairly sent away; 2 or 3 more wd have gone in a week: but I wanted to have one, at the least & lowest, before flying off. Vol IV haggled endlessly in Robson’s hands: but it is done, off forevermore;—Time & the hours wear everything to finis, if you persist!

We are just going off to The Grange, for probably a week or nearly so—certainly not for longer. “To take leave,“ it is, they are going to Nice directly, there to pass the winter, Ld A. being weakly & dreading the climate here in the Sun’s absence.— — I will keep this open; and add a word there, if I can tell you we are come. Adieu, therefore, till tea-time at The Grange. Go to Erskine’s by all means.
The Grange (4¼ p.m.)

Here we happily are, then; after a pleasant enough three-hours drive (not four hours from our own door to this); and feel already greatly comforted by the free sight of Mother Earth after so long an interval. All is green & bright here; a silence whh has something of heavenly. Neither Lord nor Lady (coming home themselves today) are yet arrived: only expected every minute. Write soon; do not forget my kindest regards to Mr Erskine & Household. Yours ever affecte T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 17 Oct. MS: NLS 517.39. Quot: A. Carlyle, NL 2:213–14.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
If I do not write you a word at present, it cannot be said to be for want of time,—there being nothing but utter idleness provided as my portion here today and every day:—no lack of “time“ at all; but a plentiful lack of every
other requisite, as composure, silence, news to send, or even a feasible human pen to write them with! Never mind: here is a scrap of a word to you; whh will convey what is needful before the week quite end.

We came hither last Saturday, are to stay till tomorrow,—one week of perfect inaction and rural exposure: it is the only taste of country I have had for a year past. It has not been wholl[y]Letter omitted. unpleasant, tho’ somewhat mournful & confused to me;—so many changes done by fleeting Time in these localities as elsewhere, since I knew them first!TC first visited The Grange Sept. 1844; see 18:198JWC to TC, 11 Sept. 1844. Our weather has been very unsteady, seldom without some beauty; and I have had a spell or two of very rapid riding,—upon blood horses on country downs, far beyond my pace in the London neighbourhoods. Yesterday (Thursday) was one of the beautifullest days of the year: we went driving a 14 miles to Hursley,Hursley Park, 4½ mi. (7 km.) SW of Winchester, Hampshire. the place where Oliver Cromwell’s Son Richard got his wife, and lived during all his young years (his wife herself all her years, being born lady):Richard Cromwell (1626–1712; ODNB), politician and lord protector of England 1658–59; m. , 1649, Dorothy (1627–76), da. of Richard Maijor (1604–60) of Hursley, which she inherited. They lived together at Hursley until Richard Cromwell fled to mainland Europe at the Restoration, 1660; Dorothy continued to live there, sending money from the estate to support her husband. it is now for 150 years past in the possessn of other people;Hursley was sold, 1718, to Sir William Heathcote (1693–1751), merchant and politician, and was currently owned by his great-great-grandson Sir William Heathcote (1801–81), 5th bart., and his 2d wife, Selina, b. Shirley (d. 1901). but there are many Cromwell remains there, Letters of C’s very genuine, a Portrait (imaginary) &c &c: a very pretty place, and very polite people; so that, in the fine weather and fine drive, we did very well. Today, in return, it is regular November storms of rain & wind and falling leaves;—but promises now to mend, and admit riding, or at least walking before the hours end. “Photographer“Robert Vernon Heath is here too, taking innumerable “views,“ these two days, of the House (inside, outside, top & bottom), of the peopleOther visitors at The Grange included Louisa and Emily Baring, Samuel Wilberforce, William Wetmore Story and family, Mary Anstruther (see JWC to MR, 21 Oct.), George Stovin Venables (see TC to JAC, 23 Oct.), and General Sir William Gomme (1828–87) (see Henry James, William Wetmore Story and His Friends [Edinburgh and London, 1903] 2:199). of the &c &c;—seems to me to be a considerable of a Humbug!— — The Lord & Lady are going for Nice directly; nothing can exceed their friendliness & hospitality to my Helpmate & me. Helpmate seems to like it better than I! We go home tomorrow, positive as her bargain.— I suppose the Doctor is gone to Linlathen;To visit Thomas Erskine. yr James is appointed to Chelsea for sunday
Evg. What hideous accidt that of the Glasgow-Edr Railway!The railway accident took place Mon., 13 Oct., 6:30 p.m., at Craigtonbridge, nr. Winchburgh, W. Lothian, about 12 mi. (19.5 km.) W of Edinburgh. The Times reported, 15 Oct.: “a fatal and disastrous collision occurred on the Edinburgh and Glasgow Railway, resulting in the death of 16 persons and the serious injury of a large number of passengers. The collision took place between the ordinary train leaving Glasgow at 5 p.m. and the Scottish Central express from Edinburgh to Perth at 6 o’clock.“ Thank God, none of ours there. Ever affectionately Yrs T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-GC[GMC], 20 Oct. Addr: Holywood / Belfast Ireland. PM: London, 21 Oct. 1862. MS: Univ. of Calif. Santa Cruz. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO GEORGIANA CRAIK

docBody.p: What a Brute you must be thinking me; that I should have been all this while without thanking you and—kissing you, for your Book!Georgiana Craik, Winifred’s Wooing. A Novelette (1862). But; “if you knew how I have been situated“! (Mr C’s constant excuse for all his sins of o(!)missionJWC spelled “omission“ with an extra “m,“ crossed it out, and added “(!).“ and commission)

In the first place the Book came when I was away—at Dover. On my return I found that Mr C had engaged we should both go to The Grange in a few days. And I had toilets to get up “at the shortest notice, and on the most reasonable terms“ (as the Undertaker signboards have it) And the trouble it costs to make one’s outside presentable amongst Lords and Ladies, (especially when it is an old and worn outside) on pin money of twenty pounds per annum is “only to be felt not described“! Nevertheless I found time, or made it, to read your Book before setting off; and the hours spent in reading it were the only pleasant ones of that week;Lena Eden (1826–79) reviewed it in the Athenaeum, 18 Oct.: “It is sometimes a relief to meet with a novel … which has no plot whatever, and no mystery, and no hidden meaning, and no particular moral,—with no pretention to being witty, or learned, or philosophical, or metaphysical, or religious, or, in short, to be anything at all, except just what it is—a thing ‘to take up in some tired or idle hour, when a better book might be thrown away’“ (492). and I “did design“ to write to you from the Grange, and tell you I liked this Book best of all you had written. But alas! at the Grange sufficient for the day was the talking and the driving and the dressing thereof!Cf. Matt. 6:34. And throughout the whole week we staid, I did not get one line written to any man, woman or child! I returned the day before yesterday. and now thank you with all my heart, tho’ late. And to make my peace—if you
should still think me a Brute—I send you two wee Photographs which look pitiful enough to obtain forgiveness from anybody for anything! Tell your Father his newspaperBelfast News-Letter; see TC to JWC, 21 Aug. found me in Dumfriesshire. and relieved me from “a certain“ alarm I had been feeling at what somebody had said; that “they had been making fun of me in the newspapers“! Love to him and MaryGeorgiana’s sister. Yours always affectionately
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-VB, 21 Oct. MS: Hilles. Hitherto unpbd. Vincenzo Botta (1818–94), Italian writer, moved to U.S. 1853 and became prof. of Italian literature and language at Univ. of the City of New York. Botta m., 1855, Anne Charlotte, b. Lynch (1815–91), American poet, feminist, and literary hostess, whom the Carlyles met with Charles Butler Nov. 1853; see JWC to LA, 19 Nov. 1853; see also TC to CBU, 28 May 1856.
div3.head: TC TO VINCENZO BOTTA

docBody.p: I was sorry to have missed you yesterday: being much occupied at present, I am liable to that kind of accident.
If you can come to us Tomorrow (Wednesday) Evening, at 8 o’clock, we shall be very happy to see you, and give our news for Mr. Butler.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: V. Botta Esq &c &c

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, 21 Oct. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries. PM: 22 Oct. 1862. MS: NLS letter 607.599; envelope 607.598B. Pbd: A. Carlyle NLM 2:271–75; Wilson 5:472–74 inc. Quot: Hansons, NE 502.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: I am not doing “what England expects of me“—my duty!— I ought to begin writing, at least, half a dozen letters that are troubling my conscience; and here am I writing to you, from no sense of duty at all, but because I like it!

Well! my wanderings for this year are over! and it must be owned they have been far and wide! The Grange visit was very successful. Every time, I come
away from there with increased affection for the Lady, and in a sort of amazement at her excessive kindness to me. That she is naturally a very kind woman, and also a very demonstrative woman, is not enough to account for the sort of passion she puts into her expressions of fondness and unwearied attentions to me! I always wonder, will it last?—but it has lasted a good while now; and I begin to feel ashamed of myself for not accepting it all with absolute faith.

Mrs Anstruther came for two days. and pressed me to spend my Xmas with her; as Lady A would be away at Nice all the winter. But the answer to that was simply “impossible“! I told her about meeting Mr SmithRev. David Smith; see JWC to TC, [15 Aug.]. at your house, and she said in her soft silky, rather drawly voice. “Oh! dear Mrs Carlyle! did you ever in all your life see so ugly a man?“—

The Bishop of Oxford was there too—and Mr C set him right in two Scripture quotations!!! But the most interesting visitor was Mr Storey the Americain Sculptor, who sang like an angel!William Wetmore Story. He had arrived in England in May to visit the International Exhibition, where his sculptures the Libyan Sibyl (1860) and Cleopatra (1860) were being shown. His letters to the Daily News, 1861, on the American Civil War, pbd. as The American Question (1862), sharply influenced English opinion in favor of the Unionists. Story recalled an evening at The Grange, where TC described the Civil War “as the burning-out of the smokiest chimney of the century,“ and engaged in debate with Wilberforce: “‘Good conscience, my Lord Bishop—what was ever the use of such a thing to any man? Take two of the best men that ever lived—what good did his good conscience ever do to Oliver Cromwell or to St Paul?’“ The Bishop protested at their mention in the same breath. “‘Well then, confine it, if ye will to St. Paul. With his good conscience he was the most meeserable of men’“ (Henry James, William Wetmore Story and His Friends [1903] 2:199–200). According to a college friend, Story had “a beautiful bass voice, and was a member of the only college glee club existing at that time“ (Mary Elizabeth Phillips, Reminiscences of William Wetmore Story [1897] 49). There was a Photographer down for three days taking views of the place at the easy rate of five guineas a-day! and Lady A made him photograph me sitting with herself standing beside me;A photograph of JWC and Lady Ashburton sitting under the Portico of The Grange (see Fielding and Sorensen opp. 155) may have been taken at this time. and he did another of Lord A and Mr C sitting on the same bench, under the PorticoSee 248JWC to EFO, 30 Oct. For The Grange’s front elevation, see 33:159TC to JWC, 17 Jan. 1858.—and another of a whole party of us sitting about on the steps of one of the Porticos. That one was half good, and the other half spoiled. Lord A, one of his Sisters, and Mrs Anstruther “had moved“—Mr C and Lady A, and the other Sister, and myself “came out perfect“— And so we “perfect“ ones were all together, we were to be “cut out“ from the failed ones. I haven’t seen the Photographs on paper yet; but hope to have them in a few days. and if they are worth anything I will send you them—to look at at least! But the rose-coloured petticoat! Oh my Dear!—I must tell you about
the first appearance of that! I put it on, the second day, and the black silk tunic trimmed with half a yard wide black lace (immitation) with long falling sleeves lined with rose colour—and a great bunch of rose-coloured ribbon on my breast, and smaller boughs at the wrists of my white under sleeves. It was really (as Miss Baring said) “quite a costume“! And in spite of its prettiness, I couldnt help feeling nervous about appearing, for the first time, in a guise which would make me remarked by all the women at least! So I dressed in good time, that I mightn’t have to walk into the drawing-room when many people were down. There had been some uncertainty about the dinner hour that day, as people were coming from London by a late train. At all events I should hear the gong sound for dressing I thought half an hour before dinner; and in the mean time I sat down, all ready, to read a novel. How long I had sat, without hearing either bell or gong I can’t say; but I was startled from my reading by a sharp knock at my bedroom door and the voice of one of the menservants informing me “every body was gone in to dinner“!
