Upon my honour, I can believe some hardened wretches have gone out to be hanged with less emotion than I had in hurrying along the corridor and down the great staircase, to have the two leaves of the dining-room door flung wide open before me by two footmen! and then to walk up the great room to my seat at the dining-table; every body’s head turned to see who was so late! To put the finishing stroke to my agony, the rose coloured petticoat was a trifle too long in front for the stooping way in which I walked, and was like to trip me at every step! But bad moments and good moments and all moments pass over! I got into my seat, Lord knows how, and any one who had heard me complaining aloud to Lady A up the table, that the gong had never been sounded, would have fancied me endowed with all the self-possession I could have wished!

Another ordeal was in store for me and my “costume“ later. Being Sunday night, the Bishop was to read a chapter and say prayers in that same dining-room before all the Servants, and such of the visitors as would attend. Eight and thirty servants were seated along two sides of the room; the men all in a line, and the women all in a line; and with these thirty eight pairs of eyes on me (six pairs of them belonging to Ladies maids!!) I had to sail up, in all that rose-colour to the top of the room, on the opposite side, first! the other Ladies being all members of the family pushed me into that horrid dignity. And the same in going out, I had to walk the length of the room—like to trip myself at every step, with the petticoat and the embarrassment!—befor one of that frightful line of servants budged!

It took all the compliments paid me on the costume to give me courage to put it on a second time! As an old Aunt of Mr C’s said when she had become somehow possessed of a one pound note and didn’t know where on earth to
hide it for safety. “They’re troubled that have the world; and troubled that want it“!TC’s grandmother Margaret Aitken; see 15:15–16JWC to TC, 14 Aug. 1842. And now my letter is long enough. And it is bedtime I was so glad of your dear letter yesterday— If you were my Sister I couldn’t have you nearer my heart, or more in my thoughts.
Love to the Dr—a kiss to Ripp, whose likeness I have opposite my bed.
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

ps.p: PS I did drive one day a great long road to the address of Mrs Clarke’s “Bell,“Probably Isabelle Wight Duncan, b. Clark (1812–78; ODNB), whose book Pre-Adamite Man (1860) Mary Russell had sent JWC; see 36:52JWC to MR, 28 Jan. 1860. Duncan currently lived in Bayswater, W London; see TC to JAC, 30 Oct. but she was “in the country.“

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 23 Oct. MS: NLS 525.98. Quot: Froude, 4:252; Southern 277–78.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
My dear Brother,—Your welcome Notes and kind remembrances of me all arrived duly: besides the Grange Note, a Saturday Review on Tuesday after we had got home, and were settling; and the day after that, a more articulate message, whh did me good in my then low estate. The Review Article was by Venables;George Stovin Venables commended the broad sweep of Frederick: “As a biographer, and … as a philosophic teacher, [Carlyle] professes to notice events and persons only as they affect the character and career of his hero; but it is fortunately as necessary that he should connect Frederick’s life with the contemporaneous history of Europe as that a physiologist should expound the relation of food or of air to animal organization. In the midst of the digressions … Mr. Carlyle will be found to have … written a history of the war of the Austrian Succession which can be understood and remembered“ (Saturday Review 14 [18 Oct. 1862]: 478).—not a bad thing at all; excellt in comparison to much that I suppose to be going, tho’ I have read only this, and long ago one other. They really do me no ill, the adverse ones, or inconceivably little; and hardly any good, the most flattering of the friendly: in my bitter solitary struggle continued almost to the death, I have got to such a contempt for the babble of idle ignorant mankind about me as is sometimes almost apallingThus in MS. to myself! “What are they to me; what am I to them,—in the presence of very Fate & Fact!”— However, as two other Copies of the Venables were pleased to come (one from Venables himself, who had spoken of it recently to Jane at the Grange, and one I guess from James Aitken),—I have sent them all off among
the kindred this day, fair wind to them;—the rather as I had plenty of waste-paper, and the tables needed clearing.

Saturday in Hampshire was one of the wettest days I ever saw; but it dried towards evg, & we came up by a very good train,—home here abt 9 o’clock, and very glad one of us to be so. I had one or two wild gallops on blood horses overfed; the company was harmless (interesting in part, some N. American people called Story, Roman by common residence); and the kindness of Lady A; to say nothing of her Lord, was really a thing to be recognised as altogether perfect and unusual. Nevertheless I felt tumbled completely heels-over-head; in very considerable pain and derangt of body all the time;—and staggered about for a couple of days here before I cd get fairly to work again. I calculate it has done me good too;—but nothing can be really good except Finis to that sad Volume now dragging itself along under all the strength of pull that I have left for it. Courage, we shall get done! There is hardly above one sheet of it fairly away from me forever; but there will soon be 5 or 6 in that happy conditn, I hope; and certainly above ⅓ of the Volume stands roughly in type. And no other Vol. coming; none, that is it!It was in Nov. 1863 that TC realized he would have to write a sixth vol. of Frederick; see Wilson 5:531.

I am going to walk today;—otherwise there had been no time for this: and there is still an importt thing whh I must not forget; read the inclose Letter from Butler, and you will see what. And return it to me, with yr opinion on the point raised: “Shall I have the cash“ (27 per cent loss upon it), “or shall I let him reinvest it, as it falls due?“See TC to JAC, 30 Oct. Botta who was here yesternight, a very honest Turin Italian, gave us plenty of news abt America: Nothing but “prosperity“ visible in N. York, trade so brisk &c;—going to whip Creation after all, especially to swallow the South out of hand (big fleet ready for bombarding Charlestown &c &c): war, if the South prove positive, “may last for thirty years,“ thinks Ba! Did you ever hear of a prettier quarrel abt nothing at all?— — Write to me Yours ever T. Carlyle

ps.p: The blue Pamphlet,Unidentified. whh accompanies, is nothing. Ask LaingDavid Laing when you have read. Irving,Probably Rev. John Irving (ca. 1797–1870) of Bonshaw in Annan parish, Dumfriesshire, army chaplain. I somehow guess, must be a Bonshaw Episcopaln Parson-Shadow?—

div3.sourceNote: TC-HK, 30 Oct. Addr: Yarm / Yorkshire. PM: London, 31 Oct. 1862. MS: UCLA. Hitherto unpbd. Herman Kindt, ed., The Autographic Mirror (‘Autographe cosmopo-lite’), containing facsimiles of documents, letters, etc. by sovereigns, statesmen, warriors, divines … literary, scientific, 4 vols. (1864–66).
div3.head: TC TO HERMAN KINDT

docBody.p: “Peter Piper picked a peck of pepper out of a paper poke“:Presumably Kindt had asked TC for an autographed specimen, although this was not published. The Autographic Mirror contained two facsimiles of TC’s writing: the Scots nursery rhyme “Simon Brodie had a cow,“ dated 23 Jan. 1849 (see 26:174JWC to TC, 14 Sept. 1851; The Autographic Mirror 2: plate 162), about which Kindt wrote: “One of the most celebrated writers of England, to whose career we shall shortly return. We now content ourselves with the remark that it is sufficiently curious that the moralist of his age, the historian of the French Revolution, should have written the Scottish doggrel that we reproduce“ (The Autographic Mirror 2:67); presumably he thought this autograph even less suitable. He also included TC’s letter to David Lester Richardson, 19 Dec. 1837 (see 9:372–75TC to DLR, 19 Dec. 1837; The Autographic Mirror 3: plates 12–13). versteht sich [does it explain itself]?—T. Carlyle
Chelsea, 30 octr 1862

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 30 Oct. MS: NLS 517.40. Quot: Southern 278.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Dear Brother,—I had decided to take yr advice (whh was also my own notn) abt the American Money-Affair; and this day, just after yr new tidings, I have written to Mr Butler in that sense anyway; namely that he is to “reinvest &c as he likes, and send Mr Adamson ‘notice from time to time’ (I did not say expressly, at the old term days,Samuel Adamson, Robert Adamson’s nephew, took over TC’s affairs after his uncle’s death in 1861. Charles Butler had been worried for some time about fluctuations in the markets and wrote to Samuel Adamson, 28 Feb., that [he] had “delayed this remittance for quite 28 days (it should have been on 1 Feby) on account of the state of exchanges. The rate being very high at present (15% for sight exchange) but I dared not delay longer. / I have no doubt that exchange will fall here shortly below present rates“ (Kimball 292). The term days (when Butler sent TC the interest on his investments) were 1 Feb. and 1 Aug.; see 36:79TC to CBU, 28 Feb. 1860. but hinted it) and ‘the Vouchers, so often as they rise to be worth sending’“ (these latter are my words). I mentioned to him the arrival of Adamson’s Letter, and your sending notice of it to me— I[n]Letter omitted. short, I had better enclose the Letter altogether (now that I bethink me): You can then write to Adamson what is proper. I shd say, To formalize into a busss from the roughly expressed wish I have signified: “Do send (and
be punctual), instead of money precise notice,—shall we say,—“once in the Half-Year; and vouchers“—in fact do you settle it, and take order with Adamson. Do,—that it fall on yr poor head, not on mine whh is still more pitiable at prest!Although TC asked John A. Carlyle to deal with these and other financial matters, there was no mention in his surviving letters to John of TC’s loan to Mary Austin, 30 Oct.: “‘lent’ to Sister (Austin) ‘for 4 months’—£100..00..0“ (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). The purpose of the loan is not known.

We are going on passably; I am a little threatening to suffer from Winter weather, but not yet much suffering; I—terribly interrupted for one thing. “Dr Dalgliesh,“ a great big black fellow, son of “the Rector“ at Annan,Dr. William Dalgleish (ca. 1805–84) lived at Masham, Yorkshire. His father, William Dalgleish, was “for many years rector of Annan and afterwards of Eskbank Academy“ (Carlisle Journal, 1835). now an Ex-Dr & solid Farmer somewhere in Yorkshire, staggered in one day: the next day, “George John Duncan“ of Ruthwell & Wife:George John Craig Duncan (1806–68), gen. secretary of the English Presbyterian Church, son of Rev. Henry Duncan (1774–1846; ODNB; see 1:223TC to AC, 26 Jan. 1820), an old friend of TC. His wife was Isabelle Wight Duncan; see JWC to MR, 21 Oct. &c &c. There is a certain Lady now in Edinr, a French Madame & Widow now, but once a Beauty in Annan, and still earlier a small “Jean Johnston“Jean Otthenin. at Tom Donaldson SchoolTom Donaldson School, Ecclefechan; see 7:346TC to DH, 19 Dec. 1834. along with me in the very morning of Life; whose pretty little face & straw-bonnet I quite well remember: now in Edinr “consulting Doctors“ abt some Child or Children of hers;—try a little if you can fish out her address:Otthenin lived with her das. Margaret and Irma at 33 Northumberland St., Edinburgh. if you can, I may give you a farther message; if you cannot, a surer indicatn tho’ a more troublesome.
docBody.name: T. C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-EF[EFO], 30 Oct. MS: NLS 1797.69. Addr: George Hotel / Bangor Ferry / North Wales. PM: London, 31 Oct. 1862. Quot: Bliss, JWC 293–300; Hansons, NE 502.
div3.head: JWC TO ELIZA FORSTER

docBody.p:
The news of you would have been too long in coming, if I had not gone and inquired about you at Frederick Chapman, and learnt from him that you were “greatly better“Eliza Forster had been ill for some time; see TC to JWC, 1 July.— I am sure nobody out of your own family can be
gladder of that than I am!— Another time, you will go away more hopefully—with more faith in the benifit of “a change“—won’t you? even with a long fatiguing journey to front. Decidedly when one is weakly, and poorly “a change“ is new life—for us women! It is almost ridiculous, the number of times that I have left London with a private idea I should not live to come back, and come back “another creature“! The wisest Dr I know (a scotch one“Dr Russell“ (TC’s note on MS). of course) told me when I was in Nithsdale the other day; “whenever you feel to be getting weak and low—nervous—sleepless—all that sort of thing; don’t sit still, listening to your sensations—dont send for a Doctor, and take “mixtures“; but pack your carpet-bag and put yourself on a railway—to anywhere“! Since I have been following that advice, I have made experience of its soundness. And look at your Husband (Bless him!) What a change for the better has been wrought on him, since he had to pack his carpet bag so often, and go on railways to somewhere!John Forster was a member of the Lunacy Commission, traveling throughout England and Wales to inspect hospitals for the insane; see 37:213–14TC to JF, 17 Aug. 1861. I expect you to return without that tired look which I understand so well! and with your eyes as bright as the[y]Letter omitted. are by nature. And then I shall expect you to drive very often to Cheyne Row. and let us try to Cheer one another up a bit. Hang it! why mightnt we go sometimes, with a mutual carpet bag, and spend a day and night at some way-side Inn, when we feel to need “a change“ from our own comfortable homes, and men-of-genius Husbands!—

But do be careful in the meantime, not to over-do your strength. Such long walks are rash. And for all so anxious as your Husband is about you, he is—a man! And men I have had occasion to observe always estimate a woman strength by their own—have too much leaning to Miss Dombey’s idea of the expediency in all cases to “make an effort.“Cf. Dickens, Dombey and Son, chap. 18.

Our visit to the Grange was as pleasant, as “beautiful Nature,“Coterie speech; see 26:142JWC to HW, 27 Aug. 1851. “High Art,“Cf. 21:240TC to RB, 23 June 1847. and the perfection of human kindness could make it! All the more pleasant that the party was not so large as usual. The Bishop of Oxford was there two days, and He and Mr C argued extensively; Mr C being always on the religious side and the Bishop on—the other side! But “if he is a Humbug (Mr C said) and of that there can be no doubt; at least it must be owned he is a very amiable Humbug! and has a great deal of natural stuff and manly vigour in him,“—Storey the Sculptor was there too, with wife and daughter. And we got quite fond of the whole lot before they left; altho’ they are Yankees.

Elise got me up in a rose coloured petticoat, with a black tunic (good god!), which made me the envy of surrounding women. “Quite a costume!” said one, “May I ask, Mrs Carlyle what Madame Elise charged you for that dress“? said another. (Emily Baring) “No—you may not, I answered, I can only tell you, it was not more than I could easily pay“!

The same high bred Lady asked if she might ask whether Lady Sandwich had mentioned Mr Carlyle or me in her will!!! “Dear me! no! (I said) she did not mention Lord Ashburton in her will; how could you dream of her mentioning us!“

We staid just the one week Mr C had agreed to stay—and he was very
impatient to be “home to one’s work“ all the while. The little mouthful of human Life did him good however; in spite of the terrific growling he carried on in my room. There was a Photographer (Vernon Heath) there, taking “Views“ and “Interiors“ at the easy rate of five guineas a day and as much french cookery and champagne as he could stow into him

figure.p: Lord Ashburton and Thomas Carlyle, by Vernon Heath, October 1862

docBody.p: Lady A made him take Lord A and Mr C sitting on one bench; which was intended to come out a touching illustration of modern friendship—but—she tells me—it has come out a picture of two Criminals in one dock; the one (Lord A) having received his sentence of death, and sinking away into insensibility; the other (Mr C) in the act of receiving his, and glaring back uneasy defiance!!See oppabove. She thinks I will hardly like to possess a copy of it. tho the man Heath thinks it “one of his most successful efforts“ and has made it into “a——transparency“!“Photh still here, in Her bedroom“ (TC’s note on MS).

Since I returned I have been up to the ears in household business. My Poetess with the Titian hair“‘Maria’ (the Hampshire piece of Affectatn)“ (TC’s note on MS). having gone to pigs and whistles! and also I have had a threatening of Influenza—that is why I have not thanked you for your letter sooner.
Mr C declares there was “never a more despicable imposition than the illustrated news views.“[X] (of what!)“ (TC’s note on MS). He was there and saw.
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A[LAI], 30 Oct. MS: NLS 20767.50.52. Quot: Fielding and Sorensen 282–83.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY AIRLIE

docBody.p:
Dearest Lady Airlie! don’t think it!— I am not—indeed I am not an ungrateful little Brute, I was right glad of your letter; I am always glad of any sign of remembrance from you; and my long delay in thanking you for it, has been a proof—if you could only see it—of my particular regard!— You can’t see it?— Let me explain.— If it had been Lady some-other-name that I didn’t care about, who had written me a letter; I should have dashed off an answer in two lines,—such an answer as can be written under any “pressure of things“—such an answer as even “Field Marshall the Duke of Wellington“ found always time to write.Arthur Wellesley (1769–1852; ODNB), 1st duke of Wellington, field-marshal, and politician; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 105–6; “His normal routine was to rise at six and write letters until nine“ (ODNB). But being you that I do care for, and have cared for ever
since you wrote me the queer wee letter in half-text, I wished to write a more elaborate and “purpose-like“ answer, than I had then leisure of mind for; and so waited for leisure of mind! Do you accept the logic of my apology? Hardly? Well never mind! The chances are, you have never turned it in your thoughts whether I had answered or not! I am so extraneous an item in your life! If I had kept my own secret, I might have been now addressing you on the (seemingly) “Voluntary Principle“— But I never do keep my own secret! that was the fatal weakness which the “old bad Fairy,“ who came “uninvited“ to my Xning,For “christening.“ bewished me—to spoil all the other giftings!Cf. the fairy tale “Sleeping Beauty.“

Can you imagine me, the most still standing woman of your acquaintance, suddenly made “like unto a wheel“?Cf. Ps. 83:13. See also 7:73–74TC to JSM, 20 Jan. 1834. For the last two months and more, I have been whirling here and whirling there just like—other people! Five weeks in Scotland, up and down among my own relations and Mr C’s; then a week at Dover with my new friend Miss Davenport Bromley! then a week at the Grange. And all the time except the one week at the Grange was Mr C left at home by himself—to try how he liked it! It was a great strain on my wifely conscience to leave him to the tender mercies of the maids, one a Methodist and a Poetess, the other a Blockhead or as he calls her a “mooncalve“! But I must either have done that, or sent for a Doctor and entered on a new carreer of “Mixtures for Mrs Carlyle.“ I think I chose the better part, and really he stood my absence extremely well—so well that my vanity was a little aggrieved. And as a woman must always give a varnish of duty to her pleasures; I try to persuade myself—or “others“—that my larking about will have the effect of keeping off my usual winter-long Influenza, and so making me a more helpful and cheerful companion for him!— I wish to Heaven he would have gone too, for a longer “change“ than that one week at the Grange; so as to make him a more cheerful companion to me! which he “is anything BUT“ (as my housemaid says)— “All work and no play makes Jack a dull Boy“! Ach! Doesn’t it?

It was very pleasant at the Grange. That Lady is adorably kind! I never in all my life met with a more considerate, unselfish Hostess. As for the caprice which I hear her frequently accused of; I have never seen a trace of it! She seems wholly occupied from morning till night in making her Husband and all about her as happy as possible in a conditional world.See Works 24:370 and 20:129.

They are going off to Nice next week—for His gout. Nice!— I wish they
were all safe back from that fatal place, which I should have thought he would never have chosen.Lord Ashburton’s first wife, Lady Harriet, went to Nice for her health; she was returning to England when she d. in Paris, 4 May 1857; see 32:147JWC to MR, 18 May 1857.
I am sending you a pair of photographs, one of which must find welcome for both. I should not have offered you mine on its own basis.

Oh such a photographing there was at the Grange! Vernon Heath was there doing “views“ and “interiors“ at the easy rate of five guineas a day and as much french cookery and champagne as he could stow into him. Like all the artists (he calls himself an artist) patronised by “our lamented Prince Consort“Prince Albert d. 14 Dec. 1861; see JWC to MW, [28 Dec. 1861]. he is pretty much of a Humbug, I think! Lady A made him photograph Lord A and Mr C sitting on the same bench under the Portico. It was hoped they would make a touching illustration of faithful friendship; but they have come out, she tells me, “a pair of horrid criminals in the same dock! one (Lord A) as if he had already had sentence of death pronounced on him, and was sinking away into deliquium; the other (Mr C) in the act of hearing his sentence, and glaring back anxious defiance!” But Mr Heath declared it to be one of his most successful efforts, and had “made them into a transparency!“— And I am to have “a transparency.“ Won’t it be nice? He did Lad[y]Letter omitted. A and me, not “sitting on one bench“ but me sitting and her standing over me. That he had not shown her yet. By the way, are you not glad that wretched Mrs Maclachlan is not to be hanged on Saturday?Jessie McLachan; see JWC to KS[KST], [30 Sept.]. How any body in his senses could doubt that the old manJames Fleming. did the murder is incomprehensible to me! By the way again, do you know that Magdalen Smith has been married by a highly respectable, very handsome and clever Artist?Madeleine Hamilton Smith (1835–1928; ODNB) of Glasgow, accused of murdering Pierre Émile L’Angelier (1823–57) by poisoning him with arsenic, 23 March 1857; the case was found “not proven“; see 32:172JWC to MR, 5 July 1857. She m., July 1861, George Wardle (1836–1910), artist; later foreman-manager of William Morris’s decorating company. with his eyes open; for on applying to the clergyman in WorcesterUnidentified further. who has kept her since soon after the trial, for leave to make proposals to “his Ward“ the good man felt it his duty to tell him every thing known of her. He replied that it made no difference He loved the girl and thought she loved him and so— A friend of mine saw them on their marriage tour looking quite happy and innocent Dont send me any grouse we really dont like it so well as chicken—your ever affectionate JWC

div3.sourceNote: TC-Librarian of the London Library [RH], [ca. 1 Nov.]. MS: Duke. Pbd. Larkin BQR 75–76; Wilson 5:493. Robert Harrison (1820–97; ODNB), librarian of the London Lib. 1857–93.
div3.head: THOMAS CARLYLE TO LIBRARIAN OF THE LONDON LIBRARY

docBody.p: Please don’t trouble me abt this Book any more!TC’s note is written on the back of a printed notice, dated 1 Nov., from the London Lib. asking for the return of “Strauss’ Jesus 3V / which he took out on the 3rd June“; David Friedrich Strauss, Life of Jesus, trans. Mary Ann Evans, 3 vols. (1846). TC gave the notice to Larkin, asking him to take it and explain that he “had never had, or seen the book“ (BQR 76). I never had it, never saw it (nor wished to see it, nor shall wish), your copy or another.
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lord A[LOA], 2 Nov. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Pbd: Wilson 5:478 inc.
div3.head: TC TO LORD ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Dear Lord Ashburton,—On, at last, fairly considering the Horse Question, “Fritz“ (my own poor old quadruped) versus your noble Grey (whh might be mine), I have to admit:
1°. That poor old Fritz is adequate apparently to carry me thro’ his Namesake’s sad Business (more adequate, at least, than I am to be carried);
2°. That he is my old friend (almost the one friend I am to have in these dark winter months); whom it were a sin, and a remorse, to desert in his decay;
3°.. That change of any kind will be attended with trouble, with uncertainty, —better to be avoided in this my nearly extinct conditn;—

And, in fine, that I am not permitted to accept your flattering Offer; but only to regard it (whh I always will and must) as a beautiful bit of friendly munificence,—and in that way, retain the soul of it, as a lasting possession.— This is the real truth of the affair.

Till Friday night it had never struck me that the Horses were going to Tattersall’sTattersall’s, horse auctioneers, Hyde Park Corner, Knightsbridge, est. by Richard Tattersall (ca. 1725–95; ODNB), 1766. probably on Monday; and that it was necessary to have the full List of them! I hope I am still in time.

The Two Criminals in the dock are miserable creatures;For Heath’s photograph of Lord Ashburton and TC, see JWC to EFEFO, 30 Oct., and 248. but otherwise have merit. Jane has carefully put them into her Book.JWC’s photograph album; see JWC to TC, [5 Sept.]. She was afraid of My Lady being in the act of taking cold. That wd never do, with Nice close ahead!— I mean to call again quàm primùm [as soon as possible]. My Proofsheets, my &c in the muddy dark weather drive me delirious!—
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-ER[ERU], [2 Nov.]. Addr: Mr Jeffrays / 114 Gt. Russell Street. PM: 3 Nov. 1862. MS: Berg. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO ELLENOR RUDING

docBody.p: How good you are! Your face does not belie you! a thousand thanks!

I shall now be able to satisfy the most importunate of my remaining Friends, who have not yet received the unspeakable boon of Photograph!Ellenor Ruding presumably supplied JWC with further copies of Jeffrey’s photographs; see JWC to MR, [21 Sept.].

Dont I remind you of “The Hare with many Friends“ in the Fable? It is to be hoped I shall make a better end than the poor Hare did!“The Hare with Many Friends,“ Aesop’s Fables, had many friends, but none that would help when she needed it.

Lady Ashburton has given me the photograph I told you about, of Lord Ashburton and Mr Carlyle sitting on one bench, which she pronounced “like two Criminals in the same dock, hearing sentence of Death pronounced on them!”

I shall bring it over to show you one of these fine days; in the hope of its giving you as hearty a laugh as it gave me. Mr C “rather likes it“ he says; because “the hair (his own hair) is black in this one!” By hair he must mean hat, for I’ll be hanged if there is a hair of his head seen; his head being completely covered by a wide-awake. the wide-awake is certainly as “black“ as could be wished!See 248JWC to EFO, 30 Oct. Yours very sincerely
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [3 and 4 Nov.]. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries / N. B. PM: London, 5 Nov. 1862. MS: letter NLS 607.598B; envelope NLS 607.602. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:129–33 inc. Quot: Surtees, Ludovisi 91. The letters are printed in the order in which they were written, although JWC wanted Mary Russell to read the second letter first.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
Now Mary Dear! pray don’t let the echoes of your voice die out of my ears—if you can help it! It makes the difference betwixt feeling near and feeling far away!—the difference betwixt writing offhand, as one speaks, and writing cramped apologies! You may not have anything momentous to tell; but I am not difficult to interest when it is you who are writing! Just fill a small sheet
with such matter as you would say to me, if I were sitting opposite you; and I shall be quite content!

Neither have I myself anything momentous to tell, except—I was going to say—that I had got a new bonnet—or rather my last winter’s bonnet transformed into a new one—but it suddenly flashes on me; that is by no means the most momentous thing I have to tell! a new bonnet is nothing in comparison of a new—maid! Ah my Dear! Yes! I am changing my housemaid!Maria Chamberlayne. I have forseen for long,—even when she was capering about me, and kissing my hands and shawl; that this emotional young Lady would not wear well; and that some fine day her self-conceit and arrogance would find the limits of my patience! Indeed I should have lost patience with her long ago if it hadn’t been for her cleverness about Mr C’s books which I fancied would make him extremely averse to parting with her; as cleverness of that sort is not a common gift with Housemaids. But not at all—at least not in prospect— He says she is “such an affected fool,“ and so heedless in other respects that it is quite agreeable to him “that she should carry her fantasticalities and incompetences elsewhere“! She had calculated on being indispensable, on the score of the Books; and was taking since soon after my return from Scotland a position in the House which was quite prepostious; domineering towards the cook, and impertinent towards me! picking and choosing at her work—in fact not behaving like a servant at all, but like a Lady who,—for a caprice, or a wager, or anything except wages and board,—was condescending to exercise light functions in the house; provided you kept her in good humour with gifts and praises! When Mr C’s attention was directed to her procedure; he saw the intolerableness as clearly as I did; so I was quite free to try conclusions with the Girl—either she should apologize for her impertinence and engage (like Magdelen Smith) “to turn over a new leaf“; or she should (as Mr C said) “carry her fantasticalities and incompetences elsewhere“! She chose, of course, the worser part; and I made all the haste possible to engage a Girl in her place, and make the fact known—that so I might protect myself against Scenes of reconciliation, which to a woman as old and nervous as I am, are just about as tiresome as Scenes of altercation! All sorts of Scenes cost me my sleep, to begin with! and are a sheer waste of vital power; which one’s servant at least ought really not to cost one!

I am going to try a new arrangement; that of keeping two women, experienced, or considering themselves so,—to do an amount of work between them which any one good experienced Servant could do singly,—having hitherto proved unmanageable with me. I have engaged a little girlFlorence Morrison. of the neighbourhood (age about fifteen) to be under the Scotch woman— She is known to me
as an honest, truthful industrious little girl. Her Parents are rather superior people in their station— The Father a Collector on the boats— She is used to work, but not at all to what Mr C’s Father would have called “the curiosities and niceities“ of a House like this. So I shall have trouble enough in licking her into shape. But trouble is always a bearable thing for me in comparison with irritation. The chief drawback is, that the Mother is sickly and this child has been her main stay at home; and tho’ both Parents have willingly sacrificed their own convenience to get their Child into so respectable a place; my fear is, that after I have had the trouble of licking her into shape, the Mother under the pressure of her home difficulties may be irresistible tempted to take her home again— Well! there is an excellent Italian Proverb. “The person who considers everything will never decide on anything“!— Meanwhile Elizabeth looks much more alive, and cheerful since she had this change in view—and I shall be delivered from the botheration of two rival queens in the kitchen at all events! That I shall have to fetch the Books and do the sewing myself, will perhaps—“keep the Devil from my elbow“!

I had a letter from my Aunt Ann the other day. The first I have had from any of them since I was at Craigenvilla—in spite of entreaties and remonstrances onmy part. She tells me that maidservantMrs. Ferguson; unidentified further. whom Grace ‘converted’ some years ago, is still praying earnestly for Mr Carlyle! She has been at it a long while now, and must be tired of writing to my Aunts to ask whether they had heard “if anything had happened through her prayers“!!!— I will send you Anns letter; burn it before or after having read it; as you like! Does it amuse you to read letters (good in their way) not addressed to yourself? Tell me that; for if it does, I could often, at the small cost of an extra stamp, send you on any letter that has pleased myself, without putting you to the trouble of returning them.

I am afraid you will not have so many visitors to enliven you in the winter; and then you will take to thinking it was livelier at Thornhill, with your window looking on the street. Oh my Dear! I wonder how the Doctor is so angelically patient with your hankering after the old House, when he has made the new one so lovely for you! Yet I can understand all that about the old House. I can, who am a woman
5 Cheyne Row / Tuesday [4 November 1862]
Dearest Mary

I wrote to you last night; but was interrupted before I had finished. And this morning, I had to go up to Bath House soon after breakfast, by appointment,
to see Lady Ashburton, who was to have set off for Nice tomorrow. I calculated on being home in time for finishing and posting my letter. I could not get away till four o’clock which would have made me too late for our Chelsea General Post.“Letters for the Provincial Mails can be posted at the Town Pillar Boxes till 5 p.m.“ (Post Office Directory [1862]). but it was just as well so; for the first thing I saw on coming in was your letter on the table.
So I begin a new letter for you to read first; that you may not have to read all thro the other, under the impression that your letter had not reached me—
For the rest; I have already pretty well said my say for this time, on the accompanying two sheets.

I found a wonderful complication at Bath House. and only the Baby starts tomorrow!! of course accompanied—by two nurses, men servants. and Lady A’s sister in law.The two nurses were Corbett (unidentified further) and Jane (Jeannie) Bean (b. ca. 1845) from the Isle of Skye; the footman was James Bailey (b. ca. 1809). Lady Ashburton’s sister-in-law was Maria Louisa Stewart-Mackenzie, known as “Mrs. George.“ It was settled while I was there that Lord A should follow on Saturday—and as for the Lady; she has suddenly taken a notion she is in the family way again!The pregnancy was apparently “imaginary“ (Surtees, Ludovisi 91). And her DrProbably Dr. Richard Quain. declares she must not stir from the sofa (on which I found her) the whole winter!!— While Lord A again cannot stand a winter in London! A pretty mess!
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

ps.p: It may seem impertinent, when you have a DR “all to yourself. to offer you advice about your treatment of yourself— But surely, with that nice carriage it would be good for you to not stay so much at home!— If i were to be taken care of you would make me drive somewhere every day, to stir me up! Why not take the same care of yourself. I am sure staying at home alone and thinking is very apt to bring on “feverish colds.“ A journey to Dumfries now and then, not doing more than you have strength for at one time; but just to amuse you and see your friends there, would be better for you I am sure than blue pill. Falling into stagnation and lowness is always the first step with me to falling into a long cold.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lord A and Lady A[LALA], 5 Nov. Pbd: Wilson, Carlyle 5:479. TC’s list of “Books Worth Reading“ for the Ashburtons; for TC’s earlier list for Henry Parkes, see TC to HP, 15 Sept.
div3.head: TC TO LORD ASHBURTON AND LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Boswell’s Tour to the Western Isles.For this and other works not noted, see TC to HP, 15 Sept. Along with Johnson; very entertaining (to a Highlander).Lady Ashburton was raised in the Highlands.
—Life of Johnson.

Hawkin’s Life of Johnson; Mrs. Piozzi’s Anecdotes;Sir John Hawkins, The Life of Samuel Johnson, LL.D. (1787); Hester Lynch Thrale [afterward Piozzi], Anecdotes of the Late Samuel Johnson, LL.D. (1786). &c. (All lives of Johnson deserve reading.)

Swift’s Works. (Gulliver, Battle of the Books, &c, are still popular. He is far the greatest of his age. Life of him by Sir Walter Scott;Sir Walter Scott, The Works of Jonathan Swift … with a life of the author, 19 vols. (Edinburgh, 1814). &c.)
Anson’s Voyage. (Capital little Book.)

Voltaire’s Tragedies; Racine’s; Corneille’sVoltaire (François-Marie Arouet), Jean Racine, Pierre Corneille: French writers and dramatists. (all worth a serious re-perusal, after one has come to the years of discretion).
Memoires sur la Revolution. (Michaud’s Collection, about 100 volumes, entertaining, every one of them.)
Petitot’s Collection (earlier French).

French Mémoires, (also about 100 volumes, do. in some degree: A good deal of good French reading, in that and the cognate kinds).Joseph-François Michaud and Jean-Joseph-François Poujoulat, Nouvelle collection des mémoires pour servir à l’histoire de France, 42 vols. (Paris, 1836–39); Claude-Bernard Petitot, Collection complète des mémoires relatifs à l’histoire de France, 130 vols. (Paris, 1819–29); Saint-Albin Berville and Jean-François Barrière, Collection des mémoires rélatifs à la Révolution Française, 68 vols. (Paris, 1820–28) (see Works 2:173).
Campbell’s (late Thomas) Specimens of British Poets.Thomas Campbell (1777–1844), Specimens of British Poets, 7 vols. (1819); see 3:233TC to JBW, 20 Dec. 1824. (Good, both criticisms and pieces.)

Pope’s Correspondence;Mr. Pope’s Literary Correspondence for Thirty Years, 5 vols. (1735–37). Marion’s Life of Gray (Gray’s letters excellent);The Works of Thomas Gray, containing his Poems and Correspondence, To which are added Memoirs of his life, ed. William Mason (1807); TC wrote Marion in error. Shenstone’s Poems, his Letters too;William Shenstone, Poems (1779) and Letters to Particular Friends (Dublin, 1770). a great deal of good English reading
in that kind. Horace Walpole’s Letters (lately edited by Cunningham)The Letters of Horace Walpole, Earl of Orford, ed. Peter Cunningham, 9 vols.(1857–59). is the best of its sort in the world.

Don Quixote; Arabian Nights; Homer (by Pope, by Cowper), Virgil (by Dryden),Alexander Pope, The Iliad and Odyssey of Homer (1767); William Cowper, The Iliad and Odyssey of Homer (1791); John Dryden, The Works of Virgil (1697).—French Translations of Classic Ancients, no end.
My paper is ended, and your patience!

div3.sourceNote: JWC-ES[EST], 6 Nov. MS: Hilles. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO EMELYN STORY

docBody.p: We are really and heartily disappointed, that you are not going to keep your promise!Presumably to visit the Carlyles at Cheyne Row. I couldn’t have believed it of you!

As for meeting you in Rome; that is a much more impossible outlook than meeting you in Heaven! at least unless my Husband miraculous developes a taste and capacity for travelling, that has never yet given the slightest sign of itself!
I can hardly see to write; the fog is so dense!—nevertheless I must go up to Bath House to see Lady A before she sets out for Nice.
Inclosed are the Photographs, which you must surely blush to look in the trusting faces of!Presumably photographs of JWC and TC by Jeffrey; see JWC to ERERU, [2 Nov.].
God bless you all! kindest regards to Mr Story and the nightingaleThe Storys’ da., Edith.—from us both
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A[LAI], 10 Nov. MS: NLS 20767.46. Pbd: Fielding and Sorensen 283–84 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY AIRLIE

docBody.p:
Darlingest of Ladyships! What a nice, dear letter you sent me! and so soon!— Decidedly, you are good!—good as gold, when you follow just your own
inspirations!— And I should be a wretch if I were long of answering this time! should be (as Mr C might say) “a vile off-scouring of Humanity, only fit to have a red-hot poker run thro’ me, or a torrent of red hot shot poured into my belly“!!! Yes! that is the style Mr C is rioting in, since the Novr fogs set in! I don’t mean his style in addressing myself—better not; I can tell him!—but his style in speaking of the greater number of his Contemporaries who have risen to “office“—or power or distinction of any sort “on the shoulders of a pack of braying jack asses (the Public)“— I don’t know whether or not people breakfast in Pandemonium, but if they do; I think it must be very much like our breakfastings in Cheyne-Row—“the blackness of Darkness“See Jude 1:13. outside; and inside, red-hot pokers, and red-hot shot, and every description of red-hot thing, flashed (figuratively) before ones eyes!— Ah you are happy who have not to pass in London “that gloomy month of November, in which the People of England hang and drown themselves“!Coterie speech; see 37:42JWC to ETW, 17 Nov. 1860. Still happier perhaps in having that blessed power of reaction which comes of Youth, and Health, and a whole Heart!

The last week has been a little enlivened for me by almost daily visits at Bath House; where the Lord and the Lady were going on like two buckets at a well in point of healthTaking turns at being ill.—and their journey postponed until today. They were to start this morning at ten finally—but I shall not be sure, till I have been up and seen the gates closed.

They were very urgent that Mr C and I would go with them or to them for two or three months. I should have liked it so much! I who was never out of this Island! But until that weary Book is done; an invitation to spend three months in Paradise even would be declined by Mr C as an “impossibility.“ Oh what a dreary winter is before me! hardly a soul here that I care for! Countess Pepoli dead, dear clever litte Mrs Twisleton dead, Lady Sandwich dead, almost all the rest gone away, not to return till the winter is past and gone. And the winter, it is inferred from premature Robin-red-breasts—multitudinous “red-rowans“ &c—will be a long and severe one. I begin to regret that I declined the offer of a certain Lady Holmes,Elizabeth Georgiana, b. Light (ca. 1820–97), m., 1848, Sir William Henry Holmes (ca. 1817–68), provost marshal of British Guiana; her father, Sir Henry Light, was governor of British Guiana 1838–48. wife of the Governor of Guiana, to present me with “a pair of lovely green parrots“ and “a little monkey of a most affectionate disposition“! With such animal resources to fall back upon I might have fronted the winter with less apprehension, But if there is one thing on earth Mr C detests more than a parrot, it is exactly a—monkey!

Are you one of the prejudiced people who hate Mazzini? If not, I will send you, to read, a little book of his on Duty, which has just been translated into English.Joseph Mazzini, The Duties of Man, trans. Emilie Venturi (1862). There was never a greater Fanatic than Mazzini! but also there was never a man more maligned! For example; there is a whole public of “braying jack asses“ accusing Mazzini of urging on the Mountebank Garibaldi to that mad expedition against Rome. And I know—knew it from Mazzini’s own lips, three weeks before Garibaldi landed on the main land that Mazzini considered his enterprise “perfectly ruinous“—had implored him to desist from it—and had written to him that he (Mazzini) would come and join him if he made the country rise—would come and join him because he was bound to him; but—that he would “come, with a dead heart“! All that, he said to me a month before aspremonte and he wrote to me, in Scotland; “I go in two days—knowing that I go, merely to involve myself in the ruin which Garibaldi has prepared for us all.“See JWC to TC, 2 Sept.

You did not say if you liked Mr C’s photograph— Surely I did not omit after all to send it? Tell me if I did; and the stupidity shall be immediately made good. Read Lady Audleys SecretMary Elizabeth Braddon, Lady Audley’s Secret, 3 vols. (1862); Lena Eden reviewed it in the Athenaeum, 25 Oct.: “It is … just the sort of book to be read by everybody,—not too sentimental for a man’s requirements, nor too useful for a woman’s; having no end of plots and conspiracies for those who like plots, and plenty of light, easy, agreeable conversation for those who do not“ (525).
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JS[JSSC], [ca. 10 Nov.]. MS: NLS 1797.227. Pbd: Fielding and Sorensen 285 inc. Tentatively dated by JWC’s reference to Garibaldi in similar terms in JWC to LAI, 10 Nov. Julie Salis Schwabe (1818–96; ODNB), philanthropist; known to the Carlyles since Jan. 1849; see JWC to JW, 29 Jan. 1849. She lived in Manchester but spent much of her time traveling through Europe, devoting her considerable energies to a variety of good causes. Appointed British representative of the Italian Ladies Philanthropic Association, 1861, in Sept. 1862 she rushed to assist the wounded Garibaldi when he was imprisoned after Aspromonte.
div3.head: JWC TO JULIE SCHWABE

docBody.p:
It is indeed very long since we met.Julie Schwabe was last mentioned in 1855; see 30:211–12JWC’s Journal, 4 Nov. 1855. How long—and how little you know of us at the present time is apparent from the contents of your letter! Heaven
bless you! Mr Carlyle thinks of nothing and cares for nothing just now, and for years back, except just Frederick the Great!—whose Life he is writing — Italy he doesnt take the slightest interest in—never did take indeed in “the emancipation of Italy“—even when the personal influence of Mazzini—irresistible in most cases—was at work on him!— Mr Carlyle’s sympathies always have been, are, and always will be with Austria!!! as for Garibaldi—! I really couldn’t help going off into fits of laughter at your applying to Mr C of all people in the world to give his voice to the lyrical recognition of Garibaldi! It will seem incredible to you; but the fact is, Mr C doesn’t admire Garibaldi at all! Has been bored to death with all the talk of him, declares him to be “the great dramatic Mountebank of the Age.“ I duly read your letter to Mr C and he told me to convey these his sentiments to you “in some mild form“— But as I dont know how to give them a mild form and at the same time not impair their positiveness; and as I have no talent for french-polishing, I tell you just the plain truth
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-CAW, 11 Nov. Addr: Mayfair / W. PM: London, 11 Nov. 1862. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Pbd. Wilson, Carlyle 5:479–80.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES A. WARD

docBody.p: Thanks to you for the Gift of Fruits in their Season; whh brings you pleasantly to memory in this gloomy exit of the Year. Spanish Onions do credit to their country; the Plums are so beautifully packed, they ought to stand untasted, merely admired as a bit of Fine Art,Possibly Elvas plums from Portugal, harvested in the autumn and preserved in sugar; cf. 36:1.—till perhaps Xmas come!

I am very busy constantly (tho’ making poorish progress); and see with patience, and in silence, “the fall of sceptres and of crowns“ (prefigured by Hudibras’s Beard);See Samuel Butler, Hudibras (1663–78) 1.1; Hudibras vowed not to cut his orange beard until monarchy was vanquished; presumably a reference to the various contemporary struggles for independence from foreign tyrants. and look with a pity and awe: whh also are silent, on the Consummation of Constitutional Palaver and Universal Suffrage, and our poor Yankee Brothers tearing one another in pieces abt Nothing at all,The American Civil War. The Unionist blockade of cotton exports was also causing extreme economic distress in the north of England. & in fact “the Earth opening,“ and Hell and its fires bursting out on
them,Cf. Num. 16:30–35. as visibly, or more so, than on Sodom & GomorrahSee Gen. 19:24. long ago!— Silence! Silence!—
docBody.name: T. Carlyle
docBody.note: TC had recently been invited to stand for the rectorship of Edinburgh Univ.; A. H. Burgess reported at a meeting, 8 Nov.: “[H]e had received a letter from Mr Carlyle, stating that it was practically impossible for him to undertake the duties of the Rectorship at present. … [But] that he had good reason to believe and hope that at the next election Mr Carlyle would willingly become a candidate“ (Scotsman, 10 Nov.). The current rector, W. E. Gladstone, was reelected; TC was elected rector in 1866.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 16 Nov. MS: NLS 525.99. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:268.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Your Notes have both come; thanks for what you give me,—better than the nothing whh is my contributn in return! Tait, here Sunday gone a week as he once in the four or five weeks is, told us he was to write, “abt purchase of a Picture of yrs:“Unidentified.—we do not hear from you, nor from Tait hitherto, whether you consented to sell, “for £50.“—

Thanks for calling in Northumbd Street: upon the once “Jane Johnstone“:Jean Johnston; see TC to JAC, 30 Oct. so soon as she returns and you can get her real name, please call again; and give my compts, if you do not yrself know her, with what I said abt old school-days in infancy &c. All I want with her, is properly that and its adjuncts,—one adjunct whh I have long wished to bring out practically. And that is, sending her perhaps a Copy of my Books with some Letter or the like,—if you now judge that it will be worth while. Do not say or hint to her anything of that:—and on the whole, knowing how excessively unwilling I am to write the smallest Note, you will so lead the matter as to spare me any trouble but a minimum! This is all I wanted,—in a kind of sad honour to old days now far away. And if the Lady is to stay ‘all Winter,’ there is of course no hurry in it. Report to me when you see good.

For ten days past, or more, I have been below par: had to take blue pill, got a whiff of cold, have been endlessly hurried about, and so tormented as I never yet was with Proofsheets (unmanageable altogether!)—in the dark muddy frosty foggy, and every way bitter & disagreeable weather. Heigho! Maria is gone too,—“no work to be had out of her, except her small utilities to
me in the Book way“;—went last week; and a new smaller specimenFlorence Morrison. is come, and of course novelties and bother in the small way.

However I fancy myself fairly round the corner now; getting mastery of my sorrows & Proofsheets; and rising to the old moderate elevation. Tell Sister Jean; she has sent me two or three Notes (the last this morning); and, sinner that I am, there was no possibility hitherto of replying.

Poor Lord Ashburton lies dangerously ill at Paris:The Ashburtons were at the Hôtel Bristol, rue du Faubourg St. Honoré, Paris. He “fell ill within a few days of their arrival … and remained seriously so for eight months“ (Surtees, Ludovisi 91). they were so far on the road to Nice for winter,—no end of struggling & confusion in getting away;—and at Paris he was found, last thursday morning, to have got inflammation of the lungs! You may figure our anxieties Nothing definite of report comes this morning: the one thing we can build upon is that the inflamn does not spread. His death wd be a heavy loss & sorrow to us,—a black consumatn of what there has already been!
docBody.name: T. C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [18 Nov.]. MS: NLS 607.604. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: This is only a line to announce the safe arrival of the ham, with absolutely “nothing to pay“! which I found most extraordinary! for altho you might have paid the carriage to London; I can’t conceive how you managed to pay the porterage from the Station to Chelsea! Pray tell me, for it is a possibility worth knowing. You cant think how much more respectable my larder looks since that ham was dangling from its ceiling. Thank you, thank you! Dearest! for all your kindness! It came (after the general post hour) yesterday evening.
Why then not have time enough to write a decently long letter by todays general post?— Because Dear I am full of anxiety and have no heart to write pleasantly.

Lord Ashburton is lying dangerously ill at a Hotel in Paris, and day after day it is a waiting for the French Post in terror that it will bring the news of his death, and the news it does bring every day is not of a sort to make one look forward more hopefully to the morrow

Mrs Anstruther,Lady Ashburton’s sister. wrote to me last Friday, by Lady A’s desire, to tell us he
was dreadfully ill. She (Mrs A) did not mean to go to them at first her own Husband being ill in London. But the Saturdays accounts being still more alarming, Mrs Anstruther left here for Paris by the night train and such is the rapidity of travelling and of Posts in these days that tho’ she only left London on Saturday night, I have had two letters from her since her arrival in ParisTrains left Victoria Station, London, at 8 p.m. and arrived in Paris at 7:20 a.m. one yesterday morning!! and one today (Tuesday)!!

Oh my Dear! think of the supposed cause of this illness damp sheets! Could such things as happen to these immensely rich people even happen to your Husband or mine?— But he is so weak this man so broken in constitution, that one must fear the worst for him in any violent attack—he has no stamina to hold out long against it.
I will write again in two days your loving JWC

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [20 Nov.]. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries. PM: London, 21 Nov. 1862. MS: NLS 607.603. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:136–40. Quot: Wilson 5:481–82.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: The last of the four notes I inclosed, which had come a few hours before I wrote to you, made us expect the worst; and as the day went on, we could not help expecting the worst with more and more of certainty. The same night we were talking very sadly of Lord Ashburton almost already in the past tense, Mr C saying; “God help me! since I am to lose him, the kindest, gentlest, friend[l]iest man in my Life here! I may say the one Friend I have in the World“!— And I, walking up and down in the room, as my way is when troubled in mind, had just answered; “It’s no use going to bed and trying to sleep, in this suspense“; when the door opened and a letter was handed me. It was from Paris, a second letter that day! I durstn’t open it. Mr C impatiently took it from me; but was himself so agitated that he couldnt read it when he had it, At last he exclaimed “better“! “I see the one word “better,“ nothing else! look there! is not that “better“? To be sure it was! And you may imagine our relief! and our thankfulness to Lady A and Mrs Anstruther for not losing a moment in telling us! The letters go on more and more favourable.

The DrsDr. David Christison (1830–1912), who had gone to Paris with Lord Ashburton, and probably Dr. Richard Quain. say “they cannot understand it.“ When do these grand Drs understand anything? But no matter about them! So that he is recovering whether they understand it or not!

I may now tell you of my household crisis which has been happily accomplished. Maria has departed this scene, and little “Flo“ (!) has entered upon it—not a little dog as you might fancy from the name, but a remarkably intelligent well-conditioned girl between 14 and 15, who was christened “Florence,“ too long and too romantic a name for household use! She is so quick at learning, that training her is next to no trouble. And Mr C is so pleased with the clever little creature that he has been much less aggravating than usual under a change. Maria wished to make me a scene at parting (of course) But I brutally declined participation in it; so she rushed up to the study with her tears to Mr C who was “dreadfully sorry for the poor creature.“ The “poor creature“ had been employing her mind latterly in impressing on Elizabeth, who is weak enoug[h] to believe what mischief-makers tell her rather than the evidence of her own senses, that she was going to be overworked (!) with only an untrained Girl instead of a fine-lady Housemaid for fellow servant. and in making herself so charming and carressing for Elizabeth, that her former tyranies were forgotten, and Elizabeth who had looked quite happy at the idea of Maria’s going, and “a girl under her,“ turned suddenly round into wearing a sullen look of victimhood and declining silently—to give me the least help in training the girl! All the better for the Girl! and perhaps also all the better for me! But [it]Word omitted. is a disappointment to find that my Scotch Blockhead is no brighter for having her “Bubblyjock“A turkey; cf. 18:14TC to JCA, 16 April 1844. taken off her! Such a woman to have had sent four hundred miles to one!Elizabeth was from Haddington; see JWC to IES, [ca. 22 June]. Mr C always speaks of her as “that horse“ “that Cow“ “that Mooncalve“! But upon my honour, it is an injustice to the horse, the cow, and even the mooncalve!— For sample of her procedure; there is a glass door into the back court consisting of two immense panes of glass; the Cow has three several times smashed one of these sheets of glass! thro the same carelessness, neglecting to latch it up!! three times in the six months she has been here!— And nobody before her ever smashed that door! Another thing that nobody before her ever did, in all the twenty eight or nine years I have lived in the house, was to upset the kitchen table!! and smash at one stroke nearly all the tumblers and glasses we had, all the china breakfast things, a Christal butter glass (my Mothers) a christal flower vase and ever so many jugs and bowels! there was a whole washing tub full of broken things! Surely honesty, sobriety, and steadiness must be grown dreadfully scarce qualities, that one puts up with such a Cook; especially, as her cooking is as careless as the rest of her doings. No variety is required of her, and she has been taught how to do the few things Mr C needs; she can do them when she cares to take pains but
every third day or so, there comes up something that provokes him into declaring “That Brute will be the death of me! It is really too bad to have wholesome food turned to poison.“ But I suppose she understands herself engaged by the half year, tho’ I never had any explanation with her as to the second half year. And so—Heaven grant me patience!
What a pack of complaints but my Dear there is nobody but you that I would think of making them to! and it is a certain easing of nature to utter them! So forgive the mean details.
Love to the Doctor—
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A[LLA], [22 Nov.]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Pbd: Wilson, Carlyle 5:465–66. Dated the Sat. after the second of Mary Anstruther’s notes to arrive Tues., 18 Nov., with news that Lord Ashburton was improving; see JWC to MR, 18 Nov. and [20 Nov.].
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Most sincerely do I thank you for writing to me just now! for remembering me at all with so much else to think of! what between the kindness and the sadness of your little note, I fairly fell to crying over it!— We had been wishing so much for a word of news about Lord Ashburton; and I “did not like“ to write to ask, for fear of bothering you. When Mr C saw me crying, he fancied Lord Ashburton must be worse, and showed so much emotion, that you would have loved him for it, had you seen, and pardoned him all his “rongs“ (as my old nurseBetty Braid. would say).— His eloquent praises of your dear Husband, his declaration emphatically repeated twice over “He is the only man in the world that I care for! that I have still any pleasure in meeting! the only friend I have left in the world!— God help me! I wish he were well again!”—all that, and still more his look and tone in saying it would have gone to your heart!
I don’t believe Lord Ashburton suspects how much true love is felt for him, beyond his own immediate circle. He is without exception the most unselfish man I ever saw in my life!—

Mr C thought he looked “so much better“ that evening we were at Bath House; he had been quite in good spirits about him since. “if he would only stay quietly at home in his own comfortable house there, and take care of himself; it would be all right!”—

You will write us two lines soon again?— I wish to God I could do any earthly thing for your or His good! But the good-doing between us has always been, alas, “with the reciprocity all on one side“!Coterie speech; see 19.196JWC to GCD, 15 Sept. 1845. and I see no help for that; unless I can find some in the Precedent of the Lion and the Mouse!“The Lion and the Mouse,“ Aesop’s Fables, in which the mouse reciprocated a gesture of mercy and freed a lion from a hunter’s trap, showing that the least may help the greatest.— Ach!
I was very disappointed at not seeing you again, but did not at all wonder!— I knew how occupied you must be, both heart and hands.

You will not forget my likeness of Baby?For a photograph of Lady Ashburton and her da., Mary, see 267above; possibly one of the photographs taken by Vernon Heath in Oct. I have my heart set on it, to an extent almost sinful! The coming Man, who will go on his knees for her grown up miniature, I defy, to desire it more than I desire her baby-photograph!

figure.p: Lady Ashburton and her daughter, Mary Florence Baring, n.d.

p.hi: Courtesy of Butler Library, Columbia University

docBody.p: God be with you dear dear Lady As[h]burton
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

ps.p: Since I began writing there has come game from you— How many times I have to return you thanks!

div3.sourceNote: TC-GS, [25 Nov.]. Pbd: G. Strachey, “Reminiscences,“ New Review 9 (July 1893): 26 inc. Letter dated by George Strachey. Strachey was an attaché at The Hague; see TC to GS, 5 June 1857.
div3.head: TC TO GEORGE STRACHEY

docBody.p: I got your letter several days ago; but have not had the least minute to myself; and this is literally the first note I have written since to any address whatever. Never in my days was I kept in such a perpetual whirl of hurries and botherations,—you know with what, and how extremely profitable it is likely to be! In six months, if it be possible to hold out so long, I shall be thro’ the worst; and in eight or nine months hence shall have done with it altogether—that is the one blessed quality I know in the affair.

I do not intend much upon the Furstenbund [Federation of princes];Faced with the threat of aggression from Austria under the new emperor Joseph II (1741–90), Prussia, Saxony, and Hanover, together with a number of smaller German states, instituted a confederation, with Prussia at its head, 23 July 1785 (Works 19:279). TC regarded the Fürstenbund as the “victorious summit of Frederick’s Public History“ (Works 19:249). but of course I shall have to mention it; and if your pleasure and opportunities do lead you to examine those old Fascicles at the HagueStrachey wrote that he had “discovered in Holland some secret diplomatic documents calculated to throw light on the latter years of Frederick’s life“ (G. Strachey, “Reminiscences“ 25); these were a series of letters from Frederick to his minister in London, ca. 1780–85, which, according to TC, contained little of interest on Prussian politics; see Works 19:177–78. (how they got there I cannot guess) and to give me, in compass of a few pages, what you can excerpt of most remarkable in Frh.’s utterances or actions, it will be a real kindness to me. I am curious to know, had he any smell then (1784–5, I think) of the terrible French conflagration which was so near breaking out,Presumably Strachey found nothing; TC wrote that Frederick saw no signs of the approaching French Revolution; see Works 19:3. to consume all
manner of Princes and their covenants, or reduce them to a charred!— Yours, with the kindest regard to a certain lady,Catherine Doveton, whom Strachey m. about this time. He wrote that TC’s letter began “with the congratulations of Mrs. Carlyle and himself on a sentimental incident of which he had been informed“ (G. Strachey, “Reminiscences“ 25–26).
docBody.name: T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 26 Novr, MS: NLS 517.41. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: My dear Jean,—You are very good to me; you alone write diligently to me without Answer; nobody else will do it,—and it is right charitable, and proper in the circumstances! Take one line written to you, as symbol & sample of many that I cannot get written.

Things have come round with me again; mostly in the old beat now again. Lord A., what was a very great relief to us, has got round; and is now waiting hopefully at Paris to gather strength, and get weather for the rail to Nice. At one time, things did look very miserable there; and we were nearly hopeless, when good news came next morning.— The frost too is away today, thank Heaven; on my score, as well as his.

Moreover, I finished a Chapter yesterday; and have had such a burning of rubbish & clips! The sorest Chapter of all (so I think it, but they are all sore) lies now close ahead; but I shall do that too, please Heaven. Inch by inch! If one stick to the ugliest monster in Nature, hour after hour, & day after day, one does get him down, and all the dirt “eaten.“— — My poor old skin is getting cracky and uncomfortable this winter; no wonder after so long tear and wear. But I get a canter on my good old Fritz (who really is a half-rational compann, in the absence of others) almost every afternoon; then a pipe with suspicion of brandy-and-water;—after whh, half an hour of real sleep; well packed under your quilt on a sofa, with old wide-awake (worn light as duffel) set on the side of face and head. Wonderfully helped, poor old wretch, in the middle of so many hindrance.

Jane is still afoot; not so ill at all, were not she so plaugedScots variant of “plagued.“ with her maids and their ineptitudes just now. Our weather has been dark, cold and ugly; especially, dark, hanging like a mortclothFuneral hangings, usually a black cloth draped over the coffin. round all one’s thots & feelings.
Could not you get us a Photograph done of that Portrait,Unidentified.—if some chance turned up? It wd be very welcome here.— Blessings on you all
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-RD[RDU], 29 Nov. Pbd: Scotsman, 3 Dec. 1862; Caledonian Mercury, 4 Dec. 1862; Glasgow Herald, 4 Dec. 1862. Robert Duncan of Ratho, not further identified.
div3.head: TC TO ROBERT DUNCAN

docBody.p: Sir—Time and human patience are too valuable to allow of any word from me, beyond the strictly necessary, on that excerpt you have been so good as to send me from the “Glasgow Morning Journal for November 26,“ in the belief that it is not mine.The article, “Occasional Discourse,“ concerning the case of Jessie McLachlan, was sent to TC by Robert Duncan. Scotsman, 3 Dec., introduced TC’s reply: “In the Glasgow Morning Journal of Wednesday last, a sort of jeu d’Esprit appeared, written in imitation of the style of Mr Thomas Carlyle, and introduced in an editorial note which stated that ‘its peculiar style rendered it unnecessary to say from what “distinguished literary person“’ it proceeded.“ The Glasgow Herald, 4 Dec., introduced it with a letter from “Sartor“: “I conceive it to be an excellent imitation of the peculiar style and phraseology of the philosopher of Chelsea.“

Rest well assured that it is not; that I have had no share in it more than the dead or the unborn;—and that, if the impertinent blockhead who did write it could be laid hold of, and put into the treadmill, or horse-whipped (in moderation), I should think it might be useful to himself and others.
You are perfectly at liberty to publish this wherever you see good.— In haste, I remain, yours, with thanks,
docBody.name: T. Carlyle.
docBody.p: Robert Duncan, Esq., &c.&c.

div3.sourceNote: TC-TW[TWO], 30 Nov. Pbd: Woolner 229; Wilson 5:485.
div3.head: TC TO THOMAS WOOLNER

docBody.p: If I could but get myself under way, on such a voyage at night! But alas, I fear that will be impossible on Tuesday.Woolner invited TC to meet Capt. Sherard Osborn (1822–75; ODNB), navy officer and author; Horatio Nelson Lay (1832–98), diplomat, currently inspector general of the Imperial Maritime Customs Service; and W. E. Gladstone, chancellor of the exchequer. Woolner reported to Emily Tennyson, 2 Dec., on his earlier meeting with Osborn and Lay: “I had a glorious night this day week [25 Nov.] with Sherard Osborn and Mr. Lay his chief: I learned more of Chinese nature and the future politics of their government than I ever knew before. Both of them are coming here this evening and Mr. Gladstone is coming too to discuss matters Chinese; so that I expect it will be highly entertaining“ (Woolner 229).

Pirates are fair game on all waters, on the part of all men. But does Captn Osborn know for certain that the Taepings require to be shot?At the Chinese govt.’s request, Lay appointed Osborn to take command of a British squadron for the suppression of the Taipings, a Christian social reform movement lasting from 1850–64; they were eventually crushed by the Chinese govt. with British and French support. One Mr. Meadows,Thomas Taylor Meadows (1819–69), interpreter to the British Consulate at Canton, left TC a copy of his book, The Chinese and Their Rebellions (1856), in 1856 (see 31:58TC to LA, 3 April 1856); their meeting is untraced but probably took place during the rule of Chinese Emperor Xian Feng (1831–61). a very ingenious man, who had been 12 years in China, and is gone back, had, when I saw him, the idea that the Taepings were intrinsically in the right;Meadows wrote: “[W]hile condemning all intervention whatever either for or against the Tae pings … [I] feel politically desirous for their success.“ He said that the present dynasty was generally hostile to foreigners, which made trade difficult, whereas the “Tae pings“ were much friendlier; their establishment would lead to a “peaceable extension of free intercourse and commercial privilege. The last fifteen years’ experience has finally proved that these advantages can be obtained from the present dynasty only by wars … wars engendering long national hatred and tending directly to destroy that very national industry which alone makes commercial intercourse valuable“ (The Chinese and Their Rebellions 324–25). and that it was the unworthy Phantasm of an “Emperor“China was currently ruled by Xian Feng’s widow, Empress Dowager Cixi (1835–1908) of the Qing dynasty, as regent for her young son. and his yellow Cousins who got hopelessly out of square!
docBody.name: T. Carlyle.

div1.p: Adamson, Samuel (1831–80), British Linen Co., Dumfries, where TC had an account; he was the nephewson of Robert Adamson (1787–1861; see10:23TC to JA, 14 Feb. 1838, and 37:26137:biographical note).

Airlie, Henrietta Blanche, b. Stanley (1829–1921), 7th countess; m., 1851, David Graham Drummond Ogilvy, Lord Airlie (1826–81), 7th earl (see 26:28926:biographical note). They lived at Cortachy Castle, Forfarshire (now Angus).

Aitken, Jean ( “Craw “) Carlyle (1810–88), TC’s sister; m., 1833, James Aitken (1809–87) from Troqueer, housepainter of English St., Dumfries; they lived in Assembly St., Dumfries. They had two sons who d. in infancy (1834–36 and 1855–56), both named Alexander; their surviving sons were James or Jamie (1836–71), who worked in a mercantile house in London from 1858; Thomas (1841–69), who was at an inst. for the deaf in Glasgow (see 29:186TC to JAC, 4 Nov. 1854); and John (1843–1911). Their das. were Anne (1839–1919), Margaret (1845–1932), and Mary (1848–95), who m., 1879, her cousin Alexander Carlyle.
Albert, prince consort (1819–14 Dec. 1861; ODNB), husband of Queen Victoria (1819–1901; ODNB).

Allingham, William (1824–89; ODNB), Irish poet, from Ballyshannon, Donegal. He worked in the Customs Service, 1846–70; first coming to London 1843, he had definitely met TC by summer 1850. Consulted TC about history books; see 25:107–8TC to WA, 29 June 1850, and 192TC to WA, 4 Sept. 1850. Later he and TC were to become close.
Anderton, Sarah; see Dilberoglue.

Anstruther, Mary Frances, b. Stewart-Mackenzie (1819–1913), sister of Lady Louisa Ashburton, m., 1838, Philip Anstruther (1802–1863). They had 11 children, Annie Nairn (ca. 1841–1931), Robert Durham (1841–90), Jemima Stewart (1845–74), Philip Morrison (1846–99), Stewart Mackenzie (1848–98), John Newdegate (b. 1850), Caroline Petre (1852–1928), Keith Francis George (1854–1915), Henry Lewis (b. 1856),
Charles William (1858–87), and Mary Helen (d. 1912). They lived at 17 Norfolk St., Park Lane, London.

Arbuckle, Robert (1802–24 Aug. 1862), physician, longtime friend of John A. Carlyle; see 5:341TC to JWC, 17 Aug. 1831, and 17:98–99TC to JWC, 28 Aug. 1843. He m. Anna Maria Taylor, b. in Brazil, a widow with two children, Anna (b. ca. 1849) and Henry (b. ca. 1850). Arbuckle and Anna Maria had five children, twins Susan and Mary (b. 1856), Robert (b. 1858), Agnes (b. 1859), and William (b. 1861).
Argyll, George Douglas Campbell (1823–1900; ODNB), 8th duke, Whig politician; m., 1844, Lady Elizabeth Georgiana, b. Leveson-Gower (1824–78).

Ashburton, William Bingham Baring (1799–1864; ODNB; see 11:40TC to MAC, 8 March 1839, and later vols.), 2d baron; politician and partner in Baring Bros., bankers. He m., first, 1823, Harriet, b. Montagu (1805–57; ODNB; see 11:40TC to MAC, 8 March 1839, and 26:ix—xv26:introduction); they met the Carlyles 1839 and became close friends. Ashburton m., second, 1858, Louisa Caroline, b. Stewart-Mackenzie (1827–1903); JWC expected not to like her, but was swiftly won over. They had one da., Mary Florence (1860–1902). They lived at Bath House, Piccadilly, London, and The Grange, Alresford, Hampshire; they also had a farm at Addiscombe, near Croydon. Where necessary for clarity, we refer in notes to Lord Ashburton’s first and second wives as Lady Harriet Ashburton and Lady Louisa Ashburton respectively, although these are not the correct forms.

Austin, Mary Carlyle (1808–88), TC’s sister, m., 1831, James Austin (1805–78), farmer of The Gill, 6 mi. (9.5 km.) SW of Ecclefechan. They had eight das.: Margaret (see Stewart); Grace (b. 1833), m., 1856, William Yeoward (b. ca. 1824), of Toronto, Canada; Jessie (b. 1836), m., 1859, George Grierson (b. 1835); Jane (b. 1840); Mary Anne (b. 1842); Catherine (b. 1844), m., 1866, her cousin James Carlyle; Isabella (b. ca. 1846); and Mary Carlyle (b. 1851); and one surviving son, James (b. 1848).
Baring, Louisa (1804–88), and Lydia Emily (1814–68), Lord Ashburton’s sisters; they lived at 23 Princes Gate, London.

Barnes, Dr. Alfred Brooke (ca. 1802–67), physician, living at 182 King’s Rd., Chelsea; m. Susannah (ca. 1804–ca. 1855); their children were Rev. Brooke Cremer (b. 1833), Dr. Herbert Sedgwick (ca. 1835–65), and Isabella (see below); their eldest child, Laura Susannah (b. 1829) was deceased.
Barnes, Isabella Emily (b. 1837), became close to JWC from their first meetings in 1859; see also 35:188. She m., 18 Feb. 1862, John Simmonds (b. 1829), barrister.
Barnet, Bessy (ca. 1810–91), m., 1862, Peyton Blakiston (1801–78), M.D.; they lived at St. Leonards-on-Sea, Sussex. Blakiston’s first wife, Frances, b. Powell, had d. 1858.
Blakiston; see Barnet.

Blunt, Abel Gerald Wilson (1827–1902), m., 1851, Frances Mary, b. Forssteen (1820–99); they had seven children, including Reginald (1857–1944). Gerald Blunt was appointed rector of St. Luke’s, Chelsea in 1860. His elder brother was Henry George Scawen Blunt (1821–99), m., 1846, Charlotte, b. Daniell (1818–86).

Braid, Betty, b. Pringle (1795–1875), Grace Welsh’s Haddington servant, close to JWC (see 21:82JWC to SS, 29 Oct. 1846, and 24:221JWC to TC, 5 Sept. 1849); b. in Prestonkirk, E. Lothian; m. Alexander (1792–1874), stonemason and shopkeeper. They had one surviving son, George Pringle (1827–65), who suffered ill health. Three other sons d. in infancy: Alexander (b. 1826), James (b. 1829), and James (b. 1831). They had lived at 15 Adam St. (see 17:127TC to JWC, 12 Sept. 1843) and moved in 1858 to Upper Stenhouse, Liberton, S Edinburgh.

Bromley, Caroline Davenport (1820–91), da. of Rev. Walter Davenport Bromley (1787–1 Dec. 1862) of Wootton Hall, Staffordshire, and his first wife, m., 1818, Caroline Barbara, b. Gooch (1791–1827). A friend of Lady Louisa Ashburton, she became a close friend of JWC. The Carlyles called her “Lark,“ “Die Lerche,“ or “Flight of Skylarks. “

Browning, Robert (1812–89; ODNB), poet, TC’s friend since the mid- 1830s (see 30:74TC to JAC, 26 Sept. 1855, and 133TC to RB, 4 Dec. 1855). His wife, m. 1846, was Elizabeth Barrett, b. Moulton Barrett (1806–61), poet. Robert Wiedeman Barrett ( “Pen “) (1849–1912) was their only child. They had been living in Florence since 1847.
Bullock, John (1815–90), from King’s Lynn, Norfolk, letter carrier, who had succeeded John Piper as the Carlyles’ postman; see 33:64TC to JWC, 1 Sept. 1857.

Butler, Charles (1802–97; see 28:314TC to JCA, 18 Nov. 1853), U.S. lawyer, financier, land speculator, entrepreneur, and philanthropist; welcome in Britain for his part in handling the threat by some U.S. states in the 1840s to repudiate their bonds; met TC Nov. 1853 and looked after his Illinois bonds and other American investments; m., 1825, Eliza, b. Ogden (1803–78). They had five children: Abraham Ogden Butler (1832–56), two other sons who d. in infancy, and two das., Emily (b. 1840) and Anna (d. 1877).

Carlyle, Alexander (Alick) (1797–1876), TC’s brother; emigrated with his family to Canada, 1843; settled at the Bield, 4½ mi. (7 km.) W of Brantford, Ontario; m., 1830, Janet, b. Clow (1809–91). They had six surviving sons: Thomas (1833–1921), John (1839–1924), Alexander (see below), James (1846–1924), William (1849–1935), and Robert (1851–1932); and three surviving das.: Jane Welsh (1831–84), m., 1852, Robert Sims; Janet (1836–1916); and Margaret (1847–1935); see 1:166TC to AC, 23 Feb. 1819. An unidentified son (1832–33), Margaret (1835–36), James (b. 1840), and Euphemia (1853–54) all d. in infancy; see 32:4TC to AC, 3 Oct. 1856.

Carlyle, Alexander (1843–1931; see 16:153TC to JCHA, 4 May 1843), Alexander and Janet’s son; m.,
1879, his cousin Mary Aitken; lived with TC from 1879 and ed. various collections of the Carlyles’ letters and other writings of TC.

Carlyle, James (Jamie) (1805–90), TC’s brother, farmer at Scotsbrig; m., 1834, Isabella, b. Calvert (ca. 1813–59). Their eldest child was James (Jr., the younger) (1835–71), who had been working in Glasgow as a clerk but was now back home; he m., 1866, his cousin Catherine Austin. The three younger children were John (1836–1901); Thomas (1839–41); and Janet (Jessie or Jenny) (1843–74).

Carlyle, John (ca. 1792–1872), TC’s half-brother; emigrated to the U.S. in 1837, then moved to Canada (see 12:228TC to AC, 15 Aug. 1840); he lived on a small farm at Mount Pleasant, nr. Brantford, Ontario; m., 1817, Margaret (Peggy), b. Benn (1798–1867). They had five children: Janet (1818–89), Mary (1821–50), John (1825–97), James (1830–1900), and William (1833–1911); the two youngest were schoolteachers.
