Carlyle, John Aitken (Jack, “The Doctor “) (1801–79; ODNB), TC’s brother, physician, and translator; m., 1852, Phoebe Elizabeth Hough Watt, b. Fowler (1810–54), wealthy widow of Fitzjames Watt (1809–48), from Leek in Staffordshire, with four sons (see Watt brothers). She d. in childbirth; the child was stillborn.
Carlyle, Margaret Aitken (1771–1853), TC’s mother; she had lived with James and Isabella Carlyle at Scotsbrig. TC’s father was James Carlyle (1758–1832); they m. 1795.
Chamberlayne, Maria, from Hampshire, servant at Cheyne Row from July 1861. Her mother was Ann, b. Weldon, m., 1838, Jeremiah Chamberlayne; Ann worked for the Ashburtons at The Grange.
Chapman, Edward (1804–80; ODNB), senior partner in Chapman & Hall, TC’s publisher since 1842 (see 14:37TC to JF, 5 Feb. 1842); he m., 1841, Mary, b. Whiting (b. ca. 1820).
Chapman, Frederic (1823–95; ODNB), Edward Chapman’s cousin and junior partner in Chapman & Hall; he m., 21 Nov. 1861, Clara, b. Woodin (d. 1866); they had one son, Frederick.

Chorley, John Rutter (1806–67; ODNB; see 19:135TC to JWC, 8 Aug. 1845), poet and scholar of Spanish literature, reviewer for the Athenaeum; highly regarded by TC. He helped supervise the building of the soundproof room in the attic of 5 Cheyne Row in 1853 (see 28:245TC to JCA, 11 Aug. 1853, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 154) and assisted in proofreading Frederick (see 34:146TC to JWC, 19 Aug. 1858).

Chrystal, Jeannie, b. Welsh (Babbie) (1818–95), JWC’s cousin; m., 1853, Andrew Chrystal (ca. 1811–83), a wine merchant from Glasgow (see 24:186TC to JWC, 10 Aug. 1849, and 26:81JWC to JW, 11 May 1851); they had a da., Mary (1857–1937). Her regular correspondence with JWC ended after her marriage.

Clough, Arthur Hugh (1819–13 Nov. 1861; ODNB), poet, known to TC since
the mid-1840s; see 20:76TC to AHC, 17 Dec. 1845, and 24:6–7TC to JWC, 3 April 1849. He m., 1854, Blanche Mary Shore, b. Smith (1828–1904), and they had at least four children.

Cooke, John George (known as George Cooke; “Kee“) (b. 1819), stockbroker; he had met JWC in 1856 (see 30:252JWC’s Journal, 18 May 1856) and became a close friend. She described him in 1864: “a man between thirty and forty; tall, strong, silent, sincere; has been a sailor, a soldier, a New Zealand settler, ‘a Man about Town,’ and a Stock Broker!!!” (Bliss, JWC 319). He lived at 47 Mount St. He had five sisters, including Charlotte (b. 1811), Margaretta (b. 1815), and Louisa (b. 1817).

Craik, George Lillie (1798–1866; ODNB; see 8:207JWC to SS, 20 Sept. 1835), author, prof. of English lit. and history, Queen’s Coll., Belfast, 1849–66; friend of the Carlyles since 1835; m., 1826, Jeannette, b. Dempster (d. 1856; see 10:159JWC to TC, 30 Aug. 1838). They had one son, George Lillie (b. ca. 1825), and three das.: Mary (1827–1909), Isabella (1829–42; see 15:221JWC to JW, 8 Dec. 1842), and Georgiana (1831–95), novelist.
Currie James (1815–96), a successful merchant in Mauritius, son of Sandy Currie (or Corrie) of Newfield, nr. Scotsbrig. Old friend of the Carlyle family.

Cushman, Charlotte Saunders (1816–76), actor. Raised in Boston, she came to Britain 1844, where she became friendly with Geraldine Jewsbury, among others; see 20:109JWC to JW, 19 Jan. 1846. She returned to the U.S. in 1849, but moved to Italy in 1852, spending winters there and much of the summers in England. From 1858 she lived with the American sculptor Emma Stebbins (1815–82). Friendly with Sarah Anderton Dilberoglue, with whom she had acted in Boston in 1852.

Darwin, Erasmus Alvey (1804–81; see 8:152TC to JAC, 15 June 1835, and 9:148TC to JAC, 17 Feb. 1837), the Carlyles’ close friend since 1835; brother of Charles Darwin (1809–82; ODNB). Erasmus lived at 57 Queen Anne St. from late 1852; in spring 1860 the house number was changed to 6.

Davidson, David (1811–1900), rtd. maj., army engineer, and inventor; childhood friend of JWC. He m., 1849, Margaret, b. Buchanan (ca. 1822–99); by 1862 they had four sons and five das. They lived at Woodcroft, Clinton Rd., Morningside, Edinburgh. His aunt, Janet Davidson (1782–1869), lived at Craighope House, Court St., Haddington (see 32:196JWC to TC, 23 July 1857).

Delepine, Elizabeth Marie Louise, b. Jäger, known as Madame Elise, milliner and dressmaker at 170 Regent St.; she m., 1857, Frederick Wooton Isaacson (1836–98), silk merchant. She inherited the business from her aunt, Jane Clarke (d. 1859), milliner (see also 33:141). TC noted on a photograph of her: “‘Madame Elise’ I think a fashionable Dressmaker, whom she [JWC] thot a real artist, and who valued her approval in a marked manner“ (photograph albums, vol. 2; Butler Lib., Columbia Univ.)

Dickens, Charles (1812–70; ODNB), novelist; friend of the Carlyles since the early 1840s; m., 1836, Catherine Thomson, b. Hogarth (1816–79); separated from her since 1858; see 33:233TC to RWE, 2 June 1858. They had 10 children, including Mary Angela (Mamie) (1838–96).

Dilberoglue, Stauros (1818–78), Greek businessman, philanthropist, and art collector. Born in Smyrna, he moved with his family to Corfu, where they were naturalized Ionian. Stauros lived in England from the mid-1830s; he was a partner in Cavafy & Co., which traded from 31 Threadneedle St., London. He m., 1859, Sarah Anderton, b. Coxon (ca. 1827–69; see 28:21–22JWC to KS, 28 Jan. 1853), actress (Anderton was her stage name). They lived at 13 Barnsbury Park. He became a naturalized Briton in 1861. His sister, Calliope (b. 1835), m., 1858, John George Honiere (b. 1814), general merchant.

Dods, William (1795–1873, see 33:79JWC to GEJ, 11 Sept. 1857), Haddington bank agent; childhood admirer of JWC; he m., first, Harriet, b. Shirreff (ca. 1804–53), with whom he had seven sons and two das.; see 37:26537:biographical note. He m., second, 1854, Jane, b. Wilkie (ca. 1809–85). His brother was Thomas Dods (1800–1878; see 33:88JWC to WDO, 19 Sept. 1857).

Donaldson sisters of Tenterfield (Sunny Bank), Haddington: Jean (1770–1860), JWC’s godmother; Jess (1774–1860); and Catherine (Kate) (1779–1852); friends of JWC’s mother. For other members of the Donaldson family, see 37:26637:biographical note.
Douglas, Thomas (1828–96), hairdresser and photographer, 69 Drumlanrig St., Thornhill.

Downes, John (1827–64), writer; originally intending to be a minister in the Free Church of Scotland, he abandoned theology for philosophy; he wrote later, “Carlyle tore my nature to pieces; Thackeray built it up again“ (William Knight, Some Nineteenth Century Scotsmen [Edinburgh, 1903] 118). He was subeditor, 1852–61, under Thomas Stewart Traill (1781–1862; ODNB), of the 8th edn. of the Encyclopaedia Britannica.

Duffy, Charles Gavan (1816–1903; ODNB), Irish nationalist, lawyer, and politician; emigrated to Australia 1855; known to the Carlyles since 1845; see 19:64–66TC to MAC, 28 April 1845. He m., 1847, as his second wife, his cousin Susan, b. Hughes (1826–78); they had six children.
Dunwoodie, Isabella; see McTurk.

Eliot, George (1819–80; ODNB), pen name of Marian (previously Mary Ann) Evans, author; her novels were much admired by JWC. From 1855 she lived with George Henry Lewes (1817–78; ODNB; see 11:205TC to UC, 16 Oct. 1839), author and journalist, known to the Carlyles since 1835.
Elise; see Delepine.
Elizabeth, from Haddington, servant at Cheyne Row, June–Dec. 1862; described as a “mooncalve.“ Her surname was possibly Gray or Lyall.
Ellice, Edward ( “Bear “) (1783–1863; ODNB), M.P. for Coventry, and a close friend of Lord Ashburton; see 32:24832:biographical note.

Emerson, Ralph Waldo (1803–82; see 6:425TC to JAC, 27 Aug. 1833), philosopher, essayist, poet, and transcendentalist. He first met TC in Aug. 1833; in spite of their differences they had close ties; he introduced many Americans to TC and played a leading part in arranging the publication of TC’s works in the U.S.

Erskine, Thomas (1788–1870; ODNB; see 10:18TC to JAC, 1 Feb. 1838), theologian and retired advocate, living at Linlathen, Dundee; known to the Carlyles since the mid-1830s. He had two widowed sisters, who lived with him: Christian (1789–1866), who m., 1817, Charles Stirling; and David (1791–1867), who m., 1821, Capt. James Paterson.

Farrer, Annie Louisa (1818–1910; see 23:108TC to JAC, 11 Sept. 1848 [where her dates are incorrect]), member of the Ashburton circle, living at 32 Dorset Sq. She had an elder sister, Mary, m., 1855, Matthew Edward Tierney (1818–1860), 3rd bart., lt. col. Coldstream Guards; and five brothers (see 25:228JWC to TC, 23 Sept. 1850).

Fergus, John (1797–1865; see 9:246JWC to TC, 17 July 1837, and 20:46TC to JF, 7 Nov. 1845), living with his sister Jessie (Janet) (b. 1794), at Whyte House, Kirkcaldy; owner of John Fergus & Co., flax spinners and bleachers; M.P. for Fife 1847–59. His other sisters were Elizabeth Pepoli (see below); Charlotte Nixon (1795–1853); Isabella (b. 1798), who m., 1824, Hugh Lumsden; and Jane (b. 1804), who m., 1841, Robert Whyt Royds (see 27:213TC to JWC, 9 Aug. 1852). They were all old friends of the Carlyles.

FitzGerald, Edward (1809–83: ODNB), poet and translator; TC’s friend since 1842 (see 15:89TC to EF, 18 Sept. 1842). He m. (reluctantly), 1856, Lucy, b. Barton (1808–98), religious writer; they separated in 1857.

Forster, John ( “Fuz “) (1812–76; ODNB; see 6:118TC to GE, 15 Feb. 1832, TC to JF, 17 Jan. 1839, and 11:7TC to JF, 25 Jan. 1839), historian, journalist, and biographer; ed. of the Examiner 1847–55; sec. to the Lunacy Commission 1855–61, and a commissioner from Feb. 1861; friend of the Carlyles since the late 1830s and TC’s literary adviser. He m., 1856, Eliza Ann, b. Crosbie (ca. 1819–94), widow of the publisher Henry Colburn (ca. 1784–1855; ODNB); they lived at 46 Montagu Sq.

Froude, James Anthony (1818–94; ODNB), journalist and historian, ed. of Fraser’s Magazine 1860–74; he m., first, 1849, Charlotte Maria, b. Grenfell (d. 1860); they had two das., Georgina Margaret (1850–1935) and Rose Mary (b. 1852), and a son, Pascall Grenfell (1854–79). He m., second, 1861, Henrietta Elizabeth Warre (d. 1874; her father, John Ashley Warre [1787–1860], had m., as his third wife, Charlotte Froude’s sister Caroline). They had a son, Ashley Anthony (1863–1949), and a da., May (b. 1867). They lived at 6 Clifton Pl., Hyde Park.
Garibaldi, Giuseppe (1807–82), Italian patriot and revolutionary.

Gilchrist, Anne, b. Burrows (1828–85; ODNB), writer; m., 1851, Alexander Gilchrist (1828–61; ODNB), biographer. They had four children: Percy Carlyle (1851–1935), Beatrice (1854–81), Herbert (1857–1914), and Grace (1859–1947). The family lived at 6 Cheyne Row 1856–62; after her husband’s death, Anne Gilchrist and her children moved to Brookbank Cottage, Shottermill, nr. Haslemere, Surrey. Her mother was Henrietta Burrows, living at Earls Colne, Essex.
Gladstone, Elizabeth, b. Clarke (d. 1897), m., 1832, Thomas Steuart Gladstone (1805–82) of Capenoch, nr. Thornhill.
Gladstone, William Ewart (1809–98; ODNB), politician, chancellor of the exchequer 1859–66; cousin of Thomas Steuart Gladstone.

Graham, William (ca. 1774–1860; see 1:274TC to WG, 15 Sept. 1820, 21:96TC to JAC, 20 Nov. 1846, and other vols.), TC’s old friend from Burnswark, 3 mi. (5 km.) N of Ecclefechan; his sister was Elizabeth (1784–1861).

Hanning, Janet Carlyle (1813–97), TC’s sister; m., 1836, Robert Hanning (1796–1878), who had emigrated to Canada in mysterious disgrace in 1841; she joined him in Hamilton, Ontario, Aug. 1851, with their two das., Margaret (b. 1838) and Mary (b. 1840). In Canada they had two more das., Catherine (b. ca. 1852) and Jane.
Hawkes, Emilie; see Venturi.
Heath, Robert Vernon (ca. 1819–95; ODNB), photographer, 43 Piccadilly, London.

Hunt, James Henry Leigh (1784–1859; ODNB), poet, essayist, and journalist; m., 1809, Marianne, b. Kent (ca. 1788–1857). They had nine children. They had first met the Carlyles 1832 (see 6:135–36TC to JHLH, 20 Feb. 1832) and had lived at 4 Upper Cheyne Row 1833–40; see also Carlyle, Reminiscences 138.
Irving, Edward (1792–1834; ODNB; see 1:92, later vols., and Carlyle, Reminiscences), the Carlyles’ great friend; religious leader and preacher.
Jeffrey, William (1826–77), photographer; he lived with his mother, Mary (b. ca. 1807), and his aunt Ellenor Ruding (b. ca. 1817), who helped him in his studio, at 114 Gt. Russell St.

Jewsbury, Geraldine Endsor (1812–80; ODNB; see 12:103–4TC to GEJ, 12 April 1840), novelist, reviewer, and misc. writer; a friend of the Carlyles, particularly of JWC, since 1841. For her sister, Maria Jane (1800–1833), also a writer, see 30:251JWC’s Journal, 16 May 1856. Her brothers were Thomas Smith (b. 1802), Henry Richard Smith (1803–73), Arthur (b. 1815), and Francis (Frank) Harding (1819–78), who m., 1853, Emily, b. Vandeburgh. Jewsbury lived with Frank in Manchester until summer 1854; now living in London at 41 Markham Sq. She met Walter Mantell (see below) late 1856 and fell in love with him; he did not reciprocate, but they remained close and exchanged over 500 letters in the course of their friendship.

Kerr, Lady Constance Harriet Mahonesa, b. Chetwynd-Talbot (1836–1901), marchioness of Lothian, m., 1854, William Schomberg Robert Kerr (1832–70), 8th marquess of Lothian, a noted bibliophile, and an invalid for much of his life. His mother was Lady Cecil Chetwynd Kerr, b. Chetwynd-Talbot (1808–77; ODNB), dowager marchioness of Lothian.

Kingsley, Charles (1819–75; ODNB), author, rector of Eversley, nr. Basingstoke, Hampshire, and prof. of modern history at Cambridge; he m., 1844, Frances Eliza, b. Grenfell (1814–91; ODNB). Known to TC since late 1840s.
Laing, David (1793–1878; ODNB), antiquary, and librarian of the Signet Library, Edinburgh, from 1837 until his death.

Larkin, Henry (1820–99), collector or cashier for the Chelsea Steamboat Co.; partner in an engineering business. His Extra Physics and the Mystery of Creation (1878) included an appendix (written in 1858) giving an analysis of Sartor Resartus; also author of Carlyle and the Open Secret of His Life (1886). For TC’s early contacts with him, see 25:322TC to HL, 29 Dec. 1850, and 27:78TC to HL, 29 March 1852. He worked on TC’s indexes and maps from 1856; see 34:57JWC to TC, 19 July 1858. He lived at Elm Cottage, Old Brompton Rd., before his marriage, 24 April 1862, to Louisa, b. Wagstaff (b. 1837); they then moved to 6 Cheyne Row. His mother, Charlotte, b. Brett (ca. 1785–1862), lived nr. Hoxton.
Lewes, G. H.; see Eliot.

Lincoln, Abraham (1809–65), lawyer and politician; president of the U.S., inaugurated 4 March 1861. He m., 1842, Mary, b. Todd (1818–82), and they had four sons, only one of whom survived into adulthood. He was assassinated 14 and d. 15 April 1865.
Lothian, Lady; see Kerr.
Mackenzie; see Stewart-Mackenzie.

Macready, William Charles (1793–1873; ODNB), actor-manager; retired 1851, the Carlyles’ friend since 1839. He m., 1824, Catherine Frances, b. Atkins (1806–52); they had 10 children, of whom at least five d. young. He moved to Wellington Sq., Cheltenham, early 1860, and m., 1860, Cecile Louise Frederica, b. Spencer (1827–1908), with whom he had a son, Cecil Frederick Nevil (1862–1946).

McTurk, Robert (1793–1860), old friend of JWC; m., 1827, Janet, b. Hastings (ca. 1802–71); they had one son, James Hastings (1832–ca. 1844). They lived at Hastings Hall, Moniaive, Dumfriesshire. His sister Isabella (ca. 1802–99), m., 1836, William Dunwoodie (1790–1848), farmer at Townhead, Dumfriesshire; they had five das. His father, James McTurk, had owned Strathmilligan, 8 mi. (13 km.) N of Craigenputtoch, where JWC’s maternal grandfather, Walter Welsh, had lived.

Mantell, Walter Baldock Durant (1820–95), politician and naturalist; b. in Sussex, England, he settled in New Zealand in 1840. He held various
official posts connected with purchasing land from the Maori, taking leave of absence in 1855 and coming to Britain to protest against unfulfilled promises. He met Geraldine Jewsbury late 1856, and corresponded extensively with her on his return to New Zealand in Oct. 1859. He was elected to the New Zealand House of Representatives, 1861, and held the post of native minister for a few months, before resigning again in protest at the treatment of the Maori; see also 33:276–77.

Mazzini, Giuseppe (1805–72; see 11:225TC to JSM, 6 Dec. 1839, and 28:xiii—xiv28:introduction), Italian revolutionary; friend of the Carlyles since the late 1830s. He was usually based in London, but continued to encourage active Italian resistance to Austrian domination.

Mill, John Stuart (1806–73; ODNB), utilitarian philosopher and economist, administrator at India House since 1823; m., 1851, Harriet Taylor (1807–58), widow of John Taylor (1796–1849); she strongly influenced Mill’s thinking. He met TC in Sept. 1831 (see 5:398TC to JWC, 4 Sept. 1831); they remained on friendly terms even after the MS of vol. 1 of The French Revolution was burned while in Mill’s keeping (see 8:66–68TC to JFR, 7 March 1835), but later became estranged because of many differences in temperament and attitudes to social questions; Mill also believed that TC and other friends disapproved of his marriage.

Milnes, Richard Monckton (1809–85; ODNB; see 9:8TC to JAC, 14 July 1836, and 12:9–10TC to RWE, 6 Jan. 1840), author, M.P. for Pontefract 1837–63; lived at 16 Upper Brook St., London, and Fryston Hall, Yorkshire; the Carlyles’ friend since the late 1830s despite political differences; Milnes supported religious and civil liberties, and championed progressive causes, such as education for the working class and prison reform. He m., 1851, Annabella, b. Hungerford Crewe (1814–74); they had two das. and a son; see 37:27037:biographical note.
Morrison, Florence (b. ca. 1847), servant at Cheyne Row from Nov. 1862.

Neuberg, Joseph (1806–67; see 11:231TC to JN, 21 Dec. 1839), a Jewish German businessman who had worked in Nottingham; naturalized British 1845, and retired from business 1849; m., 1841, Marian (d. 1848; see 23:77JWC to JN, 22 July 1848). He was introduced to TC, whom he had long admired, by Emerson, 1848; helped TC as an unpaid sec., translated his work, and twice accompanied him on visits to Germany (1852 and 1858). From 1856 Neuberg lived at Oakley Villas, 25 (recently renumbered 140) Adelaide Rd., with his widowed sister, Rosetta (or Rosette) (ca. 1816–98), who had m., ca. 1851, Adolph Frankau (1820–56; see 32:32TC to JAC, 19 Nov. 1856), and her two children, Frederick Joseph (b. 1854) and Gertrude Rosette Adolphine (b. ca. 1856). After Frankau’s death, Neuberg managed Frankau’s company, which imported meerschaum pipes and fancy goods, at 25 Clements Lane, Lombard St., London.

Oliphant; Margaret Oliphant Wilson (1828–97; ODNB), novelist, biographer,
reviewer, and misc. writer; she m., 1852, her cousin Francis Wilson Oliphant (1818–59; ODNB); their children were Margaret Wilson (1853–64), Marjorie (1854–55), a son who d. at birth (1855), Cyril Francis ( “Tids “) (1856–90), and Francis Romano ( “Cecco “) (1859–94). Her mother was Margaret Oliphant Wilson (ca. 1789–1854) and her father Francis W. Wilson (ca. 1788–1858).

Otthenin, Jean, b. Johnston (b. ca. 1796); although she is listed in Genéalogie-Lorraine with the dates “1807–70,“ she was about the same age as TC as she was his classmate at the Ecclefechan school which he left 1806; her mother, Margaret Carlyle (d. 1830), fled with her to France from a brutal husband, James Johnston (d. 1809). Jean m., 1832, Nicolas-Julien Otthenin (1785–1845), a French cavalry officer, who d. in a driving accident; see 20:18–19TC to JWC,8 Oct. 1845. Now living at 33 Northumberland St., Edinburgh, with her das. Margaret and Irma (1838–97).

Palmerston, Henry John Temple (1784–1865; ODNB), 3d Viscount Palmerston, politician; m., 1839, Emily, b. Lamb (1787–1869), widow of 5th Earl Cowper (1778–1837). Whig prime minister 1855–57 and 1859–65.
Parker, John William (1792–1870; ODNB), publisher of Fraser’s Magazine; known to TC since the 1840s; see 21:209–10TC to ES, 14 May 1847.

Parkes, Henry (1815–96; ODNB), Australian politician and journalist; he m., 1836, Clarinda, b. Varney (1813–88), and they emigrated 1839. He entered politics 1854, and was sent on a lecture tour of Britain, 1861–62, to encourage emigration.

Pepoli, Elizabeth, b. Fergus (1792–7 April 1862; see 8:223JWC to TC, 12 Oct. 1835, and 13:86JWC to TC, 9 April 1841); old Kirkcaldy friend of the Carlyles; m., 1839, Count Carlo Pepoli (1796–1881; see 8:194–95JWC to JCA, 12 Aug. 1835), poet, prof. of philosophy at Bologna, and political exile after the failed revolution against the papal govt., 1831; he returned to Bologna 1859; she lived at Felsina House, 11 St. George’s Ter., Kensington.
Piggott, Sarah (b. ca. 1844), the Carlyles’ servant, Sept. 1860–June 1861.
Plattnauer, Richard, political refugee from Prussia; see 22:10JWC to HW, 5 July 1847. Friend of the Carlyles since the mid-1840s; see 18:194JWC to JW, 29 Aug. 1844; he suffered periods of insanity.

Pott, Janet, b. Hunter (1827–1912), JWC’s cousin (see 28:367JWC to MR, 30 Dec. 1853, and 29:39JWC to MR, 3 March 1854); she m., first, 1847, Dr. Andrew Pringle (1820–58), of Lann Hall, nr. Thornhill. They had three sons: Andrew (b. 1850), Robert Hunter (b. 1852), and John James (b. 1855); see 29:228JWC to MR, 30 Dec. 1854. She m., second, 1859, Gideon Pott (1824–1905), farmer of Knowesouth, nr. Jedburgh; by 1862 they had two sons, George (b. 1860) and Gideon (b. 21 July 1862).

Quain, Richard (1816–98; ODNB), physician, specializing in heart disease, and with many wealthy and influential patients; he lived at 67 Harley St. He m., 1854, Isabella Agnes, b. Wray (1828–91); they had four das.

Rennie, George (1802–60; ODNB), sculptor and politician; old Haddington admirer of JWC; see 2:17JBW to EA, 15 Jan. 1822. He m., 1824, Jane, b. Rennie (1800–1866), whom JWC thought “a perfect fool“ (see 7:253JWC to EA, 1 Aug. 1834). They had three sons; see 35:48–49JWC to BB, 3 March 1859.

Richardson, Jane Wilhelmina (Willie) (1801–82), da. of Catherine Eliza Richardson (1777–1853; ODNB; see 4:345TC to JWC, 26 March 1828 [where called Caroline in error]), poet and novelist, whom the Carlyles knew in the late 1820s. In 1828 Willie Richardson was being “fitted out for India “; see 4:417–18JWC to EA, 21 Nov. 1828.
Robson, Charles, of Robson, Levey, & Franklyn, printers, 23 Gt. New St., Fetter Lane. Robson had been TC’s printer since 1837.
Ronca, Dominic (1816?—62), carpenter; he now lived at 4 Cheyne Row, having previously lived at no. 6 (see 28:367JWC to MR, 30 Dec. 1853, and 29:238TC to JAC, 13 Jan. 1855).
Rouse, James (ca. 1827–95; see 31:25731:biographical note), the Ashburtons’ doctor; TC liked him.

Ruskin, John (1819–1900; ODNB), author, artist, and social reformer; m., 1848, Euphemia Chalmers, b. Gray (1828–97); marriage annulled 1854. He lived in the family home at 163 Denmark Hill, S London, with his father, John James Ruskin (1785–1864), wine merchant, and mother, Margaret, b. Cock (1781–1871). He was J. M. W. Turner’s foremost admirer and was strongly influenced by TC.

Russell, Mary, b. Dobbie (1802–75; see 6:145TC to AC, 7 April 1832), close friend of JWC and her mother. She m., 1829, Dr. James Russell (ca. 1796–1878); they had moved to Holmhill, nr. Thornhill, by Oct. 1859. Her father was Rev. Edward Dobbie (1773–1857; see 14:65TC to JWC, 9 March 1842).

Sandwich, Mary Anne Julia Louisa Harriet, b. Lowry-Corry (1781–19 April 1862; see 23:103TC to MAC, 3 Sept. 1848), dowager countess; da. of Armar Lowry Corry (1740–1802), 1st earl of Belmore, Irish politican. She m., 1804, George John Montagu (1773–1818), 6th earl of Sandwich; her children included Lady Harriet Ashburton (see Ashburton) and John William Montagu (1811–84), 7th earl of Sandwich. He m., 1838, Mary, b. Paget (ca. 1823–59); they had six children: Edward George Henry (1839–1916), Victor Alexander (1841–1915), Sydney (1842–60), Oliver George Paulet (1844–93), Emily Caroline (1847–1931), and Anne Florence Adelaide (1849–1940). Lady Sandwich lived at Hinchingbrooke in Huntingdonshire (see 36:103TC to JWC, 27 April 1860) and at 46 Grosvenor Sq. in London.
Sartoris, Edward John (1817–88; see 23:71JWC to HW, 16 July 1848), m., 1842, Adelaide, b. Kemble (1815–79; ODNB), a singer before her marriage and writer.

Scott, Alexander John (1805–66; ODNB); Christian Socialist and educator (see 35:26337:biographical note); known to TC through Edward Irving since 1831 (see 5:351TC to JWC, 22 Aug. 1831). He m., 1830, Ann, b. Ker (d. 1888; see 5:416TC to JWC, 11 Sept. 1831, and 26:120TC to JAC, 5 Aug. 1851).
Silvester, John, livery stable owner, Upper Church St., Chelsea. His wife was Phoebe (ca. 1800–1865).

Sinclair, Sir George (1790–1868; ODNB; see 24:18–19TC to SGS, 10 April 1849), politician; living in Thurso Castle, Caithness. He m., 1816, Lady Catherine Camilla, b. Manners (1792–1863). They had a son and three das. (see 36:28636:biographical note); the youngest, Olivia Sophia (1823–94), became a travel writer. His father was Sir John Sinclair of Ulbster (1754–1835; ODNB), politician and agricultural improver.

Stanley, Henrietta Maria, b. Dillon (1807–95; ODNB), m., 1826, Edward John (1802–69; ODNB; see 12:59TC to JAC, 27 Feb. 1840), Whig politician, who succeeded as 2d Baron Stanley of Alderley, 1850; living at Alderley Park, Cheshire. Both were friends of the Carlyles. Lord Stanley was nicknamed Lord Ben after Sir Benjamin Backbite, a character in Richard Brinsley Sheridan’s School for Scandal (ca. 1780) (see 35:26435:biographical note). They had nine surviving children: Henry Edward John (1827–1903); Alice Margaret (1828–1910), who m., 1853, Augustus Henry Lane Fox-Pitt-Rivers; Henrietta Blanche (see Airlie); Maude Alethea (1833–1915); John ( “Johny “) Constantine (1837–78); Edward Lyulph (1839–1925); Katherine Louisa (1842–74; ODNB); Algernon Charles (1843–1928); and Rosalind Francis (1845–1921).
Stebbins, Emma; see Cushman.

Sterling, Edward (1773–1847) and Hester, b. Coningham (1783–1843); old family friends of the Carlyles. Their sons were Sir Anthony Coningham (1805–71; ODNB; see 9:103TC to JAC, 2 Dec. 1836, and later vols.), soldier; he m., 1829, Charlotte, b. Baird (d. 1863), who suffered attacks of insanity and was jealous of JWC (see 18:266–67JWC to HW, 12 Nov. 1844, and 19:9JWC to HW, 9 Jan. 1845); they lived at 3 South Pl., Knightsbridge; and John (1806–44; ODNB), writer, and particular friend of TC; see CL vols. 8–18 and Carlyle’s Life of Sterling (1851); for his children see 35:26435:biographical note—65.
Stewart, Margaret, b. Austin (1831–74), m., 1859, Thomas Stewart (1832–69), farmer at Hollybush; they had a da., Mary (b. ca. 1861).

Stewart-Mackenzie, Mary Elizabeth Frederica, b. Mackenzie (1783–28 Nov. 1862; ODNB), chief of Clan Mackenzie; she m., second, 1817, James Alexander Stewart (1784–1843); on their marriage the name Mackenzie was added to that of Stewart. They lived at Brahan Castle, Ross-shire. They had six children, including Lady Louisa Ashburton (see Ashburton), Mary Frances (see Anstruther), and George Augustus Stewart-Mackenzie (1824–52) who m., 1850, Maria Louisa, b. Marriott (b. ca. 1826).

Story, William Wetmore (1819–95), American poet, sculptor, and abolitionist; he m. Emelyn, b. Eldredge (1820–95), and they had three children, Edith Marion (1844–1907), Thomas Waldo (1855–1915), and Julian Russell (1857–1919). They lived in Rome from 1856.

Strachey, George (1828–1912), diplomat; see 17:289–90TC to GS, 3 March 1844, and 32:158TC to GS, 5 June 1857. He m.,
1862, his second wife, Catherine, b. Doveton (d. 1920). The Strachey family had been known to TC since the early 1820s; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 283–84.

Sullivan, Margaret ( “Button “) (b. ca. 1841), from Limerick, Ireland; servant at Cheyne Row from early June 1861 until June 1862; previously at 47 Mount St. Her sister Ellen worked for Mantell in New Zealand.

Tait, Robert Scott (1816–97), portrait painter and pioneer photographer; a friend of the Carlyles since 1853; living at 14 Queen Anne St., Cavendish Sq. He painted TC (see 31:84TC to AGI, 6 May 1856) and A Chelsea Interior (see 33:197JWC to MR, 29 March 1858). He took photographs of the Carlyles and their house as preparation for the painting, and he also took photographs for TC’s use in Frederick. He m., 1859, Harriet, b. Wilson (b. 1832); they had a da., Mildred (1860–1950).

Taylor, Henry (1800–1886; ODNB; see 6:40TC to MAC, 10 Nov. 1831), author and civil servant; m., 1839, Theodosia Alice, b. Spring Rice (1818–91; see 10:168JWC to TC, 9 Sept. 1838); they had two sons and three das.; see 37:27437:biographical note.

Tennyson, Alfred (1809–92; ODNB), poet; poet laureate from 1850. Friend of the Carlyles since the earlys 1840, TC and Tennyson had a strong mutual regard; he m., 1850, Emily Sarah, b. Sellwood (1813–96). From 1853 they lived at Farringford, Freshwater, Isle of Wight.

Thackeray, William Makepeace (1811–63; ODNB; see 9:271JWC to TC, 3 Aug. 1837, 288TC to JAC, 12 Aug. 1837, and later vols.), novelist; friend of the Carlyles since the 1830s. He m., 1836, Isabella, b. Shawe (1816–93), who was mentally ill from 1840. His das. were Anne Isabella (1837–1919) and Harriet Marian (1840–75); they lived at 36 Onslow Sq., London.
Trench, Richard Chenevix (1807–86; ODNB), clergyman and writer, dean of Westminster from 1856; known to TC since the 1840s (see 18:143TC to JWC, 17 July 1844); member of the Ashburton circle.

Trevelyan, Sir Walter Calverley (1797–1879; ODNB), naturalist; m., 1835, Lady Paulina, b. Jermyn (1816–66; ODNB), art patron; they lived at Wallington Hall in Northumberland. Lady Trevelyan was a great friend of Lady Louisa Ashburton.

Trollope, Anthony (1815–82; ODNB), novelist and post office surveyor; he m., 1844, Rose, b. Heseltine (1820–1917); they had two sons; see 37:27437:biographical note. From 1861 they lived at Waltham Cross, Hertfordshire.

Twisleton, Ellen, b. Dwight (1828–17 May 1862), from Boston, Mass.; JWC’s close friend and confidante; she recorded, 1855, an account of JWC’s early married life at Craigenputtoch (see 30:267–74Ellen Twisleton’s Account of Life at Craigenputtoch). She m., 1852, Hon. Edward Turner Boyd Twisleton (1809–74; ODNB), also a close and respected friend of the Carlyles (see 28:184TC to JWC, 5 July 1853); they lived at 3 Rutland Gate.

Usedom, Baron Karl Georg Ludwig Guido von (1805–84), Prussian diplomat,
and Olympia (1811–87), his second wife, m. 1849; TC stayed with them during his visit to Germany in 1858; see 34:159TC to JWC, 27 Aug. 1858, 36:237JWC to LLA, 12 Sept. 1860, and 28836:biographical note.
Veitch, Agnes (1819–79), wife of James Veitch (1816–72), of Eliock House, Sanquhar, about 10 mi. (16 km.) N of Thornhill; friend of Mary Russell’s; see 32:109JWC to MR, 24 March 1857.

Venables, George Stovin (1810–88; ODNB), lawyer and journalist; contributor to the Saturday Review from its founding, 1855, and to the Times, 1857–88; friend of Tennyson and of Thackeray, who claimed he was the model for Warrington in Pendennis (1848–50).

Venturi, Emilie (ca.1819/20?–93: ODNB), da. of William Henry Ashurst (ca. 1791–1855; ODNB; portrait painter), supporter of Italian independence and campaigner for women’s rights; unhappily married to Sydney Hawkes, whom she divorced 1861; see 30:215 and 235JWC’s Journal, 13 Nov. 1855 and 27 March 1856. She m., 1861, Carlo Venturi (ca. 1830–66). A strong supporter of Mazzini and the Young Italy movement, she wrote Joseph Mazzini: A Memoir (1875).

Ward, Charles Augustus (1828–1914), vintner, author, antiquarian, and book collector; see 29:123–4TC to CAW, 6 July 1854. He often wrote under the pseudonym Feltham Burghley; see 36:262–64TC to CAW, 24 Sept. 1860.

Watt brothers, John A. Carlyle’s stepsons: Thomas Fowler (1838–1 July 1862), went to sea in 1856 (see 32:29TC to IC, 12 Nov. 1856), then joined the army in Jan. 1861; Henry (b. 1839), at sea from 1854 (see 29:121TC to JCA, 30 June 1854); Arthur (b. 1840), at school in Edinburgh from 1856; and William (b. 1842), at the Royal Military Academy, Woolwich, from 1858.

Welsh, Alexander (Alick) (b. 1816), son of JWC’s maternal uncle John; m., ca. 1849, Sophy, b. Martin (b. ca. 1824). Their children were John (Jackie) (b. ca. 1853), Isabella Helen (b. 1856; see 31:201JWC to TC, 29 Aug. 1856), Margaret (b. 1858), and Jean (b. 1860).

Welsh, Ann (1799–1877), Elizabeth (1792–1877), and Grace (1801–67), JWC’s paternal aunts (see 14:67TC to JWC, 10 March 1842, and 16:219JWC to JW, 26 June 1843), living at Craigen Villa, Morningside, Edinburgh.
Welsh, Grace, b. Welsh (1782–1842), JWC’s mother; m., 1800, John Welsh (1776–1819; see 1:202–3JBW to EWE, 5 Oct. 1819), JWC’s father, doctor in Haddington.
Welsh, Jeannie (ca. 1798–1828), JWC’s maternal aunt; for her death, see 4:358TC to JAC, 16 April 1828, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 127–29.

Welsh, John (d. 1853; see 28:286–87TC to JCA, 12 Oct. 1853), JWC’s maternal uncle, retired brass and copper founder, who had lived at 20 Maryland St., Liverpool; m., 1808, Mary, b. Colliver (d. 1838; see 10:200TC to AC, 15 Oct. 1838); their children were Helen (ca. 1813–53), Walter, Alexander, Jeannie (see Chrystal), John (1820–60), Margaret, and Mary.
Welsh, John Amelia ( “Jackie “) (ca. 1809–64), illegitimate da. of JWC’s paternal uncle William (1790–1819; see 14:90TC to JWC, 25 March 1842) and Elizabeth Scott (b. 1782).

Welsh, Margaret, b. Kissock (1803–88; see 13:44JWC to MW, 22 Feb. 1841, and 20:128JWC to MW, 28 Feb. 1846), widow of JWC’s paternal uncle George (1793–1835), living at 19 St. Johns Grove, Richmond, nr. London. Her son was John Welsh (1824–59; ODNB; see 15:37TC to JWC, 22 Aug. 1842), F.R.S., meteorologist, whom JWC described as “worth all my cousins tied up in one bundle!” (35:58).
Welsh, Margaret (Maggie) (b. 1821), da. of JWC’s maternal uncle John; lived in Auchtertool with her brother Walter.
Welsh, Mary (1823–79), da. of JWC’s maternal uncle John; lived in Auchtertool with her brother Walter.
Welsh, Mary May (1829–85), da. of JWC’s paternal uncle Robert; m., 1859, as his second wife, Dr. Robert Martin Craven (1824–1903; see 35:26735:biographical note).

Welsh, Robert (1786–1841; see 13:118TC to JWC, 29 April 1841, and 14:217JWC to MW, 8 July 1842), JWC’s paternal uncle, Edinburgh solicitor; m., 1821, Mary, b. May (b. 1796). Their children were John May (1824–56; see 19:98–99JWC to MR, 12 July 1845), Sarah (b. 1825; d. before 1832), Elizabeth (b. 1828), Mary May (see above), Sarah (1832–56), Robert (b. 1833), Annabella (1834–55), and Grace (1836–63), who m., 1859, William Henry Dobie (b. ca. 1809).

Welsh, Rev. Walter (1815–1879; see 16:12JWC to JW, 8 Jan. 1843), son of JWC’s maternal uncle John; minister at Auchtertool, Fife, since 1842. Two of his sisters, Margaret (Maggie) and Mary, lived with him (see above).
Wilberforce, Samuel (1805–73; ODNB), bishop of Oxford; see 36:30JWC to WHB, 27 Dec. 1859.
Willisen Karl Wilhelm von (1790–1879), Prussian general and military writer; see 16:323–24JWC to TC, 28 July 1843.
Woolner, Thomas (1825–92: ODNB; see 26:37TC to TWO, 21 Feb. 1851, and 29:176–77TC to LA, 20 Oct. 1854), sculptor and poet; he moved to 29 Welbeck St. autumn 1861.
Wynn, Charlotte Williams (1807–69; ODNB; see 19:102TC to JAC, 17 July 1845), diarist; she lived at 43 Green St.
